{"q fevernum_articles": "164", "q fever": [{"archive_id": "7855851", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Australia (02): (NSW)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7855851", "date": "2019-01-29 15:23:38", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AFGHANISTAN: (HELMAND) BRITISH MILITARY, 2008-2014\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 24 Jan 2019\nSource: Tolo News [edited]\nhttps://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/90-soldiers-contracted-q-fever-while-serving-helmand\n\n\nAt least 90 British military personnel have been diagnosed with confirmed cases of Q fever after serving in Helmand, Afghanistan. According to a UK military news outlet, Forces Network, a consultant in infectious diseases and tropical medicine told to the Central London Country Court on [Tue 22 Jan 2019], that 90 confirmed cases of Q fever had been recorded among British soldiers who had served in Helmand.\n\nLieutenant Colonel Mark Bailey's testimony was heard in the case of a private with 2nd Battalion, the Mercian Regiment, who said his life has been ruined after he contracted the disease while in Helmand in 2011/2012. During his tour, his lawyers said [the private] was in contact with goats and sheep and \"was often required to take cover and jump through ditches and crawl along the ground -- coming into contact with animal products and excrement.\" The soldier was medically discharged from the Army in 2014 because of his Q fever and chronic fatigue symptoms.\n\nHumans can catch Q fever by breathing in dust from the secretions of infected farm animals such as sheep, cattle, and goats.\n\nBailey, who specializes in infectious diseases and tropical medicine, and a national expert in Q fever said he has 90 military and 10 civilian cases in his care after they were referred to him. He confirmed the 90 had served in Helmand and said the number of military cases \"built up from 2008\", Forces Network reported. Bailey told the court: \"We have seen no new cases since 2014 from Afghanistan. Occasionally we get other military cases from other locations. Cyprus most recently.\"\n\nBailey said he had seen \"one British soldier who very, very nearly died\" as a result of Q fever and subsequent complications, but there have been no UK deaths in his group.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Q fever is due to _Coxiella burnetii_, an obligate intracellular rickettsia-like bacterial pathogen. It is highly resistant to drying and heat, which enables the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. Its survival is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of its biphasic developmental cycle. Q fever is a zoonosis. Domestic ungulates such as sheep, cattle, and goats serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. The organism is shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nHumans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms. Acute symptoms of a flu-like illness usually develop within 2-3 weeks of exposure, although as many as half of humans infected with _C. burnetii_ do not show symptoms (http://www.cdc.gov/qfever/symptoms/index.html). Although most persons with acute Q fever infection recover, others may experience serious illness with complications that may include pneumonia, granulomatous hepatitis, endocarditis (especially in patients with previous cardiac valvulopathy), myocarditis, and central nervous system involvement. Pregnant women who are infected may be at risk for pre-term delivery or miscarriage.\n\nThe solider likely suffers from Q fever-associated chronic fatigue. The following related to post-Q fever fatigue syndrome is extracted from Melgar TA, Bauler TJ, Lutwick LI. Q fever in man: A one health paradigm disease. In, The Principles and Practice of Q Fever, Simoes JCC, Anastacio SF, da Silva GJ (eds), Nova Science Publishers, 2017, pp 1-24:\n\n\"Up to 20% of patients with acute Q fever report chronic fatigue more than a year later. Most of these cases meet the CDC criteria for chronic fatigue syndrome. Other symptoms include night sweats, nausea, headache, myalgia, enlarged lymph nodes, arthralgia, insomnia, depression, decreased concentration and short term memory impairment. The pathogenesis is not clear although there is evidence that genetic factors may play a role and _C. burnetii_ antigens and DNA can be found in patients' macrophages for up to 12 years and in one case 70 years after acute infection (1,2). Treatment is focused on chronic fatigue including exercise therapy and cognitive behavior therapy. There are no current recommendations for antimicrobial therapy for Q fever-associated chronic fatigue although case reports and one study demonstrated improvement with antimicrobials (3). A large placebo controlled randomized trial in the Netherlands (4,5) reported some non-sustained improvement was found with cognitive-behavioral therapy but not with long term doxycycline.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Marmion BP, Sukocheva O, Storm PA, et al. Q fever: persistence of antigenic non-viable cell residues of _Coxiella burnetii_ in the host - implications for post Q fever infection fatigue syndrome and other chronic sequelae. QJM 2009; 102(10): 673-84; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19556396.\n2. Sukocheva OA, Marmion BP, Storm PA, et al. Long-term persistence after acute Q fever of non-infectious _Coxiella burnetii_ cell components, including antigens. QJM 2010; 103(11): 847-63; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20639288.\n3. Arashima Y, Kato K, Komiya T, et al. Improvement of chronic nonspecific symptoms by long-term minocycline treatment in Japanese patients with _Coxiella burnetii_ infection considered to have post-Q fever fatigue syndrome. Intern Med 2004; 43(1): 49-54; https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/internalmedicine/43/1/43_1_49/_article.\n4. Keijmel SP, Delsing CE, Bleigenberg G, et al. Effectiveness of long-term doxycycline treatment and cognitive-behavioral therapy on fatigue severity in patients with Q fever fatigue syndrome (Qure study): a randomized controlled trial. Clin Infect Did 2017; 64(8): 998-1005; https://academic.oup.com/cid/article/64/8/998/3056564.\n5. Raijmakers RPH, Keijmel SP, Breukers EMC, et al. Long-term effect of cognitive behavioural therapy and doxycycline treatment for patients with Q fever fatigue syndrome: one-year follow-up of the Qure study. J Psychosom Res 2019; 116: 62-7; https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022399918308183.\n\nHelmand is one of the 34 provinces of Afghanistan, in the south of the country. It can be seen on a map at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helmand_Province. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Afghanistan: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21324]\nSee Also\n2018\n----\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) drought conditions, vaccination 20181106.6129612\nQ fever - Spain: (PV) waste treatment facility 20180411.5739737\nQ fever - Chile 20180127.5585265\n2017\n----\nQ fever - Chile (03): dairy industry workers, RFI 20171117.5450879\nQ fever - Chile (02): (LG, LR) dairy industry workers 20171111.5438140\nQ fever - Chile: (LG, LR) dairy industry workers 20171028.5410320\nQ fever - Australia (02): (QL) native animal source 20170923.5335445\nQ fever - Australia: (VI) occupational exposure, animal auction facility 20170720.5192560\nQ fever - Israel: RFI 20170717.5180136\nQ fever - Germany: (RP) sheep cell therapy, 2014 20170416.4974554\n2016\n----\nQ fever - Australia (03): (SA) spike in disease 20161231.4735189\nQ fever - Australia (02): (VI) meat processing workers 20160824.4437074\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) vaccination 20160706.4328443\nQ fever - Netherlands: human, 2007-2015, fatalities 20160531.4256718\n2015\n----\nQ fever - Australia (02): (VI) 20151019.3726962\nQ fever - USA, Canada: ex Germany (RP) sheep cell therapy, 2014 20151002.3684869\n.................................................ll/mj/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-01-24 00:00:00", "2019-01-22 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Helmand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7750506", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Australia: (QL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7750506", "date": "2019-01-29 15:23:38", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AFGHANISTAN: (HELMAND) BRITISH MILITARY, 2008-2014\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 24 Jan 2019\nSource: Tolo News [edited]\nhttps://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/90-soldiers-contracted-q-fever-while-serving-helmand\n\n\nAt least 90 British military personnel have been diagnosed with confirmed cases of Q fever after serving in Helmand, Afghanistan. According to a UK military news outlet, Forces Network, a consultant in infectious diseases and tropical medicine told to the Central London Country Court on [Tue 22 Jan 2019], that 90 confirmed cases of Q fever had been recorded among British soldiers who had served in Helmand.\n\nLieutenant Colonel Mark Bailey's testimony was heard in the case of a private with 2nd Battalion, the Mercian Regiment, who said his life has been ruined after he contracted the disease while in Helmand in 2011/2012. During his tour, his lawyers said [the private] was in contact with goats and sheep and \"was often required to take cover and jump through ditches and crawl along the ground -- coming into contact with animal products and excrement.\" The soldier was medically discharged from the Army in 2014 because of his Q fever and chronic fatigue symptoms.\n\nHumans can catch Q fever by breathing in dust from the secretions of infected farm animals such as sheep, cattle, and goats.\n\nBailey, who specializes in infectious diseases and tropical medicine, and a national expert in Q fever said he has 90 military and 10 civilian cases in his care after they were referred to him. He confirmed the 90 had served in Helmand and said the number of military cases \"built up from 2008\", Forces Network reported. Bailey told the court: \"We have seen no new cases since 2014 from Afghanistan. Occasionally we get other military cases from other locations. Cyprus most recently.\"\n\nBailey said he had seen \"one British soldier who very, very nearly died\" as a result of Q fever and subsequent complications, but there have been no UK deaths in his group.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Q fever is due to _Coxiella burnetii_, an obligate intracellular rickettsia-like bacterial pathogen. It is highly resistant to drying and heat, which enables the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. Its survival is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of its biphasic developmental cycle. Q fever is a zoonosis. Domestic ungulates such as sheep, cattle, and goats serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. The organism is shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nHumans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms. Acute symptoms of a flu-like illness usually develop within 2-3 weeks of exposure, although as many as half of humans infected with _C. burnetii_ do not show symptoms (http://www.cdc.gov/qfever/symptoms/index.html). Although most persons with acute Q fever infection recover, others may experience serious illness with complications that may include pneumonia, granulomatous hepatitis, endocarditis (especially in patients with previous cardiac valvulopathy), myocarditis, and central nervous system involvement. Pregnant women who are infected may be at risk for pre-term delivery or miscarriage.\n\nThe solider likely suffers from Q fever-associated chronic fatigue. The following related to post-Q fever fatigue syndrome is extracted from Melgar TA, Bauler TJ, Lutwick LI. Q fever in man: A one health paradigm disease. In, The Principles and Practice of Q Fever, Simoes JCC, Anastacio SF, da Silva GJ (eds), Nova Science Publishers, 2017, pp 1-24:\n\n\"Up to 20% of patients with acute Q fever report chronic fatigue more than a year later. Most of these cases meet the CDC criteria for chronic fatigue syndrome. Other symptoms include night sweats, nausea, headache, myalgia, enlarged lymph nodes, arthralgia, insomnia, depression, decreased concentration and short term memory impairment. The pathogenesis is not clear although there is evidence that genetic factors may play a role and _C. burnetii_ antigens and DNA can be found in patients' macrophages for up to 12 years and in one case 70 years after acute infection (1,2). Treatment is focused on chronic fatigue including exercise therapy and cognitive behavior therapy. There are no current recommendations for antimicrobial therapy for Q fever-associated chronic fatigue although case reports and one study demonstrated improvement with antimicrobials (3). A large placebo controlled randomized trial in the Netherlands (4,5) reported some non-sustained improvement was found with cognitive-behavioral therapy but not with long term doxycycline.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Bulgaria (02): (GB, SH) sheep, goat, cattle, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7458895", "date": "2019-01-29 15:23:38", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AFGHANISTAN: (HELMAND) BRITISH MILITARY, 2008-2014\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 24 Jan 2019\nSource: Tolo News [edited]\nhttps://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/90-soldiers-contracted-q-fever-while-serving-helmand\n\n\nAt least 90 British military personnel have been diagnosed with confirmed cases of Q fever after serving in Helmand, Afghanistan. According to a UK military news outlet, Forces Network, a consultant in infectious diseases and tropical medicine told to the Central London Country Court on [Tue 22 Jan 2019], that 90 confirmed cases of Q fever had been recorded among British soldiers who had served in Helmand.\n\nLieutenant Colonel Mark Bailey's testimony was heard in the case of a private with 2nd Battalion, the Mercian Regiment, who said his life has been ruined after he contracted the disease while in Helmand in 2011/2012. During his tour, his lawyers said [the private] was in contact with goats and sheep and \"was often required to take cover and jump through ditches and crawl along the ground -- coming into contact with animal products and excrement.\" The soldier was medically discharged from the Army in 2014 because of his Q fever and chronic fatigue symptoms.\n\nHumans can catch Q fever by breathing in dust from the secretions of infected farm animals such as sheep, cattle, and goats.\n\nBailey, who specializes in infectious diseases and tropical medicine, and a national expert in Q fever said he has 90 military and 10 civilian cases in his care after they were referred to him. He confirmed the 90 had served in Helmand and said the number of military cases \"built up from 2008\", Forces Network reported. Bailey told the court: \"We have seen no new cases since 2014 from Afghanistan. Occasionally we get other military cases from other locations. Cyprus most recently.\"\n\nBailey said he had seen \"one British soldier who very, very nearly died\" as a result of Q fever and subsequent complications, but there have been no UK deaths in his group.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Q fever is due to _Coxiella burnetii_, an obligate intracellular rickettsia-like bacterial pathogen. It is highly resistant to drying and heat, which enables the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. Its survival is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of its biphasic developmental cycle. Q fever is a zoonosis. Domestic ungulates such as sheep, cattle, and goats serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. The organism is shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nHumans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms. Acute symptoms of a flu-like illness usually develop within 2-3 weeks of exposure, although as many as half of humans infected with _C. burnetii_ do not show symptoms (http://www.cdc.gov/qfever/symptoms/index.html). Although most persons with acute Q fever infection recover, others may experience serious illness with complications that may include pneumonia, granulomatous hepatitis, endocarditis (especially in patients with previous cardiac valvulopathy), myocarditis, and central nervous system involvement. Pregnant women who are infected may be at risk for pre-term delivery or miscarriage.\n\nThe solider likely suffers from Q fever-associated chronic fatigue. The following related to post-Q fever fatigue syndrome is extracted from Melgar TA, Bauler TJ, Lutwick LI. Q fever in man: A one health paradigm disease. In, The Principles and Practice of Q Fever, Simoes JCC, Anastacio SF, da Silva GJ (eds), Nova Science Publishers, 2017, pp 1-24:\n\n\"Up to 20% of patients with acute Q fever report chronic fatigue more than a year later. Most of these cases meet the CDC criteria for chronic fatigue syndrome. Other symptoms include night sweats, nausea, headache, myalgia, enlarged lymph nodes, arthralgia, insomnia, depression, decreased concentration and short term memory impairment. The pathogenesis is not clear although there is evidence that genetic factors may play a role and _C. burnetii_ antigens and DNA can be found in patients' macrophages for up to 12 years and in one case 70 years after acute infection (1,2). Treatment is focused on chronic fatigue including exercise therapy and cognitive behavior therapy. There are no current recommendations for antimicrobial therapy for Q fever-associated chronic fatigue although case reports and one study demonstrated improvement with antimicrobials (3). A large placebo controlled randomized trial in the Netherlands (4,5) reported some non-sustained improvement was found with cognitive-behavioral therapy but not with long term doxycycline.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Bulgaria: (GB)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7362087", "date": "2019-01-29 15:23:38", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AFGHANISTAN: (HELMAND) BRITISH MILITARY, 2008-2014\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 24 Jan 2019\nSource: Tolo News [edited]\nhttps://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/90-soldiers-contracted-q-fever-while-serving-helmand\n\n\nAt least 90 British military personnel have been diagnosed with confirmed cases of Q fever after serving in Helmand, Afghanistan. According to a UK military news outlet, Forces Network, a consultant in infectious diseases and tropical medicine told to the Central London Country Court on [Tue 22 Jan 2019], that 90 confirmed cases of Q fever had been recorded among British soldiers who had served in Helmand.\n\nLieutenant Colonel Mark Bailey's testimony was heard in the case of a private with 2nd Battalion, the Mercian Regiment, who said his life has been ruined after he contracted the disease while in Helmand in 2011/2012. During his tour, his lawyers said [the private] was in contact with goats and sheep and \"was often required to take cover and jump through ditches and crawl along the ground -- coming into contact with animal products and excrement.\" The soldier was medically discharged from the Army in 2014 because of his Q fever and chronic fatigue symptoms.\n\nHumans can catch Q fever by breathing in dust from the secretions of infected farm animals such as sheep, cattle, and goats.\n\nBailey, who specializes in infectious diseases and tropical medicine, and a national expert in Q fever said he has 90 military and 10 civilian cases in his care after they were referred to him. He confirmed the 90 had served in Helmand and said the number of military cases \"built up from 2008\", Forces Network reported. Bailey told the court: \"We have seen no new cases since 2014 from Afghanistan. Occasionally we get other military cases from other locations. Cyprus most recently.\"\n\nBailey said he had seen \"one British soldier who very, very nearly died\" as a result of Q fever and subsequent complications, but there have been no UK deaths in his group.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Q fever is due to _Coxiella burnetii_, an obligate intracellular rickettsia-like bacterial pathogen. It is highly resistant to drying and heat, which enables the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. Its survival is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of its biphasic developmental cycle. Q fever is a zoonosis. Domestic ungulates such as sheep, cattle, and goats serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. The organism is shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nHumans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms. Acute symptoms of a flu-like illness usually develop within 2-3 weeks of exposure, although as many as half of humans infected with _C. burnetii_ do not show symptoms (http://www.cdc.gov/qfever/symptoms/index.html). Although most persons with acute Q fever infection recover, others may experience serious illness with complications that may include pneumonia, granulomatous hepatitis, endocarditis (especially in patients with previous cardiac valvulopathy), myocarditis, and central nervous system involvement. Pregnant women who are infected may be at risk for pre-term delivery or miscarriage.\n\nThe solider likely suffers from Q fever-associated chronic fatigue. The following related to post-Q fever fatigue syndrome is extracted from Melgar TA, Bauler TJ, Lutwick LI. Q fever in man: A one health paradigm disease. In, The Principles and Practice of Q Fever, Simoes JCC, Anastacio SF, da Silva GJ (eds), Nova Science Publishers, 2017, pp 1-24:\n\n\"Up to 20% of patients with acute Q fever report chronic fatigue more than a year later. Most of these cases meet the CDC criteria for chronic fatigue syndrome. Other symptoms include night sweats, nausea, headache, myalgia, enlarged lymph nodes, arthralgia, insomnia, depression, decreased concentration and short term memory impairment. The pathogenesis is not clear although there is evidence that genetic factors may play a role and _C. burnetii_ antigens and DNA can be found in patients' macrophages for up to 12 years and in one case 70 years after acute infection (1,2). Treatment is focused on chronic fatigue including exercise therapy and cognitive behavior therapy. There are no current recommendations for antimicrobial therapy for Q fever-associated chronic fatigue although case reports and one study demonstrated improvement with antimicrobials (3). A large placebo controlled randomized trial in the Netherlands (4,5) reported some non-sustained improvement was found with cognitive-behavioral therapy but not with long term doxycycline.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Marmion BP, Sukocheva O, Storm PA, et al. Q fever: persistence of antigenic non-viable cell residues of _Coxiella burnetii_ in the host - implications for post Q fever infection fatigue syndrome and other chronic sequelae. QJM 2009; 102(10): 673-84; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19556396.\n2. Sukocheva OA, Marmion BP, Storm PA, et al. Long-term persistence after acute Q fever of non-infectious _Coxiella burnetii_ cell components, including antigens. QJM 2010; 103(11): 847-63; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20639288.\n3. Arashima Y, Kato K, Komiya T, et al. Improvement of chronic nonspecific symptoms by long-term minocycline treatment in Japanese patients with _Coxiella burnetii_ infection considered to have post-Q fever fatigue syndrome. Intern Med 2004; 43(1): 49-54; https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/internalmedicine/43/1/43_1_49/_article.\n4. Keijmel SP, Delsing CE, Bleigenberg G, et al. Effectiveness of long-term doxycycline treatment and cognitive-behavioral therapy on fatigue severity in patients with Q fever fatigue syndrome (Qure study): a randomized controlled trial. Clin Infect Did 2017; 64(8): 998-1005; https://academic.oup.com/cid/article/64/8/998/3056564.\n5. Raijmakers RPH, Keijmel SP, Breukers EMC, et al. Long-term effect of cognitive behavioural therapy and doxycycline treatment for patients with Q fever fatigue syndrome: one-year follow-up of the Qure study. J Psychosom Res 2019; 116: 62-7; https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022399918308183.\n\nHelmand is one of the 34 provinces of Afghanistan, in the south of the country. It can be seen on a map at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helmand_Province. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Afghanistan: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21324]\nSee Also\n2018\n----\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) drought conditions, vaccination 20181106.6129612\nQ fever - Spain: (PV) waste treatment facility 20180411.5739737\nQ fever - Chile 20180127.5585265\n2017\n----\nQ fever - Chile (03): dairy industry workers, RFI 20171117.5450879\nQ fever - Chile (02): (LG, LR) dairy industry workers 20171111.5438140\nQ fever - Chile: (LG, LR) dairy industry workers 20171028.5410320\nQ fever - Australia (02): (QL) native animal source 20170923.5335445\nQ fever - Australia: (VI) occupational exposure, animal auction facility 20170720.5192560\nQ fever - Israel: RFI 20170717.5180136\nQ fever - Germany: (RP) sheep cell therapy, 2014 20170416.4974554\n2016\n----\nQ fever - Australia (03): (SA) spike in disease 20161231.4735189\nQ fever - Australia (02): (VI) meat processing workers 20160824.4437074\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) vaccination 20160706.4328443\nQ fever - Netherlands: human, 2007-2015, fatalities 20160531.4256718\n2015\n----\nQ fever - Australia (02): (VI) 20151019.3726962\nQ fever - USA, Canada: ex Germany (RP) sheep cell therapy, 2014 20151002.3684869\n.................................................ll/mj/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-01-24 00:00:00", "2019-01-22 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Helmand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6819886", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Spain: (RI) goat exposure", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6819886", "date": "2019-01-29 15:23:38", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AFGHANISTAN: (HELMAND) BRITISH MILITARY, 2008-2014\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 24 Jan 2019\nSource: Tolo News [edited]\nhttps://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/90-soldiers-contracted-q-fever-while-serving-helmand\n\n\nAt least 90 British military personnel have been diagnosed with confirmed cases of Q fever after serving in Helmand, Afghanistan. According to a UK military news outlet, Forces Network, a consultant in infectious diseases and tropical medicine told to the Central London Country Court on [Tue 22 Jan 2019], that 90 confirmed cases of Q fever had been recorded among British soldiers who had served in Helmand.\n\nLieutenant Colonel Mark Bailey's testimony was heard in the case of a private with 2nd Battalion, the Mercian Regiment, who said his life has been ruined after he contracted the disease while in Helmand in 2011/2012. During his tour, his lawyers said [the private] was in contact with goats and sheep and \"was often required to take cover and jump through ditches and crawl along the ground -- coming into contact with animal products and excrement.\" The soldier was medically discharged from the Army in 2014 because of his Q fever and chronic fatigue symptoms.\n\nHumans can catch Q fever by breathing in dust from the secretions of infected farm animals such as sheep, cattle, and goats.\n\nBailey, who specializes in infectious diseases and tropical medicine, and a national expert in Q fever said he has 90 military and 10 civilian cases in his care after they were referred to him. He confirmed the 90 had served in Helmand and said the number of military cases \"built up from 2008\", Forces Network reported. Bailey told the court: \"We have seen no new cases since 2014 from Afghanistan. Occasionally we get other military cases from other locations. Cyprus most recently.\"\n\nBailey said he had seen \"one British soldier who very, very nearly died\" as a result of Q fever and subsequent complications, but there have been no UK deaths in his group.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Q fever is due to _Coxiella burnetii_, an obligate intracellular rickettsia-like bacterial pathogen. It is highly resistant to drying and heat, which enables the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. Its survival is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of its biphasic developmental cycle. Q fever is a zoonosis. Domestic ungulates such as sheep, cattle, and goats serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. The organism is shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nHumans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms. Acute symptoms of a flu-like illness usually develop within 2-3 weeks of exposure, although as many as half of humans infected with _C. burnetii_ do not show symptoms (http://www.cdc.gov/qfever/symptoms/index.html). Although most persons with acute Q fever infection recover, others may experience serious illness with complications that may include pneumonia, granulomatous hepatitis, endocarditis (especially in patients with previous cardiac valvulopathy), myocarditis, and central nervous system involvement. Pregnant women who are infected may be at risk for pre-term delivery or miscarriage.\n\nThe solider likely suffers from Q fever-associated chronic fatigue. The following related to post-Q fever fatigue syndrome is extracted from Melgar TA, Bauler TJ, Lutwick LI. Q fever in man: A one health paradigm disease. In, The Principles and Practice of Q Fever, Simoes JCC, Anastacio SF, da Silva GJ (eds), Nova Science Publishers, 2017, pp 1-24:\n\n\"Up to 20% of patients with acute Q fever report chronic fatigue more than a year later. Most of these cases meet the CDC criteria for chronic fatigue syndrome. Other symptoms include night sweats, nausea, headache, myalgia, enlarged lymph nodes, arthralgia, insomnia, depression, decreased concentration and short term memory impairment. The pathogenesis is not clear although there is evidence that genetic factors may play a role and _C. burnetii_ antigens and DNA can be found in patients' macrophages for up to 12 years and in one case 70 years after acute infection (1,2). Treatment is focused on chronic fatigue including exercise therapy and cognitive behavior therapy. There are no current recommendations for antimicrobial therapy for Q fever-associated chronic fatigue although case reports and one study demonstrated improvement with antimicrobials (3). A large placebo controlled randomized trial in the Netherlands (4,5) reported some non-sustained improvement was found with cognitive-behavioral therapy but not with long term doxycycline.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Switzerland: (TI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6502499", "date": "2019-01-29 15:23:38", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AFGHANISTAN: (HELMAND) BRITISH MILITARY, 2008-2014\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 24 Jan 2019\nSource: Tolo News [edited]\nhttps://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/90-soldiers-contracted-q-fever-while-serving-helmand\n\n\nAt least 90 British military personnel have been diagnosed with confirmed cases of Q fever after serving in Helmand, Afghanistan. According to a UK military news outlet, Forces Network, a consultant in infectious diseases and tropical medicine told to the Central London Country Court on [Tue 22 Jan 2019], that 90 confirmed cases of Q fever had been recorded among British soldiers who had served in Helmand.\n\nLieutenant Colonel Mark Bailey's testimony was heard in the case of a private with 2nd Battalion, the Mercian Regiment, who said his life has been ruined after he contracted the disease while in Helmand in 2011/2012. During his tour, his lawyers said [the private] was in contact with goats and sheep and \"was often required to take cover and jump through ditches and crawl along the ground -- coming into contact with animal products and excrement.\" The soldier was medically discharged from the Army in 2014 because of his Q fever and chronic fatigue symptoms.\n\nHumans can catch Q fever by breathing in dust from the secretions of infected farm animals such as sheep, cattle, and goats.\n\nBailey, who specializes in infectious diseases and tropical medicine, and a national expert in Q fever said he has 90 military and 10 civilian cases in his care after they were referred to him. He confirmed the 90 had served in Helmand and said the number of military cases \"built up from 2008\", Forces Network reported. Bailey told the court: \"We have seen no new cases since 2014 from Afghanistan. Occasionally we get other military cases from other locations. Cyprus most recently.\"\n\nBailey said he had seen \"one British soldier who very, very nearly died\" as a result of Q fever and subsequent complications, but there have been no UK deaths in his group.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Q fever is due to _Coxiella burnetii_, an obligate intracellular rickettsia-like bacterial pathogen. It is highly resistant to drying and heat, which enables the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. Its survival is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of its biphasic developmental cycle. Q fever is a zoonosis. Domestic ungulates such as sheep, cattle, and goats serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. The organism is shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nHumans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms. Acute symptoms of a flu-like illness usually develop within 2-3 weeks of exposure, although as many as half of humans infected with _C. burnetii_ do not show symptoms (http://www.cdc.gov/qfever/symptoms/index.html). Although most persons with acute Q fever infection recover, others may experience serious illness with complications that may include pneumonia, granulomatous hepatitis, endocarditis (especially in patients with previous cardiac valvulopathy), myocarditis, and central nervous system involvement. Pregnant women who are infected may be at risk for pre-term delivery or miscarriage.\n\nThe solider likely suffers from Q fever-associated chronic fatigue. The following related to post-Q fever fatigue syndrome is extracted from Melgar TA, Bauler TJ, Lutwick LI. Q fever in man: A one health paradigm disease. In, The Principles and Practice of Q Fever, Simoes JCC, Anastacio SF, da Silva GJ (eds), Nova Science Publishers, 2017, pp 1-24:\n\n\"Up to 20% of patients with acute Q fever report chronic fatigue more than a year later. Most of these cases meet the CDC criteria for chronic fatigue syndrome. Other symptoms include night sweats, nausea, headache, myalgia, enlarged lymph nodes, arthralgia, insomnia, depression, decreased concentration and short term memory impairment. The pathogenesis is not clear although there is evidence that genetic factors may play a role and _C. burnetii_ antigens and DNA can be found in patients' macrophages for up to 12 years and in one case 70 years after acute infection (1,2). Treatment is focused on chronic fatigue including exercise therapy and cognitive behavior therapy. There are no current recommendations for antimicrobial therapy for Q fever-associated chronic fatigue although case reports and one study demonstrated improvement with antimicrobials (3). A large placebo controlled randomized trial in the Netherlands (4,5) reported some non-sustained improvement was found with cognitive-behavioral therapy but not with long term doxycycline.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Afghanistan: (HM) British military, 2008-2014", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6283697", "date": "2019-01-29 15:23:38", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AFGHANISTAN: (HELMAND) BRITISH MILITARY, 2008-2014\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 24 Jan 2019\nSource: Tolo News [edited]\nhttps://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/90-soldiers-contracted-q-fever-while-serving-helmand\n\n\nAt least 90 British military personnel have been diagnosed with confirmed cases of Q fever after serving in Helmand, Afghanistan. According to a UK military news outlet, Forces Network, a consultant in infectious diseases and tropical medicine told to the Central London Country Court on [Tue 22 Jan 2019], that 90 confirmed cases of Q fever had been recorded among British soldiers who had served in Helmand.\n\nLieutenant Colonel Mark Bailey's testimony was heard in the case of a private with 2nd Battalion, the Mercian Regiment, who said his life has been ruined after he contracted the disease while in Helmand in 2011/2012. During his tour, his lawyers said [the private] was in contact with goats and sheep and \"was often required to take cover and jump through ditches and crawl along the ground -- coming into contact with animal products and excrement.\" The soldier was medically discharged from the Army in 2014 because of his Q fever and chronic fatigue symptoms.\n\nHumans can catch Q fever by breathing in dust from the secretions of infected farm animals such as sheep, cattle, and goats.\n\nBailey, who specializes in infectious diseases and tropical medicine, and a national expert in Q fever said he has 90 military and 10 civilian cases in his care after they were referred to him. He confirmed the 90 had served in Helmand and said the number of military cases \"built up from 2008\", Forces Network reported. Bailey told the court: \"We have seen no new cases since 2014 from Afghanistan. Occasionally we get other military cases from other locations. Cyprus most recently.\"\n\nBailey said he had seen \"one British soldier who very, very nearly died\" as a result of Q fever and subsequent complications, but there have been no UK deaths in his group.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Q fever is due to _Coxiella burnetii_, an obligate intracellular rickettsia-like bacterial pathogen. It is highly resistant to drying and heat, which enables the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. Its survival is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of its biphasic developmental cycle. Q fever is a zoonosis. Domestic ungulates such as sheep, cattle, and goats serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. The organism is shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nHumans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms. Acute symptoms of a flu-like illness usually develop within 2-3 weeks of exposure, although as many as half of humans infected with _C. burnetii_ do not show symptoms (http://www.cdc.gov/qfever/symptoms/index.html). Although most persons with acute Q fever infection recover, others may experience serious illness with complications that may include pneumonia, granulomatous hepatitis, endocarditis (especially in patients with previous cardiac valvulopathy), myocarditis, and central nervous system involvement. Pregnant women who are infected may be at risk for pre-term delivery or miscarriage.\n\nThe solider likely suffers from Q fever-associated chronic fatigue. The following related to post-Q fever fatigue syndrome is extracted from Melgar TA, Bauler TJ, Lutwick LI. Q fever in man: A one health paradigm disease. In, The Principles and Practice of Q Fever, Simoes JCC, Anastacio SF, da Silva GJ (eds), Nova Science Publishers, 2017, pp 1-24:\n\n\"Up to 20% of patients with acute Q fever report chronic fatigue more than a year later. Most of these cases meet the CDC criteria for chronic fatigue syndrome. Other symptoms include night sweats, nausea, headache, myalgia, enlarged lymph nodes, arthralgia, insomnia, depression, decreased concentration and short term memory impairment. The pathogenesis is not clear although there is evidence that genetic factors may play a role and _C. burnetii_ antigens and DNA can be found in patients' macrophages for up to 12 years and in one case 70 years after acute infection (1,2). Treatment is focused on chronic fatigue including exercise therapy and cognitive behavior therapy. There are no current recommendations for antimicrobial therapy for Q fever-associated chronic fatigue although case reports and one study demonstrated improvement with antimicrobials (3). A large placebo controlled randomized trial in the Netherlands (4,5) reported some non-sustained improvement was found with cognitive-behavioral therapy but not with long term doxycycline.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Marmion BP, Sukocheva O, Storm PA, et al. Q fever: persistence of antigenic non-viable cell residues of _Coxiella burnetii_ in the host - implications for post Q fever infection fatigue syndrome and other chronic sequelae. QJM 2009; 102(10): 673-84; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19556396.\n2. Sukocheva OA, Marmion BP, Storm PA, et al. Long-term persistence after acute Q fever of non-infectious _Coxiella burnetii_ cell components, including antigens. QJM 2010; 103(11): 847-63; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20639288.\n3. Arashima Y, Kato K, Komiya T, et al. Improvement of chronic nonspecific symptoms by long-term minocycline treatment in Japanese patients with _Coxiella burnetii_ infection considered to have post-Q fever fatigue syndrome. Intern Med 2004; 43(1): 49-54; https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/internalmedicine/43/1/43_1_49/_article.\n4. Keijmel SP, Delsing CE, Bleigenberg G, et al. Effectiveness of long-term doxycycline treatment and cognitive-behavioral therapy on fatigue severity in patients with Q fever fatigue syndrome (Qure study): a randomized controlled trial. Clin Infect Did 2017; 64(8): 998-1005; https://academic.oup.com/cid/article/64/8/998/3056564.\n5. Raijmakers RPH, Keijmel SP, Breukers EMC, et al. Long-term effect of cognitive behavioural therapy and doxycycline treatment for patients with Q fever fatigue syndrome: one-year follow-up of the Qure study. J Psychosom Res 2019; 116: 62-7; https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022399918308183.\n\nHelmand is one of the 34 provinces of Afghanistan, in the south of the country. It can be seen on a map at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helmand_Province. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Afghanistan: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21324]\nSee Also\n2018\n----\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) drought conditions, vaccination 20181106.6129612\nQ fever - Spain: (PV) waste treatment facility 20180411.5739737\nQ fever - Chile 20180127.5585265\n2017\n----\nQ fever - Chile (03): dairy industry workers, RFI 20171117.5450879\nQ fever - Chile (02): (LG, LR) dairy industry workers 20171111.5438140\nQ fever - Chile: (LG, LR) dairy industry workers 20171028.5410320\nQ fever - Australia (02): (QL) native animal source 20170923.5335445\nQ fever - Australia: (VI) occupational exposure, animal auction facility 20170720.5192560\nQ fever - Israel: RFI 20170717.5180136\nQ fever - Germany: (RP) sheep cell therapy, 2014 20170416.4974554\n2016\n----\nQ fever - Australia (03): (SA) spike in disease 20161231.4735189\nQ fever - Australia (02): (VI) meat processing workers 20160824.4437074\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) vaccination 20160706.4328443\nQ fever - Netherlands: human, 2007-2015, fatalities 20160531.4256718\n2015\n----\nQ fever - Australia (02): (VI) 20151019.3726962\nQ fever - USA, Canada: ex Germany (RP) sheep cell therapy, 2014 20151002.3684869\n.................................................ll/mj/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-01-24 00:00:00", "2019-01-22 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2018-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Afghanistan", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Helmand", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6129612", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Australia: (NS) drought conditions, vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6129612", "date": "2019-01-29 15:23:38", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AFGHANISTAN: (HELMAND) BRITISH MILITARY, 2008-2014\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 24 Jan 2019\nSource: Tolo News [edited]\nhttps://www.tolonews.com/afghanistan/90-soldiers-contracted-q-fever-while-serving-helmand\n\n\nAt least 90 British military personnel have been diagnosed with confirmed cases of Q fever after serving in Helmand, Afghanistan. According to a UK military news outlet, Forces Network, a consultant in infectious diseases and tropical medicine told to the Central London Country Court on [Tue 22 Jan 2019], that 90 confirmed cases of Q fever had been recorded among British soldiers who had served in Helmand.\n\nLieutenant Colonel Mark Bailey's testimony was heard in the case of a private with 2nd Battalion, the Mercian Regiment, who said his life has been ruined after he contracted the disease while in Helmand in 2011/2012. During his tour, his lawyers said [the private] was in contact with goats and sheep and \"was often required to take cover and jump through ditches and crawl along the ground -- coming into contact with animal products and excrement.\" The soldier was medically discharged from the Army in 2014 because of his Q fever and chronic fatigue symptoms.\n\nHumans can catch Q fever by breathing in dust from the secretions of infected farm animals such as sheep, cattle, and goats.\n\nBailey, who specializes in infectious diseases and tropical medicine, and a national expert in Q fever said he has 90 military and 10 civilian cases in his care after they were referred to him. He confirmed the 90 had served in Helmand and said the number of military cases \"built up from 2008\", Forces Network reported. Bailey told the court: \"We have seen no new cases since 2014 from Afghanistan. Occasionally we get other military cases from other locations. Cyprus most recently.\"\n\nBailey said he had seen \"one British soldier who very, very nearly died\" as a result of Q fever and subsequent complications, but there have been no UK deaths in his group.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Q fever is due to _Coxiella burnetii_, an obligate intracellular rickettsia-like bacterial pathogen. It is highly resistant to drying and heat, which enables the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. Its survival is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of its biphasic developmental cycle. Q fever is a zoonosis. Domestic ungulates such as sheep, cattle, and goats serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. The organism is shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nHumans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms. Acute symptoms of a flu-like illness usually develop within 2-3 weeks of exposure, although as many as half of humans infected with _C. burnetii_ do not show symptoms (http://www.cdc.gov/qfever/symptoms/index.html). Although most persons with acute Q fever infection recover, others may experience serious illness with complications that may include pneumonia, granulomatous hepatitis, endocarditis (especially in patients with previous cardiac valvulopathy), myocarditis, and central nervous system involvement. Pregnant women who are infected may be at risk for pre-term delivery or miscarriage.\n\nThe solider likely suffers from Q fever-associated chronic fatigue. The following related to post-Q fever fatigue syndrome is extracted from Melgar TA, Bauler TJ, Lutwick LI. Q fever in man: A one health paradigm disease. In, The Principles and Practice of Q Fever, Simoes JCC, Anastacio SF, da Silva GJ (eds), Nova Science Publishers, 2017, pp 1-24:\n\n\"Up to 20% of patients with acute Q fever report chronic fatigue more than a year later. Most of these cases meet the CDC criteria for chronic fatigue syndrome. Other symptoms include night sweats, nausea, headache, myalgia, enlarged lymph nodes, arthralgia, insomnia, depression, decreased concentration and short term memory impairment. The pathogenesis is not clear although there is evidence that genetic factors may play a role and _C. burnetii_ antigens and DNA can be found in patients' macrophages for up to 12 years and in one case 70 years after acute infection (1,2). Treatment is focused on chronic fatigue including exercise therapy and cognitive behavior therapy. There are no current recommendations for antimicrobial therapy for Q fever-associated chronic fatigue although case reports and one study demonstrated improvement with antimicrobials (3). A large placebo controlled randomized trial in the Netherlands (4,5) reported some non-sustained improvement was found with cognitive-behavioral therapy but not with long term doxycycline.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Spain: (PV) waste treatment facility", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5739737", "date": "2017-07-17 13:24:15", "main_text": "Q FEVER - ISRAEL: REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 16 Jul 2017\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org> [edited]\n\n\nWe have learned from a reliable source that there has been an increase in reported cases of Q fever in Israel this year [2017].\n\nInformation available from the Israeli Weekly Epidemiological Report for epidemiological (Epi) week 25 (18-24 Jun 2017) confirms this increase (see IWER25_2017.xlsx, line 103 available at http://www.health.gov.il/UnitsOffice/HD/PH/epidemiology/Pages/epidemiology_report.aspx).\n\nAs of epidemiological week 25, there were 61 cumulative cases of Q fever reported in 2017, compared with 49 cases reported during the same time period during 2016.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Q fever in Israel was last reported by ProMED-mail in 2005 (archive no. 20050814.2378). At that time, Mod.AS wrote the following moderator comments, which apparently also apply today:\n\n\"Q fever is a worldwide zoonosis caused by _Coxiella burnetii_, a strictly intracellular bacterium that is a potential bioweapon. In Israel, the disease was first described during the 4th decade of the previous century and has been notifiable in humans and animals for more than 50 years. Cases in humans and in farm animals (cattle, sheep and goats) are recorded every year; in the latter, the infection is manifested by abortions, causing considerable economic losses.\n\nThough the world literature incriminates mainly farm animals as the source of human infection, this is not always supported by evidence in Israel; while in some human cases a link to farm animals or their fomites/products could be demonstrated, in the majority of cases, no such association is apparent. Other sources/animals should be considered as well. The current observation may indicate the need for more attention to the potential role of pets, particularly cats; the stray cat population in Israel is estimated to exceed 6-figure numbers, with high densities observed in urban areas. Epidemiological investigation regarding their infection rate with _Coxiella burnetii_ might be justifiable.\n\nFurther reading:\n1. Yarrow A, Slater PE, Costin C. Q fever in Israel. Public Health Rev. 1990-1991; 18(2): 129-37; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/2134719.\n2. Oren I, Kraoz Z, Hadani Y, et al. An outbreak of Q fever in an urban area in Israel. Eur J Clin Microbiol Infect Dis. 2005; 24(5): 338-41; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15868156.\n3. Langley JM, Tarrie TJ, Covert A, et al. Poker players' pneumonia: an urban outbreak of Q fever following exposure to a parturient cat. N Engl J Med 1988; 319(6): 354-6; available at http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM198808113190607 [subscription required].\n4. Kasatsky T. Household outbreak of Q fever pneumonia related to a parturient cat. Lancet. 1984; 2(8417-8418):1447-9; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/6151054.\n5. Marrie TJ, Durant H, Williams JC, et al. Exposure to parturient cats: a risk factor for acquisition of Q fever in Maritime Canada. J Infect Dis. 1988; 158(1): 101-8; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3392409.\"\n\nQ fever is primarily an occupational hazard for farmers, veterinarians, and abattoir workers in contact with infected domestic animals such as cattle, sheep, and goats, which serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. Humans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms that are shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products of infected animals; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nQ fever spreads in air currents for a considerable distance in agricultural regions via airborne particles containing the _C. burnetii_ to involve people living downwind from infected livestock. Widespread transmission of Q fever was recently documented in the Netherlands downwind from the index farm, a single dairy-goat farm, even beyond a 5 km (3 mi) high-risk zone (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/55/12/1591.long#T2). _C. burnetii_ is highly resistant to drying, heat, and many common disinfectants, which is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of a biphasic developmental cycle. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nAlthough often asymptomatic, the infection can present acutely 2-3 weeks after exposure as atypical pneumonia or hepatitis or as a chronic disease (mainly endocarditis) (Maurin M, Raoult D. Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev. 1999; 12(4): 518-53; available at http://cmr.asm.org/content/12/4/518.short.) Unusual complications include glomerulonephritis and rhabdomyolysis (http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/08860220701460178).\n\nDiagnosis of Q fever can usually be confirmed by serology (https://emergency.cdc.gov/agent/qfever/clinicians/diagnosis.asp). In acute Q fever, phase II antibodies are usually much higher than phase I antibodies and are detectable by indirect immunofluorescence 2 to 3 weeks after onset of illness. In chronic Q fever, phase I antibody titers are much greater than phase II titers. Phase I antibody titers of 1:800 or higher are considered diagnostic in endocarditis patients for chronic Q fever.\n\nThe tetracyclines are considered the antibiotics of choice for treatment of acute Q fever. A human vaccine for Q fever is used in Australia, but it is not available in the United States. - Mod.ML]\n\n[More information on this observed increase in Q fever in Israel including demographics, geographic distribution, and potential high risk exposures would be greatly appreciated. - Mod.MPP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/90.]\nSee Also\n2016\n----\nQ fever - Australia (02): (VI) meat processing workers 20160824.4437074\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) vaccination 20160706.4328443\n2015\n----\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) 20150717.3516801\n2014\n----\nQ fever - USA (02): (OR) vaccination, comment 20140728.2641341\nQ fever - USA: (OR) 20140726.2636921\n2005\n----\nQ fever - Israel 20050814.2378\n.................................................mpp/ml/mj/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1984-03-16 00:00:00", "1988-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5585265", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Chile", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5585265", "date": "2017-07-17 13:24:15", "main_text": "Q FEVER - ISRAEL: REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 16 Jul 2017\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org> [edited]\n\n\nWe have learned from a reliable source that there has been an increase in reported cases of Q fever in Israel this year [2017].\n\nInformation available from the Israeli Weekly Epidemiological Report for epidemiological (Epi) week 25 (18-24 Jun 2017) confirms this increase (see IWER25_2017.xlsx, line 103 available at http://www.health.gov.il/UnitsOffice/HD/PH/epidemiology/Pages/epidemiology_report.aspx).\n\nAs of epidemiological week 25, there were 61 cumulative cases of Q fever reported in 2017, compared with 49 cases reported during the same time period during 2016.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Q fever in Israel was last reported by ProMED-mail in 2005 (archive no. 20050814.2378). At that time, Mod.AS wrote the following moderator comments, which apparently also apply today:\n\n\"Q fever is a worldwide zoonosis caused by _Coxiella burnetii_, a strictly intracellular bacterium that is a potential bioweapon. In Israel, the disease was first described during the 4th decade of the previous century and has been notifiable in humans and animals for more than 50 years. Cases in humans and in farm animals (cattle, sheep and goats) are recorded every year; in the latter, the infection is manifested by abortions, causing considerable economic losses.\n\nThough the world literature incriminates mainly farm animals as the source of human infection, this is not always supported by evidence in Israel; while in some human cases a link to farm animals or their fomites/products could be demonstrated, in the majority of cases, no such association is apparent. Other sources/animals should be considered as well. The current observation may indicate the need for more attention to the potential role of pets, particularly cats; the stray cat population in Israel is estimated to exceed 6-figure numbers, with high densities observed in urban areas. Epidemiological investigation regarding their infection rate with _Coxiella burnetii_ might be justifiable.\n\nFurther reading:\n1. Yarrow A, Slater PE, Costin C. Q fever in Israel. Public Health Rev. 1990-1991; 18(2): 129-37; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/2134719.\n2. Oren I, Kraoz Z, Hadani Y, et al. An outbreak of Q fever in an urban area in Israel. Eur J Clin Microbiol Infect Dis. 2005; 24(5): 338-41; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15868156.\n3. Langley JM, Tarrie TJ, Covert A, et al. Poker players' pneumonia: an urban outbreak of Q fever following exposure to a parturient cat. N Engl J Med 1988; 319(6): 354-6; available at http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM198808113190607 [subscription required].\n4. Kasatsky T. Household outbreak of Q fever pneumonia related to a parturient cat. Lancet. 1984; 2(8417-8418):1447-9; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/6151054.\n5. Marrie TJ, Durant H, Williams JC, et al. Exposure to parturient cats: a risk factor for acquisition of Q fever in Maritime Canada. J Infect Dis. 1988; 158(1): 101-8; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3392409.\"\n\nQ fever is primarily an occupational hazard for farmers, veterinarians, and abattoir workers in contact with infected domestic animals such as cattle, sheep, and goats, which serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. Humans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms that are shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products of infected animals; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nQ fever spreads in air currents for a considerable distance in agricultural regions via airborne particles containing the _C. burnetii_ to involve people living downwind from infected livestock. Widespread transmission of Q fever was recently documented in the Netherlands downwind from the index farm, a single dairy-goat farm, even beyond a 5 km (3 mi) high-risk zone (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/55/12/1591.long#T2). _C. burnetii_ is highly resistant to drying, heat, and many common disinfectants, which is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of a biphasic developmental cycle. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nAlthough often asymptomatic, the infection can present acutely 2-3 weeks after exposure as atypical pneumonia or hepatitis or as a chronic disease (mainly endocarditis) (Maurin M, Raoult D. Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev. 1999; 12(4): 518-53; available at http://cmr.asm.org/content/12/4/518.short.) Unusual complications include glomerulonephritis and rhabdomyolysis (http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/08860220701460178).\n\nDiagnosis of Q fever can usually be confirmed by serology (https://emergency.cdc.gov/agent/qfever/clinicians/diagnosis.asp). In acute Q fever, phase II antibodies are usually much higher than phase I antibodies and are detectable by indirect immunofluorescence 2 to 3 weeks after onset of illness. In chronic Q fever, phase I antibody titers are much greater than phase II titers. Phase I antibody titers of 1:800 or higher are considered diagnostic in endocarditis patients for chronic Q fever.\n\nThe tetracyclines are considered the antibiotics of choice for treatment of acute Q fever. A human vaccine for Q fever is used in Australia, but it is not available in the United States. - Mod.ML]\n\n[More information on this observed increase in Q fever in Israel including demographics, geographic distribution, and potential high risk exposures would be greatly appreciated. - Mod.MPP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/90.]\nSee Also\n2016\n----\nQ fever - Australia (02): (VI) meat processing workers 20160824.4437074\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) vaccination 20160706.4328443\n2015\n----\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) 20150717.3516801\n2014\n----\nQ fever - USA (02): (OR) vaccination, comment 20140728.2641341\nQ fever - USA: (OR) 20140726.2636921\n2005\n----\nQ fever - Israel 20050814.2378\n.................................................mpp/ml/mj/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1984-03-16 00:00:00", "1988-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5450879", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Chile (03): dairy industry workers, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5450879", "date": "2017-07-17 13:24:15", "main_text": "Q FEVER - ISRAEL: REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 16 Jul 2017\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org> [edited]\n\n\nWe have learned from a reliable source that there has been an increase in reported cases of Q fever in Israel this year [2017].\n\nInformation available from the Israeli Weekly Epidemiological Report for epidemiological (Epi) week 25 (18-24 Jun 2017) confirms this increase (see IWER25_2017.xlsx, line 103 available at http://www.health.gov.il/UnitsOffice/HD/PH/epidemiology/Pages/epidemiology_report.aspx).\n\nAs of epidemiological week 25, there were 61 cumulative cases of Q fever reported in 2017, compared with 49 cases reported during the same time period during 2016.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Q fever in Israel was last reported by ProMED-mail in 2005 (archive no. 20050814.2378). At that time, Mod.AS wrote the following moderator comments, which apparently also apply today:\n\n\"Q fever is a worldwide zoonosis caused by _Coxiella burnetii_, a strictly intracellular bacterium that is a potential bioweapon. In Israel, the disease was first described during the 4th decade of the previous century and has been notifiable in humans and animals for more than 50 years. Cases in humans and in farm animals (cattle, sheep and goats) are recorded every year; in the latter, the infection is manifested by abortions, causing considerable economic losses.\n\nThough the world literature incriminates mainly farm animals as the source of human infection, this is not always supported by evidence in Israel; while in some human cases a link to farm animals or their fomites/products could be demonstrated, in the majority of cases, no such association is apparent. Other sources/animals should be considered as well. The current observation may indicate the need for more attention to the potential role of pets, particularly cats; the stray cat population in Israel is estimated to exceed 6-figure numbers, with high densities observed in urban areas. Epidemiological investigation regarding their infection rate with _Coxiella burnetii_ might be justifiable.\n\nFurther reading:\n1. Yarrow A, Slater PE, Costin C. Q fever in Israel. Public Health Rev. 1990-1991; 18(2): 129-37; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/2134719.\n2. Oren I, Kraoz Z, Hadani Y, et al. An outbreak of Q fever in an urban area in Israel. Eur J Clin Microbiol Infect Dis. 2005; 24(5): 338-41; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15868156.\n3. Langley JM, Tarrie TJ, Covert A, et al. Poker players' pneumonia: an urban outbreak of Q fever following exposure to a parturient cat. N Engl J Med 1988; 319(6): 354-6; available at http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM198808113190607 [subscription required].\n4. Kasatsky T. Household outbreak of Q fever pneumonia related to a parturient cat. Lancet. 1984; 2(8417-8418):1447-9; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/6151054.\n5. Marrie TJ, Durant H, Williams JC, et al. Exposure to parturient cats: a risk factor for acquisition of Q fever in Maritime Canada. J Infect Dis. 1988; 158(1): 101-8; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3392409.\"\n\nQ fever is primarily an occupational hazard for farmers, veterinarians, and abattoir workers in contact with infected domestic animals such as cattle, sheep, and goats, which serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. Humans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms that are shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products of infected animals; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nQ fever spreads in air currents for a considerable distance in agricultural regions via airborne particles containing the _C. burnetii_ to involve people living downwind from infected livestock. Widespread transmission of Q fever was recently documented in the Netherlands downwind from the index farm, a single dairy-goat farm, even beyond a 5 km (3 mi) high-risk zone (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/55/12/1591.long#T2). _C. burnetii_ is highly resistant to drying, heat, and many common disinfectants, which is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of a biphasic developmental cycle. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nAlthough often asymptomatic, the infection can present acutely 2-3 weeks after exposure as atypical pneumonia or hepatitis or as a chronic disease (mainly endocarditis) (Maurin M, Raoult D. Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev. 1999; 12(4): 518-53; available at http://cmr.asm.org/content/12/4/518.short.) Unusual complications include glomerulonephritis and rhabdomyolysis (http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/08860220701460178).\n\nDiagnosis of Q fever can usually be confirmed by serology (https://emergency.cdc.gov/agent/qfever/clinicians/diagnosis.asp). In acute Q fever, phase II antibodies are usually much higher than phase I antibodies and are detectable by indirect immunofluorescence 2 to 3 weeks after onset of illness. In chronic Q fever, phase I antibody titers are much greater than phase II titers. Phase I antibody titers of 1:800 or higher are considered diagnostic in endocarditis patients for chronic Q fever.\n\nThe tetracyclines are considered the antibiotics of choice for treatment of acute Q fever. A human vaccine for Q fever is used in Australia, but it is not available in the United States. - Mod.ML]\n\n[More information on this observed increase in Q fever in Israel including demographics, geographic distribution, and potential high risk exposures would be greatly appreciated. - Mod.MPP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/90.]\nSee Also\n2016\n----\nQ fever - Australia (02): (VI) meat processing workers 20160824.4437074\nQ fever - J Infect Dis. 1988; 158(1): 101-8; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3392409.\"\n\nQ fever is primarily an occupational hazard for farmers, veterinarians, and abattoir workers in contact with infected domestic animals such as cattle, sheep, and goats, which serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. Humans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms that are shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products of infected animals; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nQ fever spreads in air currents for a considerable distance in agricultural regions via airborne particles containing the _C. burnetii_ to involve people living downwind from infected livestock. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nAlthough often asymptomatic, the infection can present acutely 2-3 weeks after exposure as atypical pneumonia or hepatitis or as a chronic disease (mainly endocarditis) (Maurin M, Raoult D. Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev. 1999; 12(4): 518-53; available at http://cmr.asm.org/content/12/4/518.short.) Unusual complications include glomerulonephritis and rhabdomyolysis (http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/08860220701460178).\n\nDiagnosis of Q fever can usually be confirmed by serology (https://emergency.cdc.gov/agent/qfever/clinicians/diagnosis.asp).
