Public Health Rev. 1990-1991; 18(2): 129-37; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/2134719.\n2. Oren I, Kraoz Z, Hadani Y, et al. An outbreak of Q fever in an urban area in Israel. Eur J Clin Microbiol Infect Dis. 2005; 24(5): 338-41; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15868156.\n3. Langley JM, Tarrie TJ, Covert A, et al. Poker players' pneumonia: an urban outbreak of Q fever following exposure to a parturient cat. N Engl J Med 1988; 319(6): 354-6; available at http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM198808113190607 [subscription required].\n4. Kasatsky T. Household outbreak of Q fever pneumonia related to a parturient cat. Lancet. 1984; 2(8417-8418):1447-9; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/6151054.\n5. Marrie TJ, Durant H, Williams JC, et al. Exposure to parturient cats: a risk factor for acquisition of Q fever in Maritime Canada. J Infect Dis. 1988; 158(1): 101-8; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3392409.\"\n\nQ fever is primarily an occupational hazard for farmers, veterinarians, and abattoir workers in contact with infected domestic animals such as cattle, sheep, and goats, which serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. Humans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms that are shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products of infected animals; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nQ fever spreads in air currents for a considerable distance in agricultural regions via airborne particles containing the _C. burnetii_ to involve people living downwind from infected livestock. Widespread transmission of Q fever was recently documented in the Netherlands downwind from the index farm, a single dairy-goat farm, even beyond a 5 km (3 mi) high-risk zone (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/55/12/1591.long#T2). _C. burnetii_ is highly resistant to drying, heat, and many common disinfectants, which is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of a biphasic developmental cycle. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nAlthough often asymptomatic, the infection can present acutely 2-3 weeks after exposure as atypical pneumonia or hepatitis or as a chronic disease (mainly endocarditis) (Maurin M, Raoult D. Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev. 1999; 12(4): 518-53; available at http://cmr.asm.org/content/12/4/518.short.) Unusual complications include glomerulonephritis and rhabdomyolysis (http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/08860220701460178).\n\nDiagnosis of Q fever can usually be confirmed by serology (https://emergency.cdc.gov/agent/qfever/clinicians/diagnosis.asp). In acute Q fever, phase II antibodies are usually much higher than phase I antibodies and are detectable by indirect immunofluorescence 2 to 3 weeks after onset of illness. In chronic Q fever, phase I antibody titers are much greater than phase II titers. Phase I antibody titers of 1:800 or higher are considered diagnostic in endocarditis patients for chronic Q fever.\n\nThe tetracyclines are considered the antibiotics of choice for treatment of acute Q fever. A human vaccine for Q fever is used in Australia, but it is not available in the United States. - Mod.ML]\n\n[More information on this observed increase in Q fever in Israel including demographics, geographic distribution, and potential high risk exposures would be greatly appreciated. - Mod.MPP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/90.]\nSee Also\n2016\n----\nQ fever - Australia (02): (VI) meat processing workers 20160824.4437074\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) vaccination 20160706.4328443\n2015\n----\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) 20150717.3516801\n2014\n----\nQ fever - USA (02): (OR) vaccination, comment 20140728.2641341\nQ fever - USA: (OR) 20140726.2636921\n2005\n----\nQ fever - Israel 20050814.2378\n.................................................mpp/ml/mj/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1984-03-16 00:00:00", "1988-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5192560", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Australia: (VI) occupational exposure, animal auction facility", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5192560", "date": "2017-07-17 13:24:15", "main_text": "Q FEVER - ISRAEL: REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 16 Jul 2017\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org> [edited]\n\n\nWe have learned from a reliable source that there has been an increase in reported cases of Q fever in Israel this year [2017].\n\nInformation available from the Israeli Weekly Epidemiological Report for epidemiological (Epi) week 25 (18-24 Jun 2017) confirms this increase (see IWER25_2017.xlsx, line 103 available at http://www.health.gov.il/UnitsOffice/HD/PH/epidemiology/Pages/epidemiology_report.aspx).\n\nAs of epidemiological week 25, there were 61 cumulative cases of Q fever reported in 2017, compared with 49 cases reported during the same time period during 2016.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Q fever in Israel was last reported by ProMED-mail in 2005 (archive no. 20050814.2378). At that time, Mod.AS wrote the following moderator comments, which apparently also apply today:\n\n\"Q fever is a worldwide zoonosis caused by _Coxiella burnetii_, a strictly intracellular bacterium that is a potential bioweapon. In Israel, the disease was first described during the 4th decade of the previous century and has been notifiable in humans and animals for more than 50 years. Cases in humans and in farm animals (cattle, sheep and goats) are recorded every year; in the latter, the infection is manifested by abortions, causing considerable economic losses.\n\nThough the world literature incriminates mainly farm animals as the source of human infection, this is not always supported by evidence in Israel; while in some human cases a link to farm animals or their fomites/products could be demonstrated, in the majority of cases, no such association is apparent. Other sources/animals should be considered as well. The current observation may indicate the need for more attention to the potential role of pets, particularly cats; the stray cat population in Israel is estimated to exceed 6-figure numbers, with high densities observed in urban areas. Epidemiological investigation regarding their infection rate with _Coxiella burnetii_ might be justifiable.\n\nFurther reading:\n1. Yarrow A, Slater PE, Costin C. Q fever in Israel. Public Health Rev. 1990-1991; 18(2): 129-37; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/2134719.\n2. Oren I, Kraoz Z, Hadani Y, et al. An outbreak of Q fever in an urban area in Israel. Eur J Clin Microbiol Infect Dis. 2005; 24(5): 338-41; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15868156.\n3. Langley JM, Tarrie TJ, Covert A, et al. Poker players' pneumonia: an urban outbreak of Q fever following exposure to a parturient cat. N Engl J Med 1988; 319(6): 354-6; available at http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM198808113190607 [subscription required].\n4. Kasatsky T. Household outbreak of Q fever pneumonia related to a parturient cat. Lancet. 1984; 2(8417-8418):1447-9; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/6151054.\n5. Marrie TJ, Durant H, Williams JC, et al. Exposure to parturient cats: a risk factor for acquisition of Q fever in Maritime Canada. J Infect Dis. 1988; 158(1): 101-8; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3392409.\"\n\nQ fever is primarily an occupational hazard for farmers, veterinarians, and abattoir workers in contact with infected domestic animals such as cattle, sheep, and goats, which serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. Humans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms that are shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products of infected animals; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nQ fever spreads in air currents for a considerable distance in agricultural regions via airborne particles containing the _C. burnetii_ to involve people living downwind from infected livestock. Widespread transmission of Q fever was recently documented in the Netherlands downwind from the index farm, a single dairy-goat farm, even beyond a 5 km (3 mi) high-risk zone (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/55/12/1591.long#T2). _C. burnetii_ is highly resistant to drying, heat, and many common disinfectants, which is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of a biphasic developmental cycle. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nAlthough often asymptomatic, the infection can present acutely 2-3 weeks after exposure as atypical pneumonia or hepatitis or as a chronic disease (mainly endocarditis) (Maurin M, Raoult D. Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev. 1999; 12(4): 518-53; available at http://cmr.asm.org/content/12/4/518.short.) Unusual complications include glomerulonephritis and rhabdomyolysis (http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/08860220701460178).\n\nDiagnosis of Q fever can usually be confirmed by serology (https://emergency.cdc.gov/agent/qfever/clinicians/diagnosis.asp). In acute Q fever, phase II antibodies are usually much higher than phase I antibodies and are detectable by indirect immunofluorescence 2 to 3 weeks after onset of illness. In chronic Q fever, phase I antibody titers are much greater than phase II titers. Phase I antibody titers of 1:800 or higher are considered diagnostic in endocarditis patients for chronic Q fever.\n\nThe tetracyclines are considered the antibiotics of choice for treatment of acute Q fever. A human vaccine for Q fever is used in Australia, but it is not available in the United States. - Mod.ML]\n\n[More information on this observed increase in Q fever in Israel including demographics, geographic distribution, and potential high risk exposures would be greatly appreciated. - Mod.MPP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/90.]\nSee Also\n2016\n----\nQ fever - Australia (02): (VI) meat processing workers 20160824.4437074\nQ fever - At that time, Mod.AS wrote the following moderator comments, which apparently also apply today:\n\n\"Q fever is a worldwide zoonosis caused by _Coxiella burnetii_, a strictly intracellular bacterium that is a potential bioweapon. In Israel, the disease was first described during the 4th decade of the previous century and has been notifiable in humans and animals for more than 50 years. Cases in humans and in farm animals (cattle, sheep and goats) are recorded every year; in the latter, the infection is manifested by abortions, causing considerable economic losses.\n\nThough the world literature incriminates mainly farm animals as the source of human infection, this is not always supported by evidence in Israel; while in some human cases a link to farm animals or their fomites/products could be demonstrated, in the majority of cases, no such association is apparent. Other sources/animals should be considered as well. The current observation may indicate the need for more attention to the potential role of pets, particularly cats; the stray cat population in Israel is estimated to exceed 6-figure numbers, with high densities observed in urban areas. Epidemiological investigation regarding their infection rate with _Coxiella burnetii_ might be justifiable.\n\nFurther reading:\n1. Yarrow A, Slater PE, Costin C. Q fever in Israel. N Engl J Med 1988; 319(6): 354-6; available at http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM198808113190607 [subscription required].\n4. Kasatsky T. Household outbreak of Q fever pneumonia related to a parturient cat. Lancet. 1984; 2(8417-8418):1447-9; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/6151054.\n5. Marrie TJ, Durant H, Williams JC, et al. Exposure to parturient cats: a risk factor for acquisition of Q fever in Maritime Canada. J Infect Dis. 1988; 158(1): 101-8; abstract available at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3392409.\"\n\nQ fever is primarily an occupational hazard for farmers, veterinarians, and abattoir workers in contact with infected domestic animals such as cattle, sheep, and goats, which serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. Humans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms that are shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products of infected animals; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nQ fever spreads in air currents for a considerable distance in agricultural regions via airborne particles containing the _C. burnetii_ to involve people living downwind from infected livestock. Widespread transmission of Q fever was recently documented in the Netherlands downwind from the index farm, a single dairy-goat farm, even beyond a 5 km (3 mi) high-risk zone (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/55/12/1591.long#T2). _C. burnetii_ is highly resistant to drying, heat, and many common disinfectants, which is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of a biphasic developmental cycle. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nAlthough often asymptomatic, the infection can present acutely 2-3 weeks after exposure as atypical pneumonia or hepatitis or as a chronic disease (mainly endocarditis) (Maurin M, Raoult D. Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev. 1999; 12(4): 518-53; available at http://cmr.asm.org/content/12/4/518.short.) Unusual complications include glomerulonephritis and rhabdomyolysis (http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/08860220701460178).\n\nDiagnosis of Q fever can usually be confirmed by serology (https://emergency.cdc.gov/agent/qfever/clinicians/diagnosis.asp). In acute Q fever, phase II antibodies are usually much higher than phase I antibodies and are detectable by indirect immunofluorescence 2 to 3 weeks after onset of illness. In chronic Q fever, phase I antibody titers are much greater than phase II titers. Phase I antibody titers of 1:800 or higher are considered diagnostic in endocarditis patients for chronic Q fever.\n\nThe tetracyclines are considered the antibiotics of choice for treatment of acute Q fever. A human vaccine for Q fever is used in Australia, but it is not available in the United States. - Mod.ML]\n\n[More information on this observed increase in Q fever in Israel including demographics, geographic distribution, and potential high risk exposures would be greatly appreciated. - Israel 20050814.2378\n.................................................mpp/ml/mj/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2017-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2005-03-16 00:00:00", "1984-03-16 00:00:00", "1988-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2016-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4974554", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Germany: (RP) sheep cell therapy, 2014", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4974554", "date": "2015-07-17 11:38:26", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA: (NEW SOUTH WALES)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Jul 2015\nSource: The Guyra Argus [edited]\nhttp://www.guyraargus.com.au/story/3213909/hot-spot-for-q-fever/\n\n\nGuyra [New South Wales] has been identified as a hotspot for Q fever, with as much as 22 percent of the population showing exposure to the disease. The statistic was revealed on last week's [week of 6 Jul 2015] episode of the ABC program Landline [http://www.abc.net.au/landline/content/2015/s4271952.htm]. Federal Health Minister Sussan Ley has promised to keep a \"watching brief\" on the incidence of Q fever -- an infectious disease passed from animals to humans -- as dry conditions provide an ideal environment for the airborne organism to spread.\n\nQ fever can be passed on from almost any animal, but is mostly spread by goats, sheep, and cattle. The early symptoms resemble the flu and include high temperature, sweating, and body aches and pains. If caught early, it can be treated with antibiotics. But it has become increasingly clear that 20 to 25 per cent of cases do not fully recover, with sufferers going on to develop long-term chronic fatigue.\n\nApproximately 2 per cent of people who contract the disease end up with a life-threatening failure of their heart valves, and a small percentage die from the disease.\n\nQ fever -- the Q standing for Query -- is an international disease, identified in almost every country except New Zealand, but Australia is the only place that has an effective vaccine. Classed as a notifiable disease, just under 500 Australian cases are registered each year, almost half of them in Queensland.\n\nThe Q-vax vaccine was introduced to abattoir workers in the early 1990s and resulted in a halving of the number of Q fever cases nationally. A federally funded vaccination campaign targeting sheep, cattle, and dairy farmers was rolled out from 2001-2005, again with a dramatic drop in notifications.\n\nWith case numbers edging up slightly in the past 2 years, and a lack of awareness of the disease even in rural areas where it is most prevalent, there have been calls for another subsidised vaccination campaign. But Ms Ley said she would not agree to another vaccination campaign \"at this stage\".\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/47001. Guyra, a town with a population of almost 2000 people in 2011, the seat of Guyra Shire, with a population of 4397 people in 2011, is located at an elevation of 1330 m (4364 ft) above sea level on the Northern Tablelands in the New England region of New South Wales, Australia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guyra,_New_South_Wales). The New England region is about 60 km (37 mi) inland from the Pacific Coast. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people make up 10 per cent of the population of Guyra Shire.\n\n_Coxiella burnetii_, an obligate intracellular rickettsia-like bacterial pathogen causes Q fever. Q fever is primarily an occupational hazard for farmers, veterinarians, and abattoir workers in contact with infected domestic animals such as cattle, sheep, and goats, which serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. Humans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms that are shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products of infected animals; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nQ fever spreads easily in agricultural regions via airborne particles containing the _C. burnetii_ for a considerable distances to involve people living downwind from infected livestock. Widespread transmission of Q fever was recently documented in the Netherlands downwind from the index farm from a single dairy-goat farm, even beyond a 5 km (3 mi) high-risk zone (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/55/12/1591.long#T2). _C. burnetii_ is highly resistant to drying, heat, and many common disinfectants, which is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of a biphasic developmental cycle. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nGuyra was home to a large regional abattoir that employed up to 350 staff until it closed in 1995; the abattoir building now houses an angora rabbit breeding establishment (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guyra,_New_South_Wales). The principal industries include wool, lambs, and beef cattle, which may explain why Guyra is a \"hot-spot\" for Q fever.\n\nIn Australia, Q fever vaccination is recommended for those working in \"at-risk\" occupations such as abattoir workers, farmers, stockyard workers, shearers, animal transporters, and others exposed to cattle, camels, sheep, goats, and kangaroos or their products (including products of conception), veterinarians, veterinary nurses, veterinary students, professional dog and cat breeders, agricultural college staff and students, wildlife and zoo workers (working with high-risk animals), and laboratory personnel handling veterinary specimens or working with the organism; workers at pig abattoirs do not require Q fever vaccination (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/Handbook10-home~handbook10part4~handbook10-4-15).\n\nIf the person has a positive history of previous infection with Q fever, vaccination is contraindicated; in others, serum antibody determination and skin tests must be done before vaccination to exclude those likely to have severe local or systemic hypersensitivity reactions to the vaccine resulting from previous unrecognized exposure to the organism (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/Handbook10-home~handbook10part4~handbook10-4-15). Q fever vaccine is not routinely recommended for children aged less than 15 years of age and pregnant or breastfeeding women because safety of the vaccine in these situations has not been established. Revaccination is not indicated due to the possibility of severe hypersensitivity reactions. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nQ fever - USA (02): (OR) vaccination, comment 20140728.2641341\nQ fever - USA: (OR) 20140726.2636921\n2013\n----\nQ fever - Hungary: (BA) RFI 20130607.1760537\nQ fever - Spain: (AN) 20130503.1689392\n2012\n----\nQ fever - Serbia: (VO) 20120413.1100615\n2011\n----\nQ fever - Australia (05): (QL) 20111125.3447\nQ fever - Australia (04): (QL) 20111124.3434\nQ fever - Australia (03): duration of vaccine protection 20110404.1047\nQ fever - Australia (02): background 20110403.1029\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) 20110401.1005\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Australia: (SA), laboratory-acquired 20091225.4345\n2007\n----\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - Australia (SA)(03): fatality 20070730.2449\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (02): abattoir 20070713.2244\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\n2001\n----\nQ fever - Australia: background (02) 20010202.0224\nQ fever - Australia: background 20010131.0213\nQ fever - Australia (Queensland) 20010129.0204\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4735189", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Australia (03): (SA) spike in disease", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4735189", "date": "2015-07-17 11:38:26", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA: (NEW SOUTH WALES)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Jul 2015\nSource: The Guyra Argus [edited]\nhttp://www.guyraargus.com.au/story/3213909/hot-spot-for-q-fever/\n\n\nGuyra [New South Wales] has been identified as a hotspot for Q fever, with as much as 22 percent of the population showing exposure to the disease. The statistic was revealed on last week's [week of 6 Jul 2015] episode of the ABC program Landline [http://www.abc.net.au/landline/content/2015/s4271952.htm]. Federal Health Minister Sussan Ley has promised to keep a \"watching brief\" on the incidence of Q fever -- an infectious disease passed from animals to humans -- as dry conditions provide an ideal environment for the airborne organism to spread.\n\nQ fever can be passed on from almost any animal, but is mostly spread by goats, sheep, and cattle. The early symptoms resemble the flu and include high temperature, sweating, and body aches and pains. If caught early, it can be treated with antibiotics. But it has become increasingly clear that 20 to 25 per cent of cases do not fully recover, with sufferers going on to develop long-term chronic fatigue.\n\nApproximately 2 per cent of people who contract the disease end up with a life-threatening failure of their heart valves, and a small percentage die from the disease.\n\nQ fever -- the Q standing for Query -- is an international disease, identified in almost every country except New Zealand, but Australia is the only place that has an effective vaccine. Classed as a notifiable disease, just under 500 Australian cases are registered each year, almost half of them in Queensland.\n\nThe Q-vax vaccine was introduced to abattoir workers in the early 1990s and resulted in a halving of the number of Q fever cases nationally. A federally funded vaccination campaign targeting sheep, cattle, and dairy farmers was rolled out from 2001-2005, again with a dramatic drop in notifications.\n\nWith case numbers edging up slightly in the past 2 years, and a lack of awareness of the disease even in rural areas where it is most prevalent, there have been calls for another subsidised vaccination campaign. But Ms Ley said she would not agree to another vaccination campaign \"at this stage\".\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/47001. Guyra, a town with a population of almost 2000 people in 2011, the seat of Guyra Shire, with a population of 4397 people in 2011, is located at an elevation of 1330 m (4364 ft) above sea level on the Northern Tablelands in the New England region of New South Wales, Australia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guyra,_New_South_Wales). The New England region is about 60 km (37 mi) inland from the Pacific Coast. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people make up 10 per cent of the population of Guyra Shire.\n\n_Coxiella burnetii_, an obligate intracellular rickettsia-like bacterial pathogen causes Q fever. Q fever is primarily an occupational hazard for farmers, veterinarians, and abattoir workers in contact with infected domestic animals such as cattle, sheep, and goats, which serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. Humans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms that are shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products of infected animals; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nQ fever spreads easily in agricultural regions via airborne particles containing the _C. burnetii_ for a considerable distances to involve people living downwind from infected livestock. Widespread transmission of Q fever was recently documented in the Netherlands downwind from the index farm from a single dairy-goat farm, even beyond a 5 km (3 mi) high-risk zone (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/55/12/1591.long#T2). _C. burnetii_ is highly resistant to drying, heat, and many common disinfectants, which is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of a biphasic developmental cycle. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nGuyra was home to a large regional abattoir that employed up to 350 staff until it closed in 1995; the abattoir building now houses an angora rabbit breeding establishment (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guyra,_New_South_Wales). The principal industries include wool, lambs, and beef cattle, which may explain why Guyra is a \"hot-spot\" for Q fever.\n\nIn Australia, Q fever vaccination is recommended for those working in \"at-risk\" occupations such as abattoir workers, farmers, stockyard workers, shearers, animal transporters, and others exposed to cattle, camels, sheep, goats, and kangaroos or their products (including products of conception), veterinarians, veterinary nurses, veterinary students, professional dog and cat breeders, agricultural college staff and students, wildlife and zoo workers (working with high-risk animals), and laboratory personnel handling veterinary specimens or working with the organism; workers at pig abattoirs do not require Q fever vaccination (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/Handbook10-home~handbook10part4~handbook10-4-15).\n\nIf the person has a positive history of previous infection with Q fever, vaccination is contraindicated; in others, serum antibody determination and skin tests must be done before vaccination to exclude those likely to have severe local or systemic hypersensitivity reactions to the vaccine resulting from previous unrecognized exposure to the organism (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/Handbook10-home~handbook10part4~handbook10-4-15). Q fever vaccine is not routinely recommended for children aged less than 15 years of age and pregnant or breastfeeding women because safety of the vaccine in these situations has not been established. Revaccination is not indicated due to the possibility of severe hypersensitivity reactions. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nQ fever - USA (02): (OR) vaccination, comment 20140728.2641341\nQ fever - USA: (OR) 20140726.2636921\n2013\n----\nQ fever - Hungary: (BA) RFI 20130607.1760537\nQ fever - Spain: (AN) 20130503.1689392\n2012\n----\nQ fever - Serbia: (VO) 20120413.1100615\n2011\n----\nQ fever - Australia (05): (QL) 20111125.3447\nQ fever - Australia (04): (QL) 20111124.3434\nQ fever - Australia (03): duration of vaccine protection 20110404.1047\nQ fever - Australia (02): background 20110403.1029\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) 20110401.1005\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Australia: (SA), laboratory-acquired 20091225.4345\n2007\n----\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - Australia (SA)(03): fatality 20070730.2449\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (02): abattoir 20070713.2244\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\n2001\n----\nQ fever - Australia: background (02) 20010202.0224\nQ fever - Australia: background 20010131.0213\nQ fever - Australia (Queensland) 20010129.0204\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4437074", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Australia (02): (VI) meat processing workers", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4437074", "date": "2015-07-17 11:38:26", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA: (NEW SOUTH WALES)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Jul 2015\nSource: The Guyra Argus [edited]\nhttp://www.guyraargus.com.au/story/3213909/hot-spot-for-q-fever/\n\n\nGuyra [New South Wales] has been identified as a hotspot for Q fever, with as much as 22 percent of the population showing exposure to the disease. The statistic was revealed on last week's [week of 6 Jul 2015] episode of the ABC program Landline [http://www.abc.net.au/landline/content/2015/s4271952.htm]. Federal Health Minister Sussan Ley has promised to keep a \"watching brief\" on the incidence of Q fever -- an infectious disease passed from animals to humans -- as dry conditions provide an ideal environment for the airborne organism to spread.\n\nQ fever can be passed on from almost any animal, but is mostly spread by goats, sheep, and cattle. The early symptoms resemble the flu and include high temperature, sweating, and body aches and pains. If caught early, it can be treated with antibiotics. But it has become increasingly clear that 20 to 25 per cent of cases do not fully recover, with sufferers going on to develop long-term chronic fatigue.\n\nApproximately 2 per cent of people who contract the disease end up with a life-threatening failure of their heart valves, and a small percentage die from the disease.\n\nQ fever -- the Q standing for Query -- is an international disease, identified in almost every country except New Zealand, but Australia is the only place that has an effective vaccine. Classed as a notifiable disease, just under 500 Australian cases are registered each year, almost half of them in Queensland.\n\nThe Q-vax vaccine was introduced to abattoir workers in the early 1990s and resulted in a halving of the number of Q fever cases nationally. A federally funded vaccination campaign targeting sheep, cattle, and dairy farmers was rolled out from 2001-2005, again with a dramatic drop in notifications.\n\nWith case numbers edging up slightly in the past 2 years, and a lack of awareness of the disease even in rural areas where it is most prevalent, there have been calls for another subsidised vaccination campaign. But Ms Ley said she would not agree to another vaccination campaign \"at this stage\".\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/47001. Guyra, a town with a population of almost 2000 people in 2011, the seat of Guyra Shire, with a population of 4397 people in 2011, is located at an elevation of 1330 m (4364 ft) above sea level on the Northern Tablelands in the New England region of New South Wales, Australia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guyra,_New_South_Wales). The New England region is about 60 km (37 mi) inland from the Pacific Coast. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people make up 10 per cent of the population of Guyra Shire.\n\n_Coxiella burnetii_, an obligate intracellular rickettsia-like bacterial pathogen causes Q fever. Q fever is primarily an occupational hazard for farmers, veterinarians, and abattoir workers in contact with infected domestic animals such as cattle, sheep, and goats, which serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. Humans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms that are shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products of infected animals; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nQ fever spreads easily in agricultural regions via airborne particles containing the _C. burnetii_ for a considerable distances to involve people living downwind from infected livestock. Widespread transmission of Q fever was recently documented in the Netherlands downwind from the index farm from a single dairy-goat farm, even beyond a 5 km (3 mi) high-risk zone (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/55/12/1591.long#T2). _C. burnetii_ is highly resistant to drying, heat, and many common disinfectants, which is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of a biphasic developmental cycle. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nGuyra was home to a large regional abattoir that employed up to 350 staff until it closed in 1995; the abattoir building now houses an angora rabbit breeding establishment (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guyra,_New_South_Wales). The principal industries include wool, lambs, and beef cattle, which may explain why Guyra is a \"hot-spot\" for Q fever.\n\nIn Australia, Q fever vaccination is recommended for those working in \"at-risk\" occupations such as abattoir workers, farmers, stockyard workers, shearers, animal transporters, and others exposed to cattle, camels, sheep, goats, and kangaroos or their products (including products of conception), veterinarians, veterinary nurses, veterinary students, professional dog and cat breeders, agricultural college staff and students, wildlife and zoo workers (working with high-risk animals), and laboratory personnel handling veterinary specimens or working with the organism; workers at pig abattoirs do not require Q fever vaccination (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/Handbook10-home~handbook10part4~handbook10-4-15).\n\nIf the person has a positive history of previous infection with Q fever, vaccination is contraindicated; in others, serum antibody determination and skin tests must be done before vaccination to exclude those likely to have severe local or systemic hypersensitivity reactions to the vaccine resulting from previous unrecognized exposure to the organism (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/Handbook10-home~handbook10part4~handbook10-4-15). Q fever vaccine is not routinely recommended for children aged less than 15 years of age and pregnant or breastfeeding women because safety of the vaccine in these situations has not been established. Revaccination is not indicated due to the possibility of severe hypersensitivity reactions. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nQ fever - USA (02): (OR) vaccination, comment 20140728.2641341\nQ fever - USA: (OR) 20140726.2636921\n2013\n----\nQ fever - Hungary: (BA) RFI 20130607.1760537\nQ fever - Spain: (AN) 20130503.1689392\n2012\n----\nQ fever - Serbia: (VO) 20120413.1100615\n2011\n----\nQ fever - Australia (05): (QL) 20111125.3447\nQ fever - Australia (04): (QL) 20111124.3434\nQ fever - Australia (03): duration of vaccine protection 20110404.1047\nQ fever - Australia (02): background 20110403.1029\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) 20110401.1005\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Australia: (SA), laboratory-acquired 20091225.4345\n2007\n----\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - Australia (SA)(03): fatality 20070730.2449\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (02): abattoir 20070713.2244\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. The statistic was revealed on last week's [week of 6 Jul 2015] episode of the ABC program Landline [http://www.abc.net.au/landline/content/2015/s4271952.htm]. Federal Health Minister Sussan Ley has promised to keep a \"watching brief\" on the incidence of Q fever -- an infectious disease passed from animals to humans -- as dry conditions provide an ideal environment for the airborne organism to spread.\n\nQ fever can be passed on from almost any animal, but is mostly spread by goats, sheep, and cattle. The early symptoms resemble the flu and include high temperature, sweating, and body aches and pains. If caught early, it can be treated with antibiotics. But it has become increasingly clear that 20 to 25 per cent of cases do not fully recover, with sufferers going on to develop long-term chronic fatigue.\n\nApproximately 2 per cent of people who contract the disease end up with a life-threatening failure of their heart valves, and a small percentage die from the disease.\n\nQ fever -- the Q standing for Query -- is an international disease, identified in almost every country except New Zealand, but Australia is the only place that has an effective vaccine. Classed as a notifiable disease, just under 500 Australian cases are registered each year, almost half of them in Queensland.\n\nThe Q-vax vaccine was introduced to abattoir workers in the early 1990s and resulted in a halving of the number of Q fever cases nationally. But Ms Ley said she would not agree to another vaccination campaign \"at this stage\".\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/47001. Guyra, a town with a population of almost 2000 people in 2011, the seat of Guyra Shire, with a population of 4397 people in 2011, is located at an elevation of 1330 m (4364 ft) above sea level on the Northern Tablelands in the New England region of New South Wales, Australia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guyra,_New_South_Wales). The New England region is about 60 km (37 mi) inland from the Pacific Coast. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people make up 10 per cent of the population of Guyra Shire.\n\n_Coxiella burnetii_, an obligate intracellular rickettsia-like bacterial pathogen causes Q fever. Q fever is primarily an occupational hazard for farmers, veterinarians, and abattoir workers in contact with infected domestic animals such as cattle, sheep, and goats, which serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. Humans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms that are shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products of infected animals; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nQ fever spreads easily in agricultural regions via airborne particles containing the _C. burnetii_ for a considerable distances to involve people living downwind from infected livestock. Widespread transmission of Q fever was recently documented in the Netherlands downwind from the index farm from a single dairy-goat farm, even beyond a 5 km (3 mi) high-risk zone (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/55/12/1591.long#T2). _C. burnetii_ is highly resistant to drying, heat, and many common disinfectants, which is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of a biphasic developmental cycle. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nGuyra was home to a large regional abattoir that employed up to 350 staff until it closed in 1995; the abattoir building now houses an angora rabbit breeding establishment (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guyra,_New_South_Wales). The principal industries include wool, lambs, and beef cattle, which may explain why Guyra is a \"hot-spot\" for Q fever.\n\nIn Australia, Q fever vaccination is recommended for those working in \"at-risk\" occupations such as abattoir workers, farmers, stockyard workers, shearers, animal transporters, and others exposed to cattle, camels, sheep, goats, and kangaroos or their products (including products of conception), veterinarians, veterinary nurses, veterinary students, professional dog and cat breeders, agricultural college staff and students, wildlife and zoo workers (working with high-risk animals), and laboratory personnel handling veterinary specimens or working with the organism; workers at pig abattoirs do not require Q fever vaccination (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/Handbook10-home~handbook10part4~handbook10-4-15).\n\nIf the person has a positive history of previous infection with Q fever, vaccination is contraindicated; in others, serum antibody determination and skin tests must be done before vaccination to exclude those likely to have severe local or systemic hypersensitivity reactions to the vaccine resulting from previous unrecognized exposure to the organism (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/Handbook10-home~handbook10part4~handbook10-4-15). Q fever vaccine is not routinely recommended for children aged less than 15 years of age and pregnant or breastfeeding women because safety of the vaccine in these situations has not been established. Revaccination is not indicated due to the possibility of severe hypersensitivity reactions. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nQ fever - USA (02): (OR) vaccination, comment 20140728.2641341\nQ fever - USA: (OR) 20140726.2636921\n2013\n----\nQ fever - Hungary: (BA) RFI 20130607.1760537\nQ fever - Spain: (AN) 20130503.1689392\n2012\n----\nQ fever - Serbia: (VO) 20120413.1100615\n2011\n----\nQ fever - Australia (05): (QL) 20111125.3447\nQ fever - Australia (04): (QL) 20111124.3434\nQ fever - Australia (03): duration of vaccine protection 20110404.1047\nQ fever - Australia (02): background 20110403.1029\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) 20110401.1005\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Australia: (SA), laboratory-acquired 20091225.4345\n2007\n----\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - Australia (SA)(03): fatality 20070730.2449\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (02): abattoir 20070713.2244\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. The statistic was revealed on last week's [week of 6 Jul 2015] episode of the ABC program Landline [http://www.abc.net.au/landline/content/2015/s4271952.htm]. Federal Health Minister Sussan Ley has promised to keep a \"watching brief\" on the incidence of Q fever -- an infectious disease passed from animals to humans -- as dry conditions provide an ideal environment for the airborne organism to spread.\n\nQ fever can be passed on from almost any animal, but is mostly spread by goats, sheep, and cattle. The early symptoms resemble the flu and include high temperature, sweating, and body aches and pains. If caught early, it can be treated with antibiotics. But it has become increasingly clear that 20 to 25 per cent of cases do not fully recover, with sufferers going on to develop long-term chronic fatigue.\n\nApproximately 2 per cent of people who contract the disease end up with a life-threatening failure of their heart valves, and a small percentage die from the disease.\n\nQ fever -- the Q standing for Query -- is an international disease, identified in almost every country except New Zealand, but Australia is the only place that has an effective vaccine. Classed as a notifiable disease, just under 500 Australian cases are registered each year, almost half of them in Queensland.\n\nThe Q-vax vaccine was introduced to abattoir workers in the early 1990s and resulted in a halving of the number of Q fever cases nationally. A federally funded vaccination campaign targeting sheep, cattle, and dairy farmers was rolled out from 2001-2005, again with a dramatic drop in notifications.\n\nWith case numbers edging up slightly in the past 2 years, and a lack of awareness of the disease even in rural areas where it is most prevalent, there have been calls for another subsidised vaccination campaign. But Ms Ley said she would not agree to another vaccination campaign \"at this stage\".\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/47001. Guyra, a town with a population of almost 2000 people in 2011, the seat of Guyra Shire, with a population of 4397 people in 2011, is located at an elevation of 1330 m (4364 ft) above sea level on the Northern Tablelands in the New England region of New South Wales, Australia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guyra,_New_South_Wales). The New England region is about 60 km (37 mi) inland from the Pacific Coast. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people make up 10 per cent of the population of Guyra Shire.\n\n_Coxiella burnetii_, an obligate intracellular rickettsia-like bacterial pathogen causes Q fever. Q fever is primarily an occupational hazard for farmers, veterinarians, and abattoir workers in contact with infected domestic animals such as cattle, sheep, and goats, which serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. Humans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms that are shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products of infected animals; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nQ fever spreads easily in agricultural regions via airborne particles containing the _C. burnetii_ for a considerable distances to involve people living downwind from infected livestock. Widespread transmission of Q fever was recently documented in the Netherlands downwind from the index farm from a single dairy-goat farm, even beyond a 5 km (3 mi) high-risk zone (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/55/12/1591.long#T2). _C. burnetii_ is highly resistant to drying, heat, and many common disinfectants, which is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of a biphasic developmental cycle. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nGuyra was home to a large regional abattoir that employed up to 350 staff until it closed in 1995; the abattoir building now houses an angora rabbit breeding establishment (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guyra,_New_South_Wales). The principal industries include wool, lambs, and beef cattle, which may explain why Guyra is a \"hot-spot\" for Q fever.\n\nIn Australia, Q fever vaccination is recommended for those working in \"at-risk\" occupations such as abattoir workers, farmers, stockyard workers, shearers, animal transporters, and others exposed to cattle, camels, sheep, goats, and kangaroos or their products (including products of conception), veterinarians, veterinary nurses, veterinary students, professional dog and cat breeders, agricultural college staff and students, wildlife and zoo workers (working with high-risk animals), and laboratory personnel handling veterinary specimens or working with the organism; workers at pig abattoirs do not require Q fever vaccination (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/Handbook10-home~handbook10part4~handbook10-4-15).\n\nIf the person has a positive history of previous infection with Q fever, vaccination is contraindicated; in others, serum antibody determination and skin tests must be done before vaccination to exclude those likely to have severe local or systemic hypersensitivity reactions to the vaccine resulting from previous unrecognized exposure to the organism (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/Handbook10-home~handbook10part4~handbook10-4-15). Q fever vaccine is not routinely recommended for children aged less than 15 years of age and pregnant or breastfeeding women because safety of the vaccine in these situations has not been established. Revaccination is not indicated due to the possibility of severe hypersensitivity reactions. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nQ fever - USA (02): (OR) vaccination, comment 20140728.2641341\nQ fever - USA: (OR) 20140726.2636921\n2013\n----\nQ fever - Hungary: (BA) RFI 20130607.1760537\nQ fever - Spain: (AN) 20130503.1689392\n2012\n----\nQ fever - Serbia: (VO) 20120413.1100615\n2011\n----\nQ fever - Australia (05): (QL) 20111125.3447\nQ fever - Australia (04): (QL) 20111124.3434\nQ fever - Australia (03): duration of vaccine protection 20110404.1047\nQ fever - Australia (02): background 20110403.1029\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) 20110401.1005\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Australia: (SA), laboratory-acquired 20091225.4345\n2007\n----\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - Australia (SA)(03): fatality 20070730.2449\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (02): abattoir 20070713.2244\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\n2001\n----\nQ fever - Australia: background (02) 20010202.0224\nQ fever - Australia: background 20010131.0213\nQ fever - Australia (Queensland) 20010129.0204\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3726962", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Australia (02): (VI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3726962", "date": "2015-07-17 11:38:26", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA: (NEW SOUTH WALES)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Jul 2015\nSource: The Guyra Argus [edited]\nhttp://www.guyraargus.com.au/story/3213909/hot-spot-for-q-fever/\n\n\nGuyra [New South Wales] has been identified as a hotspot for Q fever, with as much as 22 percent of the population showing exposure to the disease. The statistic was revealed on last week's [week of 6 Jul 2015] episode of the ABC program Landline [http://www.abc.net.au/landline/content/2015/s4271952.htm]. Federal Health Minister Sussan Ley has promised to keep a \"watching brief\" on the incidence of Q fever -- an infectious disease passed from animals to humans -- as dry conditions provide an ideal environment for the airborne organism to spread.\n\nQ fever can be passed on from almost any animal, but is mostly spread by goats, sheep, and cattle. The early symptoms resemble the flu and include high temperature, sweating, and body aches and pains. If caught early, it can be treated with antibiotics. But it has become increasingly clear that 20 to 25 per cent of cases do not fully recover, with sufferers going on to develop long-term chronic fatigue.\n\nApproximately 2 per cent of people who contract the disease end up with a life-threatening failure of their heart valves, and a small percentage die from the disease.\n\nQ fever -- the Q standing for Query -- is an international disease, identified in almost every country except New Zealand, but Australia is the only place that has an effective vaccine. Classed as a notifiable disease, just under 500 Australian cases are registered each year, almost half of them in Queensland.\n\nThe Q-vax vaccine was introduced to abattoir workers in the early 1990s and resulted in a halving of the number of Q fever cases nationally. A federally funded vaccination campaign targeting sheep, cattle, and dairy farmers was rolled out from 2001-2005, again with a dramatic drop in notifications.\n\nWith case numbers edging up slightly in the past 2 years, and a lack of awareness of the disease even in rural areas where it is most prevalent, there have been calls for another subsidised vaccination campaign. But Ms Ley said she would not agree to another vaccination campaign \"at this stage\".\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/47001. Guyra, a town with a population of almost 2000 people in 2011, the seat of Guyra Shire, with a population of 4397 people in 2011, is located at an elevation of 1330 m (4364 ft) above sea level on the Northern Tablelands in the New England region of New South Wales, Australia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guyra,_New_South_Wales). The New England region is about 60 km (37 mi) inland from the Pacific Coast. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people make up 10 per cent of the population of Guyra Shire.\n\n_Coxiella burnetii_, an obligate intracellular rickettsia-like bacterial pathogen causes Q fever. Q fever is primarily an occupational hazard for farmers, veterinarians, and abattoir workers in contact with infected domestic animals such as cattle, sheep, and goats, which serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. Humans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms that are shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products of infected animals; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nQ fever spreads easily in agricultural regions via airborne particles containing the _C. burnetii_ for a considerable distances to involve people living downwind from infected livestock. Widespread transmission of Q fever was recently documented in the Netherlands downwind from the index farm from a single dairy-goat farm, even beyond a 5 km (3 mi) high-risk zone (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/55/12/1591.long#T2). _C. burnetii_ is highly resistant to drying, heat, and many common disinfectants, which is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of a biphasic developmental cycle. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nGuyra was home to a large regional abattoir that employed up to 350 staff until it closed in 1995; the abattoir building now houses an angora rabbit breeding establishment (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guyra,_New_South_Wales). The principal industries include wool, lambs, and beef cattle, which may explain why Guyra is a \"hot-spot\" for Q fever.\n\nIn Australia, Q fever vaccination is recommended for those working in \"at-risk\" occupations such as abattoir workers, farmers, stockyard workers, shearers, animal transporters, and others exposed to cattle, camels, sheep, goats, and kangaroos or their products (including products of conception), veterinarians, veterinary nurses, veterinary students, professional dog and cat breeders, agricultural college staff and students, wildlife and zoo workers (working with high-risk animals), and laboratory personnel handling veterinary specimens or working with the organism; workers at pig abattoirs do not require Q fever vaccination (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/Handbook10-home~handbook10part4~handbook10-4-15).\n\nIf the person has a positive history of previous infection with Q fever, vaccination is contraindicated; in others, serum antibody determination and skin tests must be done before vaccination to exclude those likely to have severe local or systemic hypersensitivity reactions to the vaccine resulting from previous unrecognized exposure to the organism (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/Handbook10-home~handbook10part4~handbook10-4-15). Q fever vaccine is not routinely recommended for children aged less than 15 years of age and pregnant or breastfeeding women because safety of the vaccine in these situations has not been established. Revaccination is not indicated due to the possibility of severe hypersensitivity reactions. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nQ fever - USA (02): (OR) vaccination, comment 20140728.2641341\nQ fever - USA: (OR) 20140726.2636921\n2013\n----\nQ fever - Hungary: (BA) RFI 20130607.1760537\nQ fever - Spain: (AN) 20130503.1689392\n2012\n----\nQ fever - Serbia: (VO) 20120413.1100615\n2011\n----\nQ fever - Australia (05): (QL) 20111125.3447\nQ fever - Australia (04): (QL) 20111124.3434\nQ fever - Australia (03): duration of vaccine protection 20110404.1047\nQ fever - Australia (02): background 20110403.1029\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) 20110401.1005\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Australia: (SA), laboratory-acquired 20091225.4345\n2007\n----\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - Australia (SA)(03): fatality 20070730.2449\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (02): abattoir 20070713.2244\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\n2001\n----\nQ fever - Australia: background (02) 20010202.0224\nQ fever - Australia: background 20010131.0213\nQ fever - Australia (Queensland) 20010129.0204\n.................................................sb/ml/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "1995-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3684869", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - USA, Canada: ex Germany (RP) sheep cell therapy, 2014", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3684869", "date": "2015-07-17 11:38:26", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA: (NEW SOUTH WALES)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Jul 2015\nSource: The Guyra Argus [edited]\nhttp://www.guyraargus.com.au/story/3213909/hot-spot-for-q-fever/\n\n\nGuyra [New South Wales] has been identified as a hotspot for Q fever, with as much as 22 percent of the population showing exposure to the disease. The statistic was revealed on last week's [week of 6 Jul 2015] episode of the ABC program Landline [http://www.abc.net.au/landline/content/2015/s4271952.htm]. Federal Health Minister Sussan Ley has promised to keep a \"watching brief\" on the incidence of Q fever -- an infectious disease passed from animals to humans -- as dry conditions provide an ideal environment for the airborne organism to spread.\n\nQ fever can be passed on from almost any animal, but is mostly spread by goats, sheep, and cattle. The early symptoms resemble the flu and include high temperature, sweating, and body aches and pains. If caught early, it can be treated with antibiotics. But it has become increasingly clear that 20 to 25 per cent of cases do not fully recover, with sufferers going on to develop long-term chronic fatigue.\n\nApproximately 2 per cent of people who contract the disease end up with a life-threatening failure of their heart valves, and a small percentage die from the disease.\n\nQ fever -- the Q standing for Query -- is an international disease, identified in almost every country except New Zealand, but Australia is the only place that has an effective vaccine. Classed as a notifiable disease, just under 500 Australian cases are registered each year, almost half of them in Queensland.\n\nThe Q-vax vaccine was introduced to abattoir workers in the early 1990s and resulted in a halving of the number of Q fever cases nationally. A federally funded vaccination campaign targeting sheep, cattle, and dairy farmers was rolled out from 2001-2005, again with a dramatic drop in notifications.\n\nWith case numbers edging up slightly in the past 2 years, and a lack of awareness of the disease even in rural areas where it is most prevalent, there have been calls for another subsidised vaccination campaign. But Ms Ley said she would not agree to another vaccination campaign \"at this stage\".\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Maps of Australia can be seen at http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/47001. The New England region is about 60 km (37 mi) inland from the Pacific Coast. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people make up 10 per cent of the population of Guyra Shire.\n\n_Coxiella burnetii_, an obligate intracellular rickettsia-like bacterial pathogen causes Q fever. Q fever is primarily an occupational hazard for farmers, veterinarians, and abattoir workers in contact with infected domestic animals such as cattle, sheep, and goats, which serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. Humans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms that are shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products of infected animals; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nQ fever spreads easily in agricultural regions via airborne particles containing the _C. burnetii_ for a considerable distances to involve people living downwind from infected livestock. Widespread transmission of Q fever was recently documented in the Netherlands downwind from the index farm from a single dairy-goat farm, even beyond a 5 km (3 mi) high-risk zone (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/55/12/1591.long#T2). _C. burnetii_ is highly resistant to drying, heat, and many common disinfectants, which is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of a biphasic developmental cycle. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nGuyra was home to a large regional abattoir that employed up to 350 staff until it closed in 1995; the abattoir building now houses an angora rabbit breeding establishment (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guyra,_New_South_Wales). The principal industries include wool, lambs, and beef cattle, which may explain why Guyra is a \"hot-spot\" for Q fever.\n\nIn Australia, Q fever vaccination is recommended for those working in \"at-risk\" occupations such as abattoir workers, farmers, stockyard workers, shearers, animal transporters, and others exposed to cattle, camels, sheep, goats, and kangaroos or their products (including products of conception), veterinarians, veterinary nurses, veterinary students, professional dog and cat breeders, agricultural college staff and students, wildlife and zoo workers (working with high-risk animals), and laboratory personnel handling veterinary specimens or working with the organism; workers at pig abattoirs do not require Q fever vaccination (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/Handbook10-home~handbook10part4~handbook10-4-15).\n\nIf the person has a positive history of previous infection with Q fever, vaccination is contraindicated; in others, serum antibody determination and skin tests must be done before vaccination to exclude those likely to have severe local or systemic hypersensitivity reactions to the vaccine resulting from previous unrecognized exposure to the organism (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/Handbook10-home~handbook10part4~handbook10-4-15). Q fever vaccine is not routinely recommended for children aged less than 15 years of age and pregnant or breastfeeding women because safety of the vaccine in these situations has not been established. Guyra, a town with a population of almost 2000 people in 2011, the seat of Guyra Shire, with a population of 4397 people in 2011, is located at an elevation of 1330 m (4364 ft) above sea level on the Northern Tablelands in the New England region of New South Wales, Australia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guyra,_New_South_Wales). The New England region is about 60 km (37 mi) inland from the Pacific Coast. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people make up 10 per cent of the population of Guyra Shire.\n\n_Coxiella burnetii_, an obligate intracellular rickettsia-like bacterial pathogen causes Q fever. Q fever is primarily an occupational hazard for farmers, veterinarians, and abattoir workers in contact with infected domestic animals such as cattle, sheep, and goats, which serve as the reservoir of infection for humans. Humans usually become infected by inhaling aerosolized organisms that are shed in urine, feces, milk, and especially birthing products of infected animals; intermittent high-level shedding occurs at the time of parturition, with millions of bacteria being released per gram of placenta.\n\nQ fever spreads easily in agricultural regions via airborne particles containing the _C. burnetii_ for a considerable distances to involve people living downwind from infected livestock. Widespread transmission of Q fever was recently documented in the Netherlands downwind from the index farm from a single dairy-goat farm, even beyond a 5 km (3 mi) high-risk zone (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/55/12/1591.long#T2). _C. burnetii_ is highly resistant to drying, heat, and many common disinfectants, which is attributed to a small cell variant of the organism that is part of a biphasic developmental cycle. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nGuyra was home to a large regional abattoir that employed up to 350 staff until it closed in 1995; the abattoir building now houses an angora rabbit breeding establishment (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guyra,_New_South_Wales). The principal industries include wool, lambs, and beef cattle, which may explain why Guyra is a \"hot-spot\" for Q fever.\n\nIn Australia, Q fever vaccination is recommended for those working in \"at-risk\" occupations such as abattoir workers, farmers, stockyard workers, shearers, animal transporters, and others exposed to cattle, camels, sheep, goats, and kangaroos or their products (including products of conception), veterinarians, veterinary nurses, veterinary students, professional dog and cat breeders, agricultural college staff and students, wildlife and zoo workers (working with high-risk animals), and laboratory personnel handling veterinary specimens or working with the organism; workers at pig abattoirs do not require Q fever vaccination (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/Handbook10-home~handbook10part4~handbook10-4-15).\n\nIf the person has a positive history of previous infection with Q fever, vaccination is contraindicated; in others, serum antibody determination and skin tests must be done before vaccination to exclude those likely to have severe local or systemic hypersensitivity reactions to the vaccine resulting from previous unrecognized exposure to the organism (http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/internet/immunise/publishing.nsf/Content/Handbook10-home~handbook10part4~handbook10-4-15). Q fever vaccine is not routinely recommended for children aged less than 15 years of age and pregnant or breastfeeding women because safety of the vaccine in these situations has not been established. Revaccination is not indicated due to the possibility of severe hypersensitivity reactions. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nQ fever - USA (02): (OR) vaccination, comment 20140728.2641341\nQ fever - USA: (OR) 20140726.2636921\n2013\n----\nQ fever - Hungary: (BA) RFI 20130607.1760537\nQ fever - Spain: (AN) 20130503.1689392\n2012\n----\nQ fever - Serbia: (VO) 20120413.1100615\n2011\n----\nQ fever - Australia (05): (QL) 20111125.3447\nQ fever - Australia (04): (QL) 20111124.3434\nQ fever - Australia (03): duration of vaccine protection 20110404.1047\nQ fever - Australia (02): background 20110403.1029\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) 20110401.1005\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Australia: (SA), laboratory-acquired 20091225.4345\n2007\n----\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - Australia (SA)(03): fatality 20070730.2449\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (02): abattoir 20070713.2244\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S.
