27(26) OIE [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=15443\n\n\nQ fever, Korea (Rep. of)\n-------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 25 Jun 2014 from Dr TaeYung Kim, Director General, Livestock Policy Bureau, Ministry for Food, Agriculture, Forestry & Fisheries, Sejong-Si, Korea (Rep. of)\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 21 May 2014\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 21 May 2014\nReport date: 25 Jun 2014\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 16 Jul 2013\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Coxiella burnetti_\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (basic), Laboratory (advanced), Necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Imsil-eup, Imsil-gun, Jeollabuk-Do\nDate of start of the outbreak: 21 May 2014\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed /Slaughtered\nSheep/goats / 975 / 2 / 0 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: goats\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nSheep/goats / 0.21 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comment: Q fever positive (placenta and fetus)\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: control of arthropods; quarantine; movement control inside the country; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); vaccination prohibited; treatment of affected animals (antibiotics)\n\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nAnimal and Plant Quarantine Agency (National laboratory) / Sheep/goats / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 21 May 2014 / Positive\n\nFuture Reporting:\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the CDC Q fever webpage http://www.cdc.gov/qfever/:\n\"Q fever is a worldwide disease with acute and chronic stages caused by the bacteria _Coxiella burnetii_. Cattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs, although a variety of species may be infected. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals. During birthing, the organisms are shed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta. The organism is extremely hardy and resistant to heat, drying, and many common disinfectants, which enables the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected animals. Other modes of transmission to humans, including tick bites, ingestion of unpasteurized milk or dairy products, and human to human transmission, are rare. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very few organisms may be required to cause infection.\"\n\nQ fever is an important zoonosis, with veterinarians, laboratory workers, farmers and abattoir workers at risk. Surveys have shown that significant numbers of livestock handlers have antibodies, indicating exposure to the organism.\n\nLess than half of people infected become ill, and most infections are mild. But affected persons can develop a high fever with headache, muscle pains, sore throat, nausea and vomiting, chest and stomach pains. The fever can last for one or 2 weeks and lead to pneumonia or affect the liver. Treatment involves long term antibiotic therapy.\n\nIn a small percentage of cases, a chronic, severe debilitating disease occurs. People with suppressed immune systems and those with pre-existing heart valve problems are at risk of this complication, which is often fatal. There is also a post Q fever syndrome of chronic fatigue.\n\nQ fever is the 2nd most commonly reported laboratory infection, with several recorded outbreaks involving 15 or more persons http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Media_Center/docs/pdf/Disease_cards/Q-FEVER-EN.pdf.\n\nThe following information was obtained from a publication titled \"Epidemiological characteristics of serologically confirmed Q Fever cases in South Korea, 2006-2011.\" In the discussion it was noted that: \"This is the 1st official report on the characteristics of Q fever patients in Korea. The annual incidence of Q fever in Korea is much lower than that in France, Australia and Taiwan (0.02 vs. 2.5, 0.1, and 0.38 per 100 000 population, respectively). As the disease has a broad spectrum of clinical manifestations, from nonspecific febrile illness to neurological disorder, and there are no known outbreaks in Korea, it is difficult for physicians to diagnose Q fever without an increased awareness. Serological diagnostic testing is limited, because it is available at only one national laboratory. Therefore, Q fever is likely to be under-diagnosed and under-reported in Korea.\"\n\n\"According to national surveys of_ C. burnetti _ seroprevalence in the Korean population, the seropositivity rate of high-risk occupation groups, such as dairy farmers, slaughterhouse workers, and veterinarians, was 3.7-10.2 percent (data not shown). Q fever is not currently considered to be a significant threat to public health in Korea. Only sporadic cases have been reported to date, but there is a possibility of an epidemic. Therefore, increased awareness among physicians for better detection and treatment of Q fever, expansion of the diagnostic system, and further investigations for undiscovered risk factors, are persistently required.\"\n\nReference:\nKwak, Wooseok et al (2013) Epidemiological Characteristics of Serologically Confirmed Q Fever Cases in South Korea, 2006-2011. Osong Public Health and Research Perspectives, Volume 4 , Issue 1, 34-38 http://www.kcdc-phrp.org/article/S2210-9099(12)00102-6/fulltext or http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3747682/.\n\nThis immediate notification report does not mention what actions, if any, were taken to address the exposed human population. Such information may be of value in future follow-up reports, particularly given that the disease in humans is under-reported.\n\nAccording to information available in the OIE WAHID database, through June 2013, Q-fever was considered absent http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Countryinformation/Animalsituation. Therefore, any additional information on Q-fever in South Korea during the 2nd semester of 2013 would be of interest, especially with respect to the number and location of previous outbreaks, given that the last reported event occurred on 16 Jul 2013. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/195.]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Germany: (BY) human, animal 20140511.2464862\nQ fever - Spain: (PV) 20140409.2393194\n2013\n----\nQ fever - French Guiana: (CY) virulent genotype, alert 20130625.1790517\nQ fever - Brazil (02) (MG) NOT 20130619.1782145\nQ fever - Brazil: (MG) 20130617.1777459\nQ fever - Hungary: (BA) RFI 20130607.1760537\nQ fever - Spain (02): (AN) background 20130504.1691296\nQ fever - Spain: (AN) 20130503.1689392\nQ fever - Argentina: (CB) "unknown"}, {"location": "France", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Korea", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Sejong - Si", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2828583", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Canada: ex Germany, sheep cell therapy, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2828583", "date": "2014-06-26 20:09:44", "main_text": "Q FEVER- SOUTH KOREA: (JEOLLABUK-DO), ANIMAL, OIE\n*************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 25 Jun 2014\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2014; 27(26) OIE [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=15443\n\n\nQ fever, Korea (Rep. of)\n-------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 25 Jun 2014 from Dr TaeYung Kim, Director General, Livestock Policy Bureau, Ministry for Food, Agriculture, Forestry & Fisheries, Sejong-Si, Korea (Rep. of)\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 21 May 2014\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 21 May 2014\nReport date: 25 Jun 2014\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 16 Jul 2013\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Coxiella burnetti_\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (basic), Laboratory (advanced), Necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Imsil-eup, Imsil-gun, Jeollabuk-Do\nDate of start of the outbreak: 21 May 2014\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed /Slaughtered\nSheep/goats / 975 / 2 / 0 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: goats\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nSheep/goats / 0.21 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comment: Q fever positive (placenta and fetus)\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: control of arthropods; quarantine; movement control inside the country; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); vaccination prohibited; treatment of affected animals (antibiotics)\n\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nAnimal and Plant Quarantine Agency (National laboratory) / Sheep/goats / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 21 May 2014 / Positive\n\nFuture Reporting:\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the CDC Q fever webpage http://www.cdc.gov/qfever/:\n\"Q fever is a worldwide disease with acute and chronic stages caused by the bacteria _Coxiella burnetii_. Cattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs, although a variety of species may be infected. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals. During birthing, the organisms are shed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta. The organism is extremely hardy and resistant to heat, drying, and many common disinfectants, which enables the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected animals. Other modes of transmission to humans, including tick bites, ingestion of unpasteurized milk or dairy products, and human to human transmission, are rare. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very few organisms may be required to cause infection.\"\n\nQ fever is an important zoonosis, with veterinarians, laboratory workers, farmers and abattoir workers at risk. Surveys have shown that significant numbers of livestock handlers have antibodies, indicating exposure to the organism.\n\nLess than half of people infected become ill, and most infections are mild. But affected persons can develop a high fever with headache, muscle pains, sore throat, nausea and vomiting, chest and stomach pains. The fever can last for one or 2 weeks and lead to pneumonia or affect the liver. Treatment involves long term antibiotic therapy.\n\nIn a small percentage of cases, a chronic, severe debilitating disease occurs. People with suppressed immune systems and those with pre-existing heart valve problems are at risk of this complication, which is often fatal. There is also a post Q fever syndrome of chronic fatigue.\n\nQ fever is the 2nd most commonly reported laboratory infection, with several recorded outbreaks involving 15 or more persons http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Media_Center/docs/pdf/Disease_cards/Q-FEVER-EN.pdf.\n\nThe following information was obtained from a publication titled \"Epidemiological characteristics of serologically confirmed Q Fever cases in South Korea, 2006-2011.\" In the discussion it was noted that: \"This is the 1st official report on the characteristics of Q fever patients in Korea. The annual incidence of Q fever in Korea is much lower than that in France, Australia and Taiwan (0.02 vs. 2.5, 0.1, and 0.38 per 100 000 population, respectively). As the disease has a broad spectrum of clinical manifestations, from nonspecific febrile illness to neurological disorder, and there are no known outbreaks in Korea, it is difficult for physicians to diagnose Q fever without an increased awareness. Serological diagnostic testing is limited, because it is available at only one national laboratory. Therefore, Q fever is likely to be under-diagnosed and under-reported in Korea.\"\n\n\"According to national surveys of_ C. burnetti _ seroprevalence in the Korean population, the seropositivity rate of high-risk occupation groups, such as dairy farmers, slaughterhouse workers, and veterinarians, was 3.7-10.2 percent (data not shown). Q fever is not currently considered to be a significant threat to public health in Korea. Only sporadic cases have been reported to date, but there is a possibility of an epidemic. Therefore, increased awareness among physicians for better detection and treatment of Q fever, expansion of the diagnostic system, and further investigations for undiscovered risk factors, are persistently required.\"\n\nReference:\nKwak, Wooseok et al (2013) Epidemiological Characteristics of Serologically Confirmed Q Fever Cases in South Korea, 2006-2011. Osong Public Health and Research Perspectives, Volume 4 , Issue 1, 34-38 http://www.kcdc-phrp.org/article/S2210-9099(12)00102-6/fulltext or http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3747682/.\n\nThis immediate notification report does not mention what actions, if any, were taken to address the exposed human population. Such information may be of value in future follow-up reports, particularly given that the disease in humans is under-reported.\n\nAccording to information available in the OIE WAHID database, through June 2013, Q-fever was considered absent http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Countryinformation/Animalsituation. Therefore, any additional information on Q-fever in South Korea during the 2nd semester of 2013 would be of interest, especially with respect to the number and location of previous outbreaks, given that the last reported event occurred on 16 Jul 2013. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/195.]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Germany: (BY) human, animal 20140511.2464862\nQ fever - Spain: (PV) 20140409.2393194\n2013\n----\nQ fever - French Guiana: (CY) virulent genotype, alert 20130625.1790517\nQ fever - Brazil (02) (MG) NOT 20130619.1782145\nQ fever - Brazil: (MG) 20130617.1777459\nQ fever - Hungary: (BA) RFI 20130607.1760537\nQ fever - Spain (02): (AN) background 20130504.1691296\nQ fever - Spain: (AN) 20130503.1689392\nQ fever - Argentina: (CB) Cattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs, although a variety of species may be infected. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals. During birthing, the organisms are shed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta. The organism is extremely hardy and resistant to heat, drying, and many common disinfectants, which enables the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected animals. Cattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs, although a variety of species may be infected. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals. During birthing, the organisms are shed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta. The organism is extremely hardy and resistant to heat, drying, and many common disinfectants, which enables the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected animals. Other modes of transmission to humans, including tick bites, ingestion of unpasteurized milk or dairy products, and human to human transmission, are rare. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very few organisms may be required to cause infection.\"\n\nQ fever is an important zoonosis, with veterinarians, laboratory workers, farmers and abattoir workers at risk. Surveys have shown that significant numbers of livestock handlers have antibodies, indicating exposure to the organism.\n\nLess than half of people infected become ill, and most infections are mild. But affected persons can develop a high fever with headache, muscle pains, sore throat, nausea and vomiting, chest and stomach pains. The fever can last for one or 2 weeks and lead to pneumonia or affect the liver. Treatment involves long term antibiotic therapy.\n\nIn a small percentage of cases, a chronic, severe debilitating disease occurs. People with suppressed immune systems and those with pre-existing heart valve problems are at risk of this complication, which is often fatal. There is also a post Q fever syndrome of chronic fatigue.\n\nQ fever is the 2nd most commonly reported laboratory infection, with several recorded outbreaks involving 15 or more persons http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Media_Center/docs/pdf/Disease_cards/Q-FEVER-EN.pdf.\n\nThe following information was obtained from a publication titled \"Epidemiological characteristics of serologically confirmed Q Fever cases in South Korea, 2006-2011.\" In the discussion it was noted that: \"This is the 1st official report on the characteristics of Q fever patients in Korea. The annual incidence of Q fever in Korea is much lower than that in France, Australia and Taiwan (0.02 vs. 2.5, 0.1, and 0.38 per 100 000 population, respectively). As the disease has a broad spectrum of clinical manifestations, from nonspecific febrile illness to neurological disorder, and there are no known outbreaks in Korea, it is difficult for physicians to diagnose Q fever without an increased awareness. Serological diagnostic testing is limited, because it is available at only one national laboratory. Therefore, Q fever is likely to be under-diagnosed and under-reported in Korea.\"\n\n\"According to national surveys of_ C. burnetti _ seroprevalence in the Korean population, the seropositivity rate of high-risk occupation groups, such as dairy farmers, slaughterhouse workers, and veterinarians, was 3.7-10.2 percent (data not shown). Q fever is not currently considered to be a significant threat to public health in Korea. Only sporadic cases have been reported to date, but there is a possibility of an epidemic. Therefore, increased awareness among physicians for better detection and treatment of Q fever, expansion of the diagnostic system, and further investigations for undiscovered risk factors, are persistently required.\"\n\nReference:\nKwak, Wooseok et al (2013) Epidemiological Characteristics of Serologically Confirmed Q Fever Cases in South Korea, 2006-2011. Osong Public Health and Research Perspectives, Volume 4 , Issue 1, 34-38 http://www.kcdc-phrp.org/article/S2210-9099(12)00102-6/fulltext or http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3747682/.\n\nThis immediate notification report does not mention what actions, if any, were taken to address the exposed human population. disease information 2014; 27(26) OIE [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=15443\n\n\nQ fever, Korea (Rep. of)\n-------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 25 Jun 2014 from Dr TaeYung Kim, Director General, Livestock Policy Bureau, Ministry for Food, Agriculture, Forestry & Fisheries, Sejong-Si, Korea (Rep. of)\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 21 May 2014\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 21 May 2014\nReport date: 25 Jun 2014\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 16 Jul 2013\nManifestation of disease: Clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Coxiella burnetti_\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (basic), Laboratory (advanced), Necropsy\nThis event pertains to the whole country\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1: Imsil-eup, Imsil-gun, Jeollabuk-Do\nDate of start of the outbreak: 21 May 2014\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed /Slaughtered\nSheep/goats / 975 / 2 / 0 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: goats\n\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nSheep/goats / 0.21 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comment: Q fever positive (placenta and fetus)\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: control of arthropods; quarantine; movement control inside the country; disinfection of infected premises/establishment(s); vaccination prohibited; treatment of affected animals (antibiotics)\n\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nAnimal and Plant Quarantine Agency (National laboratory) / Sheep/goats / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 21 May 2014 / Positive\n\nFuture Reporting:\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the CDC Q fever webpage http://www.cdc.gov/qfever/:\n\"Q fever is a worldwide disease with acute and chronic stages caused by the bacteria _Coxiella burnetii_. Cattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs, although a variety of species may be infected. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals. During birthing, the organisms are shed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta. The organism is extremely hardy and resistant to heat, drying, and many common disinfectants, which enables the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected animals. Other modes of transmission to humans, including tick bites, ingestion of unpasteurized milk or dairy products, and human to human transmission, are rare. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very few organisms may be required to cause infection.\"\n\nQ fever is an important zoonosis, with veterinarians, laboratory workers, farmers and abattoir workers at risk. Surveys have shown that significant numbers of livestock handlers have antibodies, indicating exposure to the organism.\n\nLess than half of people infected become ill, and most infections are mild. But affected persons can develop a high fever with headache, muscle pains, sore throat, nausea and vomiting, chest and stomach pains. The fever can last for one or 2 weeks and lead to pneumonia or affect the liver. Treatment involves long term antibiotic therapy.\n\nIn a small percentage of cases, a chronic, severe debilitating disease occurs. People with suppressed immune systems and those with pre-existing heart valve problems are at risk of this complication, which is often fatal. There is also a post Q fever syndrome of chronic fatigue.\n\nQ fever is the 2nd most commonly reported laboratory infection, with several recorded outbreaks involving 15 or more persons http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Media_Center/docs/pdf/Disease_cards/Q-FEVER-EN.pdf.\n\nThe following information was obtained from a publication titled \"Epidemiological characteristics of serologically confirmed Q Fever cases in South Korea, 2006-2011.\" In the discussion it was noted that: \"This is the 1st official report on the characteristics of Q fever patients in Korea. The annual incidence of Q fever in Korea is much lower than that in France, Australia and Taiwan (0.02 vs. 2.5, 0.1, and 0.38 per 100 000 population, respectively). As the disease has a broad spectrum of clinical manifestations, from nonspecific febrile illness to neurological disorder, and there are no known outbreaks in Korea, it is difficult for physicians to diagnose Q fever without an increased awareness. Serological diagnostic testing is limited, because it is available at only one national laboratory. Therefore, Q fever is likely to be under-diagnosed and under-reported in Korea.\"\n\n\"According to national surveys of_ C. burnetti _ seroprevalence in the Korean population, the seropositivity rate of high-risk occupation groups, such as dairy farmers, slaughterhouse workers, and veterinarians, was 3.7-10.2 percent (data not shown). Q fever is not currently considered to be a significant threat to public health in Korea. Only sporadic cases have been reported to date, but there is a possibility of an epidemic. Therefore, increased awareness among physicians for better detection and treatment of Q fever, expansion of the diagnostic system, and further investigations for undiscovered risk factors, are persistently required.\"\n\nReference:\nKwak, Wooseok et al (2013) Epidemiological Characteristics of Serologically Confirmed Q Fever Cases in South Korea, 2006-2011. Osong Public Health and Research Perspectives, Volume 4 , Issue 1, 34-38 http://www.kcdc-phrp.org/article/S2210-9099(12)00102-6/fulltext or http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3747682/.\n\nThis immediate notification report does not mention what actions, if any, were taken to address the exposed human population. Such information may be of value in future follow-up reports, particularly given that the disease in humans is under-reported.\n\nAccording to information available in the OIE WAHID database, through June 2013, Q-fever was considered absent http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Countryinformation/Animalsituation. Therefore, any additional information on Q-fever in South Korea during the 2nd semester of 2013 would be of interest, especially with respect to the number and location of previous outbreaks, given that the last reported event occurred on 16 Jul 2013. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/195.]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Germany: (BY) human, animal 20140511.2464862\nQ fever - Spain: (PV) 20140409.2393194\n2013\n----\nQ fever - French Guiana: (CY) virulent genotype, alert 20130625.1790517\nQ fever - Brazil (02) (MG) NOT 20130619.1782145\nQ fever - Brazil: (MG) 20130617.1777459\nQ fever - Hungary: (BA) RFI 20130607.1760537\nQ fever - Spain (02): (AN) background 20130504.1691296\nQ fever - Spain: (AN) 20130503.1689392\nQ fever - Argentina: (CB) Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\nThe location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the CDC Q fever webpage http://www.cdc.gov/qfever/:\n\"Q fever is a worldwide disease with acute and chronic stages caused by the bacteria _Coxiella burnetii_. Cattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs, although a variety of species may be infected. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals. During birthing, the organisms are shed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta. The organism is extremely hardy and resistant to heat, drying, and many common disinfectants, which enables the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment.\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected animals. Other modes of transmission to humans, including tick bites, ingestion of unpasteurized milk or dairy products, and human to human transmission, are rare. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very few organisms may be required to cause infection.\"\n\nQ fever is an important zoonosis, with veterinarians, laboratory workers, farmers and abattoir workers at risk. Surveys have shown that significant numbers of livestock handlers have antibodies, indicating exposure to the organism.\n\nLess than half of people infected become ill, and most infections are mild. But affected persons can develop a high fever with headache, muscle pains, sore throat, nausea and vomiting, chest and stomach pains. The fever can last for one or 2 weeks and lead to pneumonia or affect the liver. Treatment involves long term antibiotic therapy.\n\nIn a small percentage of cases, a chronic, severe debilitating disease occurs. People with suppressed immune systems and those with pre-existing heart valve problems are at risk of this complication, which is often fatal. There is also a post Q fever syndrome of chronic fatigue.\n\nQ fever is the 2nd most commonly reported laboratory infection, with several recorded outbreaks involving 15 or more persons http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Media_Center/docs/pdf/Disease_cards/Q-FEVER-EN.pdf.\n\nThe following information was obtained from a publication titled \"Epidemiological characteristics of serologically confirmed Q Fever cases in South Korea, 2006-2011.\" In the discussion it was noted that: \"This is the 1st official report on the characteristics of Q fever patients in Korea. The annual incidence of Q fever in Korea is much lower than that in France, Australia and Taiwan (0.02 vs. 2.5, 0.1, and 0.38 per 100 000 population, respectively). As the disease has a broad spectrum of clinical manifestations, from nonspecific febrile illness to neurological disorder, and there are no known outbreaks in Korea, it is difficult for physicians to diagnose Q fever without an increased awareness. Serological diagnostic testing is limited, because it is available at only one national laboratory. Therefore, Q fever is likely to be under-diagnosed and under-reported in Korea.\"\n\n\"According to national surveys of_ C. burnetti _ seroprevalence in the Korean population, the seropositivity rate of high-risk occupation groups, such as dairy farmers, slaughterhouse workers, and veterinarians, was 3.7-10.2 percent (data not shown). Q fever is not currently considered to be a significant threat to public health in Korea. Only sporadic cases have been reported to date, but there is a possibility of an epidemic. Therefore, increased awareness among physicians for better detection and treatment of Q fever, expansion of the diagnostic system, and further investigations for undiscovered risk factors, are persistently required.\"\n\nReference:\nKwak, Wooseok et al (2013) Epidemiological Characteristics of Serologically Confirmed Q Fever Cases in South Korea, 2006-2011. Osong Public Health and Research Perspectives, Volume 4 , Issue 1, 34-38 http://www.kcdc-phrp.org/article/S2210-9099(12)00102-6/fulltext or http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3747682/.\n\nThis immediate notification report does not mention what actions, if any, were taken to address the exposed human population. Si", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2464862", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Germany: (BY) human, animal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2464862", "date": "2013-05-04 10:06:52", "main_text": "Q FEVER - SPAIN (02): (ANDALUSIA) BACKGROUND\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 4 May 2013\nSource: GIDEON (Global Infectious Disease Epidemiology Network) [edited]\nhttp://www.gideononline.com\n\n\nThe following background data on Q fever in Spain are abstracted from Gideon http://www.gideononline.com and the Gideon e-book series. [1,2]:\n\nTime and place:\nThe 1st cases of Q fever in Spain were reported in 1950. Q fever rates are highest in the Basque region (accounting for 60 per cent of community-acquired pneumonias) and Navarre. Pneumonia is the predominant clinical presentation in the north, and hepatitis in the south. Ten outbreaks were registered during 1981 to 1985. 130 cases of Q fever were reported in the Basque Country during 1981 to 1984; and 1261 cases in Gipuzkoa (Basque Country) during 1984 to 2004.\n\nRates of Q fever in Spain have been decreasing for over 25 years; see graph: http://cdn.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/QfeverSpain.png.\n\nPrevalence surveys:\n5 per cent of community-acquired pneumonia in Palma de Mallorca (1992 to 1994)\n18.5 per cent of community-acquired pneumonia (2006 to 2007)\n30 per cent of patients with fever exceeding 7 days\n20.1 per cent of women with spontaneous abortion vs. 9.7 per cent of controls (Burgos, 2009 to 2010)\n13.7 per cent of patients hospitalized with fever lasting 1-4 weeks (Grenada, 2000 to 2005)\n3 per cent of ovine flocks in northern Spain (1999 to 2003)\n22 per cent of sheep flocks in the Basque Country (2009 publication)\n5.1 per cent of roe deer (_Capreolus capreolus_), 4.3 per cent of wild boar (_Sus scrofa_), 9.1 per cent of European hare (_Lepus europaeus_), 11 per cent of vultures (_Gyps fulvus_), 14 per cent of black kites (_Milvus migrans_) and 0 per cent of associated ticks (Basque region, 2010 publication)\n_Coxiella burnetii_ has been detected in ticks (_Haemaphysalis punctata_) in the Basque Country (2003 to 2005)\n\nSeroprevalence surveys:\n50 per cent of persons in rural Soria Province (1996 to 1999)\n38.5 per cent of adults in the rural Basque Country (1993 publication)\n40.6 per cent of adults in Leon Province (1996 publication)\n48.6 per cent of adults in Eastern Cantabria (1998 publication)\n10.02 per cent to 11.02 percent of veterinary students in Zaragoza (2000 publication)\n15.3 per cent of the population of Valles Occidental (2006 publication)\n23.1 per cent of blood donors in Albacete (2007 publication)\n11.8 per cent of sheep, 8.7 per cent of goats, and 6.7 per cent of beef cattle in semi-extensive grazing systems in northern Spain (2010 publication)\n30 per cent of herds and 6.76 per cent of cattle in the Madrid region (2012 publication)\n\nNotable outbreaks:\n1982 - An outbreak (42 cases) of Q fever was reported in Valmaseda, Basque region.\n1990 - An outbreak (30 cases) was reported in Billabona, Zizurkil, and Guipuzcoa.\n1998 - An outbreak (14 cases) related to sheep was reported in Soria Province.\n2003 - An outbreak (60 cases) was reported in Asturias.\n2006 (publication year) - An outbreak (22 cases) was associated with a visit to a school farm.\n2012 (publication year) - An outbreak was reported in flock of sheep.\n\nReferences:\n1. Berger SA. Infectious diseases of Spain, 2013. 575 pages, 194 graphs, 3284 references. Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-spain/\n2. Berger SA. Q-fever: global status, 2013. 78 pages, 58 graphs, 1035 references. Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/q-fever-global-status/\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nSteve Berger\nGeographic Medicine,\nTel Aviv Medical Center\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Steve Berger for providing background information on Q fever in Spain.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Spain can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1zJm. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Spain: (AN) 20130503.1689392\n2012\n---\nQ fever - Serbia: (VO) 20120413.1100615\nQ fever - Netherlands: human, 2007-2010 20120229.1056949\n2011\n---\nQ fever - Australia (04): (QL) 20111124.3434\nQ fever - USA (03): (WA, MT), caprine, human 20111014.3071\nQ fever - USA: raw cow's milk, ex goat 20110624.1938\nQ fever - Australia (03): duration of vaccine protection 20110404.1047\nQ fever - Australia (02): background 20110403.1029\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) 20110401.1005\nQ fever - Germany: (NW, HE) human, animal 20110223.0604\nQ fever - Netherlands: human, animal 20110213.0490\n2009\n---\nQ fever - Australia: (SA), laboratory-acquired 20091225.4345\n2007\n---\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (03): fatality 20070730.2449\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (02): abattoir 20070713.2244\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2005\n---\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\n2004\n---\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\n.................................................ml/msp/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1950-03-16 00:00:00", "1981-03-16 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "1261-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1982-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "1035-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Zizurkil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Burgos", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zaragoza", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madrid", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Leon Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tel Aviv", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Palma de Mallorca", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grenada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Asturias", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gipuzkoa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Billabona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Soria Province", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2393194", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Spain: (PV)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2393194", "date": "2013-05-04 10:06:52", "main_text": "Q FEVER - SPAIN (02): (ANDALUSIA) BACKGROUND\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 4 May 2013\nSource: GIDEON (Global Infectious Disease Epidemiology Network) [edited]\nhttp://www.gideononline.com\n\n\nThe following background data on Q fever in Spain are abstracted from Gideon http://www.gideononline.com and the Gideon e-book series. [1,2]:\n\nTime and place:\nThe 1st cases of Q fever in Spain were reported in 1950. Q fever rates are highest in the Basque region (accounting for 60 per cent of community-acquired pneumonias) and Navarre. Pneumonia is the predominant clinical presentation in the north, and hepatitis in the south. Ten outbreaks were registered during 1981 to 1985. 130 cases of Q fever were reported in the Basque Country during 1981 to 1984; and 1261 cases in Gipuzkoa (Basque Country) during 1984 to 2004.\n\nRates of Q fever in Spain have been decreasing for over 25 years; see graph: http://cdn.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/QfeverSpain.png.\n\nPrevalence surveys:\n5 per cent of community-acquired pneumonia in Palma de Mallorca (1992 to 1994)\n18.5 per cent of community-acquired pneumonia (2006 to 2007)\n30 per cent of patients with fever exceeding 7 days\n20.1 per cent of women with spontaneous abortion vs. 9.7 per cent of controls (Burgos, 2009 to 2010)\n13.7 per cent of patients hospitalized with fever lasting 1-4 weeks (Grenada, 2000 to 2005)\n3 per cent of ovine flocks in northern Spain (1999 to 2003)\n22 per cent of sheep flocks in the Basque Country (2009 publication)\n5.1 per cent of roe deer (_Capreolus capreolus_), 4.3 per cent of wild boar (_Sus scrofa_), 9.1 per cent of European hare (_Lepus europaeus_), 11 per cent of vultures (_Gyps fulvus_), 14 per cent of black kites (_Milvus migrans_) and 0 per cent of associated ticks (Basque region, 2010 publication)\n_Coxiella burnetii_ has been detected in ticks (_Haemaphysalis punctata_) in the Basque Country (2003 to 2005)\n\nSeroprevalence surveys:\n50 per cent of persons in rural Soria Province (1996 to 1999)\n38.5 per cent of adults in the rural Basque Country (1993 publication)\n40.6 per cent of adults in Leon Province (1996 publication)\n48.6 per cent of adults in Eastern Cantabria (1998 publication)\n10.02 per cent to 11.02 percent of veterinary students in Zaragoza (2000 publication)\n15.3 per cent of the population of Valles Occidental (2006 publication)\n23.1 per cent of blood donors in Albacete (2007 publication)\n11.8 per cent of sheep, 8.7 per cent of goats, and 6.7 per cent of beef cattle in semi-extensive grazing systems in northern Spain (2010 publication)\n30 per cent of herds and 6.76 per cent of cattle in the Madrid region (2012 publication)\n\nNotable outbreaks:\n1982 - An outbreak (42 cases) of Q fever was reported in Valmaseda, Basque region.\n1990 - An outbreak (30 cases) was reported in Billabona, Zizurkil, and Guipuzcoa.\n1998 - An outbreak (14 cases) related to sheep was reported in Soria Province.\n2003 - An outbreak (60 cases) was reported in Asturias.\n2006 (publication year) - An outbreak (22 cases) was associated with a visit to a school farm.\n2012 (publication year) - An outbreak was reported in flock of sheep.\n\nReferences:\n1. Berger SA. Infectious diseases of Spain, 2013. 575 pages, 194 graphs, 3284 references. Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-spain/\n2. Berger SA. French Guiana: (CY) virulent genotype, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1790517", "date": "2013-05-04 10:06:52", "main_text": "Q FEVER - SPAIN (02): (ANDALUSIA) BACKGROUND\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 4 May 2013\nSource: GIDEON (Global Infectious Disease Epidemiology Network) [edited]\nhttp://www.gideononline.com\n\n\nThe following background data on Q fever in Spain are abstracted from Gideon http://www.gideononline.com and the Gideon e-book series. [1,2]:\n\nTime and place:\nThe 1st cases of Q fever in Spain were reported in 1950. Q fever rates are highest in the Basque region (accounting for 60 per cent of community-acquired pneumonias) and Navarre. Pneumonia is the predominant clinical presentation in the north, and hepatitis in the south. Ten outbreaks were registered during 1981 to 1985. 130 cases of Q fever were reported in the Basque Country during 1981 to 1984; and 1261 cases in Gipuzkoa (Basque Country) during 1984 to 2004.\n\nRates of Q fever in Spain have been decreasing for over 25 years; see graph: http://cdn.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/QfeverSpain.png.\n\nPrevalence surveys:\n5 per cent of community-acquired pneumonia in Palma de Mallorca (1992 to 1994)\n18.5 per cent of community-acquired pneumonia (2006 to 2007)\n30 per cent of patients with fever exceeding 7 days\n20.1 per cent of women with spontaneous abortion vs. 9.7 per cent of controls (Burgos, 2009 to 2010)\n13.7 per cent of patients hospitalized with fever lasting 1-4 weeks (Grenada, 2000 to 2005)\n3 per cent of ovine flocks in northern Spain (1999 to 2003)\n22 per cent of sheep flocks in the Basque Country (2009 publication)\n5.1 per cent of roe deer (_Capreolus capreolus_), 4.3 per cent of wild boar (_Sus scrofa_), 9.1 per cent of European hare (_Lepus europaeus_), 11 per cent of vultures (_Gyps fulvus_), 14 per cent of black kites (_Milvus migrans_) and 0 per cent of associated ticks (Basque region, 2010 publication)\n_Coxiella burnetii_ has been detected in ticks (_Haemaphysalis punctata_) in the Basque Country (2003 to 2005)\n\nSeroprevalence surveys:\n50 per cent of persons in rural Soria Province (1996 to 1999)\n38.5 per cent of adults in the rural Basque Country (1993 publication)\n40.6 per cent of adults in Leon Province (1996 publication)\n48.6 per cent of adults in Eastern Cantabria (1998 publication)\n10.02 per cent to 11.02 percent of veterinary students in Zaragoza (2000 publication)\n15.3 per cent of the population of Valles Occidental (2006 publication)\n23.1 per cent of blood donors in Albacete (2007 publication)\n11.8 per cent of sheep, 8.7 per cent of goats, and 6.7 per cent of beef cattle in semi-extensive grazing systems in northern Spain (2010 publication)\n30 per cent of herds and 6.76 per cent of cattle in the Madrid region (2012 publication)\n\nNotable outbreaks:\n1982 - An outbreak (42 cases) of Q fever was reported in Valmaseda, Basque region.\n1990 - An outbreak (30 cases) was reported in Billabona, Zizurkil, and Guipuzcoa.\n1998 - An outbreak (14 cases) related to sheep was reported in Soria Province.\n2003 - An outbreak (60 cases) was reported in Asturias.\n2006 (publication year) - An outbreak (22 cases) was associated with a visit to a school farm.\n2012 (publication year) - An outbreak was reported in flock of sheep.\n\nReferences:\n1. Berger SA. Infectious diseases of Spain, 2013. 575 pages, 194 graphs, 3284 references. Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-spain/\n2. Berger SA. Q-fever: global status, 2013. 78 pages, 58 graphs, 1035 references. Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/q-fever-global-status/\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nSteve Berger\nGeographic Medicine,\nTel Aviv Medical Center\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Steve Berger for providing background information on Q fever in Spain.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Spain can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1zJm. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Spain: (AN) 20130503.1689392\n2012\n---\nQ fever - Serbia: (VO) 20120413.1100615\nQ fever - Netherlands: human, 2007-2010 20120229.1056949\n2011\n---\nQ fever - Australia (04): (QL) 20111124.3434\nQ fever - USA (03): (WA, MT), caprine, human 20111014.3071\nQ fever - USA: raw cow's milk, ex goat 20110624.1938\nQ fever - Australia (03): duration of vaccine protection 20110404.1047\nQ fever - Australia (02): background 20110403.1029\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) 20110401.1005\nQ fever - Germany: (NW, HE) human, animal 20110223.0604\nQ fever - Netherlands: human, animal 20110213.0490\n2009\n---\nQ fever - Australia: (SA), laboratory-acquired 20091225.4345\n2007\n---\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (03): fatality 20070730.2449\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (02): abattoir 20070713.2244\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2005\n---\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\n2004\n---\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. [1,2]:\n\nTime and place:\nThe 1st cases of Q fever in Spain were reported in 1950. Q fever rates are highest in the Basque region (accounting for 60 per cent of community-acquired pneumonias) and Navarre. Pneumonia is the predominant clinical presentation in the north, and hepatitis in the south. Ten outbreaks were registered during 1981 to 1985. 130 cases of Q fever were reported in the Basque Country during 1981 to 1984; and 1261 cases in Gipuzkoa (Basque Country) during 1984 to 2004.\n\nRates of Q fever in Spain have been decreasing for over 25 years; see graph: http://cdn.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/QfeverSpain.png.\n\nPrevalence surveys:\n5 per cent of community-acquired pneumonia in Palma de Mallorca (1992 to 1994)\n18.5 per cent of community-acquired pneumonia (2006 to 2007)\n30 per cent of patients with fever exceeding 7 days\n20.1 per cent of women with spontaneous abortion vs. 9.7 per cent of controls (Burgos, 2009 to 2010)\n13.7 per cent of patients hospitalized with fever lasting 1-4 weeks (Grenada, 2000 to 2005)\n3 per cent of ovine flocks in northern Spain (1999 to 2003)\n22 per cent of sheep flocks in the Basque Country (2009 publication)\n5.1 per cent of roe deer (_Capreolus capreolus_), 4.3 per cent of wild boar (_Sus scrofa_), 9.1 per cent of European hare (_Lepus europaeus_), 11 per cent of vultures (_Gyps fulvus_), 14 per cent of black kites (_Milvus migrans_) and 0 per cent of associated ticks (Basque region, 2010 publication)\n_Coxiella burnetii_ has been detected in ticks (_Haemaphysalis punctata_) in the Basque Country (2003 to 2005)\n\nSeroprevalence surveys:\n50 per cent of persons in rural Soria Province (1996 to 1999)\n38.5 per cent of adults in the rural Basque Country (1993 publication)\n40.6 per cent of adults in Leon Province (1996 publication)\n48.6 per cent of adults in Eastern Cantabria (1998 publication)\n10.02 per cent to 11.02 percent of veterinary students in Zaragoza (2000 publication)\n15.3 per cent of the population of Valles Occidental (2006 publication)\n23.1 per cent of blood donors in Albacete (2007 publication)\n11.8 per cent of sheep, 8.7 per cent of goats, and 6.7 per cent of beef cattle in semi-extensive grazing systems in northern Spain (2010 publication)\n30 per cent of herds and 6.76 per cent of cattle in the Madrid region (2012 publication)\n\nNotable outbreaks:\n1982 - An outbreak (42 cases) of Q fever was reported in Valmaseda, Basque region.\n1990 - An outbreak (30 cases) was reported in Billabona, Zizurkil, and Guipuzcoa.\n1998 - An outbreak (14 cases) related to sheep was reported in Soria Province.\n2003 - An outbreak (60 cases) was reported in Asturias.\n2006 (publication year) - An outbreak (22 cases) was associated with a visit to a school farm.\n2012 (publication year) - An outbreak was reported in flock of sheep.\n\nReferences:\n1. Australia) 20041214.3309\n.................................................ml/msp/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1950-03-16 00:00:00", "1981-03-16 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "1261-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1982-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "1035-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Zizurkil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Burgos", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zaragoza", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madrid", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Leon Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tel Aviv", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Palma de Mallorca", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grenada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Asturias", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gipuzkoa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Billabona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Soria Province", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1760537", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Hungary: (BA) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1760537", "date": "2013-05-04 10:06:52", "main_text": "Q FEVER - SPAIN (02): (ANDALUSIA) BACKGROUND\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sat 4 May 2013\nSource: GIDEON (Global Infectious Disease Epidemiology Network) [edited]\nhttp://www.gideononline.com\n\n\nThe following background data on Q fever in Spain are abstracted from Gideon http://www.gideononline.com and the Gideon e-book series. [1,2]:\n\nTime and place:\nThe 1st cases of Q fever in Spain were reported in 1950. Q fever rates are highest in the Basque region (accounting for 60 per cent of community-acquired pneumonias) and Navarre. Pneumonia is the predominant clinical presentation in the north, and hepatitis in the south. Ten outbreaks were registered during 1981 to 1985. 130 cases of Q fever were reported in the Basque Country during 1981 to 1984; and 1261 cases in Gipuzkoa (Basque Country) during 1984 to 2004.\n\nRates of Q fever in Spain have been decreasing for over 25 years; see graph: http://cdn.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/QfeverSpain.png.\n\nPrevalence surveys:\n5 per cent of community-acquired pneumonia in Palma de Mallorca (1992 to 1994)\n18.5 per cent of community-acquired pneumonia (2006 to 2007)\n30 per cent of patients with fever exceeding 7 days\n20.1 per cent of women with spontaneous abortion vs. 9.7 per cent of controls (Burgos, 2009 to 2010)\n13.7 per cent of patients hospitalized with fever lasting 1-4 weeks (Grenada, 2000 to 2005)\n3 per cent of ovine flocks in northern Spain (1999 to 2003)\n22 per cent of sheep flocks in the Basque Country (2009 publication)\n5.1 per cent of roe deer (_Capreolus capreolus_), 4.3 per cent of wild boar (_Sus scrofa_), 9.1 per cent of European hare (_Lepus europaeus_), 11 per cent of vultures (_Gyps fulvus_), 14 per cent of black kites (_Milvus migrans_) and 0 per cent of associated ticks (Basque region, 2010 publication)\n_Coxiella burnetii_ has been detected in ticks (_Haemaphysalis punctata_) in the Basque Country (2003 to 2005)\n\nSeroprevalence surveys:\n50 per cent of persons in rural Soria Province (1996 to 1999)\n38.5 per cent of adults in the rural Basque Country (1993 publication)\n40.6 per cent of adults in Leon Province (1996 publication)\n48.6 per cent of adults in Eastern Cantabria (1998 publication)\n10.02 per cent to 11.02 percent of veterinary students in Zaragoza (2000 publication)\n15.3 per cent of the population of Valles Occidental (2006 publication)\n23.1 per cent of blood donors in Albacete (2007 publication)\n11.8 per cent of sheep, 8.7 per cent of goats, and 6.7 per cent of beef cattle in semi-extensive grazing systems in northern Spain (2010 publication)\n30 per cent of herds and 6.76 per cent of cattle in the Madrid region (2012 publication)\n\nNotable outbreaks:\n1982 - An outbreak (42 cases) of Q fever was reported in Valmaseda, Basque region.\n1990 - An outbreak (30 cases) was reported in Billabona, Zizurkil, and Guipuzcoa.\n1998 - An outbreak (14 cases) related to sheep was reported in Soria Province.\n2003 - An outbreak (60 cases) was reported in Asturias.\n2006 (publication year) - An outbreak (22 cases) was associated with a visit to a school farm.\n2012 (publication year) - An outbreak was reported in flock of sheep.\n\nReferences:\n1. Berger SA. Infectious diseases of Spain, 2013. 575 pages, 194 graphs, 3284 references. Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/country/infectious-diseases-of-spain/\n2. Berger SA. Q-fever: global status, 2013. 78 pages, 58 graphs, 1035 references. Gideon e-books, http://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/q-fever-global-status/\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nSteve Berger\nGeographic Medicine,\nTel Aviv Medical Center\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Steve Berger for providing background information on Q fever in Spain.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Spain can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/r/1zJm. - Mod.ML]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Spain: (AN) 20130503.1689392\n2012\n---\nQ fever - Serbia: (VO) 20120413.1100615\nQ fever - Netherlands: human, 2007-2010 20120229.1056949\n2011\n---\nQ fever - Australia (04): (QL) 20111124.3434\nQ fever - USA (03): (WA, MT), caprine, human 20111014.3071\nQ fever - USA: raw cow's milk, ex goat 20110624.1938\nQ fever - Australia (03): duration of vaccine protection 20110404.1047\nQ fever - Australia (02): background 20110403.1029\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) 20110401.1005\nQ fever - Germany: (NW, HE) human, animal 20110223.0604\nQ fever - Netherlands: human, animal 20110213.0490\n2009\n---\nQ fever - Australia: (SA), laboratory-acquired 20091225.4345\n2007\n---\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (03): fatality 20070730.2449\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (02): abattoir 20070713.2244\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2005\n---\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\n2004\n---\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\n.................................................ml/msp/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1950-03-16 00:00:00", "1981-03-16 00:00:00", "1985-03-16 00:00:00", "1261-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2012-03-16 00:00:00", "1982-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "2003-03-16 00:00:00", "2006-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "2013-03-16 00:00:00", "1035-03-16 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Zizurkil", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Burgos", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Zaragoza", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Madrid", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SPAIN", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Leon Province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Tel Aviv", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Palma de Mallorca", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Grenada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Asturias", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gipuzkoa", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Billabona", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Soria Province", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1691296", "headline": "PRO> Q fever - [1,2]:\n\nTime and place:\nThe 1st cases of Q fever in Spain were reported in 1950. Q fever rates are highest in the Basque region (accounting for 60 per cent of community-acquired pneumonias) and Navarre. Pneumonia is the predominant clinical presentation in the north, and hepatitis in the south. Ten outbreaks were registered during 1981 to 1985. 130 cases of Q fever were reported in the Basque Country during 1981 to 1984; and 1261 cases in Gipuzkoa (Basque Country) during 1984 to 2004.\n\nRates of Q fever in Spain have been decreasing for over 25 years; see graph: http://cdn.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/QfeverSpain.png.\n\nPrevalence surveys:\n5 per cent of community-acquired pneumonia in Palma de Mallorca (1992 to 1994)\n18.5 per cent of community-acquired pneumonia (2006 to 2007)\n30 per cent of patients with fever exceeding 7 days\n20.1 per cent of women with spontaneous abortion vs. 9.7 per cent of controls (Burgos, 2009 to 2010)\n13.7 per cent of patients hospitalized with fever lasting 1-4 weeks (Grenada, 2000 to 2005)\n3 per cent of ovine flocks in northern Spain (1999 to 2003)\n22 per cent of sheep flocks in the Basque Country (2009 publication)\n5.1 per cent of roe deer (_Capreolus capreolus_), 4.3 per cent of wild boar (_Sus scrofa_), 9.1 per cent of European hare (_Lepus europaeus_), 11 per cent of vultures (_Gyps fulvus_), 14 per cent of black kites (_Milvus migrans_) and 0 per cent of associated ticks (Basque region, 2010 publication)\n_Coxiella burnetii_ has been detected in ticks (_Haemaphysalis punctata_) in the Basque Country (2003 to 2005)\n\nSeroprevalence surveys:\n50 per cent of persons in rural Soria Province (1996 to 1999)\n38.5 per cent of adults in the rural Basque Country (1993 publication)\n40.6 per cent of adults in Leon Province (1996 publication)\n48.6 per cent of adults in Eastern Cantabria (1998 publication)\n10.02 per cent to 11.02 percent of veterinary students in Zaragoza (2000 publication)\n15.3 per cent of the population of Valles Occidental (2006 publication)\n23.1 per cent of blood donors in Albacete (2007 publication)\n11.8 per cent of sheep, 8.7 per cent of goats, and 6.7 per cent of beef cattle in semi-extensive grazing systems in northern Spain (2010 publication)\n30 per cent of herds and 6.76 per cent of cattle in the Madrid region (2012 publication)\n\nNotable outbreaks:\n1982 - An outbreak (42 cases) of Q fever was reported in Valmaseda, Basque region.\n1990 - An outbreak (30 cases) was reported in Billabona, Zizurkil, and Guipuzcoa.\n1998 - An outbreak (14 cases) related to sheep was reported in Soria Province.\n2003 - An outbreak (60 cases) was reported in Asturias.\n2006 (publication year) - An outbreak (22 cases) was associated with a visit to a school farm.\n2012 (publication year) - An outbreak was reported in flock of sheep.\n\nReferences:\n1. Argentina: (CB) ticks, 1st report", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1655919", "date": "2011-11-25 11:43:36", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA (05): (QUEENSLAND)\n**************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 25 Nov 2011\nFrom: Jaimie Frazer <attackrate@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\n[Re: ProMED-mail Q fever - Australia (04): (QL) 20111124.3434]\n--------------------------------------------------------------\nThe article you comment on likely relates to a recently published\npaper in the Australian Veterinary Journal, which provides some\ncontext. The paper is:\n\nA Cooper, R Hedlefs, N Ketheesan, B Govan: Serological evidence of\n_Coxiella burnetii_ infection in dogs in a regional centre. Austral\nVet J 2011; 89(10): 385-7.\n\nAbstract\n--------\nObjective: investigate the seroprevalence of the causative agent of Q\nfever, _Coxiella burnetii_ in domestic dogs in the Townsville region,\nNorth Queensland, Australia.\n\nMethod: blood samples were collected from dogs attending veterinary\nclinics for routine procedures.\n\nResults: an overall seropositivity of 21.8 percent (95 percent\nconfidence interval (CI) 21.6-22.1 percent) was observed. A\nretrospective study of samples collected in the same region during\n1984-85 was also performed, with an overall seropositivity of 16.0\npercent (95 percent CI 15.9-16.2).\n\nConclusion: evidence of _C. burnetii_ infection in domestic dogs may\nhave public health implications for dog owners, as well as\nveterinarians because of occupational exposure. This study is the 1st\nknown investigation of _C. burnetii_ seroprevalence in dogs in\nQueensland.\n\n--\nDr Jaimie Frazer\nVeterinarian\n<attackrate@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Frazer for his contribution regarding the\nseroprevalence of Q fever in Queensland. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Australia (04): (QL) 20111124.3434\nQ fever - Australia (03): duration of vaccine protection\n20110404.1047\nQ fever - Australia (02): background 20110403.1029\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) 20110401.1005\nQ fever - Germany: (NW, HE) human, animal 20110223.0604\nQ fever - Netherlands: human, animal 20110213.0490\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Australia: (SA), laboratory-acquired 20091225.4345\nQ fever, caprine - Netherlands: (LI) 20090331.1230\n2007\n----\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (03): fatality 20070730.2449\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (02): abattoir 20070713.2244\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S.
