The paper is:\n\nA Cooper, R Hedlefs, N Ketheesan, B Govan: Serological evidence of\n_Coxiella burnetii_ infection in dogs in a regional centre. Austral\nVet J 2011; 89(10): 385-7.\n\nAbstract\n--------\nObjective: investigate the seroprevalence of the causative agent of Q\nfever, _Coxiella burnetii_ in domestic dogs in the Townsville region,\nNorth Queensland, Australia.\n\nMethod: blood samples were collected from dogs attending veterinary\nclinics for routine procedures.\n\nResults: an overall seropositivity of 21.8 percent (95 percent\nconfidence interval (CI) 21.6-22.1 percent) was observed. A\nretrospective study of samples collected in the same region during\n1984-85 was also performed, with an overall seropositivity of 16.0\npercent (95 percent CI 15.9-16.2).\n\nConclusion: evidence of _C. burnetii_ infection in domestic dogs may\nhave public health implications for dog owners, as well as\nveterinarians because of occupational exposure. This study is the 1st\nknown investigation of _C. burnetii_ seroprevalence in dogs in\nQueensland.\n\n--\nDr Jaimie Frazer\nVeterinarian\n<attackrate@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Frazer for his contribution regarding the\nseroprevalence of Q fever in Queensland. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Australia (04): (QL) 20111124.3434\nQ fever - Australia (03): duration of vaccine protection\n20110404.1047\nQ fever - Australia (02): background 20110403.1029\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) 20110401.1005\nQ fever - Germany: (NW, HE) human, animal 20110223.0604\nQ fever - Netherlands: human, animal 20110213.0490\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Australia: (SA), laboratory-acquired 20091225.4345\nQ fever, caprine - Netherlands: (LI) 20090331.1230\n2007\n----\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (03): fatality 20070730.2449\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (02): abattoir 20070713.2244\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\n.................................................ll/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Townsville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Queensland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "958800", "headline": "PRO/AH> Q fever - Australia (05): (QL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=958800", "date": "2011-11-25 11:43:36", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA (05): (QUEENSLAND)\n**************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 25 Nov 2011\nFrom: Jaimie Frazer <attackrate@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\n[Re: ProMED-mail Q fever - Australia (04): (QL) 20111124.3434]\n--------------------------------------------------------------\nThe article you comment on likely relates to a recently published\npaper in the Australian Veterinary Journal, which provides some\ncontext. The paper is:\n\nA Cooper, R Hedlefs, N Ketheesan, B Govan: Serological evidence of\n_Coxiella burnetii_ infection in dogs in a regional centre. Austral\nVet J 2011; 89(10): 385-7.\n\nAbstract\n--------\nObjective: investigate the seroprevalence of the causative agent of Q\nfever, _Coxiella burnetii_ in domestic dogs in the Townsville region,\nNorth Queensland, Australia.\n\nMethod: blood samples were collected from dogs attending veterinary\nclinics for routine procedures.\n\nResults: an overall seropositivity of 21.8 percent (95 percent\nconfidence interval (CI) 21.6-22.1 percent) was observed. A\nretrospective study of samples collected in the same region during\n1984-85 was also performed, with an overall seropositivity of 16.0\npercent (95 percent CI 15.9-16.2).\n\nConclusion: evidence of _C. burnetii_ infection in domestic dogs may\nhave public health implications for dog owners, as well as\nveterinarians because of occupational exposure. This study is the 1st\nknown investigation of _C. burnetii_ seroprevalence in dogs in\nQueensland.\n\n--\nDr Jaimie Frazer\nVeterinarian\n<attackrate@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Dr Frazer for his contribution regarding the\nseroprevalence of Q fever in Queensland. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Australia (04): (QL) 20111124.3434\nQ fever - Australia (03): duration of vaccine protection\n20110404.1047\nQ fever - Australia (02): background 20110403.1029\nQ fever - Australia: (NS) 20110401.1005\nQ fever - Germany: (NW, HE) human, animal 20110223.0604\nQ fever - Netherlands: human, animal 20110213.0490\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Australia: (SA), laboratory-acquired 20091225.4345\nQ fever, caprine - Netherlands: (LI) 20090331.1230\n2007\n----\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (03): fatality 20070730.2449\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (02): abattoir 20070713.2244\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\n.................................................ll/mj/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2011-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Townsville", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Queensland", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "957322", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Australia (04): (QL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=957322", "date": "2011-04-01 10:11:24", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA: (NEW SOUTH WALES)\n**************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 30 Mar 2011\nSource: The Coffs Coast Advocate [edited]\nhttp://www.coffscoastadvocate.com.au/story/2011/03/30/six-coffs-coast-q-fever-victims-found-infection/\n\n\nReports of the little known Q fever on the Coffs Coast [New South\nWales] are causing concern to residents and health authorities. There\nare unconfirmed reports of up to 6 cases presenting at the Coffs\nHarbour Health Campus during the past 6 weeks.\n\nQ Fever is a disease contracted by infection from bacteria found\ntypically in the urine, feces, or milk from cattle and sheep. The\ndirector of public health for the North Coast, Paul Corben, said there\nwas a vaccine available for those working with animals, like vets and\nabattoir workers, but it was a 2-step process which involved a skin\ntest and blood sample before the doctor made a decision, because if\nthe person showed evidence of prior immunity, the vaccine caused \"a\nnasty local reaction.\"\n\nMr Corbin said while they had seen a couple of probable or confirmed\ncases of Q fever from south of Coffs Harbour to as far north as\nWoolgoolga, there was nothing that warranted extra follow-up or\nindicated a higher risk than normal. He said the North Coast averaged\nabout 40 confirmed cases of Q fever annually.\n\nA reader who contacted The Advocate said one man from Emerald Beach\nhad died and she had almost lost a friend this week [week of 28 Mar\n2011], who was now in the intensive care unit. She believed the cases\nwere focused on the northern beaches. \"It is not where you would\nnormally find Q fever,\" Mr Corben said. \"But it is a hardy bacterium\nand very persistent in the environment. We have done normal follow-up\nand there is nothing that links those people together. We are still\nwaiting for some lab reports. You traditionally think of Q fever as\nassociated with farm areas but there have been recent outbreaks in\nother areas.\n\nMr Corben said Q fever was particularly likely to be associated with\nanimal birthing times.\n\n[Byline: Belinda Scott]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Coffs Coast area of New South Wales can be seen on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0DPp. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[Q fever was first described in Australia where this posting\noriginates. It was called \"Query fever\" because the causative agent\nwas initially unknown. _Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was\ndiscovered in 1937. This organism is an agent that can be resistant to\nheat and desiccation and highly infectious by the aerosol route. A\nsingle inhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in\n[non-human] primates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was\nfound to be 1.7 organisms (1).\n\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including\nother species of livestock and domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does\nnot usually cause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion\nin goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection.\nOrganisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals.\nMost importantly, during birthing the organisms are shed in high\nnumbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta. Contact with\ncontaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small-cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication (along with the less resistant\nlarge-cell form) and are metabolically dormant and spore-like (3).\n\nThe Q fever organism is a category B bioterrorism agent and, in fact,\nalthough not thought to be related to bioterrorism, was spread by mail\nin a post office in the UK in 1987 (4).\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. Instances of other modes of transmission to humans,\nincluding tick bites and human to human transmission, are rare.\n\nAn earlier outbreak of infection in 51 persons in Scotland, UK, was\ntied to a meat processing plant and appeared to spread via aerosol for\nat least 0.5 mi (0.8 km).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C: An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of \"Q fever.\" Pub Hlth Rep 1041; 56:\n1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D: Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12: 518-53.\n(available at http://cmr.asm.org/cgi/content/full/12/4/518).\n3. Norlander L: Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes\nInfect 2000; 2:417-24 (abstract available at\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10817644).\n4. Winner SJ, Eglin RP, Moore VI, Mayon-White RT: An outbreak of Q\nfever affecting postal workers in Oxfordshire. J Infect 1987; 14(3):\n255-61 (abstract available at\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3585037). - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Germany: (NW, HE) human, animal 20110223.0604\nQ fever - Netherlands: human, animal 20110213.0490\n2010\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (31): (NB) investigation report 20100930.3546\nQ fever - Netherlands: monitoring 20100103.0028\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (19): update 20091229.4375\nQ fever - Australia: (SA), laboratory-acquired 20091225.4345\nQ fever, caprine - Netherlands: (LI) 20090331.1230\nQ fever - Netherlands: sheep & goat vaccination 20090228.0841\n2007\n----\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (03): fatality 20070730.2449\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (02): abattoir 20070713.2244\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\n.................................................sb/ll/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1937-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "1041-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oxfordshire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Emerald Beach", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "908764", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - USA (03): (WA, MT) , caprine, human", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=908764", "date": "2011-04-01 10:11:24", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA: (NEW SOUTH WALES)\n**************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 30 Mar 2011\nSource: The Coffs Coast Advocate [edited]\nhttp://www.coffscoastadvocate.com.au/story/2011/03/30/six-coffs-coast-q-fever-victims-found-infection/\n\n\nReports of the little known Q fever on the Coffs Coast [New South\nWales] are causing concern to residents and health authorities. There\nare unconfirmed reports of up to 6 cases presenting at the Coffs\nHarbour Health Campus during the past 6 weeks.\n\nQ Fever is a disease contracted by infection from bacteria found\ntypically in the urine, feces, or milk from cattle and sheep. The\ndirector of public health for the North Coast, Paul Corben, said there\nwas a vaccine available for those working with animals, like vets and\nabattoir workers, but it was a 2-step process which involved a skin\ntest and blood sample before the doctor made a decision, because if\nthe person showed evidence of prior immunity, the vaccine caused \"a\nnasty local reaction.\"\n\nMr Corbin said while they had seen a couple of probable or confirmed\ncases of Q fever from south of Coffs Harbour to as far north as\nWoolgoolga, there was nothing that warranted extra follow-up or\nindicated a higher risk than normal. He said the North Coast averaged\nabout 40 confirmed cases of Q fever annually.\n\nA reader who contacted The Advocate said one man from Emerald Beach\nhad died and she had almost lost a friend this week [week of 28 Mar\n2011], who was now in the intensive care unit. She believed the cases\nwere focused on the northern beaches. \"It is not where you would\nnormally find Q fever,\" Mr Corben said. \"But it is a hardy bacterium\nand very persistent in the environment. We have done normal follow-up\nand there is nothing that links those people together. We are still\nwaiting for some lab reports. You traditionally think of Q fever as\nassociated with farm areas but there have been recent outbreaks in\nother areas.\n\nMr Corben said Q fever was particularly likely to be associated with\nanimal birthing times.\n\n[Byline: Belinda Scott]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Coffs Coast area of New South Wales can be seen on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0DPp. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[Q fever was first described in Australia where this posting\noriginates. It was called \"Query fever\" because the causative agent\nwas initially unknown. _Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was\ndiscovered in 1937. This organism is an agent that can be resistant to\nheat and desiccation and highly infectious by the aerosol route. A\nsingle inhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in\n[non-human] primates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was\nfound to be 1.7 organisms (1).\n\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including\nother species of livestock and domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does\nnot usually cause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion\nin goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection.\nOrganisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals.\nMost importantly, during birthing the organisms are shed in high\nnumbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta. Contact with\ncontaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small-cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication (along with the less resistant\nlarge-cell form) and are metabolically dormant and spore-like (3).\n\nThe Q fever organism is a category B bioterrorism agent and, in fact,\nalthough not thought to be related to bioterrorism, was spread by mail\nin a post office in the UK in 1987 (4).\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. Instances of other modes of transmission to humans,\nincluding tick bites and human to human transmission, are rare.\n\nAn earlier outbreak of infection in 51 persons in Scotland, UK, was\ntied to a meat processing plant and appeared to spread via aerosol for\nat least 0.5 mi (0.8 km).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C: An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of \"Q fever.\" Pub Hlth Rep 1041; 56:\n1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D: Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12: 518-53.\n(available at http://cmr.asm.org/cgi/content/full/12/4/518).\n3. Norlander L: Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes\nInfect 2000; 2:417-24 (abstract available at\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10817644).\n4. Winner SJ, Eglin RP, Moore VI, Mayon-White RT: An outbreak of Q\nfever affecting postal workers in Oxfordshire. J Infect 1987; 14(3):\n255-61 (abstract available at\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3585037). - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Germany: (NW, HE) human, animal 20110223.0604\nQ fever - Netherlands: human, animal 20110213.0490\n2010\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (31): (NB) investigation report 20100930.3546\nQ fever - Netherlands: monitoring 20100103.0028\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (19): update 20091229.4375\nQ fever - Australia: (SA), laboratory-acquired 20091225.4345\nQ fever, caprine - Netherlands: (LI) 20090331.1230\nQ fever - Netherlands: sheep & goat vaccination 20090228.0841\n2007\n----\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (03): fatality 20070730.2449\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (02): abattoir 20070713.2244\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\n.................................................sb/ll/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1937-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "1041-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oxfordshire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Emerald Beach", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "866442", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - USA (02): (AK) seals", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=866442", "date": "2011-04-01 10:11:24", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA: (NEW SOUTH WALES)\n**************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 30 Mar 2011\nSource: The Coffs Coast Advocate [edited]\nhttp://www.coffscoastadvocate.com.au/story/2011/03/30/six-coffs-coast-q-fever-victims-found-infection/\n\n\nReports of the little known Q fever on the Coffs Coast [New South\nWales] are causing concern to residents and health authorities. There\nare unconfirmed reports of up to 6 cases presenting at the Coffs\nHarbour Health Campus during the past 6 weeks.\n\nQ Fever is a disease contracted by infection from bacteria found\ntypically in the urine, feces, or milk from cattle and sheep. The\ndirector of public health for the North Coast, Paul Corben, said there\nwas a vaccine available for those working with animals, like vets and\nabattoir workers, but it was a 2-step process which involved a skin\ntest and blood sample before the doctor made a decision, because if\nthe person showed evidence of prior immunity, the vaccine caused \"a\nnasty local reaction.\"\n\nMr Corbin said while they had seen a couple of probable or confirmed\ncases of Q fever from south of Coffs Harbour to as far north as\nWoolgoolga, there was nothing that warranted extra follow-up or\nindicated a higher risk than normal. He said the North Coast averaged\nabout 40 confirmed cases of Q fever annually.\n\nA reader who contacted The Advocate said one man from Emerald Beach\nhad died and she had almost lost a friend this week [week of 28 Mar\n2011], who was now in the intensive care unit. She believed the cases\nwere focused on the northern beaches. \"It is not where you would\nnormally find Q fever,\" Mr Corben said. \"But it is a hardy bacterium\nand very persistent in the environment. We have done normal follow-up\nand there is nothing that links those people together. We are still\nwaiting for some lab reports. You traditionally think of Q fever as\nassociated with farm areas but there have been recent outbreaks in\nother areas.\n\nMr Corben said Q fever was particularly likely to be associated with\nanimal birthing times.\n\n[Byline: Belinda Scott]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Coffs Coast area of New South Wales can be seen on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0DPp. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[Q fever was first described in Australia where this posting\noriginates. It was called \"Query fever\" because the causative agent\nwas initially unknown. _Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was\ndiscovered in 1937. This organism is an agent that can be resistant to\nheat and desiccation and highly infectious by the aerosol route. A\nsingle inhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in\n[non-human] primates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was\nfound to be 1.7 organisms (1).\n\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including\nother species of livestock and domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does\nnot usually cause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion\nin goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection.\nOrganisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals.\nMost importantly, during birthing the organisms are shed in high\nnumbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta. Contact with\ncontaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small-cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication (along with the less resistant\nlarge-cell form) and are metabolically dormant and spore-like (3).\n\nThe Q fever organism is a category B bioterrorism agent and, in fact,\nalthough not thought to be related to bioterrorism, was spread by mail\nin a post office in the UK in 1987 (4).\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. Instances of other modes of transmission to humans,\nincluding tick bites and human to human transmission, are rare.\n\nAn earlier outbreak of infection in 51 persons in Scotland, UK, was\ntied to a meat processing plant and appeared to spread via aerosol for\nat least 0.5 mi (0.8 km).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C: An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of \"Q fever.\" Pub Hlth Rep 1041; 56:\n1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D: Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12: 518-53.\n(available at http://cmr.asm.org/cgi/content/full/12/4/518).\n3. Norlander L: Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes\nInfect 2000; 2:417-24 (abstract available at\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10817644).\n4. Winner SJ, Eglin RP, Moore VI, Mayon-White RT: An outbreak of Q\nfever affecting postal workers in Oxfordshire. J Infect 1987; 14(3):\n255-61 (abstract available at\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3585037). - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Germany: (NW, HE) human, animal 20110223.0604\nQ fever - Netherlands: human, animal 20110213.0490\n2010\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (31): (NB) investigation report 20100930.3546\nQ fever - Netherlands: monitoring 20100103.0028\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (19): update 20091229.4375\nQ fever - Australia: (SA), laboratory-acquired 20091225.4345\nQ fever, caprine - Netherlands: (LI) 20090331.1230\nQ fever - Netherlands: sheep & goat vaccination 20090228.0841\n2007\n----\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (03): fatality 20070730.2449\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (02): abattoir 20070713.2244\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\n.................................................sb/ll/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1937-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "1041-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oxfordshire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Emerald Beach", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "825865", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Luxembourg: animal, susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=825865", "date": "2011-04-01 10:11:24", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA: (NEW SOUTH WALES)\n**************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 30 Mar 2011\nSource: The Coffs Coast Advocate [edited]\nhttp://www.coffscoastadvocate.com.au/story/2011/03/30/six-coffs-coast-q-fever-victims-found-infection/\n\n\nReports of the little known Q fever on the Coffs Coast [New South\nWales] are causing concern to residents and health authorities. There\nare unconfirmed reports of up to 6 cases presenting at the Coffs\nHarbour Health Campus during the past 6 weeks.\n\nQ Fever is a disease contracted by infection from bacteria found\ntypically in the urine, feces, or milk from cattle and sheep. The\ndirector of public health for the North Coast, Paul Corben, said there\nwas a vaccine available for those working with animals, like vets and\nabattoir workers, but it was a 2-step process which involved a skin\ntest and blood sample before the doctor made a decision, because if\nthe person showed evidence of prior immunity, the vaccine caused \"a\nnasty local reaction.\"\n\nMr Corbin said while they had seen a couple of probable or confirmed\ncases of Q fever from south of Coffs Harbour to as far north as\nWoolgoolga, there was nothing that warranted extra follow-up or\nindicated a higher risk than normal. He said the North Coast averaged\nabout 40 confirmed cases of Q fever annually.\n\nA reader who contacted The Advocate said one man from Emerald Beach\nhad died and she had almost lost a friend this week [week of 28 Mar\n2011], who was now in the intensive care unit. She believed the cases\nwere focused on the northern beaches. \"It is not where you would\nnormally find Q fever,\" Mr Corben said. \"But it is a hardy bacterium\nand very persistent in the environment. We have done normal follow-up\nand there is nothing that links those people together. We are still\nwaiting for some lab reports. You traditionally think of Q fever as\nassociated with farm areas but there have been recent outbreaks in\nother areas.\n\nMr Corben said Q fever was particularly likely to be associated with\nanimal birthing times.\n\n[Byline: Belinda Scott]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Coffs Coast area of New South Wales can be seen on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0DPp. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[Q fever was first described in Australia where this posting\noriginates. It was called \"Query fever\" because the causative agent\nwas initially unknown. _Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was\ndiscovered in 1937. This organism is an agent that can be resistant to\nheat and desiccation and highly infectious by the aerosol route. A\nsingle inhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in\n[non-human] primates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was\nfound to be 1.7 organisms (1).\n\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including\nother species of livestock and domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does\nnot usually cause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion\nin goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection.\nOrganisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals.\nMost importantly, during birthing the organisms are shed in high\nnumbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta. Contact with\ncontaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small-cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication (along with the less resistant\nlarge-cell form) and are metabolically dormant and spore-like (3).\n\nThe Q fever organism is a category B bioterrorism agent and, in fact,\nalthough not thought to be related to bioterrorism, was spread by mail\nin a post office in the UK in 1987 (4).\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. Instances of other modes of transmission to humans,\nincluding tick bites and human to human transmission, are rare.\n\nAn earlier outbreak of infection in 51 persons in Scotland, UK, was\ntied to a meat processing plant and appeared to spread via aerosol for\nat least 0.5 mi (0.8 km).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C: An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of \"Q fever.\" Pub Hlth Rep 1041; 56:\n1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D: Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12: 518-53.\n(available at http://cmr.asm.org/cgi/content/full/12/4/518).\n3. Norlander L: Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes\nInfect 2000; 2:417-24 (abstract available at\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10817644).\n4. Winner SJ, Eglin RP, Moore VI, Mayon-White RT: An outbreak of Q\nfever affecting postal workers in Oxfordshire. J Infect 1987; 14(3):\n255-61 (abstract available at\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3585037). - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Germany: (NW, HE) human, animal 20110223.0604\nQ fever - Netherlands: human, animal 20110213.0490\n2010\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (31): (NB) investigation report 20100930.3546\nQ fever - Netherlands: monitoring 20100103.0028\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (19): update 20091229.4375\nQ fever - Australia: (SA), laboratory-acquired 20091225.4345\nQ fever, caprine - Netherlands: (LI) 20090331.1230\nQ fever - Netherlands: sheep & goat vaccination 20090228.0841\n2007\n----\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (03): fatality 20070730.2449\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (02): abattoir 20070713.2244\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. There\nare unconfirmed reports of up to 6 cases presenting at the Coffs\nHarbour Health Campus during the past 6 weeks.\n\nQ Fever is a disease contracted by infection from bacteria found\ntypically in the urine, feces, or milk from cattle and sheep. The\ndirector of public health for the North Coast, Paul Corben, said there\nwas a vaccine available for those working with animals, like vets and\nabattoir workers, but it was a 2-step process which involved a skin\ntest and blood sample before the doctor made a decision, because if\nthe person showed evidence of prior immunity, the vaccine caused \"a\nnasty local reaction.\"\n\nMr Corbin said while they had seen a couple of probable or confirmed\ncases of Q fever from south of Coffs Harbour to as far north as\nWoolgoolga, there was nothing that warranted extra follow-up or\nindicated a higher risk than normal. He said the North Coast averaged\nabout 40 confirmed cases of Q fever annually.\n\nA reader who contacted The Advocate said one man from Emerald Beach\nhad died and she had almost lost a friend this week [week of 28 Mar\n2011], who was now in the intensive care unit. She believed the cases\nwere focused on the northern beaches. \"It is not where you would\nnormally find Q fever,\" Mr Corben said. \"But it is a hardy bacterium\nand very persistent in the environment. We have done normal follow-up\nand there is nothing that links those people together. We are still\nwaiting for some lab reports. You traditionally think of Q fever as\nassociated with farm areas but there have been recent outbreaks in\nother areas.\n\nMr Corben said Q fever was particularly likely to be associated with\nanimal birthing times.\n\n[Byline: Belinda Scott]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Coffs Coast area of New South Wales can be seen on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0DPp. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[Q fever was first described in Australia where this posting\noriginates. It was called \"Query fever\" because the causative agent\nwas initially unknown. _Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was\ndiscovered in 1937. This organism is an agent that can be resistant to\nheat and desiccation and highly infectious by the aerosol route. A\nsingle inhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in\n[non-human] primates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was\nfound to be 1.7 organisms (1).\n\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including\nother species of livestock and domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does\nnot usually cause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion\nin goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection.\nOrganisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals.\nMost importantly, during birthing the organisms are shed in high\nnumbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta. Contact with\ncontaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small-cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication (along with the less resistant\nlarge-cell form) and are metabolically dormant and spore-like (3).\n\nThe Q fever organism is a category B bioterrorism agent and, in fact,\nalthough not thought to be related to bioterrorism, was spread by mail\nin a post office in the UK in 1987 (4).\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. Instances of other modes of transmission to humans,\nincluding tick bites and human to human transmission, are rare.\n\nAn earlier outbreak of infection in 51 persons in Scotland, UK, was\ntied to a meat processing plant and appeared to spread via aerosol for\nat least 0.5 mi (0.8 km).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C: An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of \"Q fever.\" Pub Hlth Rep 1041; 56:\n1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D: Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12: 518-53.\n(available at http://cmr.asm.org/cgi/content/full/12/4/518).\n3. Norlander L: Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes\nInfect 2000; 2:417-24 (abstract available at\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10817644).\n4. Winner SJ, Eglin RP, Moore VI, Mayon-White RT: An outbreak of Q\nfever affecting postal workers in Oxfordshire. J Infect 1987; 14(3):\n255-61 (abstract available at\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3585037). - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Germany: (NW, HE) human, animal 20110223.0604\nQ fever - Netherlands: human, animal 20110213.0490\n2010\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (31): (NB) investigation report 20100930.3546\nQ fever - Netherlands: monitoring 20100103.0028\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (19): update 20091229.4375\nQ fever - Australia: (SA), laboratory-acquired 20091225.4345\nQ fever, caprine - Netherlands: (LI) 20090331.1230\nQ fever - Netherlands: sheep & goat vaccination 20090228.0841\n2007\n----\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (03): fatality 20070730.2449\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (02): abattoir 20070713.2244\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\n.................................................sb/ll/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1937-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "1041-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oxfordshire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Emerald Beach", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "689109", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Australia: (NS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=689109", "date": "2011-04-01 10:11:24", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA: (NEW SOUTH WALES)\n**************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 30 Mar 2011\nSource: The Coffs Coast Advocate [edited]\nhttp://www.coffscoastadvocate.com.au/story/2011/03/30/six-coffs-coast-q-fever-victims-found-infection/\n\n\nReports of the little known Q fever on the Coffs Coast [New South\nWales] are causing concern to residents and health authorities. There\nare unconfirmed reports of up to 6 cases presenting at the Coffs\nHarbour Health Campus during the past 6 weeks.\n\nQ Fever is a disease contracted by infection from bacteria found\ntypically in the urine, feces, or milk from cattle and sheep. The\ndirector of public health for the North Coast, Paul Corben, said there\nwas a vaccine available for those working with animals, like vets and\nabattoir workers, but it was a 2-step process which involved a skin\ntest and blood sample before the doctor made a decision, because if\nthe person showed evidence of prior immunity, the vaccine caused \"a\nnasty local reaction.\"\n\nMr Corbin said while they had seen a couple of probable or confirmed\ncases of Q fever from south of Coffs Harbour to as far north as\nWoolgoolga, there was nothing that warranted extra follow-up or\nindicated a higher risk than normal. He said the North Coast averaged\nabout 40 confirmed cases of Q fever annually.\n\nA reader who contacted The Advocate said one man from Emerald Beach\nhad died and she had almost lost a friend this week [week of 28 Mar\n2011], who was now in the intensive care unit. She believed the cases\nwere focused on the northern beaches. \"It is not where you would\nnormally find Q fever,\" Mr Corben said. \"But it is a hardy bacterium\nand very persistent in the environment. We have done normal follow-up\nand there is nothing that links those people together. We are still\nwaiting for some lab reports. You traditionally think of Q fever as\nassociated with farm areas but there have been recent outbreaks in\nother areas.\n\nMr Corben said Q fever was particularly likely to be associated with\nanimal birthing times.\n\n[Byline: Belinda Scott]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The Coffs Coast area of New South Wales can be seen on the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/0DPp. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\n\n[Q fever was first described in Australia where this posting\noriginates. It was called \"Query fever\" because the causative agent\nwas initially unknown. _Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was\ndiscovered in 1937. This organism is an agent that can be resistant to\nheat and desiccation and highly infectious by the aerosol route. A\nsingle inhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in\n[non-human] primates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was\nfound to be 1.7 organisms (1).\n\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including\nother species of livestock and domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does\nnot usually cause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion\nin goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection.\nOrganisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals.\nMost importantly, during birthing the organisms are shed in high\nnumbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta. Contact with\ncontaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small-cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication (along with the less resistant\nlarge-cell form) and are metabolically dormant and spore-like (3).\n\nThe Q fever organism is a category B bioterrorism agent and, in fact,\nalthough not thought to be related to bioterrorism, was spread by mail\nin a post office in the UK in 1987 (4).\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. Instances of other modes of transmission to humans,\nincluding tick bites and human to human transmission, are rare.\n\nAn earlier outbreak of infection in 51 persons in Scotland, UK, was\ntied to a meat processing plant and appeared to spread via aerosol for\nat least 0.5 mi (0.8 km).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C: An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of \"Q fever.\" Pub Hlth Rep 1041; 56:\n1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D: Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12: 518-53.\n(available at http://cmr.asm.org/cgi/content/full/12/4/518).\n3. Norlander L: Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes\nInfect 2000; 2:417-24 (abstract available at\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10817644).\n4. J Infect 1987; 14(3):\n255-61 (abstract available at\nhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3585037). - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Germany: (NW, HE) human, animal 20110223.0604\nQ fever - Netherlands: human, animal 20110213.0490\n2010\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (31): (NB) investigation report 20100930.3546\nQ fever - Netherlands: monitoring 20100103.0028\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (19): update 20091229.4375\nQ fever - Australia: (SA), laboratory-acquired 20091225.4345\nQ fever, caprine - Netherlands: (LI) 20090331.1230\nQ fever - Netherlands: sheep & goat vaccination 20090228.0841\n2007\n----\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (03): fatality 20070730.2449\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (02): abattoir 20070713.2244\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Only\n9 holdings remain to be heard from. This was reported by ministers\nVerburg (Agriculture) and Klink (Health) today [1 Jun 2010] in a\nletter to the House.\n\nAlleviation of the measures regarding Q fever control will become\nfeasible only when all commercial farms have completed their full\nvaccination. Until then, the general ban upon breeding and\nintroduction of animals into such farms, as well as the biweekly\ntank-milk monitoring, will be maintained.\n\nSituation of human epidemic:\n----------------------------\nThe rapid increase in the number of reported cases, seen during\nApril-May 2009, has not (yet) been observed in 2010. This may be an\nindication of the absence, this year, of the disease peaking. The\nministers write that this is a hopeful sign, but drawing conclusions,\nbased upon these data, is still premature.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Though yet to be fully scrutinised and confirmed, the above promising\nupdate is good news, probably justifying the extreme measures applied.\nHopefully, this trend will be maintained when breeding is renewed and\nduring the next parturition season in goats and sheep.\n\nThe conclusions and recommendations of the Dutch Q fever Evaluation\nCommittee, nominated by the 2 ministers and chaired by Prof. van Dijk,\nare expected in September 2010 (following the extension of the\ninvestigation period). - Only\n9 holdings remain to be heard from. This was reported by ministers\nVerburg (Agriculture) and Klink (Health) today [1 Jun 2010] in a\nletter to the House.\n\nAlleviation of the measures regarding Q fever control will become\nfeasible only when all commercial farms have completed their full\nvaccination. Until then, the general ban upon breeding and\nintroduction of animals into such farms, as well as the biweekly\ntank-milk monitoring, will be maintained.\n\nSituation of human epidemic:\n----------------------------\nThe rapid increase in the number of reported cases, seen during\nApril-May 2009, has not (yet) been observed in 2010. This may be an\nindication of the absence, this year, of the disease peaking. The\nministers write that this is a hopeful sign, but drawing conclusions,\nbased upon these data, is still premature.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Though yet to be fully scrutinised and confirmed, the above promising\nupdate is good news, probably justifying the extreme measures applied.\nHopefully, this trend will be maintained when breeding is renewed and\nduring the next parturition season in goats and sheep.\n\nThe conclusions and recommendations of the Dutch Q fever Evaluation\nCommittee, nominated by the 2 ministers and chaired by Prof. van Dijk,\nare expected in September 2010 (following the extension of the\ninvestigation period). - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (27): risk assessment, Europe 20100525.1742\nQ fever - Netherlands (26): update, EFSA 20100512.1544\nQ fever - Netherlands (23): scientific advice, update 20100324.0945\nQ fever - Only\n9 holdings remain to be heard from. This was reported by ministers\nVerburg (Agriculture) and Klink (Health) today [1 Jun 2010] in a\nletter to the House.\n\nAlleviation of the measures regarding Q fever control will become\nfeasible only when all commercial farms have completed their full\nvaccination. This may be an\nindication of the absence, this year, of the disease peaking. The\nministers write that this is a hopeful sign, but drawing conclusions,\nbased upon these data, is still premature.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Though yet to be fully scrutinised and confirmed, the above promising\nupdate is good news, probably justifying the extreme measures applied.\nHopefully, this trend will be maintained when breeding is renewed and\nduring the next parturition season in goats and sheep.\n\nThe conclusions and recommendations of the Dutch Q fever Evaluation\nCommittee, nominated by the 2 ministers and chaired by Prof. van Dijk,\nare expected in September 2010 (following the extension of the\ninvestigation period). - The\nministers write that this is a hopeful sign, but drawing conclusions,\nbased upon these data, is still premature.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Though yet to be fully scrutinised and confirmed, the above promising\nupdate is good news, probably justifying the extreme measures applied.\nHopefully, this trend will be maintained when breeding is renewed and\nduring the next parturition season in goats and sheep.\n\nThe conclusions and recommendations of the Dutch Q fever Evaluation\nCommittee, nominated by the 2 ministers and chaired by Prof. van Dijk,\nare expected in September 2010 (following the extension of the\ninvestigation period). - Only\n9 holdings remain to be heard from. This was reported by ministers\nVerburg (Agriculture) and Klink (Health) today [1 Jun 2010] in a\nletter to the House.\n\nAlleviation of the measures regarding Q fever control will become\nfeasible only when all commercial farms have completed their full\nvaccination. Until then, the general ban upon breeding and\nintroduction of animals into such farms, as well as the biweekly\ntank-milk monitoring, will be maintained.\n\nSituation of human epidemic:\n----------------------------\nThe rapid increase in the number of reported cases, seen during\nApril-May 2009, has not (yet) been observed in 2010. This may be an\nindication of the absence, this year, of the disease peaking. The\nministers write that this is a hopeful sign, but drawing conclusions,\nbased upon these data, is still premature.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Though yet to be fully scrutinised and confirmed, the above promising\nupdate is good news, probably justifying the extreme measures applied.\nHopefully, this trend will be maintained when breeding is renewed and\nduring the next parturition season in goats and sheep.\n\nThe conclusions and recommendations of the Dutch Q fever Evaluation\nCommittee, nominated by the 2 ministers and chaired by Prof. van Dijk,\nare expected in September 2010 (following the extension of the\ninvestigation period). - Only\n9 holdings remain to be heard from. This was reported by ministers\nVerburg (Agriculture) and Klink (Health) today [1 Jun 2010] in a\nletter to the House.\n\nAlleviation of the measures regarding Q fever control will become\nfeasible only when all commercial farms have completed their full\nvaccination. Until then, the general ban upon breeding and\nintroduction of animals into such farms, as well as the biweekly\ntank-milk monitoring, will be maintained.\n\nSituation of human epidemic:\n----------------------------\nThe rapid increase in the number of reported cases, seen during\nApril-May 2009, has not (yet) been observed in 2010. This may be an\nindication of the absence, this year, of the disease peaking. The\nministers write that this is a hopeful sign, but drawing conclusions,\nbased upon these data, is still premature.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Though yet to be fully scrutinised and confirmed, the above promising\nupdate is good news, probably justifying the extreme measures applied.\nHopefully, this trend will be maintained when breeding is renewed and\nduring the next parturition season in goats and sheep.\n\nThe conclusions and recommendations of the Dutch Q fever Evaluation\nCommittee, nominated by the 2 ministers and chaired by Prof. van Dijk,\nare expected in September 2010 (following the extension of the\ninvestigation period). - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-09-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-23 00:00:00", "2021-03-21 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "belgium", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "434061", "headline": "PRO/AH> Q fever - Netherlands (27): risk assessment, Europe", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=434061", "date": "2010-03-10 09:00:03", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (20): CANADIAN POLICY UPDATE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 8 Mar 2010\nFrom: Paula Menzies [edited]\n<pmenzies@uoguelph.ca>\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Q fever - Netherlands (18): update & review 20100303.0703\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n[Following the posting above of minutes taken from Paula Menzies'\npresentation of 25 Feb 2010 at the Breda Q fever conference, the\noriginal text of the presentation has been kindly submitted by the\nauthor to replace previous versions. Dr Menzies is gratefully\nacknowledged. - Mod.AS]\n\nPaula Menzies (Canada): Q fever and coxiellosis in Canada\n---------------------------------------------------------\nAlthough small ruminant numbers are lower in Canada than in other\ncountries, in Ontario sheep and goats are often raised in confinement\nsituations with high stocking densities.\n\nReported human Q fever (notifiable) cases are low in Ontario.\nCoxiellosis (Q fever) is not reportable in animals, but annually\nnotifiable. No action is taken by the federal or provincial\ngovernments after diagnosis. No routine surveillance in animals is\ncurrently performed.\n\nOutbreaks of human Q fever are usually related to visiting farms and\nfairs and outbreaks of abortion in sheep and goats due to _Coxiella_\n-- but human disease has been associated with parturient cats with no\ncontact with livestock. No human cases have been linked to infection\nin cattle; but there are links with wildlife, such as, snaring hares.\nAfter the cod fishery collapsed, Newfoundland imported goats to start\na dairy goat industry. The outbreak of coxiellosis associated with\nmixing of these introduced animals resulted in 80 cases of human Q\nfever in the surrounding community.\n\nCoxiellosis -- the disease in animals -- is unlikely to become\nreportable in Canada. Q fever in humans is likely under-diagnosed in\ngeneral. Better communication of the risks of this infection to\nmedical health professionals and the public in general, is needed. A\nsero-prevalence study in sheep and goat flocks and their caregivers\nis commencing in May [2010] in Ontario. This will help to clarify the\nimportance of the infection in this province.\n\n--\nDr Paula I Menzies\nAssoc Professor Dip.ECSRHM\nSmall Ruminant Research Coordinator\nRuminant Health Management Group\nDepartment of Population Medicine\nOntario Veterinary College, University of Guelph\nGuelph, Ontario Canada N1G 2W1\n<pmenzies@uoguelph.ca>\n\n[The CFIA (Canadian Food Inspection Agency) website\n(<http://www.inspection.gc.ca/english/anima/disemala/guidee.shtml>)\nincludes 3 lists of animal diseases:\n\n1. A list of the (32) reportable animal diseases (as mentioned by Dr\nMenzies, Q fever not included).\nAnimal owners, veterinarians and laboratories are required to\nimmediately report the presence of an animal that is contaminated or\nsuspected of being contaminated with one of these diseases to a CFIA\ndistrict veterinarian. Control or eradication measures will be\napplied immediately.\n\n2. Immediately notifiable diseases (for laboratories only).\nIn general, immediately notifiable diseases are diseases exotic to\nCanada for which there are no control or eradication programs.\nThe CFIA can undertake control measures for such diseases when\nnotified of their presence in Canada. This category also includes\nsome rare indigenous diseases. A herd or flock of origin must be\ncertified as being free from these diseases in order to meet import\nrequirements of trading partners.\n\n3. Annually notifiable diseases (for laboratories only; Q fever included).\nAnnually notifiable diseases are diseases for which Canada must\nsubmit an annual report to the World Organisation for Animal Health\n(OIE) indicating their presence within Canada. In general, they are\ndiseases that are present in Canada, but are not classified as\nreportable or immediately notifiable.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (19): Canadian policy clarified 20100306.0742\nQ fever - Netherlands (18): update & review 20100303.0703\n...................................arn/mj/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "426126", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands (26): update, EFSA", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=426126", "date": "2010-03-10 09:00:03", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (20): CANADIAN POLICY UPDATE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 8 Mar 2010\nFrom: Paula Menzies [edited]\n<pmenzies@uoguelph.ca>\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Q fever - Netherlands (18): update & review 20100303.0703\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n[Following the posting above of minutes taken from Paula Menzies'\npresentation of 25 Feb 2010 at the Breda Q fever conference, the\noriginal text of the presentation has been kindly submitted by the\nauthor to replace previous versions. Dr Menzies is gratefully\nacknowledged. - Mod.AS]\n\nPaula Menzies (Canada): Q fever and coxiellosis in Canada\n---------------------------------------------------------\nAlthough small ruminant numbers are lower in Canada than in other\ncountries, in Ontario sheep and goats are often raised in confinement\nsituations with high stocking densities.\n\nReported human Q fever (notifiable) cases are low in Ontario.\nCoxiellosis (Q fever) is not reportable in animals, but annually\nnotifiable. No action is taken by the federal or provincial\ngovernments after diagnosis. No routine surveillance in animals is\ncurrently performed.\n\nOutbreaks of human Q fever are usually related to visiting farms and\nfairs and outbreaks of abortion in sheep and goats due to _Coxiella_\n-- but human disease has been associated with parturient cats with no\ncontact with livestock. No human cases have been linked to infection\nin cattle; but there are links with wildlife, such as, snaring hares.\nAfter the cod fishery collapsed, Newfoundland imported goats to start\na dairy goat industry. The outbreak of coxiellosis associated with\nmixing of these introduced animals resulted in 80 cases of human Q\nfever in the surrounding community.\n\nCoxiellosis -- the disease in animals -- is unlikely to become\nreportable in Canada. Q fever in humans is likely under-diagnosed in\ngeneral. Better communication of the risks of this infection to\nmedical health professionals and the public in general, is needed. A\nsero-prevalence study in sheep and goat flocks and their caregivers\nis commencing in May [2010] in Ontario. This will help to clarify the\nimportance of the infection in this province.\n\n--\nDr Paula I Menzies\nAssoc Professor Dip.ECSRHM\nSmall Ruminant Research Coordinator\nRuminant Health Management Group\nDepartment of Population Medicine\nOntario Veterinary College, University of Guelph\nGuelph, Ontario Canada N1G 2W1\n<pmenzies@uoguelph.ca>\n\n[The CFIA (Canadian Food Inspection Agency) website\n(<http://www.inspection.gc.ca/english/anima/disemala/guidee.shtml>)\nincludes 3 lists of animal diseases:\n\n1. A list of the (32) reportable animal diseases (as mentioned by Dr\nMenzies, Q fever not included).\nAnimal owners, veterinarians and laboratories are required to\nimmediately report the presence of an animal that is contaminated or\nsuspected of being contaminated with one of these diseases to a CFIA\ndistrict veterinarian. Control or eradication measures will be\napplied immediately.\n\n2. Immediately notifiable diseases (for laboratories only).\nIn general, immediately notifiable diseases are diseases exotic to\nCanada for which there are no control or eradication programs.\nThe CFIA can undertake control measures for such diseases when\nnotified of their presence in Canada. This category also includes\nsome rare indigenous diseases. A herd or flock of origin must be\ncertified as being free from these diseases in order to meet import\nrequirements of trading partners.\n\n3. Annually notifiable diseases (for laboratories only; Q fever included).\nAnnually notifiable diseases are diseases for which Canada must\nsubmit an annual report to the World Organisation for Animal Health\n(OIE) indicating their presence within Canada. In general, they are\ndiseases that are present in Canada, but are not classified as\nreportable or immediately notifiable.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (19): Canadian policy clarified 20100306.0742\nQ fever - Netherlands (18): update & review 20100303.0703\n...................................arn/mj/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Dr Menzies is gratefully\nacknowledged. - Mod.AS]\n\nPaula Menzies (Canada): Q fever and coxiellosis in Canada\n---------------------------------------------------------\nAlthough small ruminant numbers are lower in Canada than in other\ncountries, in Ontario sheep and goats are often raised in confinement\nsituations with high stocking densities.\n\nReported human Q fever (notifiable) cases are low in Ontario.\nCoxiellosis (Q fever) is not reportable in animals, but annually\nnotifiable. No action is taken by the federal or provincial\ngovernments after diagnosis. No routine surveillance in animals is\ncurrently performed.\n\nOutbreaks of human Q fever are usually related to visiting farms and\nfairs and outbreaks of abortion in sheep and goats due to _Coxiella_\n-- but human disease has been associated with parturient cats with no\ncontact with livestock. No human cases have been linked to infection\nin cattle; but there are links with wildlife, such as, snaring hares.\nAfter the cod fishery collapsed, Newfoundland imported goats to start\na dairy goat industry. The outbreak of coxiellosis associated with\nmixing of these introduced animals resulted in 80 cases of human Q\nfever in the surrounding community.\n\nCoxiellosis -- the disease in animals -- is unlikely to become\nreportable in Canada. Q fever in humans is likely under-diagnosed in\ngeneral. Better communication of the risks of this infection to\nmedical health professionals and the public in general, is needed. A\nsero-prevalence study in sheep and goat flocks and their caregivers\nis commencing in May [2010] in Ontario. This will help to clarify the\nimportance of the infection in this province.\n\n--\nDr Paula I Menzies\nAssoc Professor Dip.ECSRHM\nSmall Ruminant Research Coordinator\nRuminant Health Management Group\nDepartment of Population Medicine\nOntario Veterinary College, University of Guelph\nGuelph, Ontario Canada N1G 2W1\n<pmenzies@uoguelph.ca>\n\n[The CFIA (Canadian Food Inspection Agency) website\n(<http://www.inspection.gc.ca/english/anima/disemala/guidee.shtml>)\nincludes 3 lists of animal diseases:\n\n1. A list of the (32) reportable animal diseases (as mentioned by Dr\nMenzies, Q fever not included).\nAnimal owners, veterinarians and laboratories are required to\nimmediately report the presence of an animal that is contaminated or\nsuspected of being contaminated with one of these diseases to a CFIA\ndistrict veterinarian. Control or eradication measures will be\napplied immediately.\n\n2. Immediately notifiable diseases (for laboratories only).\nIn general, immediately notifiable diseases are diseases exotic to\nCanada for which there are no control or eradication programs.\nThe CFIA can undertake control measures for such diseases when\nnotified of their presence in Canada. This category also includes\nsome rare indigenous diseases. A herd or flock of origin must be\ncertified as being free from these diseases in order to meet import\nrequirements of trading partners.\n\n3. Annually notifiable diseases (for laboratories only; Q fever included).\nAnnually notifiable diseases are diseases for which Canada must\nsubmit an annual report to the World Organisation for Animal Health\n(OIE) indicating their presence within Canada. In general, they are\ndiseases that are present in Canada, but are not classified as\nreportable or immediately notifiable.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (19): Canadian policy clarified 20100306.0742\nQ fever - Netherlands (18): update & review 20100303.0703\n...................................arn/mj/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nDonate to ProMED-mail. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-02-25 00:00:00", "2021-05-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ontario", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "411770", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands (24): update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=411770", "date": "2010-03-10 09:00:03", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (20): CANADIAN POLICY UPDATE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 8 Mar 2010\nFrom: Paula Menzies [edited]\n<pmenzies@uoguelph.ca>\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Q fever - Netherlands (18): update & review 20100303.0703\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n[Following the posting above of minutes taken from Paula Menzies'\npresentation of 25 Feb 2010 at the Breda Q fever conference, the\noriginal text of the presentation has been kindly submitted by the\nauthor to replace previous versions. Dr Menzies is gratefully\nacknowledged. - Mod.AS]\n\nPaula Menzies (Canada): Q fever and coxiellosis in Canada\n---------------------------------------------------------\nAlthough small ruminant numbers are lower in Canada than in other\ncountries, in Ontario sheep and goats are often raised in confinement\nsituations with high stocking densities.\n\nReported human Q fever (notifiable) cases are low in Ontario.\nCoxiellosis (Q fever) is not reportable in animals, but annually\nnotifiable. No action is taken by the federal or provincial\ngovernments after diagnosis. No routine surveillance in animals is\ncurrently performed.\n\nOutbreaks of human Q fever are usually related to visiting farms and\nfairs and outbreaks of abortion in sheep and goats due to _Coxiella_\n-- but human disease has been associated with parturient cats with no\ncontact with livestock. No human cases have been linked to infection\nin cattle; but there are links with wildlife, such as, snaring hares.\nAfter the cod fishery collapsed, Newfoundland imported goats to start\na dairy goat industry. The outbreak of coxiellosis associated with\nmixing of these introduced animals resulted in 80 cases of human Q\nfever in the surrounding community.\n\nCoxiellosis -- the disease in animals -- is unlikely to become\nreportable in Canada. Q fever in humans is likely under-diagnosed in\ngeneral. Better communication of the risks of this infection to\nmedical health professionals and the public in general, is needed. A\nsero-prevalence study in sheep and goat flocks and their caregivers\nis commencing in May [2010] in Ontario. This will help to clarify the\nimportance of the infection in this province.\n\n--\nDr Paula I Menzies\nAssoc Professor Dip.ECSRHM\nSmall Ruminant Research Coordinator\nRuminant Health Management Group\nDepartment of Population Medicine\nOntario Veterinary College, University of Guelph\nGuelph, Ontario Canada N1G 2W1\n<pmenzies@uoguelph.ca>\n\n[The CFIA (Canadian Food Inspection Agency) website\n(<http://www.inspection.gc.ca/english/anima/disemala/guidee.shtml>)\nincludes 3 lists of animal diseases:\n\n1. A list of the (32) reportable animal diseases (as mentioned by Dr\nMenzies, Q fever not included).\nAnimal owners, veterinarians and laboratories are required to\nimmediately report the presence of an animal that is contaminated or\nsuspected of being contaminated with one of these diseases to a CFIA\ndistrict veterinarian. Control or eradication measures will be\napplied immediately.\n\n2. Immediately notifiable diseases (for laboratories only).\nIn general, immediately notifiable diseases are diseases exotic to\nCanada for which there are no control or eradication programs.\nThe CFIA can undertake control measures for such diseases when\nnotified of their presence in Canada. This category also includes\nsome rare indigenous diseases. A herd or flock of origin must be\ncertified as being free from these diseases in order to meet import\nrequirements of trading partners.\n\n3. Annually notifiable diseases (for laboratories only; Q fever included).\nAnnually notifiable diseases are diseases for which Canada must\nsubmit an annual report to the World Organisation for Animal Health\n(OIE) indicating their presence within Canada. In general, they are\ndiseases that are present in Canada, but are not classified as\nreportable or immediately notifiable.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (19): Canadian policy clarified 20100306.0742\nQ fever - Netherlands (18): update & review 20100303.0703\n...................................arn/mj/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
