Dr Menzies is gratefully\nacknowledged. - Mod.AS]\n\nPaula Menzies (Canada): Q fever and coxiellosis in Canada\n---------------------------------------------------------\nAlthough small ruminant numbers are lower in Canada than in other\ncountries, in Ontario sheep and goats are often raised in confinement\nsituations with high stocking densities.\n\nReported human Q fever (notifiable) cases are low in Ontario.\nCoxiellosis (Q fever) is not reportable in animals, but annually\nnotifiable. No action is taken by the federal or provincial\ngovernments after diagnosis. No routine surveillance in animals is\ncurrently performed.\n\nOutbreaks of human Q fever are usually related to visiting farms and\nfairs and outbreaks of abortion in sheep and goats due to _Coxiella_\n-- but human disease has been associated with parturient cats with no\ncontact with livestock. No human cases have been linked to infection\nin cattle; but there are links with wildlife, such as, snaring hares.\nAfter the cod fishery collapsed, Newfoundland imported goats to start\na dairy goat industry. The outbreak of coxiellosis associated with\nmixing of these introduced animals resulted in 80 cases of human Q\nfever in the surrounding community.\n\nCoxiellosis -- the disease in animals -- is unlikely to become\nreportable in Canada. Q fever in humans is likely under-diagnosed in\ngeneral. Better communication of the risks of this infection to\nmedical health professionals and the public in general, is needed. A\nsero-prevalence study in sheep and goat flocks and their caregivers\nis commencing in May [2010] in Ontario. This will help to clarify the\nimportance of the infection in this province.\n\n--\nDr Paula I Menzies\nAssoc Professor Dip.ECSRHM\nSmall Ruminant Research Coordinator\nRuminant Health Management Group\nDepartment of Population Medicine\nOntario Veterinary College, University of Guelph\nGuelph, Ontario Canada N1G 2W1\n<pmenzies@uoguelph.ca>\n\n[The CFIA (Canadian Food Inspection Agency) website\n(<http://www.inspection.gc.ca/english/anima/disemala/guidee.shtml>)\nincludes 3 lists of animal diseases:\n\n1. A list of the (32) reportable animal diseases (as mentioned by Dr\nMenzies, Q fever not included).\nAnimal owners, veterinarians and laboratories are required to\nimmediately report the presence of an animal that is contaminated or\nsuspected of being contaminated with one of these diseases to a CFIA\ndistrict veterinarian. Control or eradication measures will be\napplied immediately.\n\n2. Immediately notifiable diseases (for laboratories only).\nIn general, immediately notifiable diseases are diseases exotic to\nCanada for which there are no control or eradication programs.\nThe CFIA can undertake control measures for such diseases when\nnotified of their presence in Canada. This category also includes\nsome rare indigenous diseases. A herd or flock of origin must be\ncertified as being free from these diseases in order to meet import\nrequirements of trading partners.\n\n3. Annually notifiable diseases (for laboratories only; Q fever included).\nAnnually notifiable diseases are diseases for which Canada must\nsubmit an annual report to the World Organisation for Animal Health\n(OIE) indicating their presence within Canada. In general, they are\ndiseases that are present in Canada, but are not classified as\nreportable or immediately notifiable.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (19): Canadian policy clarified 20100306.0742\nQ fever - Netherlands (18): update & review 20100303.0703\n...................................arn/mj/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Dr Menzies is gratefully\nacknowledged. - Mod.AS]\n\nPaula Menzies (Canada): Q fever and coxiellosis in Canada\n---------------------------------------------------------\nAlthough small ruminant numbers are lower in Canada than in other\ncountries, in Ontario sheep and goats are often raised in confinement\nsituations with high stocking densities.\n\nReported human Q fever (notifiable) cases are low in Ontario.\nCoxiellosis (Q fever) is not reportable in animals, but annually\nnotifiable. No action is taken by the federal or provincial\ngovernments after diagnosis. No routine surveillance in animals is\ncurrently performed.\n\nOutbreaks of human Q fever are usually related to visiting farms and\nfairs and outbreaks of abortion in sheep and goats due to _Coxiella_\n-- but human disease has been associated with parturient cats with no\ncontact with livestock. No human cases have been linked to infection\nin cattle; but there are links with wildlife, such as, snaring hares.\nAfter the cod fishery collapsed, Newfoundland imported goats to start\na dairy goat industry. The outbreak of coxiellosis associated with\nmixing of these introduced animals resulted in 80 cases of human Q\nfever in the surrounding community.\n\nCoxiellosis -- the disease in animals -- is unlikely to become\nreportable in Canada. Q fever in humans is likely under-diagnosed in\ngeneral. Better communication of the risks of this infection to\nmedical health professionals and the public in general, is needed. A\nsero-prevalence study in sheep and goat flocks and their caregivers\nis commencing in May [2010] in Ontario. This will help to clarify the\nimportance of the infection in this province.\n\n--\nDr Paula I Menzies\nAssoc Professor Dip.ECSRHM\nSmall Ruminant Research Coordinator\nRuminant Health Management Group\nDepartment of Population Medicine\nOntario Veterinary College, University of Guelph\nGuelph, Ontario Canada N1G 2W1\n<pmenzies@uoguelph.ca>\n\n[The CFIA (Canadian Food Inspection Agency) website\n(<http://www.inspection.gc.ca/english/anima/disemala/guidee.shtml>)\nincludes 3 lists of animal diseases:\n\n1. A list of the (32) reportable animal diseases (as mentioned by Dr\nMenzies, Q fever not included).\nAnimal owners, veterinarians and laboratories are required to\nimmediately report the presence of an animal that is contaminated or\nsuspected of being contaminated with one of these diseases to a CFIA\ndistrict veterinarian. Control or eradication measures will be\napplied immediately.\n\n2. Immediately notifiable diseases (for laboratories only).\nIn general, immediately notifiable diseases are diseases exotic to\nCanada for which there are no control or eradication programs.\nThe CFIA can undertake control measures for such diseases when\nnotified of their presence in Canada. This category also includes\nsome rare indigenous diseases. A herd or flock of origin must be\ncertified as being free from these diseases in order to meet import\nrequirements of trading partners.\n\n3. Annually notifiable diseases (for laboratories only; Q fever included).\nAnnually notifiable diseases are diseases for which Canada must\nsubmit an annual report to the World Organisation for Animal Health\n(OIE) indicating their presence within Canada. In general, they are\ndiseases that are present in Canada, but are not classified as\nreportable or immediately notifiable.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (19): Canadian policy clarified 20100306.0742\nQ fever - Netherlands (18): update & review 20100303.0703\n...................................arn/mj/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. A list of the (32) reportable animal diseases (as mentioned by Dr\nMenzies, Q fever not included).\nAnimal owners, veterinarians and laboratories are required to\nimmediately report the presence of an animal that is contaminated or\nsuspected of being contaminated with one of these diseases to a CFIA\ndistrict veterinarian. Control or eradication measures will be\napplied immediately.\n\n2. Immediately notifiable diseases (for laboratories only).\nIn general, immediately notifiable diseases are diseases exotic to\nCanada for which there are no control or eradication programs.\nThe CFIA can undertake control measures for such diseases when\nnotified of their presence in Canada. This category also includes\nsome rare indigenous diseases. A herd or flock of origin must be\ncertified as being free from these diseases in order to meet import\nrequirements of trading partners.\n\n3. Annually notifiable diseases (for laboratories only; Q fever included).\nAnnually notifiable diseases are diseases for which Canada must\nsubmit an annual report to the World Organisation for Animal Health\n(OIE) indicating their presence within Canada. A\nsero-prevalence study in sheep and goat flocks and their caregivers\nis commencing in May [2010] in Ontario. This will help to clarify the\nimportance of the infection in this province.\n\n--\nDr Paula I Menzies\nAssoc Professor Dip.ECSRHM\nSmall Ruminant Research Coordinator\nRuminant Health Management Group\nDepartment of Population Medicine\nOntario Veterinary College, University of Guelph\nGuelph, Ontario Canada N1G 2W1\n<pmenzies@uoguelph.ca>\n\n[The CFIA (Canadian Food Inspection Agency) website\n(<http://www.inspection.gc.ca/english/anima/disemala/guidee.shtml>)\nincludes 3 lists of animal diseases:\n\n1. A list of the (32) reportable animal diseases (as mentioned by Dr\nMenzies, Q fever not included).\nAnimal owners, veterinarians and laboratories are required to\nimmediately report the presence of an animal that is contaminated or\nsuspected of being contaminated with one of these diseases to a CFIA\ndistrict veterinarian. Control or eradication measures will be\napplied immediately.\n\n2. Immediately notifiable diseases (for laboratories only).\nIn general, immediately notifiable diseases are diseases exotic to\nCanada for which there are no control or eradication programs.\nThe CFIA can undertake control measures for such diseases when\nnotified of their presence in Canada. This category also includes\nsome rare indigenous diseases. A herd or flock of origin must be\ncertified as being free from these diseases in order to meet import\nrequirements of trading partners.\n\n3. Annually notifiable diseases (for laboratories only; Q fever included).\nAnnually notifiable diseases are diseases for which Canada must\nsubmit an annual report to the World Organisation for Animal Health\n(OIE) indicating their presence within Canada. In general, they are\ndiseases that are present in Canada, but are not classified as\nreportable or immediately notifiable.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (19): Canadian policy clarified 20100306.0742\nQ fever - Netherlands (18): update & review 20100303.0703\n...................................arn/mj/lm\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. In Hilvarenbeek, this refers to a\nfarm including 1050 dairy goats, in Esch 3000 and in Liessel 1030\ndairy goats. The declaration followed the identification of the Q\nfever bacterium in each of the 3 farms in 2 separate tests, performed\nin both the Animal Health Service (GD) laboratory as well as in the\nCentral Veterinary Institute (CVI), in 2 different milk samples.\n\nThe Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority (VWA) of the Ministry\nof Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality (LNV) has placed warning\nsigns on the farms. The full addresses and the locations of the\ninfected farms will be made public on the web-site of the VWA.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In total, 71 dairy farms have been found infected with _Coxiella\nburnetii_ in the Netherlands since October 2009, of which there are\n70 goat farms and one sheep farm. The total number of commercial\ndairy goat and sheep farms in the Netherlands is approximately 450.\n\nAll pregnant animals on the 1st 68 infected farms have been culled,\nto be followed by the pregnant goats in the 3 newly-added farms.\nThese 3 farms are located in the province North Brabant, the Dutch\nprovince with the highest density of dairy goats. The total number of\nculled animals will have exceeded, by now, 40 000.\n\nThe detailed list and map of 68 Q-fever infected farms, as of 8 Feb\n2010, are available at:\n<http://www.vwa.nl/portal/page?_pageid=119,2025799&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_document_id=932575&p_node_id=2167182&p_mode=BROWSE>.\nBulk milk tests (PCR) of dairy goat and sheep farms with more than 50\nmilking animals have become compulsory in the Netherlands as of 1 Oct\n2009. On 14 Dec 2009 it became a requirement to perform the sampling\nand test every 2 weeks instead of the previously requirement of every\n2 months. The change was explained by the possibility that the\nexcretion of the bacterium may be intermittent.\n\nAccording to the official policy, initial testing is carried out by\nthe regional animal-health service (GD) laboratory; if found\npositive, a visit is paid to the farm, the issue explained to the\nowners, guidelines provided and a 2nd sample taken, sent for\nconfirmation to the Central Veterinary Institute in Lelystad. If\nconfirmed, the farm is declared officially infected.\n\nThe Netherlands notified the OIE of 63 Q fever outbreaks in dairy\ngoats on 13 Jan 2010; the reason for notification was \"unexpected\nincrease in incidence of a listed disease.\" The immediate\nnotification is available at:\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=8842>.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (11): culling dispute 20100206.0407\nQ fever - Netherlands (10): international response 20100204.0380\nQ fever - Netherlands (09): zoo-sanitary measures 20100128.0307\nQ fever - Netherlands (08): sheep, update 20100125.0278\nQ fever - Netherlands (07): update 20100115.0182\nQ fever - Netherlands (06): OIE 20100115.0181\nQ fever - Netherlands (05): investigation committee 20100112.0144\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): culling 20100111.0119\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): update 20100107.0079\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): update 20100105.0047\nQ fever - Netherlands: monitoring 20100103.0028\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (19): update 20091229.4375\nQ fever - Netherlands (18): update 20091225.4334\nQ fever - Netherlands (17): pathogenicity, RFI 20091222.4312\nQ fever - Netherlands (16): pathogenicity, RFI 20091222.4304\nQ fever - Netherlands (15): update 20091219.4286\nQ fever - Netherlands (14): update 20091217.4271\nQ fever, animals - Belgium: RFI 20091213.4234\nQ fever - Netherlands (13): control measures 20091209.4198\nQ fever - Netherlands (12): update 20091207.4173\nQ fever - Netherlands (11): public health 20091113.3930\nQ fever - Netherlands (10): update 20091107.3861\nQ fever - Netherlands (09): predictions 20091004.3452\nQ fever - Netherlands (08): update, monitoring & animal\nvaccination 20090927.3380\nQ fever - Netherlands (07) 20090908.3169\nQ fever - Netherlands (06) 20090814.2889\nQ fever - Netherlands (05) 20090629.2355\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): fatalities 20090626.2330\nQ Fever - Netherlands (03): update, animal vaccination 20090510.1744\nQ Fever - Netherlands (02): (NB) 20090508.1721\nQ fever, caprine - Netherlands: (LI) 20090331.1230\nQ fever - Netherlands: sheep & goat vaccination 20090228.0841\n2008\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): sheep & goat vaccination 20081023.3352\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): (NBR, GEL) 20080802.2367\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): (NBR) 20080728.2306\nQ fever - Netherlands: (NBR) 20080725.2267\n2007\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland) 20070809.2592\n....................arn/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1050-03-16 00:00:00", "1030-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-10-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-12-14 00:00:00", "2010-01-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "GD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hilvarenbeek", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Liessel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lelystad", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "388661", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands (16): human, animal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=388661", "date": "2010-02-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (12): 3 NEW OUTBREAKS\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 12 Feb 2010\nSource: Dutch Ministry of Agriculture press release [in Dutch, trans.\nMod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/portal/page?_pageid=116,1640333&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_news_item_id=25078>\n\n\nQ-fever infection in Hilvarenbeek, Esch, and Liessel\n----------------------------------------------------\nA total of 3 dairy goat farms, in Hilvarenbeek, Esch and Liessehave,\nbeen declared as Q-fever infected. In Hilvarenbeek, this refers to a\nfarm including 1050 dairy goats, in Esch 3000 and in Liessel 1030\ndairy goats. The declaration followed the identification of the Q\nfever bacterium in each of the 3 farms in 2 separate tests, performed\nin both the Animal Health Service (GD) laboratory as well as in the\nCentral Veterinary Institute (CVI), in 2 different milk samples.\n\nThe Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority (VWA) of the Ministry\nof Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality (LNV) has placed warning\nsigns on the farms. The full addresses and the locations of the\ninfected farms will be made public on the web-site of the VWA.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In total, 71 dairy farms have been found infected with _Coxiella\nburnetii_ in the Netherlands since October 2009, of which there are\n70 goat farms and one sheep farm. The total number of commercial\ndairy goat and sheep farms in the Netherlands is approximately 450.\n\nAll pregnant animals on the 1st 68 infected farms have been culled,\nto be followed by the pregnant goats in the 3 newly-added farms.\nThese 3 farms are located in the province North Brabant, the Dutch\nprovince with the highest density of dairy goats. The total number of\nculled animals will have exceeded, by now, 40 000.\n\nThe detailed list and map of 68 Q-fever infected farms, as of 8 Feb\n2010, are available at:\n<http://www.vwa.nl/portal/page?_pageid=119,2025799&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_document_id=932575&p_node_id=2167182&p_mode=BROWSE>.\nBulk milk tests (PCR) of dairy goat and sheep farms with more than 50\nmilking animals have become compulsory in the Netherlands as of 1 Oct\n2009. On 14 Dec 2009 it became a requirement to perform the sampling\nand test every 2 weeks instead of the previously requirement of every\n2 months. The change was explained by the possibility that the\nexcretion of the bacterium may be intermittent.\n\nAccording to the official policy, initial testing is carried out by\nthe regional animal-health service (GD) laboratory; if found\npositive, a visit is paid to the farm, the issue explained to the\nowners, guidelines provided and a 2nd sample taken, sent for\nconfirmation to the Central Veterinary Institute in Lelystad. If\nconfirmed, the farm is declared officially infected.\n\nThe Netherlands notified the OIE of 63 Q fever outbreaks in dairy\ngoats on 13 Jan 2010; the reason for notification was \"unexpected\nincrease in incidence of a listed disease.\" The immediate\nnotification is available at:\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=8842>.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (11): culling dispute 20100206.0407\nQ fever - Netherlands (10): international response 20100204.0380\nQ fever - Netherlands (09): zoo-sanitary measures 20100128.0307\nQ fever - Netherlands (08): sheep, update 20100125.0278\nQ fever - Netherlands (07): update 20100115.0182\nQ fever - Netherlands (06): OIE 20100115.0181\nQ fever - Netherlands (05): investigation committee 20100112.0144\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): culling 20100111.0119\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): update 20100107.0079\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): update 20100105.0047\nQ fever - Netherlands: monitoring 20100103.0028\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (19): update 20091229.4375\nQ fever - Netherlands (14): update 20091217.4271\nQ fever, animals - Belgium: RFI 20091213.4234\nQ fever - Netherlands (13): control measures 20091209.4198\nQ fever - Netherlands (12): update 20091207.4173\nQ fever - Netherlands (11): public health 20091113.3930\nQ fever - Netherlands (10): update 20091107.3861\nQ fever - Netherlands (09): predictions 20091004.3452\nQ fever - Netherlands (08): update, monitoring & animal\nvaccination 20090927.3380\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): (NBR, GEL) 20080802.2367\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): (NBR) 20080728.2306\nQ fever - Netherlands: (NBR) 20080725.2267\n2007\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland) 20070809.2592\n....................arn/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1050-03-16 00:00:00", "1030-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-10-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-12-14 00:00:00", "2010-01-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "GD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hilvarenbeek", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Liessel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lelystad", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "383676", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands (13): human, animal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=383676", "date": "2010-02-13 23:50:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (12): 3 NEW OUTBREAKS\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 12 Feb 2010\nSource: Dutch Ministry of Agriculture press release [in Dutch, trans.\nMod.AS, edited]\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/portal/page?_pageid=116,1640333&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_news_item_id=25078>\n\n\nQ-fever infection in Hilvarenbeek, Esch, and Liessel\n----------------------------------------------------\nA total of 3 dairy goat farms, in Hilvarenbeek, Esch and Liessehave,\nbeen declared as Q-fever infected. In Hilvarenbeek, this refers to a\nfarm including 1050 dairy goats, in Esch 3000 and in Liessel 1030\ndairy goats. The declaration followed the identification of the Q\nfever bacterium in each of the 3 farms in 2 separate tests, performed\nin both the Animal Health Service (GD) laboratory as well as in the\nCentral Veterinary Institute (CVI), in 2 different milk samples.\n\nThe Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority (VWA) of the Ministry\nof Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality (LNV) has placed warning\nsigns on the farms. The full addresses and the locations of the\ninfected farms will be made public on the web-site of the VWA.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In total, 71 dairy farms have been found infected with _Coxiella\nburnetii_ in the Netherlands since October 2009, of which there are\n70 goat farms and one sheep farm. The total number of commercial\ndairy goat and sheep farms in the Netherlands is approximately 450.\n\nAll pregnant animals on the 1st 68 infected farms have been culled,\nto be followed by the pregnant goats in the 3 newly-added farms.\nThese 3 farms are located in the province North Brabant, the Dutch\nprovince with the highest density of dairy goats. The total number of\nculled animals will have exceeded, by now, 40 000.\n\nThe detailed list and map of 68 Q-fever infected farms, as of 8 Feb\n2010, are available at:\n<http://www.vwa.nl/portal/page?_pageid=119,2025799&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_document_id=932575&p_node_id=2167182&p_mode=BROWSE>.\nBulk milk tests (PCR) of dairy goat and sheep farms with more than 50\nmilking animals have become compulsory in the Netherlands as of 1 Oct\n2009. On 14 Dec 2009 it became a requirement to perform the sampling\nand test every 2 weeks instead of the previously requirement of every\n2 months. The change was explained by the possibility that the\nexcretion of the bacterium may be intermittent.\n\nAccording to the official policy, initial testing is carried out by\nthe regional animal-health service (GD) laboratory; if found\npositive, a visit is paid to the farm, the issue explained to the\nowners, guidelines provided and a 2nd sample taken, sent for\nconfirmation to the Central Veterinary Institute in Lelystad. If\nconfirmed, the farm is declared officially infected.\n\nThe Netherlands notified the OIE of 63 Q fever outbreaks in dairy\ngoats on 13 Jan 2010; the reason for notification was \"unexpected\nincrease in incidence of a listed disease.\" The immediate\nnotification is available at:\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=event_summary&reportid=8842>.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1050-03-16 00:00:00", "1030-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-10-16 00:00:00", "2010-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-12-14 00:00:00", "2010-01-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "GD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hilvarenbeek", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Liessel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Lelystad", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "377440", "headline": "PRO/AH> Q fever - Netherlands (11): culling dispute", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=377440", "date": "2010-01-11 12:00:04", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (04): CULLING\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 8 Jan 2010\nSource: Dutch Ministry of Agriculture press release [in Dutch, trans.\nMod.AS, abridged, edited]\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/portal/page?_pageid=116,1640333&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_news_item_id=24982>\n\n\nThe message that ministers Verburg (LNV) and Klink (VWS) had decided\nto refrain from culling goats in children's petting farms and\neducational institutions [see posting 20100107.0079 ] has prompted\nmany questions. Why are all pregnant animals on infected large dairy\nfarms culled, while those in small holdings and children's farms are\nnot? Is this not a double standard? The answer is: It seems so, but\nthere are good reasons for the distinction.\n\nAll control measures are considered from a public health point of\nview. During 2009, 2300 people became ill in the Netherlands from the\nQ fever bacterium. Therefore, everything is now focused on the aim to\nreduce this number as far as possible over the coming years.\n\nCulling in infected, large-scale holdings\n-----------------------------------\nThe greatest risk to public health is posed by large groups of\npregnant dairy goats and sheep, which excrete very large quantities of\nthe Q fever bacteria during normal birthing or abortions. This was\nindicated in the advice received from the expert group led by Roel\nCoutinho of RIVM (the Dutch National Institute for Public Health and\nEnvironment). If an infected goat gives birth to a live lamb, millions\nof Q-fever bacteria are released; in case of an abortion, their\nnumbers go into the billions.\n\nIn large farms, most matings are managed to take place within a short\nperiod, or mating is synchronised, leading to the birth of many\nanimals taking place during comparatively short periods, many on the\nsame days. Similarly, abortions, if occurring, may involve many\nanimals, sometimes taking the form of abortion \"storms.\" In case those\nanimals are infected by Q fever, this means the excretion of very\nlarge quantities of bacteria by many animals simultaneously: This is\nthe greatest threat to public health. Consequently, the presence of\ninfected pregnant animals on the farm should be prevented ahead of the\nlambing season (which usually starts in January). Since individual\ntesting of animals in the short term is not possible, all pregnant\nanimals on infected farms should be culled. [Subscribers are also\nreferred to the research paper cited in the commentary to posting\n20100107.0079. The authors indicated, among other things, that \"the\nstudy showed that a non-negligible [i.e. epidemiologically significant\n- Mod.JW] proportion of seronegative animals that delivered normally\ncould excrete _C. burnetii_.\" - Mod.AS]\n\nSaving animals on children's farms\n---------------------------------\nQ fever may infect sheep and goats also on petting farms, small\nholders' yards or occupational therapeutic farms (\"businesses with a\npublic function\".) The difference between these farms and large\nmilk-producing goat or sheep farms is the number of animals crowded\ntogether and birthing (or aborting) simultaneously. In small-scale\nfarms, there are fewer animals in a state of Q fever bacteria\nsecretion. Therefore, these holdings pose a lower risk to human\nhealth, and the pregnant animals on these farms are not culled.\n\nResearch shows that, so far, the Q fever bacterium has hardly ever\nbeen found in children's farms. Yet, visitors to petting farms where Q\nfever-infected sheep or goats are kept may always be exposed to some\nrisk of getting infected.\n\nThe RIVM-led expert group was asked to provide advice pertaining to\nthe said risk on petting farms or other small-scale holdings with less\nthan 50 animals. According to experts, it is generally not necessary\nto take additional measures concerning such holdings.\n\nHowever, it was recommended to pay special attention to hygiene on\nchildren's farms. In addition, children's (\"petting\") farms and\noccupational therapeutic farms are advised to let the birthing take\nplace in separate pens without pubic access. This will prevent contact\nbetween infected birthing or aborting animals and visitors, and the\nexcretion of bacteria close to visitors, and further diminish the risk\nof infection.\n\nFurthermore, it has been decided that petting and therapeutic farms\nwill be vaccinated with priority. Fortunately, there is vaccine enough\navailable for all such establishments.\n\nAdults and children visiting petting farms are advised to pay\nattention to hygiene. Appropriate advisory information is available on\nthe website of the VWA (Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Additional explanation on the significant weight of the large dairy\ngoat farms in the large-scale dissemination of _C. burnetii_ can be\nfound in the advisory letter to Ministers sent by Prof Coutinho on 17\nJul 2009. It provided several examples demonstrating the temporal and\nspatial association between large, infected dairy goat farms and human\ninfection. The 1st example (2007) came from Herpen village, where many\nhuman infections were recorded around a goat farm with an abortion\nstorm. A significant case was that of Helmond town in 2008: the\npercentage of infected humans increased in proportion to the proximity\nof their dwellings to a large dairy goat establishment. Similar\nfindings of measurable connections were recorded in South Limburg.\n\nA map showing all commercial dairy goat/sheep flocks regarded infected\nas of 8 Jan 2010, indicating the 5-km zone around each, is available\nat\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/gebiedskaart_100108_tcm92-65083.pdf>.\n\nA map showing municipalities with notified Q fever patients (per 100\n000), 1 Jan-22 Dec 2009, as well as the locations of infected\ncommercial dairy goat farms, is available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/Q-koorts%20incidentie_tcm92-60500.pdf>.\n\nA 62nd infected farm has been officially added to the list on 9 Jan\n2010, located in Een West in Drente province. The holding includes 450\ngoats, 249 of them pregnant; those are to be culled on 11 Jan 2010\n(today).\n\nThe Dutch delegation is expected to present an updating report on the\nQ fever situation during the next meeting of the EU's Standing\nCommittee on the Food Chain and Animal Health (SCFCAH), due in\nBrussels on Tue 12 Jan 2010. The last report on the issue (dated 6 Oct\n2009) was presented during the 3 Nov 2009 meeting (available at\n<http://ec.europa.eu/food/committees/regulatory/scfcah/animal_health/presentations/0304112009_q_fever_nl.pdf>).\n\nThose interested in additional information may refer to the paper \"Q\nfever outbreaks in small ruminants and people in the Netherlands\" by\nR. Van den Brom & P. Vellema in Small Ruminant Research 86 (2009)\n74-79. Journal homepage: <http://www.elsevier.com/locate/smallrumres>.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): update 20100107.0079\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): update 20100105.0047\nQ fever - Netherlands: monitoring 20100103.0028\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (19): update 20091229.4375\nQ fever - Netherlands (18): update 20091225.4334\nQ fever - Netherlands (17): pathogenicity, RFI 20091222.4312\nQ fever - Netherlands (16): pathogenicity, RFI 20091222.4304\nQ fever - Netherlands (15): update 20091219.4286\nQ fever - Netherlands (14): update 20091217.4271\nQ fever, animals - Belgium: RFI 20091213.4234\nQ fever - Netherlands (13): control measures 20091209.4198\nQ fever - Netherlands (12): update 20091207.4173\nQ fever - Netherlands (11): public health 20091113.3930\nQ fever - Netherlands (10): update 20091107.3861\nQ fever - Netherlands (09): predictions 20091004.3452\nQ fever - Netherlands (08): update, monitoring & animal vaccination\n20090927.3380\nQ fever - Netherlands (07) 20090908.3169\nQ fever - Netherlands (06) 20090814.2889\nQ fever - Netherlands (05) 20090629.2355\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): fatalities 20090626.2330\nQ Fever - Netherlands (03): update, animal vaccination 20090510.1744\nQ Fever - Netherlands (02): (NB) 20090508.1721\nQ fever, caprine - Netherlands: (LI) 20090331.1230\nQ fever - If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-01-08 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-01-09 00:00:00", "2010-01-11 00:00:00", "2010-01-12 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Drente province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Verburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Een West", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Limburg", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "376585", "headline": "PRO/AH> Q fever - Netherlands (10): international response", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=376585", "date": "2010-01-11 12:00:04", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (04): CULLING\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 8 Jan 2010\nSource: Dutch Ministry of Agriculture press release [in Dutch, trans.\nMod.AS, abridged, edited]\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/portal/page?_pageid=116,1640333&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_news_item_id=24982>\n\n\nThe message that ministers Verburg (LNV) and Klink (VWS) had decided\nto refrain from culling goats in children's petting farms and\neducational institutions [see posting 20100107.0079 ] has prompted\nmany questions. Why are all pregnant animals on infected large dairy\nfarms culled, while those in small holdings and children's farms are\nnot? Is this not a double standard? The answer is: It seems so, but\nthere are good reasons for the distinction.\n\nAll control measures are considered from a public health point of\nview. During 2009, 2300 people became ill in the Netherlands from the\nQ fever bacterium. Therefore, everything is now focused on the aim to\nreduce this number as far as possible over the coming years.\n\nCulling in infected, large-scale holdings\n-----------------------------------\nThe greatest risk to public health is posed by large groups of\npregnant dairy goats and sheep, which excrete very large quantities of\nthe Q fever bacteria during normal birthing or abortions. This was\nindicated in the advice received from the expert group led by Roel\nCoutinho of RIVM (the Dutch National Institute for Public Health and\nEnvironment). If an infected goat gives birth to a live lamb, millions\nof Q-fever bacteria are released; in case of an abortion, their\nnumbers go into the billions.\n\nIn large farms, most matings are managed to take place within a short\nperiod, or mating is synchronised, leading to the birth of many\nanimals taking place during comparatively short periods, many on the\nsame days. Similarly, abortions, if occurring, may involve many\nanimals, sometimes taking the form of abortion \"storms.\" In case those\nanimals are infected by Q fever, this means the excretion of very\nlarge quantities of bacteria by many animals simultaneously: This is\nthe greatest threat to public health. Consequently, the presence of\ninfected pregnant animals on the farm should be prevented ahead of the\nlambing season (which usually starts in January). Since individual\ntesting of animals in the short term is not possible, all pregnant\nanimals on infected farms should be culled. [Subscribers are also\nreferred to the research paper cited in the commentary to posting\n20100107.0079. The authors indicated, among other things, that \"the\nstudy showed that a non-negligible [i.e. epidemiologically significant\n- Mod.JW] proportion of seronegative animals that delivered normally\ncould excrete _C. burnetii_.\" - Mod.AS]\n\nSaving animals on children's farms\n---------------------------------\nQ fever may infect sheep and goats also on petting farms, small\nholders' yards or occupational therapeutic farms (\"businesses with a\npublic function\".) The difference between these farms and large\nmilk-producing goat or sheep farms is the number of animals crowded\ntogether and birthing (or aborting) simultaneously. In small-scale\nfarms, there are fewer animals in a state of Q fever bacteria\nsecretion. Therefore, these holdings pose a lower risk to human\nhealth, and the pregnant animals on these farms are not culled.\n\nResearch shows that, so far, the Q fever bacterium has hardly ever\nbeen found in children's farms. Yet, visitors to petting farms where Q\nfever-infected sheep or goats are kept may always be exposed to some\nrisk of getting infected.\n\nThe RIVM-led expert group was asked to provide advice pertaining to\nthe said risk on petting farms or other small-scale holdings with less\nthan 50 animals. According to experts, it is generally not necessary\nto take additional measures concerning such holdings.\n\nHowever, it was recommended to pay special attention to hygiene on\nchildren's farms. In addition, children's (\"petting\") farms and\noccupational therapeutic farms are advised to let the birthing take\nplace in separate pens without pubic access. This will prevent contact\nbetween infected birthing or aborting animals and visitors, and the\nexcretion of bacteria close to visitors, and further diminish the risk\nof infection.\n\nFurthermore, it has been decided that petting and therapeutic farms\nwill be vaccinated with priority. Fortunately, there is vaccine enough\navailable for all such establishments.\n\nAdults and children visiting petting farms are advised to pay\nattention to hygiene. Appropriate advisory information is available on\nthe website of the VWA (Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Additional explanation on the significant weight of the large dairy\ngoat farms in the large-scale dissemination of _C. burnetii_ can be\nfound in the advisory letter to Ministers sent by Prof Coutinho on 17\nJul 2009. It provided several examples demonstrating the temporal and\nspatial association between large, infected dairy goat farms and human\ninfection. The 1st example (2007) came from Herpen village, where many\nhuman infections were recorded around a goat farm with an abortion\nstorm. A significant case was that of Helmond town in 2008: the\npercentage of infected humans increased in proportion to the proximity\nof their dwellings to a large dairy goat establishment. Similar\nfindings of measurable connections were recorded in South Limburg.\n\nA map showing all commercial dairy goat/sheep flocks regarded infected\nas of 8 Jan 2010, indicating the 5-km zone around each, is available\nat\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/gebiedskaart_100108_tcm92-65083.pdf>.\n\nA map showing municipalities with notified Q fever patients (per 100\n000), 1 Jan-22 Dec 2009, as well as the locations of infected\ncommercial dairy goat farms, is available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/Q-koorts%20incidentie_tcm92-60500.pdf>.\n\nA 62nd infected farm has been officially added to the list on 9 Jan\n2010, located in Een West in Drente province. The holding includes 450\ngoats, 249 of them pregnant; those are to be culled on 11 Jan 2010\n(today).\n\nThe Dutch delegation is expected to present an updating report on the\nQ fever situation during the next meeting of the EU's Standing\nCommittee on the Food Chain and Animal Health (SCFCAH), due in\nBrussels on Tue 12 Jan 2010. The last report on the issue (dated 6 Oct\n2009) was presented during the 3 Nov 2009 meeting (available at\n<http://ec.europa.eu/food/committees/regulatory/scfcah/animal_health/presentations/0304112009_q_fever_nl.pdf>).\n\nThose interested in additional information may refer to the paper \"Q\nfever outbreaks in small ruminants and people in the Netherlands\" by\nR. Van den Brom & P. Vellema in Small Ruminant Research 86 (2009)\n74-79. Journal homepage: <http://www.elsevier.com/locate/smallrumres>.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): update 20100107.0079\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): update 20100105.0047\nQ fever - Netherlands: monitoring 20100103.0028\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (19): update 20091229.4375\nQ fever - Netherlands (18): update 20091225.4334\nQ fever - Netherlands (17): pathogenicity, RFI 20091222.4312\nQ fever - Netherlands (16): pathogenicity, RFI 20091222.4304\nQ fever - Netherlands (15): update 20091219.4286\nQ fever - Netherlands (14): update 20091217.4271\nQ fever, animals - Belgium: RFI 20091213.4234\nQ fever - Netherlands (13): control measures 20091209.4198\nQ fever - Netherlands (12): update 20091207.4173\nQ fever - Netherlands (11): public health 20091113.3930\nQ fever - Netherlands (10): update 20091107.3861\nQ fever - Netherlands (09): predictions 20091004.3452\nQ fever - Netherlands (08): update, monitoring & animal vaccination\n20090927.3380\nQ fever - Netherlands (07) 20090908.3169\nQ fever - Netherlands (06) 20090814.2889\nQ fever - Netherlands (05) 20090629.2355\nQ fever - Netherlands (08): sheep, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=370771", "date": "2010-01-11 12:00:04", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (04): CULLING\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 8 Jan 2010\nSource: Dutch Ministry of Agriculture press release [in Dutch, trans.\nMod.AS, abridged, edited]\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/portal/page?_pageid=116,1640333&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_news_item_id=24982>\n\n\nThe message that ministers Verburg (LNV) and Klink (VWS) had decided\nto refrain from culling goats in children's petting farms and\neducational institutions [see posting 20100107.0079 ] has prompted\nmany questions. Why are all pregnant animals on infected large dairy\nfarms culled, while those in small holdings and children's farms are\nnot? Is this not a double standard? The answer is: It seems so, but\nthere are good reasons for the distinction.\n\nAll control measures are considered from a public health point of\nview. During 2009, 2300 people became ill in the Netherlands from the\nQ fever bacterium. Therefore, everything is now focused on the aim to\nreduce this number as far as possible over the coming years.\n\nCulling in infected, large-scale holdings\n-----------------------------------\nThe greatest risk to public health is posed by large groups of\npregnant dairy goats and sheep, which excrete very large quantities of\nthe Q fever bacteria during normal birthing or abortions. This was\nindicated in the advice received from the expert group led by Roel\nCoutinho of RIVM (the Dutch National Institute for Public Health and\nEnvironment). If an infected goat gives birth to a live lamb, millions\nof Q-fever bacteria are released; in case of an abortion, their\nnumbers go into the billions.\n\nIn large farms, most matings are managed to take place within a short\nperiod, or mating is synchronised, leading to the birth of many\nanimals taking place during comparatively short periods, many on the\nsame days. Similarly, abortions, if occurring, may involve many\nanimals, sometimes taking the form of abortion \"storms.\" In case those\nanimals are infected by Q fever, this means the excretion of very\nlarge quantities of bacteria by many animals simultaneously: This is\nthe greatest threat to public health. Consequently, the presence of\ninfected pregnant animals on the farm should be prevented ahead of the\nlambing season (which usually starts in January). Since individual\ntesting of animals in the short term is not possible, all pregnant\nanimals on infected farms should be culled. [Subscribers are also\nreferred to the research paper cited in the commentary to posting\n20100107.0079. The authors indicated, among other things, that \"the\nstudy showed that a non-negligible [i.e. epidemiologically significant\n- Mod.JW] proportion of seronegative animals that delivered normally\ncould excrete _C. burnetii_.\" - Mod.AS]\n\nSaving animals on children's farms\n---------------------------------\nQ fever may infect sheep and goats also on petting farms, small\nholders' yards or occupational therapeutic farms (\"businesses with a\npublic function\".) The difference between these farms and large\nmilk-producing goat or sheep farms is the number of animals crowded\ntogether and birthing (or aborting) simultaneously. In small-scale\nfarms, there are fewer animals in a state of Q fever bacteria\nsecretion. Therefore, these holdings pose a lower risk to human\nhealth, and the pregnant animals on these farms are not culled.\n\nResearch shows that, so far, the Q fever bacterium has hardly ever\nbeen found in children's farms. Yet, visitors to petting farms where Q\nfever-infected sheep or goats are kept may always be exposed to some\nrisk of getting infected.\n\nThe RIVM-led expert group was asked to provide advice pertaining to\nthe said risk on petting farms or other small-scale holdings with less\nthan 50 animals. According to experts, it is generally not necessary\nto take additional measures concerning such holdings.\n\nHowever, it was recommended to pay special attention to hygiene on\nchildren's farms. In addition, children's (\"petting\") farms and\noccupational therapeutic farms are advised to let the birthing take\nplace in separate pens without pubic access. This will prevent contact\nbetween infected birthing or aborting animals and visitors, and the\nexcretion of bacteria close to visitors, and further diminish the risk\nof infection.\n\nFurthermore, it has been decided that petting and therapeutic farms\nwill be vaccinated with priority. Fortunately, there is vaccine enough\navailable for all such establishments.\n\nAdults and children visiting petting farms are advised to pay\nattention to hygiene. Appropriate advisory information is available on\nthe website of the VWA (Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Additional explanation on the significant weight of the large dairy\ngoat farms in the large-scale dissemination of _C. burnetii_ can be\nfound in the advisory letter to Ministers sent by Prof Coutinho on 17\nJul 2009. It provided several examples demonstrating the temporal and\nspatial association between large, infected dairy goat farms and human\ninfection. The 1st example (2007) came from Herpen village, where many\nhuman infections were recorded around a goat farm with an abortion\nstorm. A significant case was that of Helmond town in 2008: the\npercentage of infected humans increased in proportion to the proximity\nof their dwellings to a large dairy goat establishment. Similar\nfindings of measurable connections were recorded in South Limburg.\n\nA map showing all commercial dairy goat/sheep flocks regarded infected\nas of 8 Jan 2010, indicating the 5-km zone around each, is available\nat\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/gebiedskaart_100108_tcm92-65083.pdf>.\n\nA map showing municipalities with notified Q fever patients (per 100\n000), 1 Jan-22 Dec 2009, as well as the locations of infected\ncommercial dairy goat farms, is available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/Q-koorts%20incidentie_tcm92-60500.pdf>.\n\nA 62nd infected farm has been officially added to the list on 9 Jan\n2010, located in Een West in Drente province. The holding includes 450\ngoats, 249 of them pregnant; those are to be culled on 11 Jan 2010\n(today).\n\nThe Dutch delegation is expected to present an updating report on the\nQ fever situation during the next meeting of the EU's Standing\nCommittee on the Food Chain and Animal Health (SCFCAH), due in\nBrussels on Tue 12 Jan 2010. The last report on the issue (dated 6 Oct\n2009) was presented during the 3 Nov 2009 meeting (available at\n<http://ec.europa.eu/food/committees/regulatory/scfcah/animal_health/presentations/0304112009_q_fever_nl.pdf>).\n\nThose interested in additional information may refer to the paper \"Q\nfever outbreaks in small ruminants and people in the Netherlands\" by\nR. Van den Brom & P. Vellema in Small Ruminant Research 86 (2009)\n74-79. Journal homepage: <http://www.elsevier.com/locate/smallrumres>.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): update 20100107.0079\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): update 20100105.0047\nQ fever - Netherlands: monitoring 20100103.0028\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (19): update 20091229.4375\nQ fever - Netherlands (18): update 20091225.4334\nQ fever - Netherlands (17): pathogenicity, RFI 20091222.4312\nQ fever - Netherlands (16): pathogenicity, RFI 20091222.4304\nQ fever - Netherlands (15): update 20091219.4286\nQ fever - Netherlands (14): update 20091217.4271\nQ fever, animals - Belgium: RFI 20091213.4234\nQ fever - Netherlands (13): control measures 20091209.4198\nQ fever - Netherlands (12): update 20091207.4173\nQ fever - Netherlands (11): public health 20091113.3930\nQ fever - Netherlands (10): update 20091107.3861\nQ fever - Netherlands (09): predictions 20091004.3452\nQ fever - Netherlands (08): update, monitoring & animal vaccination\n20090927.3380\nQ fever - Netherlands (07) 20090908.3169\nQ fever - Netherlands (06) 20090814.2889\nQ fever - Netherlands (05) 20090629.2355\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): fatalities 20090626.2330\nQ Fever - Netherlands (03): update, animal vaccination 20090510.1744\nQ Fever - Netherlands (02): (NB) 20090508.1721\nQ fever, caprine - Netherlands: (LI) 20090331.1230\nQ fever - Netherlands: sheep & goat vaccination 20090228.0841\n2008\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): sheep & goat vaccination 20081023.3352\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): (NBR, GEL) 20080802.2367\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): (NBR) 20080728.2306\nQ fever - Netherlands: (NBR) 20080725.2267\n2007\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland) 20070809.2592\n....................................................arn/msp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-01-08 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-01-09 00:00:00", "2010-01-11 00:00:00", "2010-01-12 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Drente province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Verburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Een West", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Limburg", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "366325", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands (07): update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=366325", "date": "2010-01-11 12:00:04", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (04): CULLING\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 8 Jan 2010\nSource: Dutch Ministry of Agriculture press release [in Dutch, trans.\nMod.AS, abridged, edited]\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/portal/page?_pageid=116,1640333&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_news_item_id=24982>\n\n\nThe message that ministers Verburg (LNV) and Klink (VWS) had decided\nto refrain from culling goats in children's petting farms and\neducational institutions [see posting 20100107.0079 ] has prompted\nmany questions. Why are all pregnant animals on infected large dairy\nfarms culled, while those in small holdings and children's farms are\nnot? Is this not a double standard? The answer is: It seems so, but\nthere are good reasons for the distinction.\n\nAll control measures are considered from a public health point of\nview. During 2009, 2300 people became ill in the Netherlands from the\nQ fever bacterium. Therefore, everything is now focused on the aim to\nreduce this number as far as possible over the coming years.\n\nCulling in infected, large-scale holdings\n-----------------------------------\nThe greatest risk to public health is posed by large groups of\npregnant dairy goats and sheep, which excrete very large quantities of\nthe Q fever bacteria during normal birthing or abortions. This was\nindicated in the advice received from the expert group led by Roel\nCoutinho of RIVM (the Dutch National Institute for Public Health and\nEnvironment). If an infected goat gives birth to a live lamb, millions\nof Q-fever bacteria are released; in case of an abortion, their\nnumbers go into the billions.\n\nIn large farms, most matings are managed to take place within a short\nperiod, or mating is synchronised, leading to the birth of many\nanimals taking place during comparatively short periods, many on the\nsame days. Similarly, abortions, if occurring, may involve many\nanimals, sometimes taking the form of abortion \"storms.\" In case those\nanimals are infected by Q fever, this means the excretion of very\nlarge quantities of bacteria by many animals simultaneously: This is\nthe greatest threat to public health. Consequently, the presence of\ninfected pregnant animals on the farm should be prevented ahead of the\nlambing season (which usually starts in January). Since individual\ntesting of animals in the short term is not possible, all pregnant\nanimals on infected farms should be culled. [Subscribers are also\nreferred to the research paper cited in the commentary to posting\n20100107.0079. The authors indicated, among other things, that \"the\nstudy showed that a non-negligible [i.e. epidemiologically significant\n- Mod.JW] proportion of seronegative animals that delivered normally\ncould excrete _C. burnetii_.\" - Mod.AS]\n\nSaving animals on children's farms\n---------------------------------\nQ fever may infect sheep and goats also on petting farms, small\nholders' yards or occupational therapeutic farms (\"businesses with a\npublic function\".) The difference between these farms and large\nmilk-producing goat or sheep farms is the number of animals crowded\ntogether and birthing (or aborting) simultaneously. In small-scale\nfarms, there are fewer animals in a state of Q fever bacteria\nsecretion. Therefore, these holdings pose a lower risk to human\nhealth, and the pregnant animals on these farms are not culled.\n\nResearch shows that, so far, the Q fever bacterium has hardly ever\nbeen found in children's farms. Yet, visitors to petting farms where Q\nfever-infected sheep or goats are kept may always be exposed to some\nrisk of getting infected.\n\nThe RIVM-led expert group was asked to provide advice pertaining to\nthe said risk on petting farms or other small-scale holdings with less\nthan 50 animals. According to experts, it is generally not necessary\nto take additional measures concerning such holdings.\n\nHowever, it was recommended to pay special attention to hygiene on\nchildren's farms. In addition, children's (\"petting\") farms and\noccupational therapeutic farms are advised to let the birthing take\nplace in separate pens without pubic access. This will prevent contact\nbetween infected birthing or aborting animals and visitors, and the\nexcretion of bacteria close to visitors, and further diminish the risk\nof infection.\n\nFurthermore, it has been decided that petting and therapeutic farms\nwill be vaccinated with priority. Fortunately, there is vaccine enough\navailable for all such establishments.\n\nAdults and children visiting petting farms are advised to pay\nattention to hygiene. Appropriate advisory information is available on\nthe website of the VWA (Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Additional explanation on the significant weight of the large dairy\ngoat farms in the large-scale dissemination of _C. burnetii_ can be\nfound in the advisory letter to Ministers sent by Prof Coutinho on 17\nJul 2009. It provided several examples demonstrating the temporal and\nspatial association between large, infected dairy goat farms and human\ninfection. The 1st example (2007) came from Herpen village, where many\nhuman infections were recorded around a goat farm with an abortion\nstorm. A significant case was that of Helmond town in 2008: the\npercentage of infected humans increased in proportion to the proximity\nof their dwellings to a large dairy goat establishment. Similar\nfindings of measurable connections were recorded in South Limburg.\n\nA map showing all commercial dairy goat/sheep flocks regarded infected\nas of 8 Jan 2010, indicating the 5-km zone around each, is available\nat\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/gebiedskaart_100108_tcm92-65083.pdf>.\n\nA map showing municipalities with notified Q fever patients (per 100\n000), 1 Jan-22 Dec 2009, as well as the locations of infected\ncommercial dairy goat farms, is available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/Q-koorts%20incidentie_tcm92-60500.pdf>.\n\nA 62nd infected farm has been officially added to the list on 9 Jan\n2010, located in Een West in Drente province. The holding includes 450\ngoats, 249 of them pregnant; those are to be culled on 11 Jan 2010\n(today).\n\nThe Dutch delegation is expected to present an updating report on the\nQ fever situation during the next meeting of the EU's Standing\nCommittee on the Food Chain and Animal Health (SCFCAH), due in\nBrussels on Tue 12 Jan 2010. The last report on the issue (dated 6 Oct\n2009) was presented during the 3 Nov 2009 meeting (available at\n<http://ec.europa.eu/food/committees/regulatory/scfcah/animal_health/presentations/0304112009_q_fever_nl.pdf>).\n\nThose interested in additional information may refer to the paper \"Q\nfever outbreaks in small ruminants and people in the Netherlands\" by\nR. Van den Brom & P. Vellema in Small Ruminant Research 86 (2009)\n74-79. Journal homepage: <http://www.elsevier.com/locate/smallrumres>.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): update 20100107.0079\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): update 20100105.0047\nQ fever - Netherlands: monitoring 20100103.0028\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (19): update 20091229.4375\nQ fever - Netherlands (18): update 20091225.4334\nQ fever - Netherlands (17): pathogenicity, RFI 20091222.4312\nQ fever - Netherlands (16): pathogenicity, RFI 20091222.4304\nQ fever - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-01-08 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-01-09 00:00:00", "2010-01-11 00:00:00", "2010-01-12 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Drente province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Verburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Een West", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Limburg", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "366297", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands (06): OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=366297", "date": "2010-01-11 12:00:04", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (04): CULLING\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 8 Jan 2010\nSource: Dutch Ministry of Agriculture press release [in Dutch, trans.\nMod.AS, abridged, edited]\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/portal/page?_pageid=116,1640333&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_news_item_id=24982>\n\n\nThe message that ministers Verburg (LNV) and Klink (VWS) had decided\nto refrain from culling goats in children's petting farms and\neducational institutions [see posting 20100107.0079 ] has prompted\nmany questions. Why are all pregnant animals on infected large dairy\nfarms culled, while those in small holdings and children's farms are\nnot? Is this not a double standard? The answer is: It seems so, but\nthere are good reasons for the distinction.\n\nAll control measures are considered from a public health point of\nview. During 2009, 2300 people became ill in the Netherlands from the\nQ fever bacterium. Therefore, everything is now focused on the aim to\nreduce this number as far as possible over the coming years.\n\nCulling in infected, large-scale holdings\n-----------------------------------\nThe greatest risk to public health is posed by large groups of\npregnant dairy goats and sheep, which excrete very large quantities of\nthe Q fever bacteria during normal birthing or abortions. This was\nindicated in the advice received from the expert group led by Roel\nCoutinho of RIVM (the Dutch National Institute for Public Health and\nEnvironment). Similarly, abortions, if occurring, may involve many\nanimals, sometimes taking the form of abortion \"storms.\" In case those\nanimals are infected by Q fever, this means the excretion of very\nlarge quantities of bacteria by many animals simultaneously: This is\nthe greatest threat to public health. Consequently, the presence of\ninfected pregnant animals on the farm should be prevented ahead of the\nlambing season (which usually starts in January). Since individual\ntesting of animals in the short term is not possible, all pregnant\nanimals on infected farms should be culled. [Subscribers are also\nreferred to the research paper cited in the commentary to posting\n20100107.0079. The authors indicated, among other things, that \"the\nstudy showed that a non-negligible [i.e. epidemiologically significant\n- Mod.JW] proportion of seronegative animals that delivered normally\ncould excrete _C. burnetii_.\" - Mod.AS]\n\nSaving animals on children's farms\n---------------------------------\nQ fever may infect sheep and goats also on petting farms, small\nholders' yards or occupational therapeutic farms (\"businesses with a\npublic function\".) The difference between these farms and large\nmilk-producing goat or sheep farms is the number of animals crowded\ntogether and birthing (or aborting) simultaneously. In small-scale\nfarms, there are fewer animals in a state of Q fever bacteria\nsecretion. Therefore, these holdings pose a lower risk to human\nhealth, and the pregnant animals on these farms are not culled.\n\nResearch shows that, so far, the Q fever bacterium has hardly ever\nbeen found in children's farms. Yet, visitors to petting farms where Q\nfever-infected sheep or goats are kept may always be exposed to some\nrisk of getting infected.\n\nThe RIVM-led expert group was asked to provide advice pertaining to\nthe said risk on petting farms or other small-scale holdings with less\nthan 50 animals. According to experts, it is generally not necessary\nto take additional measures concerning such holdings.\n\nHowever, it was recommended to pay special attention to hygiene on\nchildren's farms. In addition, children's (\"petting\") farms and\noccupational therapeutic farms are advised to let the birthing take\nplace in separate pens without pubic access. This will prevent contact\nbetween infected birthing or aborting animals and visitors, and the\nexcretion of bacteria close to visitors, and further diminish the risk\nof infection.\n\nFurthermore, it has been decided that petting and therapeutic farms\nwill be vaccinated with priority. Fortunately, there is vaccine enough\navailable for all such establishments.\n\nAdults and children visiting petting farms are advised to pay\nattention to hygiene. Appropriate advisory information is available on\nthe website of the VWA (Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Additional explanation on the significant weight of the large dairy\ngoat farms in the large-scale dissemination of _C. burnetii_ can be\nfound in the advisory letter to Ministers sent by Prof Coutinho on 17\nJul 2009. It provided several examples demonstrating the temporal and\nspatial association between large, infected dairy goat farms and human\ninfection. The 1st example (2007) came from Herpen village, where many\nhuman infections were recorded around a goat farm with an abortion\nstorm. A significant case was that of Helmond town in 2008: the\npercentage of infected humans increased in proportion to the proximity\nof their dwellings to a large dairy goat establishment. Similar\nfindings of measurable connections were recorded in South Limburg.\n\nA map showing all commercial dairy goat/sheep flocks regarded infected\nas of 8 Jan 2010, indicating the 5-km zone around each, is available\nat\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/gebiedskaart_100108_tcm92-65083.pdf>.\n\nA map showing municipalities with notified Q fever patients (per 100\n000), 1 Jan-22 Dec 2009, as well as the locations of infected\ncommercial dairy goat farms, is available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/Q-koorts%20incidentie_tcm92-60500.pdf>.\n\nA 62nd infected farm has been officially added to the list on 9 Jan\n2010, located in Een West in Drente province. The holding includes 450\ngoats, 249 of them pregnant; those are to be culled on 11 Jan 2010\n(today).\n\nThe Dutch delegation is expected to present an updating report on the\nQ fever situation during the next meeting of the EU's Standing\nCommittee on the Food Chain and Animal Health (SCFCAH), due in\nBrussels on Tue 12 Jan 2010. The last report on the issue (dated 6 Oct\n2009) was presented during the 3 Nov 2009 meeting (available at\n<http://ec.europa.eu/food/committees/regulatory/scfcah/animal_health/presentations/0304112009_q_fever_nl.pdf>).\n\nThose interested in additional information may refer to the paper \"Q\nfever outbreaks in small ruminants and people in the Netherlands\" by\nR. Van den Brom & P. Vellema in Small Ruminant Research 86 (2009)\n74-79. Journal homepage: <http://www.elsevier.com/locate/smallrumres>.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): update 20100107.0079\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): update 20100105.0047\nQ fever - Netherlands: monitoring 20100103.0028\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (19): update 20091229.4375\nQ fever - Netherlands (18): update 20091225.4334\nQ fever - Netherlands (17): pathogenicity, RFI 20091222.4312\nQ fever - Netherlands (16): pathogenicity, RFI 20091222.4304\nQ fever -
