If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-01-08 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-01-09 00:00:00", "2010-01-11 00:00:00", "2010-01-12 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Drente province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Verburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Een West", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Limburg", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "364265", "headline": "PRO/AH> Q fever - Netherlands (05): investigation committee", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=364265", "date": "2010-01-11 12:00:04", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (04): CULLING\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 8 Jan 2010\nSource: Dutch Ministry of Agriculture press release [in Dutch, trans.\nMod.AS, abridged, edited]\n<http://www.minlnv.nl/portal/page?_pageid=116,1640333&_dad=portal&_schema=PORTAL&p_news_item_id=24982>\n\n\nThe message that ministers Verburg (LNV) and Klink (VWS) had decided\nto refrain from culling goats in children's petting farms and\neducational institutions [see posting 20100107.0079 ] has prompted\nmany questions. Why are all pregnant animals on infected large dairy\nfarms culled, while those in small holdings and children's farms are\nnot? Is this not a double standard? The answer is: It seems so, but\nthere are good reasons for the distinction.\n\nAll control measures are considered from a public health point of\nview. During 2009, 2300 people became ill in the Netherlands from the\nQ fever bacterium. Therefore, everything is now focused on the aim to\nreduce this number as far as possible over the coming years.\n\nCulling in infected, large-scale holdings\n-----------------------------------\nThe greatest risk to public health is posed by large groups of\npregnant dairy goats and sheep, which excrete very large quantities of\nthe Q fever bacteria during normal birthing or abortions. This was\nindicated in the advice received from the expert group led by Roel\nCoutinho of RIVM (the Dutch National Institute for Public Health and\nEnvironment). If an infected goat gives birth to a live lamb, millions\nof Q-fever bacteria are released; in case of an abortion, their\nnumbers go into the billions.\n\nIn large farms, most matings are managed to take place within a short\nperiod, or mating is synchronised, leading to the birth of many\nanimals taking place during comparatively short periods, many on the\nsame days. Similarly, abortions, if occurring, may involve many\nanimals, sometimes taking the form of abortion \"storms.\" In case those\nanimals are infected by Q fever, this means the excretion of very\nlarge quantities of bacteria by many animals simultaneously: This is\nthe greatest threat to public health. Consequently, the presence of\ninfected pregnant animals on the farm should be prevented ahead of the\nlambing season (which usually starts in January). Since individual\ntesting of animals in the short term is not possible, all pregnant\nanimals on infected farms should be culled. [Subscribers are also\nreferred to the research paper cited in the commentary to posting\n20100107.0079. The authors indicated, among other things, that \"the\nstudy showed that a non-negligible [i.e. epidemiologically significant\n- Mod.JW] proportion of seronegative animals that delivered normally\ncould excrete _C. burnetii_.\" - Mod.AS]\n\nSaving animals on children's farms\n---------------------------------\nQ fever may infect sheep and goats also on petting farms, small\nholders' yards or occupational therapeutic farms (\"businesses with a\npublic function\".) The difference between these farms and large\nmilk-producing goat or sheep farms is the number of animals crowded\ntogether and birthing (or aborting) simultaneously. In small-scale\nfarms, there are fewer animals in a state of Q fever bacteria\nsecretion. Therefore, these holdings pose a lower risk to human\nhealth, and the pregnant animals on these farms are not culled.\n\nResearch shows that, so far, the Q fever bacterium has hardly ever\nbeen found in children's farms. Yet, visitors to petting farms where Q\nfever-infected sheep or goats are kept may always be exposed to some\nrisk of getting infected.\n\nThe RIVM-led expert group was asked to provide advice pertaining to\nthe said risk on petting farms or other small-scale holdings with less\nthan 50 animals. According to experts, it is generally not necessary\nto take additional measures concerning such holdings.\n\nHowever, it was recommended to pay special attention to hygiene on\nchildren's farms. In addition, children's (\"petting\") farms and\noccupational therapeutic farms are advised to let the birthing take\nplace in separate pens without pubic access. This will prevent contact\nbetween infected birthing or aborting animals and visitors, and the\nexcretion of bacteria close to visitors, and further diminish the risk\nof infection.\n\nFurthermore, it has been decided that petting and therapeutic farms\nwill be vaccinated with priority. Fortunately, there is vaccine enough\navailable for all such establishments.\n\nAdults and children visiting petting farms are advised to pay\nattention to hygiene. Appropriate advisory information is available on\nthe website of the VWA (Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority).\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Additional explanation on the significant weight of the large dairy\ngoat farms in the large-scale dissemination of _C. burnetii_ can be\nfound in the advisory letter to Ministers sent by Prof Coutinho on 17\nJul 2009. It provided several examples demonstrating the temporal and\nspatial association between large, infected dairy goat farms and human\ninfection. The 1st example (2007) came from Herpen village, where many\nhuman infections were recorded around a goat farm with an abortion\nstorm. A significant case was that of Helmond town in 2008: the\npercentage of infected humans increased in proportion to the proximity\nof their dwellings to a large dairy goat establishment. Similar\nfindings of measurable connections were recorded in South Limburg.\n\nA map showing all commercial dairy goat/sheep flocks regarded infected\nas of 8 Jan 2010, indicating the 5-km zone around each, is available\nat\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/gebiedskaart_100108_tcm92-65083.pdf>.\n\nA map showing municipalities with notified Q fever patients (per 100\n000), 1 Jan-22 Dec 2009, as well as the locations of infected\ncommercial dairy goat farms, is available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/Q-koorts%20incidentie_tcm92-60500.pdf>.\n\nA 62nd infected farm has been officially added to the list on 9 Jan\n2010, located in Een West in Drente province. The holding includes 450\ngoats, 249 of them pregnant; those are to be culled on 11 Jan 2010\n(today).\n\nThe Dutch delegation is expected to present an updating report on the\nQ fever situation during the next meeting of the EU's Standing\nCommittee on the Food Chain and Animal Health (SCFCAH), due in\nBrussels on Tue 12 Jan 2010. The last report on the issue (dated 6 Oct\n2009) was presented during the 3 Nov 2009 meeting (available at\n<http://ec.europa.eu/food/committees/regulatory/scfcah/animal_health/presentations/0304112009_q_fever_nl.pdf>).\n\nThose interested in additional information may refer to the paper \"Q\nfever outbreaks in small ruminants and people in the Netherlands\" by\nR. Van den Brom & P. Vellema in Small Ruminant Research 86 (2009)\n74-79. Journal homepage: <http://www.elsevier.com/locate/smallrumres>.\n- Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): update 20100107.0079\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): update 20100105.0047\nQ fever - Netherlands: monitoring 20100103.0028\n2009\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (19): update 20091229.4375\nQ fever - Netherlands (18): update 20091225.4334\nQ fever - Netherlands (17): pathogenicity, RFI 20091222.4312\nQ fever - Netherlands (16): pathogenicity, RFI 20091222.4304\nQ fever - Netherlands (15): update 20091219.4286\nQ fever - Netherlands (14): update 20091217.4271\nQ fever, animals - Belgium: RFI 20091213.4234\nQ fever - Netherlands (13): control measures 20091209.4198\nQ fever - Netherlands (12): update 20091207.4173\nQ fever - Netherlands (11): public health 20091113.3930\nQ fever - Netherlands (10): update 20091107.3861\nQ fever - Netherlands (09): predictions 20091004.3452\nQ fever - Netherlands (08): update, monitoring & animal vaccination\n20090927.3380\nQ fever - Netherlands (07) 20090908.3169\nQ fever - Netherlands (06) 20090814.2889\nQ fever - Netherlands (05) 20090629.2355\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): fatalities 20090626.2330\nQ Fever - Netherlands (03): update, animal vaccination 20090510.1744\nQ Fever - Netherlands (02): (NB) 20090508.1721\nQ fever, caprine - Netherlands: (LI) 20090331.1230\nQ fever - Netherlands: sheep & goat vaccination 20090228.0841\n2008\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): sheep & goat vaccination 20081023.3352\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): (NBR, GEL) 20080802.2367\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): (NBR) 20080728.2306\nQ fever - Netherlands: (NBR) 20080725.2267\n2007\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland) 20070809.2592\n....................................................arn/msp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-01-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-01-08 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2010-01-09 00:00:00", "2010-01-11 00:00:00", "2010-01-12 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "belgium", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Drente province", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Verburg", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Een West", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "South Limburg", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "363352", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - [Subscribers are also\nreferred to the research paper cited in the commentary to posting\n20100107.0079. Netherlands (03): update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=361661", "date": "2009-12-22 18:00:03", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (17): PATHOGENICITY, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 22 Dec 2009\nFrom: Catherine Filejski <Catherine.Filejski@ontario.ca> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Q fever - Netherlands (16): pathogenicity, RFI 20091222.4304\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nWith respect to the request for information about the strain(s) of\n_Coxiella burnetii_ causing the Dutch Q Fever outbreak, the US\nCenters for Disease Control Emerging Infectious Diseases journal\npublished a letter from Dutch researchers working in Nijmegen and\nEindhoven in April 2009, reporting some preliminary results from\nmultiple-locus variable-number tandem repeat analysis (MLVA) typing\nof _C. burnetii_ from a variety of human and animal clinical samples\nlinked to the outbreak obtained from different locations in the Netherlands.\n\nThe article (Multigenotype Q Fever Outbreak, the Netherlands by CHW\nKlaassen, MH Nabuurs-Franssen, JJHC Tilburg, et al, Emerg Infect Dis.\n2009 April; 15(4): 613-4. doi: 10.3201/eid1504.081612) is available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/eid/content/15/4/613.htm>.\n\nThe authors reported results showing \"that the unprecedented, ongoing\nQ fever outbreak in the Netherlands involves multiple genotypes of\n_C. burnetii_. Because most of the genotypes differ only by a single\nrepeat difference, they might represent microvariants of a\nhypervirulent strain that has been introduced in the Dutch animal population.\"\n\n--\nDr Catherine Filejski, DVM, MA, MEPA, PhD[ABD]\nVeterinary Consultant\nEnteric, Zoonotic and Vector-Borne Disease Unit\nPrevention and Control Section\nPublic Health Protection and Prevention Branch\nOntario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care\nToronto, ON M2M 4K5\nCanada\n<Catherine.Filejski@ontario.ca>\n\n[The authors of the letter to the editor of 'Emerging Infectious\nDiseases' above hypothesize that the Dutch strain of _C. burnetii_ is\n'hypervirulent'. Experimental evidence for such statement and/or for\nthe pathogenicity of the strain, as alluded to in ProMED-mail posting\n20091222.4304, has yet to be provided. Our request for information is\nmaintained. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (16): pathogenicity, RFI 20091222.4304\n...................................arn/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-04-16 00:00:00", "2009-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Zoonotic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "356014", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands (18): update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=356014", "date": "2009-12-22 18:00:03", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (17): PATHOGENICITY, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 22 Dec 2009\nFrom: Catherine Filejski <Catherine.Filejski@ontario.ca> [edited]\n\n\nRe: ProMED-mail Q fever - Netherlands (16): pathogenicity, RFI 20091222.4304\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nWith respect to the request for information about the strain(s) of\n_Coxiella burnetii_ causing the Dutch Q Fever outbreak, the US\nCenters for Disease Control Emerging Infectious Diseases journal\npublished a letter from Dutch researchers working in Nijmegen and\nEindhoven in April 2009, reporting some preliminary results from\nmultiple-locus variable-number tandem repeat analysis (MLVA) typing\nof _C. burnetii_ from a variety of human and animal clinical samples\nlinked to the outbreak obtained from different locations in the Netherlands.\n\nThe article (Multigenotype Q Fever Outbreak, the Netherlands by CHW\nKlaassen, MH Nabuurs-Franssen, JJHC Tilburg, et al, Emerg Infect Dis.\n2009 April; 15(4): 613-4. doi: 10.3201/eid1504.081612) is available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/eid/content/15/4/613.htm>.\n\nThe authors reported results showing \"that the unprecedented, ongoing\nQ fever outbreak in the Netherlands involves multiple genotypes of\n_C. burnetii_. Because most of the genotypes differ only by a single\nrepeat difference, they might represent microvariants of a\nhypervirulent strain that has been introduced in the Dutch animal population.\"\n\n--\nDr Catherine Filejski, DVM, MA, MEPA, PhD[ABD]\nVeterinary Consultant\nEnteric, Zoonotic and Vector-Borne Disease Unit\nPrevention and Control Section\nPublic Health Protection and Prevention Branch\nOntario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care\nToronto, ON M2M 4K5\nCanada\n<Catherine.Filejski@ontario.ca>\n\n[The authors of the letter to the editor of 'Emerging Infectious\nDiseases' above hypothesize that the Dutch strain of _C. burnetii_ is\n'hypervirulent'. Experimental evidence for such statement and/or for\nthe pathogenicity of the strain, as alluded to in ProMED-mail posting\n20091222.4304, has yet to be provided. Our request for information is\nmaintained. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (16): pathogenicity, RFI 20091222.4304\n...................................arn/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. 15(4): 613-4. doi: 10.3201/eid1504.081612) is available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/eid/content/15/4/613.htm>.\n\nThe authors reported results showing \"that the unprecedented, ongoing\nQ fever outbreak in the Netherlands involves multiple genotypes of\n_C. burnetii_. Because most of the genotypes differ only by a single\nrepeat difference, they might represent microvariants of a\nhypervirulent strain that has been introduced in the Dutch animal population.\"\n\n--\nDr Catherine Filejski, DVM, MA, MEPA, PhD[ABD]\nVeterinary Consultant\nEnteric, Zoonotic and Vector-Borne Disease Unit\nPrevention and Control Section\nPublic Health Protection and Prevention Branch\nOntario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care\nToronto, ON M2M 4K5\nCanada\n<Catherine.Filejski@ontario.ca>\n\n[The authors of the letter to the editor of 'Emerging Infectious\nDiseases' above hypothesize that the Dutch strain of _C. burnetii_ is\n'hypervirulent'. Experimental evidence for such statement and/or for\nthe pathogenicity of the strain, as alluded to in ProMED-mail posting\n20091222.4304, has yet to be provided. Our request for information is\nmaintained. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (16): pathogenicity, RFI 20091222.4304\n...................................arn/mj/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-04-16 00:00:00", "2009-04-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Zoonotic", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "354557", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands (16): pathogenicity, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=354557", "date": "2009-11-07 19:00:03", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (10): UPDATE\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 03 Nov 2009\nSource: VETSWEB.COM [edited]\n<http://www.vetsweb.com/news/netherlands-q-fever-in-quarter-of-the-goat-farms-598.html>\n\n\nNetherlands: Q fever in quarter of the goat farms\n-------------------------------------------------\nCurrently 80 out of the 360 goat farms in the Netherlands appear infected\nwith Q fever. This was reported by the Animal Health Service in Deventer.\nConfirmation of tests will take another 2 weeks. Measures will not be\napplied until 4 weeks from now.\n\nSo far this year 4 goat farms in the Netherlands were officially declared\ncontaminated, based on a former detection method. A farm was considered\ninfected only if the percentage of abortions was larger than 5 per cent.\nHowever, it appears that the agriculture ministry knew that another 41\nfarms had infected goats, based on milk sample tests. No measures were\napplied to these farms. In sheep farms Q fever is rare. From 40 farms, only\none proved infected.\n\nQ fever is a serious zoonosis, that causes not that severe problems in\ngoats, but has high morbidity in people with serious symptoms: fatigue,\nhigh fever, serious headaches, severe pneumonia, sometimes resulting in\nhospitalization and even death. The causal agent is _Coxiella burnetii_,\nwhich spreads through air. The bacteria is particularly dangerous in case\nof pregnancy or heart valve abnormalities.\n\nIn the Netherlands, the outbreak started in 2007 in Herpen, a village in\nthe south of the country, and since then the disease has spread every year.\n6 people died. This year 2100 people were infected. It is the largest\noutbreak of Q fever ever reported in the world.\n\nControlling the disease is difficult, because the bacteria does not\ndisappear from the soil. Until now, measures consisted of prohibition of\nspreading out manure and moving animals from infected farms.\n\nResults of vaccination are still being investigated by the Animal Health\nService. The vaccine seems to prevent abortion and animals produce\nsufficient antibodies, but it is not clear yet whether excretion of\nbacteria is prevented. Milk production may decrease by 8 to 10 percent in\nthe 1st weeks following vaccination.\n\nThe Dutch authorities commissioned the National Institute for Public Health\nand the Environment (RIVM) to develop scenarios to fight Q fever,\nconsidering also moving or closing down farms.\n\nSource: NOVA/Animal Health Service/Agrarisch dagblad\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to data from RIVM (the National Dutch Institute for Public\nHealth and the Environment), as of 29 Oct 2009, 2236 cases of Q fever have\nbeen suspected since 1 Jan 2009, 2126 of which have been\nlaboratory-confirmed and 110 regarded as \"probable\". 6 Q fever patients\ndied. The numbers for previous years were: 2007 -- 168, 2008 -- 1000. A\nhistogram presenting weekly figures for the period 1 Jan 2007 - 28 Oct 2009\nis available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/epicurve%20Q-koorts_tcm92-59728.pdf#%20class=>.\nA map, showing the distribution of the disease throughout the Netherlands\nduring 2009 (incidence per 100 000 inhabitants), is available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/Qkoorts_per_gemeente_tcm92-60500.pdf#%20class=>.\n\nThe EU's Standing Committee on the Food Chain and Animal Health (SCFCAH),\nSection : Animal Health & Animal Welfare, included the subject \"Information\nfrom the Netherlands on the Q fever situation\" on its agenda for the\nmeeting of 3-4 Nov 2009. A protocol of the meeting, with the updated Q\nfever information, is expected. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (09): predictions 20091004.3452\nQ fever - Netherlands (08): update, monitoring & animal vaccination\n20090927.3380\nQ fever - Netherlands (07) 20090908.3169\nQ fever - Netherlands (06) 20090814.2889\nQ fever - Netherlands (05) 20090629.2355\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): fatalities 20090626.2330\nQ Fever - Netherlands (03): update, animal vaccination 20090510.1744\nQ Fever - Netherlands (02): (NB) 20090508.1721\nQ fever, caprine - Netherlands: (LI) 20090331.1230\nQ fever - Netherlands: sheep & goat vaccination 20090228.0841\n2008\n---\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): sheep & goat vaccination 20081023.3352\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): (NBR, GEL) 20080802.2367\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): (NBR) 20080728.2306\nQ fever - Netherlands: (NBR) 20080725.2267\n2007\n---\nQ fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland) 20070809.2592\n\n....................arn/ejp/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2100-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-01-01 00:00:00", "2126-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "353641", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands (15): update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=353641", "date": "2009-11-07 19:00:03", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (10): UPDATE\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 03 Nov 2009\nSource: VETSWEB.COM [edited]\n<http://www.vetsweb.com/news/netherlands-q-fever-in-quarter-of-the-goat-farms-598.html>\n\n\nNetherlands: Q fever in quarter of the goat farms\n-------------------------------------------------\nCurrently 80 out of the 360 goat farms in the Netherlands appear infected\nwith Q fever. This was reported by the Animal Health Service in Deventer.\nConfirmation of tests will take another 2 weeks. Measures will not be\napplied until 4 weeks from now.\n\nSo far this year 4 goat farms in the Netherlands were officially declared\ncontaminated, based on a former detection method. A farm was considered\ninfected only if the percentage of abortions was larger than 5 per cent.\nHowever, it appears that the agriculture ministry knew that another 41\nfarms had infected goats, based on milk sample tests. No measures were\napplied to these farms. In sheep farms Q fever is rare. From 40 farms, only\none proved infected.\n\nQ fever is a serious zoonosis, that causes not that severe problems in\ngoats, but has high morbidity in people with serious symptoms: fatigue,\nhigh fever, serious headaches, severe pneumonia, sometimes resulting in\nhospitalization and even death. The causal agent is _Coxiella burnetii_,\nwhich spreads through air. The bacteria is particularly dangerous in case\nof pregnancy or heart valve abnormalities.\n\nIn the Netherlands, the outbreak started in 2007 in Herpen, a village in\nthe south of the country, and since then the disease has spread every year.\n6 people died. This year 2100 people were infected. It is the largest\noutbreak of Q fever ever reported in the world.\n\nControlling the disease is difficult, because the bacteria does not\ndisappear from the soil. Until now, measures consisted of prohibition of\nspreading out manure and moving animals from infected farms.\n\nResults of vaccination are still being investigated by the Animal Health\nService. The vaccine seems to prevent abortion and animals produce\nsufficient antibodies, but it is not clear yet whether excretion of\nbacteria is prevented. Milk production may decrease by 8 to 10 percent in\nthe 1st weeks following vaccination.\n\nThe Dutch authorities commissioned the National Institute for Public Health\nand the Environment (RIVM) to develop scenarios to fight Q fever,\nconsidering also moving or closing down farms.\n\nSource: NOVA/Animal Health Service/Agrarisch dagblad\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to data from RIVM (the National Dutch Institute for Public\nHealth and the Environment), as of 29 Oct 2009, 2236 cases of Q fever have\nbeen suspected since 1 Jan 2009, 2126 of which have been\nlaboratory-confirmed and 110 regarded as \"probable\". 6 Q fever patients\ndied. The numbers for previous years were: 2007 -- 168, 2008 -- 1000. A\nhistogram presenting weekly figures for the period 1 Jan 2007 - 28 Oct 2009\nis available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/epicurve%20Q-koorts_tcm92-59728.pdf#%20class=>.\nA map, showing the distribution of the disease throughout the Netherlands\nduring 2009 (incidence per 100 000 inhabitants), is available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/Qkoorts_per_gemeente_tcm92-60500.pdf#%20class=>.\n\nThe EU's Standing Committee on the Food Chain and Animal Health (SCFCAH),\nSection : Animal Health & Animal Welfare, included the subject \"Information\nfrom the Netherlands on the Q fever situation\" on its agenda for the\nmeeting of 3-4 Nov 2009. A protocol of the meeting, with the updated Q\nfever information, is expected. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (09): predictions 20091004.3452\nQ fever - Netherlands (08): update, monitoring & animal vaccination\n20090927.3380\nQ fever - Netherlands (07) 20090908.3169\nQ fever - Netherlands (06) 20090814.2889\nQ fever - Netherlands (05) 20090629.2355\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): fatalities 20090626.2330\nQ Fever - Netherlands (03): update, animal vaccination 20090510.1744\nQ Fever - Netherlands (02): (NB) 20090508.1721\nQ fever, caprine - Netherlands: (LI) 20090331.1230\nQ fever - Netherlands: sheep & goat vaccination 20090228.0841\n2008\n---\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): sheep & goat vaccination 20081023.3352\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): (NBR, GEL) 20080802.2367\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): (NBR) 20080728.2306\nQ fever - Netherlands: (NBR) 20080725.2267\n2007\n---\nQ fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland) 20070809.2592\n\n....................arn/ejp/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2100-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-01-01 00:00:00", "2126-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "350567", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever, animals - Belgium: RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=350567", "date": "2009-11-07 19:00:03", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (10): UPDATE\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 03 Nov 2009\nSource: VETSWEB.COM [edited]\n<http://www.vetsweb.com/news/netherlands-q-fever-in-quarter-of-the-goat-farms-598.html>\n\n\nNetherlands: Q fever in quarter of the goat farms\n-------------------------------------------------\nCurrently 80 out of the 360 goat farms in the Netherlands appear infected\nwith Q fever. This was reported by the Animal Health Service in Deventer.\nConfirmation of tests will take another 2 weeks. Measures will not be\napplied until 4 weeks from now.\n\nSo far this year 4 goat farms in the Netherlands were officially declared\ncontaminated, based on a former detection method. A farm was considered\ninfected only if the percentage of abortions was larger than 5 per cent.\nHowever, it appears that the agriculture ministry knew that another 41\nfarms had infected goats, based on milk sample tests. No measures were\napplied to these farms. In sheep farms Q fever is rare. From 40 farms, only\none proved infected.\n\nQ fever is a serious zoonosis, that causes not that severe problems in\ngoats, but has high morbidity in people with serious symptoms: fatigue,\nhigh fever, serious headaches, severe pneumonia, sometimes resulting in\nhospitalization and even death. The causal agent is _Coxiella burnetii_,\nwhich spreads through air. The bacteria is particularly dangerous in case\nof pregnancy or heart valve abnormalities.\n\nIn the Netherlands, the outbreak started in 2007 in Herpen, a village in\nthe south of the country, and since then the disease has spread every year.\n6 people died. This year 2100 people were infected. It is the largest\noutbreak of Q fever ever reported in the world.\n\nControlling the disease is difficult, because the bacteria does not\ndisappear from the soil. Until now, measures consisted of prohibition of\nspreading out manure and moving animals from infected farms.\n\nResults of vaccination are still being investigated by the Animal Health\nService. The vaccine seems to prevent abortion and animals produce\nsufficient antibodies, but it is not clear yet whether excretion of\nbacteria is prevented. Milk production may decrease by 8 to 10 percent in\nthe 1st weeks following vaccination.\n\nThe Dutch authorities commissioned the National Institute for Public Health\nand the Environment (RIVM) to develop scenarios to fight Q fever,\nconsidering also moving or closing down farms.\n\nSource: NOVA/Animal Health Service/Agrarisch dagblad\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to data from RIVM (the National Dutch Institute for Public\nHealth and the Environment), as of 29 Oct 2009, 2236 cases of Q fever have\nbeen suspected since 1 Jan 2009, 2126 of which have been\nlaboratory-confirmed and 110 regarded as \"probable\". 6 Q fever patients\ndied. The numbers for previous years were: 2007 -- 168, 2008 -- 1000. A\nhistogram presenting weekly figures for the period 1 Jan 2007 - 28 Oct 2009\nis available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/epicurve%20Q-koorts_tcm92-59728.pdf#%20class=>.\nA map, showing the distribution of the disease throughout the Netherlands\nduring 2009 (incidence per 100 000 inhabitants), is available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/Qkoorts_per_gemeente_tcm92-60500.pdf#%20class=>.\n\nThe EU's Standing Committee on the Food Chain and Animal Health (SCFCAH),\nSection : Animal Health & Animal Welfare, included the subject \"Information\nfrom the Netherlands on the Q fever situation\" on its agenda for the\nmeeting of 3-4 Nov 2009. A protocol of the meeting, with the updated Q\nfever information, is expected. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (09): predictions 20091004.3452\nQ fever - Netherlands (08): update, monitoring & animal vaccination\n20090927.3380\nQ fever - Netherlands (07) 20090908.3169\nQ fever - Netherlands (06) 20090814.2889\nQ fever - Netherlands (05) 20090629.2355\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): fatalities 20090626.2330\nQ Fever - Netherlands (03): update, animal vaccination 20090510.1744\nQ Fever - Netherlands (02): (NB) 20090508.1721\nQ fever, caprine - Netherlands: (LI) 20090331.1230\nQ fever - Netherlands: sheep & goat vaccination 20090228.0841\n2008\n---\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): sheep & goat vaccination 20081023.3352\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): (NBR, GEL) 20080802.2367\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): (NBR) 20080728.2306\nQ fever - Netherlands: (NBR) 20080725.2267\n2007\n---\nQ fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland) 20070809.2592\n\n....................arn/ejp/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Milk production may decrease by 8 to 10 percent in\nthe 1st weeks following vaccination.\n\nThe Dutch authorities commissioned the National Institute for Public Health\nand the Environment (RIVM) to develop scenarios to fight Q fever,\nconsidering also moving or closing down farms.\n\nSource: NOVA/Animal Health Service/Agrarisch dagblad\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to data from RIVM (the National Dutch Institute for Public\nHealth and the Environment), as of 29 Oct 2009, 2236 cases of Q fever have\nbeen suspected since 1 Jan 2009, 2126 of which have been\nlaboratory-confirmed and 110 regarded as \"probable\". 6 Q fever patients\ndied. The numbers for previous years were: 2007 -- 168, 2008 -- 1000. A\nhistogram presenting weekly figures for the period 1 Jan 2007 - 28 Oct 2009\nis available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/epicurve%20Q-koorts_tcm92-59728.pdf#%20class=>.\nA map, showing the distribution of the disease throughout the Netherlands\nduring 2009 (incidence per 100 000 inhabitants), is available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/Qkoorts_per_gemeente_tcm92-60500.pdf#%20class=>.\n\nThe EU's Standing Committee on the Food Chain and Animal Health (SCFCAH),\nSection : Animal Health & Animal Welfare, included the subject \"Information\nfrom the Netherlands on the Q fever situation\" on its agenda for the\nmeeting of 3-4 Nov 2009. A protocol of the meeting, with the updated Q\nfever information, is expected. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (09): predictions 20091004.3452\nQ fever - Netherlands (08): update, monitoring & animal vaccination\n20090927.3380\nQ fever - Netherlands (07) 20090908.3169\nQ fever - Netherlands (06) 20090814.2889\nQ fever - Netherlands (05) 20090629.2355\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): fatalities 20090626.2330\nQ Fever - Netherlands (03): update, animal vaccination 20090510.1744\nQ Fever - Netherlands (02): (NB) 20090508.1721\nQ fever, caprine - Netherlands: (LI) 20090331.1230\nQ fever - Netherlands: sheep & goat vaccination 20090228.0841\n2008\n---\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): sheep & goat vaccination 20081023.3352\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): (NBR, GEL) 20080802.2367\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): (NBR) 20080728.2306\nQ fever - Netherlands: (NBR) 20080725.2267\n2007\n---\nQ fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland) 20070809.2592\n\n....................arn/ejp/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2100-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-01-01 00:00:00", "2126-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "327099", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands (10): update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=327099", "date": "2009-11-07 19:00:03", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (10): UPDATE\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 03 Nov 2009\nSource: VETSWEB.COM [edited]\n<http://www.vetsweb.com/news/netherlands-q-fever-in-quarter-of-the-goat-farms-598.html>\n\n\nNetherlands: Q fever in quarter of the goat farms\n-------------------------------------------------\nCurrently 80 out of the 360 goat farms in the Netherlands appear infected\nwith Q fever. This was reported by the Animal Health Service in Deventer.\nConfirmation of tests will take another 2 weeks. Measures will not be\napplied until 4 weeks from now.\n\nSo far this year 4 goat farms in the Netherlands were officially declared\ncontaminated, based on a former detection method. A farm was considered\ninfected only if the percentage of abortions was larger than 5 per cent.\nHowever, it appears that the agriculture ministry knew that another 41\nfarms had infected goats, based on milk sample tests. No measures were\napplied to these farms. In sheep farms Q fever is rare. From 40 farms, only\none proved infected.\n\nQ fever is a serious zoonosis, that causes not that severe problems in\ngoats, but has high morbidity in people with serious symptoms: fatigue,\nhigh fever, serious headaches, severe pneumonia, sometimes resulting in\nhospitalization and even death. The causal agent is _Coxiella burnetii_,\nwhich spreads through air. The bacteria is particularly dangerous in case\nof pregnancy or heart valve abnormalities.\n\nIn the Netherlands, the outbreak started in 2007 in Herpen, a village in\nthe south of the country, and since then the disease has spread every year.\n6 people died. This year 2100 people were infected. It is the largest\noutbreak of Q fever ever reported in the world.\n\nControlling the disease is difficult, because the bacteria does not\ndisappear from the soil. Until now, measures consisted of prohibition of\nspreading out manure and moving animals from infected farms.\n\nResults of vaccination are still being investigated by the Animal Health\nService. The vaccine seems to prevent abortion and animals produce\nsufficient antibodies, but it is not clear yet whether excretion of\nbacteria is prevented. Milk production may decrease by 8 to 10 percent in\nthe 1st weeks following vaccination.\n\nThe Dutch authorities commissioned the National Institute for Public Health\nand the Environment (RIVM) to develop scenarios to fight Q fever,\nconsidering also moving or closing down farms.\n\nSource: NOVA/Animal Health Service/Agrarisch dagblad\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to data from RIVM (the National Dutch Institute for Public\nHealth and the Environment), as of 29 Oct 2009, 2236 cases of Q fever have\nbeen suspected since 1 Jan 2009, 2126 of which have been\nlaboratory-confirmed and 110 regarded as \"probable\". 6 Q fever patients\ndied. The numbers for previous years were: 2007 -- 168, 2008 -- 1000. A\nhistogram presenting weekly figures for the period 1 Jan 2007 - 28 Oct 2009\nis available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/epicurve%20Q-koorts_tcm92-59728.pdf#%20class=>.\nA map, showing the distribution of the disease throughout the Netherlands\nduring 2009 (incidence per 100 000 inhabitants), is available at\n<http://www.rivm.nl/cib/binaries/Qkoorts_per_gemeente_tcm92-60500.pdf#%20class=>.\n\nThe EU's Standing Committee on the Food Chain and Animal Health (SCFCAH),\nSection : Animal Health & Animal Welfare, included the subject \"Information\nfrom the Netherlands on the Q fever situation\" on its agenda for the\nmeeting of 3-4 Nov 2009. A protocol of the meeting, with the updated Q\nfever information, is expected. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (09): predictions 20091004.3452\nQ fever - Netherlands (08): update, monitoring & animal vaccination\n20090927.3380\nQ fever - Netherlands (07) 20090908.3169\nQ fever - Netherlands (06) 20090814.2889\nQ fever - Netherlands (05) 20090629.2355\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): fatalities 20090626.2330\nQ Fever - Netherlands (03): update, animal vaccination 20090510.1744\nQ Fever - Netherlands (02): (NB) 20090508.1721\nQ fever, caprine - Netherlands: (LI) 20090331.1230\nQ fever - Netherlands: sheep & goat vaccination 20090228.0841\n2008\n---\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): sheep & goat vaccination 20081023.3352\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): (NBR, GEL) 20080802.2367\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): (NBR) 20080728.2306\nQ fever - Netherlands: (NBR) 20080725.2267\n2007\n---\nQ fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland) 20070809.2592\n\n....................arn/ejp/sh\n\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2100-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-01-01 00:00:00", "2126-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2009-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "304016", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands (09): predictions", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=304016", "date": "2009-05-08 15:00:05", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (02): (NORTH BRABANT)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 6 May 2009\nSource: Dutch News [edited]\n<http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2009/05/q_fever_cases_surge.php>\n\n\nThe number of cases of Q fever reported among humans in the\nNetherlands has risen 'explosively' over the past few weeks, the\nVolkskrant reports on Wednesday [6 May 2009]. The paper says over 200\ncases have been reported in recent days, half of them in\nNoord-Brabant province.\n\nQ fever was rarely known among humans in the Netherlands until 2007,\nwhen 168 cases were reported. In 2008, there were more than 1000\ninfections in the Netherlands.\n\nThe infection is spread by livestock, which shed the bacteria in\nurine, feces, birth products, and milk. The bacteria can reach humans\nafter feces and dirty straw are used as fertilizer and blown about,\nthe Volkskrant says. The disease, which leads to spontaneous abortion\nin sheep and goats, causes flu-like symptoms in humans but can lead\nto lung infections.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The pathogenic organism of Q fever, often acquired by close exposure\nto animals, is infectious with a very low inoculum and may be\naerosolized over a distance. It is not clear what contact the\ninfected people had with animals or how close they were to farms.\n\n_Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was discovered in 1937.\nThis organism is an agent that can be resistant to heat and\ndesiccation, and is highly infectious by the aerosol route. A single\ninhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human]\nprimates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was found to be\n1.7 organisms (1).\n\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals,\nincluding other species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C.\nburnetii_ does not usually cause clinical disease in these animals,\nalthough abortion in goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_\ninfection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of\ninfected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta.\nContact with contaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication along with the less resistant\nlarge cell form, metabolically dormant, and spore-like (3).\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. Other modes of transmission to humans, including tick\nbites and human-to-human transmission, are rare.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C: An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of \"Q fever.\" Pub Hlth Rep 1941; 56: 1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D: Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12: 518-53\n[available at\n<http://cmr.asm.org/cgi/content/full/12/4/518>].\n3. Norlander L: Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes\nInfect 2000; 2: 417-24 [abstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10817644>.\n4. CDC online: Q fever; available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/qfever>.\n\nThe location of the southern province of Noord-Brabant (North\nBrabant) can be found on map at\n<http://www.amsterdam.co.kr/general/maps/nl_map_provinces.gif>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the Netherlands is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00bv>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands: sheep & goat vaccination 20090228.0841\n2008\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): sheep & goat vaccination 20081023.3352\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): (NBR, GEL) 20080802.2367\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): (NBR) 20080728.2306\nQ fever - Netherlands: (NBR) 20080725.2267\n2007\n----\nQ fever - UK (England) (02) 20070921.3142\nQ fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland) 20070809.2592\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - UK (England): alert, RFI 20070723.2367\nQ fever, veterinary students - Slovenia 20070720.2332\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n...................................ll/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2009-05-06 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "1941-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the \n Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "300311", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands (08): update, monitoring & animal vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=300311", "date": "2009-05-08 15:00:05", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (02): (NORTH BRABANT)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 6 May 2009\nSource: Dutch News [edited]\n<http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2009/05/q_fever_cases_surge.php>\n\n\nThe number of cases of Q fever reported among humans in the\nNetherlands has risen 'explosively' over the past few weeks, the\nVolkskrant reports on Wednesday [6 May 2009]. It is not clear what contact the\ninfected people had with animals or how close they were to farms.\n\n_Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was discovered in 1937.\nThis organism is an agent that can be resistant to heat and\ndesiccation, and is highly infectious by the aerosol route. A single\ninhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human]\nprimates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was found to be\n1.7 organisms (1).\n\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals,\nincluding other species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C.\nburnetii_ does not usually cause clinical disease in these animals,\nalthough abortion in goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_\ninfection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of\ninfected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta.\nContact with contaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication along with the less resistant\nlarge cell form, metabolically dormant, and spore-like (3).\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. Other modes of transmission to humans, including tick\nbites and human-to-human transmission, are rare.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C: An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of \"Q fever.\" Pub Hlth Rep 1941; 56: 1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D: Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12: 518-53\n[available at\n<http://cmr.asm.org/cgi/content/full/12/4/518>].\n3. Norlander L: Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes\nInfect 2000; 2: 417-24 [abstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10817644>.\n4. CDC online: Q fever; available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/qfever>.\n\nThe location of the southern province of Noord-Brabant (North\nBrabant) can be found on map at\n<http://www.amsterdam.co.kr/general/maps/nl_map_provinces.gif>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the Netherlands is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00bv>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands: sheep & goat vaccination 20090228.0841\n2008\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): sheep & goat vaccination 20081023.3352\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): (NBR, GEL) 20080802.2367\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): (NBR) 20080728.2306\nQ fever - Netherlands: (NBR) 20080725.2267\n2007\n----\nQ fever - UK (England) (02) 20070921.3142\nQ fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland) 20070809.2592\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - UK (England): alert, RFI 20070723.2367\nQ fever, veterinary students - Slovenia 20070720.2332\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n...................................ll/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2009-05-06 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "1941-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the \n Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "267526", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=267526", "date": "2009-05-08 15:00:05", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (02): (NORTH BRABANT)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 6 May 2009\nSource: Dutch News [edited]\n<http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2009/05/q_fever_cases_surge.php>\n\n\nThe number of cases of Q fever reported among humans in the\nNetherlands has risen 'explosively' over the past few weeks, the\nVolkskrant reports on Wednesday [6 May 2009]. The paper says over 200\ncases have been reported in recent days, half of them in\nNoord-Brabant province.\n\nQ fever was rarely known among humans in the Netherlands until 2007,\nwhen 168 cases were reported. In 2008, there were more than 1000\ninfections in the Netherlands.\n\nThe infection is spread by livestock, which shed the bacteria in\nurine, feces, birth products, and milk. The bacteria can reach humans\nafter feces and dirty straw are used as fertilizer and blown about,\nthe Volkskrant says. The disease, which leads to spontaneous abortion\nin sheep and goats, causes flu-like symptoms in humans but can lead\nto lung infections.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The pathogenic organism of Q fever, often acquired by close exposure\nto animals, is infectious with a very low inoculum and may be\naerosolized over a distance. It is not clear what contact the\ninfected people had with animals or how close they were to farms.\n\n_Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was discovered in 1937.\nThis organism is an agent that can be resistant to heat and\ndesiccation, and is highly infectious by the aerosol route. A single\ninhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human]\nprimates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was found to be\n1.7 organisms (1).\n\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals,\nincluding other species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C.\nburnetii_ does not usually cause clinical disease in these animals,\nalthough abortion in goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_\ninfection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of\ninfected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta.\nContact with contaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication along with the less resistant\nlarge cell form, metabolically dormant, and spore-like (3).\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. Other modes of transmission to humans, including tick\nbites and human-to-human transmission, are rare.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C: An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of \"Q fever.\" Pub Hlth Rep 1941; 56: 1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D: Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12: 518-53\n[available at\n<http://cmr.asm.org/cgi/content/full/12/4/518>].\n3. Norlander L: Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes\nInfect 2000; 2: 417-24 [abstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10817644>.\n4. CDC online: Q fever; available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/qfever>.\n\nThe location of the southern province of Noord-Brabant (North\nBrabant) can be found on map at\n<http://www.amsterdam.co.kr/general/maps/nl_map_provinces.gif>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the Netherlands is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00bv>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands: sheep & goat vaccination 20090228.0841\n2008\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): sheep & goat vaccination 20081023.3352\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): (NBR, GEL) 20080802.2367\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): (NBR) 20080728.2306\nQ fever - Netherlands: (NBR) 20080725.2267\n2007\n----\nQ fever - UK (England) (02) 20070921.3142\nQ fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland) 20070809.2592\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - UK (England): alert, RFI 20070723.2367\nQ fever, veterinary students - Slovenia 20070720.2332\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n...................................ll/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta.\nContact with contaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. The paper says over 200\ncases have been reported in recent days, half of them in\nNoord-Brabant province.\n\nQ fever was rarely known among humans in the Netherlands until 2007,\nwhen 168 cases were reported. In 2008, there were more than 1000\ninfections in the Netherlands.\n\nThe infection is spread by livestock, which shed the bacteria in\nurine, feces, birth products, and milk. The bacteria can reach humans\nafter feces and dirty straw are used as fertilizer and blown about,\nthe Volkskrant says. The disease, which leads to spontaneous abortion\nin sheep and goats, causes flu-like symptoms in humans but can lead\nto lung infections.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The pathogenic organism of Q fever, often acquired by close exposure\nto animals, is infectious with a very low inoculum and may be\naerosolized over a distance. It is not clear what contact the\ninfected people had with animals or how close they were to farms.\n\n_Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was discovered in 1937.\nThis organism is an agent that can be resistant to heat and\ndesiccation, and is highly infectious by the aerosol route. A single\ninhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human]\nprimates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was found to be\n1.7 organisms (1).\n\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals,\nincluding other species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C.\nburnetii_ does not usually cause clinical disease in these animals,\nalthough abortion in goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_\ninfection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of\ninfected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta.\nContact with contaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication along with the less resistant\nlarge cell form, metabolically dormant, and spore-like (3).\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. Other modes of transmission to humans, including tick\nbites and human-to-human transmission, are rare.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C: An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of \"Q fever.\" Pub Hlth Rep 1941; 56: 1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D: Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12: 518-53\n[available at\n<http://cmr.asm.org/cgi/content/full/12/4/518>].\n3. Norlander L: Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes\nInfect 2000; 2: 417-24 [abstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10817644>.\n4. CDC online: Q fever; available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/qfever>.\n\nThe location of the southern province of Noord-Brabant (North\nBrabant) can be found on map at\n<http://www.amsterdam.co.kr/general/maps/nl_map_provinces.gif>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the Netherlands is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00bv>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands: sheep & goat vaccination 20090228.0841\n2008\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): sheep & goat vaccination 20081023.3352\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): (NBR, GEL) 20080802.2367\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): (NBR) 20080728.2306\nQ fever - Netherlands: (NBR) 20080725.2267\n2007\n----\nQ fever - UK (England) (02) 20070921.3142\nQ fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland) 20070809.2592\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - UK (England): alert, RFI 20070723.2367\nQ fever, veterinary students - Slovenia 20070720.2332\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n...................................ll/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2009-05-06 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "1941-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the \n Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "192729", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q Fever - Netherlands (02): (NB)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=192729", "date": "2009-05-08 15:00:05", "main_text": "Q FEVER - NETHERLANDS (02): (NORTH BRABANT)\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 6 May 2009\nSource: Dutch News [edited]\n<http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2009/05/q_fever_cases_surge.php>\n\n\nThe number of cases of Q fever reported among humans in the\nNetherlands has risen 'explosively' over the past few weeks, the\nVolkskrant reports on Wednesday [6 May 2009]. The paper says over 200\ncases have been reported in recent days, half of them in\nNoord-Brabant province.\n\nQ fever was rarely known among humans in the Netherlands until 2007,\nwhen 168 cases were reported. In 2008, there were more than 1000\ninfections in the Netherlands.\n\nThe infection is spread by livestock, which shed the bacteria in\nurine, feces, birth products, and milk. The bacteria can reach humans\nafter feces and dirty straw are used as fertilizer and blown about,\nthe Volkskrant says. The disease, which leads to spontaneous abortion\nin sheep and goats, causes flu-like symptoms in humans but can lead\nto lung infections.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The pathogenic organism of Q fever, often acquired by close exposure\nto animals, is infectious with a very low inoculum and may be\naerosolized over a distance. It is not clear what contact the\ninfected people had with animals or how close they were to farms.\n\n_Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was discovered in 1937.\nThis organism is an agent that can be resistant to heat and\ndesiccation, and is highly infectious by the aerosol route. A single\ninhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human]\nprimates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was found to be\n1.7 organisms (1).\n\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals,\nincluding other species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C.\nburnetii_ does not usually cause clinical disease in these animals,\nalthough abortion in goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_\ninfection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of\ninfected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta.\nContact with contaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\n\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication along with the less resistant\nlarge cell form, metabolically dormant, and spore-like (3).\n\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\n\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. Other modes of transmission to humans, including tick\nbites and human-to-human transmission, are rare.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C: An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of \"Q fever.\" Pub Hlth Rep 1941; 56: 1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D: Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12: 518-53\n[available at\n<http://cmr.asm.org/cgi/content/full/12/4/518>].\n3. Norlander L: Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes\nInfect 2000; 2: 417-24 [abstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10817644>.\n4. CDC online: Q fever; available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/qfever>.\n\nThe location of the southern province of Noord-Brabant (North\nBrabant) can be found on map at\n<http://www.amsterdam.co.kr/general/maps/nl_map_provinces.gif>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of the Netherlands is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00bv>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands: sheep & goat vaccination 20090228.0841\n2008\n----\nQ fever - Netherlands (04): sheep & goat vaccination 20081023.3352\nQ fever - Netherlands (03): (NBR, GEL) 20080802.2367\nQ fever - Netherlands (02): (NBR) 20080728.2306\nQ fever - Netherlands: (NBR) 20080725.2267\n2007\n----\nQ fever - UK (England) (02) 20070921.3142\nQ fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland) 20070809.2592\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - UK (England): alert, RFI 20070723.2367\nQ fever, veterinary students - Slovenia 20070720.2332\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n...................................ll/mj/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
