For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2009-05-06 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2008-03-16 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "1941-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the \n Netherlands", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "169517", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever, caprine - Netherlands: (LI)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=169517", "date": "2007-09-21 16:00:09", "main_text": "Q FEVER - UK (ENGLAND) (02)\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 20 Sep 2007\nSource: BBC [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/gloucestershire/7004615.stm>\n\nAn outbreak of a rare illness called Q fever, which is caught from infected\nlivestock, is being investigated in the Cheltenham area of Gloucestershire.\nA total of 28 cases have been identified among local people, most requiring\nhospital treatment.\nVictims can suffer severe pnuemonia while others show no ill effects. Some\npeople recover without treatment. The infection is often caught by close\ncontact with farm animals but it can be also be blown through the air. A\nteam led by the Health Protection Agency is looking at how residents may\nhave caught the infection.\nEpidemiologist Dr Deirdre Lewis said: \"Q fever is generally a mild\ninfection but we know that it can cause complications, so we've been keen\nto look into this as thoroughly as we can. We've not had any reported cases\nof Q fever in Gloucestershire residents since 2002, so seeing 28, mostly\nfrom the Cheltenham area, is unusual.\"\nThe evidence so far points to the period of risk being more than 3 months\nago. Most of the patients, who are aged between 40 and 70, are said to be\nrecovering well after falling ill earlier in the summer.\nQ, standing for Query, fever, was so called originally because for many\nyears its cause was unknown. It tends to be more common around the lambing\nseason, although it can occur at any time of year.\n\"I appreciate that news of this outbreak will surprise some local people,\"\nsaid Dr Lewis. \"They can be reassured that we're working hard to\ninvestigate it.\"\nAn outbreak of Q fever in Solihull in 1989 led to 147 human cases.\nResearchers have suggested that it was caused by a combination of outdoor\nlambing and calving and particular weather conditions leading to the\ninfective organism being blown several miles to populated areas.\n--\ncommunicated by:\nAndrea Jones\nH Jones and Sons\n<agency@hjones-sons.co.uk>\n[ProMED-mail previously posted regarding the early part of this outbreak [Q\nfever - UK (England): alert, RFI 20070723.2367].\n_Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was discovered in 1937. This\norganism is an agent that can be resistant to heat and desiccation, and is\nhighly infectious by the aerosol route. A single inhaled organism may\nproduce clinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human] primates, the dose to kill\n50 per cent of the primates was found to be 1.7 organisms (1).\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including\nother species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does not\nusually cause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats\nand sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection. Organisms are\nexcreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals. Most importantly,\nduring birthing the organisms are shed in high numbers within the amniotic\nfluids and the placenta. Contact with contaminated wool is known to be a\nmode of transmission (2).\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication along with the less resistant large\ncell form, metabolically dormant, and spore-like (3).\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from\nair that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental\nmaterial, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are\noften very susceptible to the disease, and very few organisms may be\nrequired to cause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration\nof the contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other\nmodes of transmission to humans, including tick bites and human-to-human\ntransmission, are rare.\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C. An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of \"Q fever.\" Pub Hlth Rep 1941; 56: 1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D. Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12: 518-53.\n3. Norlander L. Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes Infect\n2000; 2: 417-24.\nCheltenham is in the west of England, in Gloucestershire, and can be found\non a map at <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheltenham>. More information is\nneeded to assess how these individuals acquired this airborne infection,\nwhich can spread over at least 1/2 mile. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland) 20070809.2592\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - UK (England): alert, RFI 20070723.2367\nQ fever, veterinary students - Slovenia 20070720.2332\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2006\n---\nQ fever - USA (IA,IL): RFI 20061130.3391\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) (02) 20060825.2394\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) 20060721.2001\n2005\n---\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\nQ fever, contaminated wool - Russia (Moscow) 20051025.3118\nQ fever - Israel 20050814.2378\nQ fever - USA (CO) 20050810.2329\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\n2004\n---\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\nQ fever - Bulgaria (Botevgrad) 20040829.2413\nQ fever - Bosnia & Herzegovina (Banja Luka) 20040513.1291\n2002\n---\nQ fever - UK (Wales) 20021027.5653\nQ fever - France (Chamonix) (02) 20020911.5283\nQ fever - France (Chamonix) 20020903.5224\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany (02) 20020629.4632\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany: RFI 20020626.4607\nQ fever - Bosnia & Herzegovina (Livno) 20020328.3832\n2001\n---\nQ fever - Australia (Queensland) 20010129.0204\n.................ll/ejp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "1941-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gloucestershire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Solihull", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "161153", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands: sheep & goat vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=161153", "date": "2007-09-21 16:00:09", "main_text": "Q FEVER - UK (ENGLAND) (02)\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 20 Sep 2007\nSource: BBC [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/gloucestershire/7004615.stm>\n\nAn outbreak of a rare illness called Q fever, which is caught from infected\nlivestock, is being investigated in the Cheltenham area of Gloucestershire.\nA total of 28 cases have been identified among local people, most requiring\nhospital treatment.\nVictims can suffer severe pnuemonia while others show no ill effects. Some\npeople recover without treatment. The infection is often caught by close\ncontact with farm animals but it can be also be blown through the air. A\nteam led by the Health Protection Agency is looking at how residents may\nhave caught the infection.\nEpidemiologist Dr Deirdre Lewis said: \"Q fever is generally a mild\ninfection but we know that it can cause complications, so we've been keen\nto look into this as thoroughly as we can. We've not had any reported cases\nof Q fever in Gloucestershire residents since 2002, so seeing 28, mostly\nfrom the Cheltenham area, is unusual.\"\nThe evidence so far points to the period of risk being more than 3 months\nago. Most of the patients, who are aged between 40 and 70, are said to be\nrecovering well after falling ill earlier in the summer.\nQ, standing for Query, fever, was so called originally because for many\nyears its cause was unknown. It tends to be more common around the lambing\nseason, although it can occur at any time of year.\n\"I appreciate that news of this outbreak will surprise some local people,\"\nsaid Dr Lewis. \"They can be reassured that we're working hard to\ninvestigate it.\"\nAn outbreak of Q fever in Solihull in 1989 led to 147 human cases.\nResearchers have suggested that it was caused by a combination of outdoor\nlambing and calving and particular weather conditions leading to the\ninfective organism being blown several miles to populated areas.\n--\ncommunicated by:\nAndrea Jones\nH Jones and Sons\n<agency@hjones-sons.co.uk>\n[ProMED-mail previously posted regarding the early part of this outbreak [Q\nfever - UK (England): alert, RFI 20070723.2367].\n_Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was discovered in 1937. This\norganism is an agent that can be resistant to heat and desiccation, and is\nhighly infectious by the aerosol route. A single inhaled organism may\nproduce clinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human] primates, the dose to kill\n50 per cent of the primates was found to be 1.7 organisms (1).\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including\nother species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does not\nusually cause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats\nand sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection. Organisms are\nexcreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals. Most importantly,\nduring birthing the organisms are shed in high numbers within the amniotic\nfluids and the placenta. Contact with contaminated wool is known to be a\nmode of transmission (2).\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication along with the less resistant large\ncell form, metabolically dormant, and spore-like (3).\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from\nair that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental\nmaterial, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are\noften very susceptible to the disease, and very few organisms may be\nrequired to cause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration\nof the contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other\nmodes of transmission to humans, including tick bites and human-to-human\ntransmission, are rare.\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C. An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of \"Q fever.\" Pub Hlth Rep 1941; 56: 1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D. Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12: 518-53.\n3. Norlander L. Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes Infect\n2000; 2: 417-24.\nCheltenham is in the west of England, in Gloucestershire, and can be found\non a map at <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheltenham>. More information is\nneeded to assess how these individuals acquired this airborne infection,\nwhich can spread over at least 1/2 mile. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland) 20070809.2592\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - UK (England): alert, RFI 20070723.2367\nQ fever, veterinary students - Slovenia 20070720.2332\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2006\n---\nQ fever - USA (IA,IL): RFI 20061130.3391\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) (02) 20060825.2394\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) 20060721.2001\n2005\n---\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\nQ fever, contaminated wool - Russia (Moscow) 20051025.3118\nQ fever - Israel 20050814.2378\nQ fever - USA (CO) 20050810.2329\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\n2004\n---\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\nQ fever - Bulgaria (Botevgrad) 20040829.2413\nQ fever - Bosnia & Herzegovina (Banja Luka) 20040513.1291\n2002\n---\nQ fever - UK (Wales) 20021027.5653\nQ fever - France (Chamonix) (02) 20020911.5283\nQ fever - France (Chamonix) 20020903.5224\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany (02) 20020629.4632\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany: RFI 20020626.4607\nQ fever - Bosnia & Herzegovina (Livno) 20020328.3832\n2001\n---\nQ fever - Australia (Queensland) 20010129.0204\n.................ll/ejp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "1941-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gloucestershire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Solihull", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "121718", "headline": "PRO/AH> Q fever - Netherlands (04): sheep & goat vaccination", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=121718", "date": "2007-09-21 16:00:09", "main_text": "Q FEVER - UK (ENGLAND) (02)\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 20 Sep 2007\nSource: BBC [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/gloucestershire/7004615.stm>\n\nAn outbreak of a rare illness called Q fever, which is caught from infected\nlivestock, is being investigated in the Cheltenham area of Gloucestershire.\nA total of 28 cases have been identified among local people, most requiring\nhospital treatment.\nVictims can suffer severe pnuemonia while others show no ill effects. Some\npeople recover without treatment. The infection is often caught by close\ncontact with farm animals but it can be also be blown through the air. A\nteam led by the Health Protection Agency is looking at how residents may\nhave caught the infection.\nEpidemiologist Dr Deirdre Lewis said: \"Q fever is generally a mild\ninfection but we know that it can cause complications, so we've been keen\nto look into this as thoroughly as we can. We've not had any reported cases\nof Q fever in Gloucestershire residents since 2002, so seeing 28, mostly\nfrom the Cheltenham area, is unusual.\"\nThe evidence so far points to the period of risk being more than 3 months\nago. Most of the patients, who are aged between 40 and 70, are said to be\nrecovering well after falling ill earlier in the summer.\nQ, standing for Query, fever, was so called originally because for many\nyears its cause was unknown. It tends to be more common around the lambing\nseason, although it can occur at any time of year.\n\"I appreciate that news of this outbreak will surprise some local people,\"\nsaid Dr Lewis. \"They can be reassured that we're working hard to\ninvestigate it.\"\nAn outbreak of Q fever in Solihull in 1989 led to 147 human cases.\nResearchers have suggested that it was caused by a combination of outdoor\nlambing and calving and particular weather conditions leading to the\ninfective organism being blown several miles to populated areas.\n--\ncommunicated by:\nAndrea Jones\nH Jones and Sons\n<agency@hjones-sons.co.uk>\n[ProMED-mail previously posted regarding the early part of this outbreak [Q\nfever - UK (England): alert, RFI 20070723.2367].\n_Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was discovered in 1937. This\norganism is an agent that can be resistant to heat and desiccation, and is\nhighly infectious by the aerosol route. A single inhaled organism may\nproduce clinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human] primates, the dose to kill\n50 per cent of the primates was found to be 1.7 organisms (1).\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including\nother species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does not\nusually cause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats\nand sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection. Organisms are\nexcreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals. Most importantly,\nduring birthing the organisms are shed in high numbers within the amniotic\nfluids and the placenta. Contact with contaminated wool is known to be a\nmode of transmission (2).\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication along with the less resistant large\ncell form, metabolically dormant, and spore-like (3).\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from\nair that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental\nmaterial, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are\noften very susceptible to the disease, and very few organisms may be\nrequired to cause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration\nof the contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other\nmodes of transmission to humans, including tick bites and human-to-human\ntransmission, are rare.\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C. An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of \"Q fever.\" Pub Hlth Rep 1941; 56: 1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D. Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12: 518-53.\n3. Norlander L. Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes Infect\n2000; 2: 417-24.\nCheltenham is in the west of England, in Gloucestershire, and can be found\non a map at <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheltenham>. More information is\nneeded to assess how these individuals acquired this airborne infection,\nwhich can spread over at least 1/2 mile. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland) 20070809.2592\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - UK (England): alert, RFI 20070723.2367\nQ fever, veterinary students - Slovenia 20070720.2332\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2006\n---\nQ fever - USA (IA,IL): RFI 20061130.3391\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) (02) 20060825.2394\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) 20060721.2001\n2005\n---\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\nQ fever, contaminated wool - Russia (Moscow) 20051025.3118\nQ fever - Israel 20050814.2378\nQ fever - USA (CO) 20050810.2329\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\n2004\n---\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\nQ fever - Bulgaria (Botevgrad) 20040829.2413\nQ fever - Bosnia & Herzegovina (Banja Luka) 20040513.1291\n2002\n---\nQ fever - UK (Wales) 20021027.5653\nQ fever - France (Chamonix) (02) 20020911.5283\nQ fever - France (Chamonix) 20020903.5224\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany (02) 20020629.4632\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany: RFI 20020626.4607\nQ fever - Bosnia & Herzegovina (Livno) 20020328.3832\n2001\n---\nQ fever - Australia (Queensland) 20010129.0204\n.................ll/ejp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Some\npeople recover without treatment. The infection is often caught by close\ncontact with farm animals but it can be also be blown through the air. A\nteam led by the Health Protection Agency is looking at how residents may\nhave caught the infection.\nEpidemiologist Dr Deirdre Lewis said: \"Q fever is generally a mild\ninfection but we know that it can cause complications, so we've been keen\nto look into this as thoroughly as we can. Most of the patients, who are aged between 40 and 70, are said to be\nrecovering well after falling ill earlier in the summer.\nQ, standing for Query, fever, was so called originally because for many\nyears its cause was unknown. It tends to be more common around the lambing\nseason, although it can occur at any time of year.\n\"I appreciate that news of this outbreak will surprise some local people,\"\nsaid Dr Lewis. \"They can be reassured that we're working hard to\ninvestigate it.\"\nAn outbreak of Q fever in Solihull in 1989 led to 147 human cases.\nResearchers have suggested that it was caused by a combination of outdoor\nlambing and calving and particular weather conditions leading to the\ninfective organism being blown several miles to populated areas.\n--\ncommunicated by:\nAndrea Jones\nH Jones and Sons\n<agency@hjones-sons.co.uk>\n[ProMED-mail previously posted regarding the early part of this outbreak [Q\nfever - UK (England): alert, RFI 20070723.2367].\n_Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was discovered in 1937. This\norganism is an agent that can be resistant to heat and desiccation, and is\nhighly infectious by the aerosol route. A single inhaled organism may\nproduce clinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human] primates, the dose to kill\n50 per cent of the primates was found to be 1.7 organisms (1).\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including\nother species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does not\nusually cause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats\nand sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection. Organisms are\nexcreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals. Most importantly,\nduring birthing the organisms are shed in high numbers within the amniotic\nfluids and the placenta. Contact with contaminated wool is known to be a\nmode of transmission (2).\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication along with the less resistant large\ncell form, metabolically dormant, and spore-like (3).\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from\nair that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental\nmaterial, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are\noften very susceptible to the disease, and very few organisms may be\nrequired to cause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration\nof the contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other\nmodes of transmission to humans, including tick bites and human-to-human\ntransmission, are rare.\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C. An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Norlander L. Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes Infect\n2000; 2: 417-24.\nCheltenham is in the west of England, in Gloucestershire, and can be found\non a map at <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheltenham>. A\nteam led by the Health Protection Agency is looking at how residents may\nhave caught the infection.\nEpidemiologist Dr Deirdre Lewis said: \"Q fever is generally a mild\ninfection but we know that it can cause complications, so we've been keen\nto look into this as thoroughly as we can. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "1941-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gloucestershire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Solihull", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "97879", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands: (NBR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=97879", "date": "2007-09-21 16:00:09", "main_text": "Q FEVER - UK (ENGLAND) (02)\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 20 Sep 2007\nSource: BBC [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/gloucestershire/7004615.stm>\n\nAn outbreak of a rare illness called Q fever, which is caught from infected\nlivestock, is being investigated in the Cheltenham area of Gloucestershire.\nA total of 28 cases have been identified among local people, most requiring\nhospital treatment.\nVictims can suffer severe pnuemonia while others show no ill effects. Some\npeople recover without treatment. The infection is often caught by close\ncontact with farm animals but it can be also be blown through the air. A\nteam led by the Health Protection Agency is looking at how residents may\nhave caught the infection.\nEpidemiologist Dr Deirdre Lewis said: \"Q fever is generally a mild\ninfection but we know that it can cause complications, so we've been keen\nto look into this as thoroughly as we can. We've not had any reported cases\nof Q fever in Gloucestershire residents since 2002, so seeing 28, mostly\nfrom the Cheltenham area, is unusual.\"\nThe evidence so far points to the period of risk being more than 3 months\nago. Most of the patients, who are aged between 40 and 70, are said to be\nrecovering well after falling ill earlier in the summer.\nQ, standing for Query, fever, was so called originally because for many\nyears its cause was unknown. It tends to be more common around the lambing\nseason, although it can occur at any time of year.\n\"I appreciate that news of this outbreak will surprise some local people,\"\nsaid Dr Lewis. \"They can be reassured that we're working hard to\ninvestigate it.\"\nAn outbreak of Q fever in Solihull in 1989 led to 147 human cases.\nResearchers have suggested that it was caused by a combination of outdoor\nlambing and calving and particular weather conditions leading to the\ninfective organism being blown several miles to populated areas.\n--\ncommunicated by:\nAndrea Jones\nH Jones and Sons\n<agency@hjones-sons.co.uk>\n[ProMED-mail previously posted regarding the early part of this outbreak [Q\nfever - UK (England): alert, RFI 20070723.2367].\n_Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was discovered in 1937. This\norganism is an agent that can be resistant to heat and desiccation, and is\nhighly infectious by the aerosol route. A single inhaled organism may\nproduce clinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human] primates, the dose to kill\n50 per cent of the primates was found to be 1.7 organisms (1).\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including\nother species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does not\nusually cause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats\nand sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection. Organisms are\nexcreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals. Most importantly,\nduring birthing the organisms are shed in high numbers within the amniotic\nfluids and the placenta. Contact with contaminated wool is known to be a\nmode of transmission (2).\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication along with the less resistant large\ncell form, metabolically dormant, and spore-like (3).\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from\nair that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental\nmaterial, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are\noften very susceptible to the disease, and very few organisms may be\nrequired to cause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration\nof the contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other\nmodes of transmission to humans, including tick bites and human-to-human\ntransmission, are rare.\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C. An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of \"Q fever.\" Pub Hlth Rep 1941; 56: 1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D. Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12: 518-53.\n3. Norlander L. Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes Infect\n2000; 2: 417-24.\nCheltenham is in the west of England, in Gloucestershire, and can be found\non a map at <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheltenham>. More information is\nneeded to assess how these individuals acquired this airborne infection,\nwhich can spread over at least 1/2 mile. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland) 20070809.2592\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - UK (England): alert, RFI 20070723.2367\nQ fever, veterinary students - Slovenia 20070720.2332\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2006\n---\nQ fever - USA (IA,IL): RFI 20061130.3391\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) (02) 20060825.2394\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) 20060721.2001\n2005\n---\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\nQ fever, contaminated wool - Russia (Moscow) 20051025.3118\nQ fever - Israel 20050814.2378\nQ fever - USA (CO) 20050810.2329\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\n2004\n---\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\nQ fever - Bulgaria (Botevgrad) 20040829.2413\nQ fever - Bosnia & Herzegovina (Banja Luka) 20040513.1291\n2002\n---\nQ fever - UK (Wales) 20021027.5653\nQ fever - France (Chamonix) (02) 20020911.5283\nQ fever - France (Chamonix) 20020903.5224\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany (02) 20020629.4632\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany: RFI 20020626.4607\nQ fever - Bosnia & Herzegovina (Livno) 20020328.3832\n2001\n---\nQ fever - Australia (Queensland) 20010129.0204\n.................ll/ejp/sh\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "1941-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gloucestershire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Solihull", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "83542", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - USA: (IA), RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=83542", "date": "2007-09-21 16:00:09", "main_text": "Q FEVER - UK (ENGLAND) (02)\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Thu 20 Sep 2007\nSource: BBC [edited]\n<http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/gloucestershire/7004615.stm>\n\nAn outbreak of a rare illness called Q fever, which is caught from infected\nlivestock, is being investigated in the Cheltenham area of Gloucestershire.\nA total of 28 cases have been identified among local people, most requiring\nhospital treatment.\nVictims can suffer severe pnuemonia while others show no ill effects. Some\npeople recover without treatment. The infection is often caught by close\ncontact with farm animals but it can be also be blown through the air. A\nteam led by the Health Protection Agency is looking at how residents may\nhave caught the infection.\nEpidemiologist Dr Deirdre Lewis said: \"Q fever is generally a mild\ninfection but we know that it can cause complications, so we've been keen\nto look into this as thoroughly as we can. We've not had any reported cases\nof Q fever in Gloucestershire residents since 2002, so seeing 28, mostly\nfrom the Cheltenham area, is unusual.\"\nThe evidence so far points to the period of risk being more than 3 months\nago. Most of the patients, who are aged between 40 and 70, are said to be\nrecovering well after falling ill earlier in the summer.\nQ, standing for Query, fever, was so called originally because for many\nyears its cause was unknown. It tends to be more common around the lambing\nseason, although it can occur at any time of year.\n\"I appreciate that news of this outbreak will surprise some local people,\"\nsaid Dr Lewis. \"They can be reassured that we're working hard to\ninvestigate it.\"\nAn outbreak of Q fever in Solihull in 1989 led to 147 human cases.\nResearchers have suggested that it was caused by a combination of outdoor\nlambing and calving and particular weather conditions leading to the\ninfective organism being blown several miles to populated areas.\n--\ncommunicated by:\nAndrea Jones\nH Jones and Sons\n<agency@hjones-sons.co.uk>\n[ProMED-mail previously posted regarding the early part of this outbreak [Q\nfever - UK (England): alert, RFI 20070723.2367].\n_Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was discovered in 1937. This\norganism is an agent that can be resistant to heat and desiccation, and is\nhighly infectious by the aerosol route. A single inhaled organism may\nproduce clinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human] primates, the dose to kill\n50 per cent of the primates was found to be 1.7 organisms (1).\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including\nother species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does not\nusually cause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats\nand sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection. Organisms are\nexcreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals. Most importantly,\nduring birthing the organisms are shed in high numbers within the amniotic\nfluids and the placenta. Contact with contaminated wool is known to be a\nmode of transmission (2).\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication along with the less resistant large\ncell form, metabolically dormant, and spore-like (3).\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from\nair that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental\nmaterial, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are\noften very susceptible to the disease, and very few organisms may be\nrequired to cause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration\nof the contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other\nmodes of transmission to humans, including tick bites and human-to-human\ntransmission, are rare.\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C. An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of \"Q fever.\" Pub Hlth Rep 1941; 56: 1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D. Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12: 518-53.\n3. Norlander L. Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes Infect\n2000; 2: 417-24.\nCheltenham is in the west of England, in Gloucestershire, and can be found\non a map at <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheltenham>. More information is\nneeded to assess how these individuals acquired this airborne infection,\nwhich can spread over at least 1/2 mile. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland) 20070809.2592\nQ fever - Australia (SA) (04) 20070731.2458\nQ fever - UK (England): alert, RFI 20070723.2367\nQ fever, veterinary students - Slovenia 20070720.2332\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2006\n---\nQ fever - USA (IA,IL): RFI 20061130.3391\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) (02) 20060825.2394\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) 20060721.2001\n2005\n---\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\nQ fever, contaminated wool - Russia (Moscow) 20051025.3118\nQ fever - Israel 20050814.2378\nQ fever - USA (CO) 20050810.2329\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\n2004\n---\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Some\npeople recover without treatment. The infection is often caught by close\ncontact with farm animals but it can be also be blown through the air. A\nteam led by the Health Protection Agency is looking at how residents may\nhave caught the infection.\nEpidemiologist Dr Deirdre Lewis said: \"Q fever is generally a mild\ninfection but we know that it can cause complications, so we've been keen\nto look into this as thoroughly as we can. We've not had any reported cases\nof Q fever in Gloucestershire residents since 2002, so seeing 28, mostly\nfrom the Cheltenham area, is unusual.\"\nThe evidence so far points to the period of risk being more than 3 months\nago. Most of the patients, who are aged between 40 and 70, are said to be\nrecovering well after falling ill earlier in the summer.\nQ, standing for Query, fever, was so called originally because for many\nyears its cause was unknown. It tends to be more common around the lambing\nseason, although it can occur at any time of year.\n\"I appreciate that news of this outbreak will surprise some local people,\"\nsaid Dr Lewis. \"They can be reassured that we're working hard to\ninvestigate it.\"\nAn outbreak of Q fever in Solihull in 1989 led to 147 human cases.\nResearchers have suggested that it was caused by a combination of outdoor\nlambing and calving and particular weather conditions leading to the\ninfective organism being blown several miles to populated areas.\n--\ncommunicated by:\nAndrea Jones\nH Jones and Sons\n<agency@hjones-sons.co.uk>\n[ProMED-mail previously posted regarding the early part of this outbreak [Q\nfever - UK (England): alert, RFI 20070723.2367].\n_Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was discovered in 1937. This\norganism is an agent that can be resistant to heat and desiccation, and is\nhighly infectious by the aerosol route. A single inhaled organism may\nproduce clinical illness. Indeed, in [non-human] primates, the dose to kill\n50 per cent of the primates was found to be 1.7 organisms (1).\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including\nother species of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does not\nusually cause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats\nand sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_ infection. Organisms are\nexcreted in milk, urine, and feces of infected animals. Most importantly,\nduring birthing the organisms are shed in high numbers within the amniotic\nfluids and the placenta. Contact with contaminated wool is known to be a\nmode of transmission (2).\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication along with the less resistant large\ncell form, metabolically dormant, and spore-like (3).\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from\nair that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental\nmaterial, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are\noften very susceptible to the disease, and very few organisms may be\nrequired to cause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration\nof the contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other\nmodes of transmission to humans, including tick bites and human-to-human\ntransmission, are rare.\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C. An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "1941-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "England", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Gloucestershire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Solihull", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "22090", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Netherlands (Noord-Brabant, Gelderland)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=22090", "date": "2007-06-24 23:50:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA (SOUTH AUSTRALIA)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri 22 Jun 2007\nSource: Australian Broasting Corp [edited]\n<http://www.abc.net.au/rural/news/content/2007/s1959257.htm>\nThe South Australian Department of Health has confirmed a Q fever\noutbreak at Waikerie in the state's Riverland. The infectious disease\ncauses flu-like symptoms and is carried by a range of livestock\nincluding sheep, cattle and goats.\nLocal residents are claiming a nearby goat abattoir is the cause of\nthe human infection of which there have been 3 confirmed cases and 5\npotential.\nMark Gothard from Kerridale International Trading which operates the\nabattoir says the facility poses no more risk to residents than local farms.\n\"It's a possible contributor but there's also, the more I hear about\nQ fever, the more I learn about Q fever, the possibility for\ninfection from animals are so wide and varied you could get it from\nalmost anywhere,\" he said.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n*****\n[2]\nDate: Thu 21 Jun 2007\nSource: News.com.au [edited]\n<http://www.news.com.au/story/0,23599,21944620-1702,00.html#>\n\nA fever originating from animals has struck down 3 people who live\nnear a goat abattoir northeast of Adelaide. The South Australian\nHealth Department today, 21 Jun 2007, said a small cluster of people\nhad been diagnosed with Q fever in the Riverland town of Waikerie\nsince early April 2007.\nSA Communicable Diseases Control Branch director Ann Koehler said 3\npeople had been diagnosed with the fever with another probable case\nexpected. Ms. Koehler said 4 other people were being tested for the\nbacterial infection, which causes flu-like symptoms including fever,\nchills and sweats, and can be treated with antibiotics.\nPeople become infected by breathing in contaminated dust from\ndroppings of infected animals. Ms. Koehler said people should not be\nconcerned as the 12 cases of the fever diagnosed so far in 2007 was a\nlow number compared with other colds and influenza.\nShe said the Loxton Waikerie Council and the Environmental Protection\nAuthority were working with the abattoir to improve safety.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Q fever was first described in Australia where this posting\noriginates. It was called \"Query fever\" because the causative agent\nwas initially unknown. _Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was\ndiscovered in 1937. This organism is an agent that can be resistant to\nheat and desiccation and highly infectious by the aerosol route. A\nsingle inhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in\n[non-human] primates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was\nfound to be 1.7 organisms (1).\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals,\nincluding other species of livestock and domesticated pets. _C.\nburnetii_ does not usually cause clinical disease in these animals,\nalthough abortion in goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_\ninfection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of\ninfected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta.\nContact with contaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small-cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication (along with the less resistant\nlarge-cell form) and are metabolically dormant and spore-like (3).\nThe Q fever organism is a Category B bioterrorism agent and, in fact,\nalthough not thought to be related to bioterrorism, was spread by\nmail in a post office in the UK in 1987 (4).\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. Instances of other modes of transmission to humans,\nincluding tick bites and human to human transmission, are rare.\nAn earlier outbreak of infection in 51 persons in Scotland, UK, was\ntied to a meat processing plant and appeared to spread via aerosol\nfor at least 1/2 mile.\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C: An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of \"Q fever.\" Pub Hlth Rep 1041; 56:1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D: Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12:518-53.\n3. Norlander L: Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes\nInfect 2000; 2:417-24.\n4. Winner SJ, Eglin RP, Moore VI, Mayon-White RT: An outbreak of Q\nfever affecting postal workers in Oxforshire. J Infect 1987; 14:255-61.\nA map of the island country showing the location of South Australia\ncan be found at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Australia>.\nAn ongoing drought in the area may produce more cases related to\neasier aerosolization of the organism's infectious form. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2006\n----\nQ fever - USA (IA,IL): RFI 20061130.3391\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) (02) 20060825.2394\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) 20060721.2001\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\nQ fever, contaminated wool - Russia (Moscow) 20051025.3118\nQ fever - Israel 20050814.2378\nQ fever - USA (CO) 20050810.2329\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\nQ fever - Bulgaria (Botevgrad) 20040829.2413\nQ fever - Bosnia & Herzegovina (Banja Luka) 20040513.1291\n2002\n----\nQ fever - UK (Wales) 20021027.5653\nQ fever - France (Chamonix) (02) 20020911.5283\nQ fever - France (Chamonix) 20020903.5224\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany (02) 20020629.4632\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany: RFI 20020626.4607\nQ fever - Bosnia & Herzegovina (Livno) 20020328.3832\n2001\n----\nQ fever - Germany (N.Rhine Westphalia) 20010723.1438\nQ fever - UK: background 20010702.1262\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA (Wyoming) (02) 20010205.0234\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA (Wyoming) 20010201.0221\nQ fever - Australia (Queensland) 20010129.0204\n1999\n----\nQ fever, emerging - Bulgaria 19990818.1422\n...................ll/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "1041-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oxforshire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "19985", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Australia (SA) (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=19985", "date": "2007-06-24 23:50:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA (SOUTH AUSTRALIA)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri 22 Jun 2007\nSource: Australian Broasting Corp [edited]\n<http://www.abc.net.au/rural/news/content/2007/s1959257.htm>\nThe South Australian Department of Health has confirmed a Q fever\noutbreak at Waikerie in the state's Riverland. Ms. Koehler said 4 other people were being tested for the\nbacterial infection, which causes flu-like symptoms including fever,\nchills and sweats, and can be treated with antibiotics.\nPeople become infected by breathing in contaminated dust from\ndroppings of infected animals. The infectious disease\ncauses flu-like symptoms and is carried by a range of livestock\nincluding sheep, cattle and goats.\nLocal residents are claiming a nearby goat abattoir is the cause of\nthe human infection of which there have been 3 confirmed cases and 5\npotential.\nMark Gothard from Kerridale International Trading which operates the\nabattoir says the facility poses no more risk to residents than local farms.\n\"It's a possible contributor but there's also, the more I hear about\nQ fever, the more I learn about Q fever, the possibility for\ninfection from animals are so wide and varied you could get it from\nalmost anywhere,\" he said.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n*****\n[2]\nDate: Thu 21 Jun 2007\nSource: News.com.au [edited]\n<http://www.news.com.au/story/0,23599,21944620-1702,00.html#>\n\nA fever originating from animals has struck down 3 people who live\nnear a goat abattoir northeast of Adelaide. The South Australian\nHealth Department today, 21 Jun 2007, said a small cluster of people\nhad been diagnosed with Q fever in the Riverland town of Waikerie\nsince early April 2007.\nSA Communicable Diseases Control Branch director Ann Koehler said 3\npeople had been diagnosed with the fever with another probable case\nexpected. Ms. Koehler said 4 other people were being tested for the\nbacterial infection, which causes flu-like symptoms including fever,\nchills and sweats, and can be treated with antibiotics.\nPeople become infected by breathing in contaminated dust from\ndroppings of infected animals. Ms. Koehler said people should not be\nconcerned as the 12 cases of the fever diagnosed so far in 2007 was a\nlow number compared with other colds and influenza.\nShe said the Loxton Waikerie Council and the Environmental Protection\nAuthority were working with the abattoir to improve safety.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Q fever was first described in Australia where this posting\noriginates. This organism is an agent that can be resistant to\nheat and desiccation and highly infectious by the aerosol route. A\nsingle inhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta.\nContact with contaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small-cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication (along with the less resistant\nlarge-cell form) and are metabolically dormant and spore-like (3).\nThe Q fever organism is a Category B bioterrorism agent and, in fact,\nalthough not thought to be related to bioterrorism, was spread by\nmail in a post office in the UK in 1987 (4).\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "1041-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oxforshire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "18717", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - UK (England): alert, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=18717", "date": "2007-06-24 23:50:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA (SOUTH AUSTRALIA)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri 22 Jun 2007\nSource: Australian Broasting Corp [edited]\n<http://www.abc.net.au/rural/news/content/2007/s1959257.htm>\nThe South Australian Department of Health has confirmed a Q fever\noutbreak at Waikerie in the state's Riverland. The infectious disease\ncauses flu-like symptoms and is carried by a range of livestock\nincluding sheep, cattle and goats.\nLocal residents are claiming a nearby goat abattoir is the cause of\nthe human infection of which there have been 3 confirmed cases and 5\npotential.\nMark Gothard from Kerridale International Trading which operates the\nabattoir says the facility poses no more risk to residents than local farms.\n\"It's a possible contributor but there's also, the more I hear about\nQ fever, the more I learn about Q fever, the possibility for\ninfection from animals are so wide and varied you could get it from\nalmost anywhere,\" he said.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n*****\n[2]\nDate: Thu 21 Jun 2007\nSource: News.com.au [edited]\n<http://www.news.com.au/story/0,23599,21944620-1702,00.html#>\n\nA fever originating from animals has struck down 3 people who live\nnear a goat abattoir northeast of Adelaide. The South Australian\nHealth Department today, 21 Jun 2007, said a small cluster of people\nhad been diagnosed with Q fever in the Riverland town of Waikerie\nsince early April 2007.\nSA Communicable Diseases Control Branch director Ann Koehler said 3\npeople had been diagnosed with the fever with another probable case\nexpected. Ms. Koehler said 4 other people were being tested for the\nbacterial infection, which causes flu-like symptoms including fever,\nchills and sweats, and can be treated with antibiotics.\nPeople become infected by breathing in contaminated dust from\ndroppings of infected animals. Ms. Koehler said people should not be\nconcerned as the 12 cases of the fever diagnosed so far in 2007 was a\nlow number compared with other colds and influenza.\nShe said the Loxton Waikerie Council and the Environmental Protection\nAuthority were working with the abattoir to improve safety.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Q fever was first described in Australia where this posting\noriginates. It was called \"Query fever\" because the causative agent\nwas initially unknown. _Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was\ndiscovered in 1937. This organism is an agent that can be resistant to\nheat and desiccation and highly infectious by the aerosol route. A\nsingle inhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in\n[non-human] primates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was\nfound to be 1.7 organisms (1).\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals,\nincluding other species of livestock and domesticated pets. _C.\nburnetii_ does not usually cause clinical disease in these animals,\nalthough abortion in goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_\ninfection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of\ninfected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta.\nContact with contaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small-cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication (along with the less resistant\nlarge-cell form) and are metabolically dormant and spore-like (3).\nThe Q fever organism is a Category B bioterrorism agent and, in fact,\nalthough not thought to be related to bioterrorism, was spread by\nmail in a post office in the UK in 1987 (4).\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. Instances of other modes of transmission to humans,\nincluding tick bites and human to human transmission, are rare.\nAn earlier outbreak of infection in 51 persons in Scotland, UK, was\ntied to a meat processing plant and appeared to spread via aerosol\nfor at least 1/2 mile.\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C: An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of \"Q fever.\" Pub Hlth Rep 1041; 56:1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D: Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12:518-53.\n3. Norlander L: Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes\nInfect 2000; 2:417-24.\n4. Winner SJ, Eglin RP, Moore VI, Mayon-White RT: An outbreak of Q\nfever affecting postal workers in Oxforshire. J Infect 1987; 14:255-61.\nA map of the island country showing the location of South Australia\ncan be found at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Australia>.\nAn ongoing drought in the area may produce more cases related to\neasier aerosolization of the organism's infectious form. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2006\n----\nQ fever - USA (IA,IL): RFI 20061130.3391\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) (02) 20060825.2394\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) 20060721.2001\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\nQ fever, contaminated wool - Russia (Moscow) 20051025.3118\nQ fever - Israel 20050814.2378\nQ fever - USA (CO) 20050810.2329\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\nQ fever - Bulgaria (Botevgrad) 20040829.2413\nQ fever - Bosnia & Herzegovina (Banja Luka) 20040513.1291\n2002\n----\nQ fever - UK (Wales) 20021027.5653\nQ fever - France (Chamonix) (02) 20020911.5283\nQ fever - France (Chamonix) 20020903.5224\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany (02) 20020629.4632\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany: RFI 20020626.4607\nQ fever - Bosnia & Herzegovina (Livno) 20020328.3832\n2001\n----\nQ fever - Germany (N.Rhine Westphalia) 20010723.1438\nQ fever - UK: background 20010702.1262\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA (Wyoming) (02) 20010205.0234\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA (Wyoming) 20010201.0221\nQ fever - Australia (Queensland) 20010129.0204\n1999\n----\nQ fever, emerging - Bulgaria 19990818.1422\n...................ll/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "1041-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oxforshire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "18518", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever, veterinary students - Slovenia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=18518", "date": "2007-06-24 23:50:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA (SOUTH AUSTRALIA)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri 22 Jun 2007\nSource: Australian Broasting Corp [edited]\n<http://www.abc.net.au/rural/news/content/2007/s1959257.htm>\nThe South Australian Department of Health has confirmed a Q fever\noutbreak at Waikerie in the state's Riverland. The infectious disease\ncauses flu-like symptoms and is carried by a range of livestock\nincluding sheep, cattle and goats.\nLocal residents are claiming a nearby goat abattoir is the cause of\nthe human infection of which there have been 3 confirmed cases and 5\npotential.\nMark Gothard from Kerridale International Trading which operates the\nabattoir says the facility poses no more risk to residents than local farms.\n\"It's a possible contributor but there's also, the more I hear about\nQ fever, the more I learn about Q fever, the possibility for\ninfection from animals are so wide and varied you could get it from\nalmost anywhere,\" he said.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n*****\n[2]\nDate: Thu 21 Jun 2007\nSource: News.com.au [edited]\n<http://www.news.com.au/story/0,23599,21944620-1702,00.html#>\n\nA fever originating from animals has struck down 3 people who live\nnear a goat abattoir northeast of Adelaide. The South Australian\nHealth Department today, 21 Jun 2007, said a small cluster of people\nhad been diagnosed with Q fever in the Riverland town of Waikerie\nsince early April 2007.\nSA Communicable Diseases Control Branch director Ann Koehler said 3\npeople had been diagnosed with the fever with another probable case\nexpected. Ms. Koehler said 4 other people were being tested for the\nbacterial infection, which causes flu-like symptoms including fever,\nchills and sweats, and can be treated with antibiotics.\nPeople become infected by breathing in contaminated dust from\ndroppings of infected animals. Ms. Koehler said people should not be\nconcerned as the 12 cases of the fever diagnosed so far in 2007 was a\nlow number compared with other colds and influenza.\nShe said the Loxton Waikerie Council and the Environmental Protection\nAuthority were working with the abattoir to improve safety.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Q fever was first described in Australia where this posting\noriginates. It was called \"Query fever\" because the causative agent\nwas initially unknown. _Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was\ndiscovered in 1937. This organism is an agent that can be resistant to\nheat and desiccation and highly infectious by the aerosol route. A\nsingle inhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in\n[non-human] primates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was\nfound to be 1.7 organisms (1).\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals,\nincluding other species of livestock and domesticated pets. _C.\nburnetii_ does not usually cause clinical disease in these animals,\nalthough abortion in goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_\ninfection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of\ninfected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta.\nContact with contaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small-cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication (along with the less resistant\nlarge-cell form) and are metabolically dormant and spore-like (3).\nThe Q fever organism is a Category B bioterrorism agent and, in fact,\nalthough not thought to be related to bioterrorism, was spread by\nmail in a post office in the UK in 1987 (4).\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. Instances of other modes of transmission to humans,\nincluding tick bites and human to human transmission, are rare.\nAn earlier outbreak of infection in 51 persons in Scotland, UK, was\ntied to a meat processing plant and appeared to spread via aerosol\nfor at least 1/2 mile.\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C: An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of \"Q fever.\" Pub Hlth Rep 1041; 56:1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D: Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12:518-53.\n3. Norlander L: Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes\nInfect 2000; 2:417-24.\n4. Winner SJ, Eglin RP, Moore VI, Mayon-White RT: An outbreak of Q\nfever affecting postal workers in Oxforshire. J Infect 1987; 14:255-61.\nA map of the island country showing the location of South Australia\ncan be found at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Australia>.\nAn ongoing drought in the area may produce more cases related to\neasier aerosolization of the organism's infectious form. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2006\n----\nQ fever - USA (IA,IL): RFI 20061130.3391\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) (02) 20060825.2394\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) 20060721.2001\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\nQ fever, contaminated wool - Russia (Moscow) 20051025.3118\nQ fever - Israel 20050814.2378\nQ fever - USA (CO) 20050810.2329\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S.
