For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "1041-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oxforshire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "16329", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, Q fever, lab workers - USA (TX)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=16329", "date": "2007-06-24 23:50:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER - AUSTRALIA (SOUTH AUSTRALIA)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n[1]\nDate: Fri 22 Jun 2007\nSource: Australian Broasting Corp [edited]\n<http://www.abc.net.au/rural/news/content/2007/s1959257.htm>\nThe South Australian Department of Health has confirmed a Q fever\noutbreak at Waikerie in the state's Riverland. The infectious disease\ncauses flu-like symptoms and is carried by a range of livestock\nincluding sheep, cattle and goats.\nLocal residents are claiming a nearby goat abattoir is the cause of\nthe human infection of which there have been 3 confirmed cases and 5\npotential.\nMark Gothard from Kerridale International Trading which operates the\nabattoir says the facility poses no more risk to residents than local farms.\n\"It's a possible contributor but there's also, the more I hear about\nQ fever, the more I learn about Q fever, the possibility for\ninfection from animals are so wide and varied you could get it from\nalmost anywhere,\" he said.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n*****\n[2]\nDate: Thu 21 Jun 2007\nSource: News.com.au [edited]\n<http://www.news.com.au/story/0,23599,21944620-1702,00.html#>\n\nA fever originating from animals has struck down 3 people who live\nnear a goat abattoir northeast of Adelaide. The South Australian\nHealth Department today, 21 Jun 2007, said a small cluster of people\nhad been diagnosed with Q fever in the Riverland town of Waikerie\nsince early April 2007.\nSA Communicable Diseases Control Branch director Ann Koehler said 3\npeople had been diagnosed with the fever with another probable case\nexpected. Ms. Koehler said 4 other people were being tested for the\nbacterial infection, which causes flu-like symptoms including fever,\nchills and sweats, and can be treated with antibiotics.\nPeople become infected by breathing in contaminated dust from\ndroppings of infected animals. Ms. Koehler said people should not be\nconcerned as the 12 cases of the fever diagnosed so far in 2007 was a\nlow number compared with other colds and influenza.\nShe said the Loxton Waikerie Council and the Environmental Protection\nAuthority were working with the abattoir to improve safety.\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED Rapporteur Joseph Dudley\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Q fever was first described in Australia where this posting\noriginates. It was called \"Query fever\" because the causative agent\nwas initially unknown. _Coxiella burnetii_, the causative agent, was\ndiscovered in 1937. This organism is an agent that can be resistant to\nheat and desiccation and highly infectious by the aerosol route. A\nsingle inhaled organism may produce clinical illness. Indeed, in\n[non-human] primates, the dose to kill 50 percent of the primates was\nfound to be 1.7 organisms (1).\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals,\nincluding other species of livestock and domesticated pets. _C.\nburnetii_ does not usually cause clinical disease in these animals,\nalthough abortion in goats and sheep has been linked to _C. burnetii_\ninfection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and feces of\ninfected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers within the amniotic fluids and the placenta.\nContact with contaminated wool is known to be a mode of transmission (2).\nThe organisms can be resistant to heat, drying, and many common\ndisinfectants. These features enable the bacteria to survive for long\nperiods in the environment. This very stable form of _C. burnetii_ is\nassociated with compact small-cell variants of the organism that are\nproduced during standard replication (along with the less resistant\nlarge-cell form) and are metabolically dormant and spore-like (3).\nThe Q fever organism is a Category B bioterrorism agent and, in fact,\nalthough not thought to be related to bioterrorism, was spread by\nmail in a post office in the UK in 1987 (4).\nInfection of humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms\nfrom air that contains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried\nplacental material, birth fluids, and excreta of infected herd\nanimals. Humans are often very susceptible to the disease, and very\nfew organisms may be required to cause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and\ninspiration of the contaminated food, is a less common mode of\ntransmission. Instances of other modes of transmission to humans,\nincluding tick bites and human to human transmission, are rare.\nAn earlier outbreak of infection in 51 persons in Scotland, UK, was\ntied to a meat processing plant and appeared to spread via aerosol\nfor at least 1/2 mile.\n1. Lille RD, Perrin TL, Armstrong C: An institutional outbreak of\npneumonitis. III. Histopathology in man and rhesus monkeys in the\npneumonitis due to the virus of \"Q fever.\" Pub Hlth Rep 1041; 56:1419-25.\n2. Maurin M, Raoult D: Q fever. Clin Microbiol Rev 1999; 12:518-53.\n3. Norlander L: Q fever epidemiology and pathogenesis. Microbes\nInfect 2000; 2:417-24.\n4. Winner SJ, Eglin RP, Moore VI, Mayon-White RT: An outbreak of Q\nfever affecting postal workers in Oxforshire. J Infect 1987; 14:255-61.\nA map of the island country showing the location of South Australia\ncan be found at:\n<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Australia>.\nAn ongoing drought in the area may produce more cases related to\neasier aerosolization of the organism's infectious form. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\n2006\n----\nQ fever - USA (IA,IL): RFI 20061130.3391\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) (02) 20060825.2394\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) 20060721.2001\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\nQ fever, contaminated wool - Russia (Moscow) 20051025.3118\nQ fever - Israel 20050814.2378\nQ fever - USA (CO) 20050810.2329\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\nQ fever - Bulgaria (Botevgrad) 20040829.2413\nQ fever - Bosnia & Herzegovina (Banja Luka) 20040513.1291\n2002\n----\nQ fever - UK (Wales) 20021027.5653\nQ fever - France (Chamonix) (02) 20020911.5283\nQ fever - France (Chamonix) 20020903.5224\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany (02) 20020629.4632\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany: RFI 20020626.4607\nQ fever - Bosnia & Herzegovina (Livno) 20020328.3832\n2001\n----\nQ fever - Germany (N.Rhine Westphalia) 20010723.1438\nQ fever - UK: background 20010702.1262\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA (Wyoming) (02) 20010205.0234\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA (Wyoming) 20010201.0221\nQ fever - Australia (Queensland) 20010129.0204\n1999\n----\nQ fever, emerging - Bulgaria 19990818.1422\n...................ll/ejp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2007-03-16 00:00:00", "2007-03-16 00:00:00", "1937-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "1041-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1987-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Scotland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Oxforshire", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4937", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - USA (IA,IL): RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4937", "date": "2005-08-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER - USA (COLORADO)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInfectious Disease products\n<http://www.intl.elsevierhealth.com/infectiousdiseases/>\nDate: Tue, 9 Aug 2005\nFrom: George Robertson <grobertson@dorbiopharma.com>\nSource: The Denver Channel [edited]\n<http://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/2455821/detail.html>\n\nFever on bioterrorism watch list showing up in Colorado\n-------------------------------------------------------\nA disease called Q fever, which is on bioterrorism watch lists along with\nthings like smallpox and anthrax, has shown up in an unusual number of cases\nthis summer in Colorado, health officials say. The source is probably\ndiseased livestock such as sheep or goats, health officials said.\nThe state health department has confirmed 13 human cases in the state in 2005,\nincluding 6 in Weld County. In 2004, there were 3 confirmed cases throughout\nColorado, said John Pape, a state health department epidemiologist.\nQ fever, or \"query\" fever, is caused by a bacterium called _Coxiella\nburnetii_. It builds up in [livestock] placental tissues, putting\nveterinarians and farmers at high risk, though it is treatable with\nantibiotics and is rarely fatal. Symptoms include a high fever and headache,\nand may include profuse sweating and hallucinations.\n\"Most people, even untreated, get better in 2 to 3 weeks,\" said Dr. Daniel\nMogyoros, an infectious disease specialist with Kaiser Permanente. \"Most\ndoctors go through their training and most of their career without ever seeing\nthis disease.\"\nWeld County health officials have investigated 6 more possible cases but have\nnot yet confirmed them, said Jill Burch, a county public health nurse.\n--\nGeorge A. Robertson, PhD\nDOR Biopharma\nMiami, FL\ufffd\n<grobertson@dorbiopharma.com>\n[The following is adapted from the CDC site on Q fever (a Category B\nbioterrorism disease)\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/qfever/index.htm#Significance%20for%\n20Bioterrorism>.\nQ fever is a zoonotic disease caused by _Coxiella burnetii_, a species of\nbacterium that is distributed globally. In 1999, Q fever became a notifiable\ndisease in the USA, but reporting is not required in many other countries.\nBecause the disease is underreported, scientists cannot reliably assess how\nmany cases of Q fever have actually occurred worldwide. Many human infections\nare inapparent.\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including other\nspecies of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does not usually\ncause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats and sheep\nhas been linked to infection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and\nfeces of infected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers in the amniotic fluids and the placenta. The organisms\nare resistant to heat, drying, and many common disinfectants. These features\nenable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. Infection\nof humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from air that\ncontains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental material,\nbirth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are often very\nsusceptible to the disease, and only very few organisms may be required to\ncause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration of\nthe contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other modes of\ntransmission to humans, including tick bites and human-to-human transmission,\nare rare.\nOnly about one-half of all people infected with _C. burnetii_ show signs of\nclinical illness. Most acute cases of Q fever begin with sudden onset of one\nor more of the following: high fevers (up to 104-105 degrees F), severe\nheadache, general malaise, myalgia, confusion, sore throat, chills, sweats,\nnon-productive cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and chest\npain. Fever usually lasts for 1 to 2 weeks. Weight loss can occur and persist\nfor some time. 30 to 50 percent of patients with a symptomatic infection will\ndevelop pneumonia. Additionally, a majority of patients have abnormal results\non liver function tests and some will develop hepatitis. In general, most\npatients will recover to good health within several months without any\ntreatment. Only 1-2 percent of people with acute Q fever die of the disease.\nChronic Q fever, characterized by infection that persists for more than 6\nmonths, is uncommon but is a much more serious disease. Patients who have had\nacute Q fever may develop the chronic form as soon as 1 year or as long as 20\nyears after initial infection. A serious complication of chronic Q fever is\nendocarditis, generally involving the aortic heart valves, less commonly the\nmitral valve. Most patients who develop chronic Q fever have pre-existing\nvalvular heart disease or have a history of vascular graft. Transplant\nrecipients, patients with cancer, and those with chronic kidney disease are\nalso at risk of developing chronic Q fever. As many as 65 percent of persons\nwith chronic Q fever may die of the disease.\ufffd\nDoxycycline is the treatment of choice for acute Q fever. Antibiotic treatment\nis most effective when initiated within the first 3 days of illness. A dose of\n100 mg of doxycycline taken orally twice daily for 15-21 days is a frequently\nprescribed therapy. Quinolone antibiotics have demonstrated good in vitro\nactivity against _C. burnetii_ and may be considered by the physician. Therapy\nshould be started again if the disease relapses. Chronic Q fever endocarditis\nis much more difficult to treat effectively and often requires the use of\nmultiple drugs.\nSince _Coxiella burnetii_ is a highly infectious agent that is rather\nresistant to heat and drying, it is considered relevant in bioterrorism. It\ncan become airborne and inhaled by humans. A single _C. burnetii_ organism may\ncause disease in a susceptible person. This agent could be developed for use\nin biological warfare and is considered a potential terrorist threat. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\n2001\n----\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA Wyoming (02) 20010205.0234\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA (Wyoming) 20010201.0221\n1996\n----\nQ fever - San Mateo County (USA) (2) 19960922.1617\nQ Fever - San Mateo County (USA): RFI 19960920.1609\n........................ll/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever", "smallpox"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Weld County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Mateo County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2460", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland)(02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2460", "date": "2005-08-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER - USA (COLORADO)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInfectious Disease products\n<http://www.intl.elsevierhealth.com/infectiousdiseases/>\nDate: Tue, 9 Aug 2005\nFrom: George Robertson <grobertson@dorbiopharma.com>\nSource: The Denver Channel [edited]\n<http://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/2455821/detail.html>\n\nFever on bioterrorism watch list showing up in Colorado\n-------------------------------------------------------\nA disease called Q fever, which is on bioterrorism watch lists along with\nthings like smallpox and anthrax, has shown up in an unusual number of cases\nthis summer in Colorado, health officials say. The source is probably\ndiseased livestock such as sheep or goats, health officials said.\nThe state health department has confirmed 13 human cases in the state in 2005,\nincluding 6 in Weld County. In 2004, there were 3 confirmed cases throughout\nColorado, said John Pape, a state health department epidemiologist.\nQ fever, or \"query\" fever, is caused by a bacterium called _Coxiella\nburnetii_. It builds up in [livestock] placental tissues, putting\nveterinarians and farmers at high risk, though it is treatable with\nantibiotics and is rarely fatal. Symptoms include a high fever and headache,\nand may include profuse sweating and hallucinations.\n\"Most people, even untreated, get better in 2 to 3 weeks,\" said Dr. Daniel\nMogyoros, an infectious disease specialist with Kaiser Permanente. \"Most\ndoctors go through their training and most of their career without ever seeing\nthis disease.\"\nWeld County health officials have investigated 6 more possible cases but have\nnot yet confirmed them, said Jill Burch, a county public health nurse.\n--\nGeorge A. Robertson, PhD\nDOR Biopharma\nMiami, FL\ufffd\n<grobertson@dorbiopharma.com>\n[The following is adapted from the CDC site on Q fever (a Category B\nbioterrorism disease)\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/qfever/index.htm#Significance%20for%\n20Bioterrorism>.\nQ fever is a zoonotic disease caused by _Coxiella burnetii_, a species of\nbacterium that is distributed globally. In 1999, Q fever became a notifiable\ndisease in the USA, but reporting is not required in many other countries.\nBecause the disease is underreported, scientists cannot reliably assess how\nmany cases of Q fever have actually occurred worldwide. Many human infections\nare inapparent.\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including other\nspecies of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does not usually\ncause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats and sheep\nhas been linked to infection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and\nfeces of infected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers in the amniotic fluids and the placenta. The organisms\nare resistant to heat, drying, and many common disinfectants. These features\nenable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. Infection\nof humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from air that\ncontains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental material,\nbirth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are often very\nsusceptible to the disease, and only very few organisms may be required to\ncause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration of\nthe contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other modes of\ntransmission to humans, including tick bites and human-to-human transmission,\nare rare.\nOnly about one-half of all people infected with _C. burnetii_ show signs of\nclinical illness. Most acute cases of Q fever begin with sudden onset of one\nor more of the following: high fevers (up to 104-105 degrees F), severe\nheadache, general malaise, myalgia, confusion, sore throat, chills, sweats,\nnon-productive cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and chest\npain. Fever usually lasts for 1 to 2 weeks. Weight loss can occur and persist\nfor some time. 30 to 50 percent of patients with a symptomatic infection will\ndevelop pneumonia. Additionally, a majority of patients have abnormal results\non liver function tests and some will develop hepatitis. In general, most\npatients will recover to good health within several months without any\ntreatment. Only 1-2 percent of people with acute Q fever die of the disease.\nChronic Q fever, characterized by infection that persists for more than 6\nmonths, is uncommon but is a much more serious disease. Patients who have had\nacute Q fever may develop the chronic form as soon as 1 year or as long as 20\nyears after initial infection. A serious complication of chronic Q fever is\nendocarditis, generally involving the aortic heart valves, less commonly the\nmitral valve. Most patients who develop chronic Q fever have pre-existing\nvalvular heart disease or have a history of vascular graft. Transplant\nrecipients, patients with cancer, and those with chronic kidney disease are\nalso at risk of developing chronic Q fever. As many as 65 percent of persons\nwith chronic Q fever may die of the disease.\ufffd\nDoxycycline is the treatment of choice for acute Q fever. Antibiotic treatment\nis most effective when initiated within the first 3 days of illness. A dose of\n100 mg of doxycycline taken orally twice daily for 15-21 days is a frequently\nprescribed therapy. Quinolone antibiotics have demonstrated good in vitro\nactivity against _C. burnetii_ and may be considered by the physician. Therapy\nshould be started again if the disease relapses. Chronic Q fever endocarditis\nis much more difficult to treat effectively and often requires the use of\nmultiple drugs.\nSince _Coxiella burnetii_ is a highly infectious agent that is rather\nresistant to heat and drying, it is considered relevant in bioterrorism. It\ncan become airborne and inhaled by humans. A single _C. burnetii_ organism may\ncause disease in a susceptible person. This agent could be developed for use\nin biological warfare and is considered a potential terrorist threat. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\n2001\n----\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA Wyoming (02) 20010205.0234\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA (Wyoming) 20010201.0221\n1996\n----\nQ fever - San Mateo County (USA) (2) 19960922.1617\nQ Fever - San Mateo County (USA): RFI 19960920.1609\n........................ll/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever", "smallpox"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Weld County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Mateo County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1984", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1984", "date": "2005-08-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER - USA (COLORADO)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInfectious Disease products\n<http://www.intl.elsevierhealth.com/infectiousdiseases/>\nDate: Tue, 9 Aug 2005\nFrom: George Robertson <grobertson@dorbiopharma.com>\nSource: The Denver Channel [edited]\n<http://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/2455821/detail.html>\n\nFever on bioterrorism watch list showing up in Colorado\n-------------------------------------------------------\nA disease called Q fever, which is on bioterrorism watch lists along with\nthings like smallpox and anthrax, has shown up in an unusual number of cases\nthis summer in Colorado, health officials say. The source is probably\ndiseased livestock such as sheep or goats, health officials said.\nThe state health department has confirmed 13 human cases in the state in 2005,\nincluding 6 in Weld County. In 2004, there were 3 confirmed cases throughout\nColorado, said John Pape, a state health department epidemiologist.\nQ fever, or \"query\" fever, is caused by a bacterium called _Coxiella\nburnetii_. It builds up in [livestock] placental tissues, putting\nveterinarians and farmers at high risk, though it is treatable with\nantibiotics and is rarely fatal. Symptoms include a high fever and headache,\nand may include profuse sweating and hallucinations.\n\"Most people, even untreated, get better in 2 to 3 weeks,\" said Dr. Daniel\nMogyoros, an infectious disease specialist with Kaiser Permanente. \"Most\ndoctors go through their training and most of their career without ever seeing\nthis disease.\"\nWeld County health officials have investigated 6 more possible cases but have\nnot yet confirmed them, said Jill Burch, a county public health nurse.\n--\nGeorge A. Robertson, PhD\nDOR Biopharma\nMiami, FL\ufffd\n<grobertson@dorbiopharma.com>\n[The following is adapted from the CDC site on Q fever (a Category B\nbioterrorism disease)\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/qfever/index.htm#Significance%20for%\n20Bioterrorism>.\nQ fever is a zoonotic disease caused by _Coxiella burnetii_, a species of\nbacterium that is distributed globally. In 1999, Q fever became a notifiable\ndisease in the USA, but reporting is not required in many other countries.\nBecause the disease is underreported, scientists cannot reliably assess how\nmany cases of Q fever have actually occurred worldwide. Many human infections\nare inapparent.\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including other\nspecies of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does not usually\ncause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats and sheep\nhas been linked to infection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and\nfeces of infected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers in the amniotic fluids and the placenta. The organisms\nare resistant to heat, drying, and many common disinfectants. These features\nenable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. Infection\nof humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from air that\ncontains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental material,\nbirth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are often very\nsusceptible to the disease, and only very few organisms may be required to\ncause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration of\nthe contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other modes of\ntransmission to humans, including tick bites and human-to-human transmission,\nare rare.\nOnly about one-half of all people infected with _C. burnetii_ show signs of\nclinical illness. Most acute cases of Q fever begin with sudden onset of one\nor more of the following: high fevers (up to 104-105 degrees F), severe\nheadache, general malaise, myalgia, confusion, sore throat, chills, sweats,\nnon-productive cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and chest\npain. Fever usually lasts for 1 to 2 weeks. Weight loss can occur and persist\nfor some time. 30 to 50 percent of patients with a symptomatic infection will\ndevelop pneumonia. Additionally, a majority of patients have abnormal results\non liver function tests and some will develop hepatitis. In general, most\npatients will recover to good health within several months without any\ntreatment. Only 1-2 percent of people with acute Q fever die of the disease.\nChronic Q fever, characterized by infection that persists for more than 6\nmonths, is uncommon but is a much more serious disease. Patients who have had\nacute Q fever may develop the chronic form as soon as 1 year or as long as 20\nyears after initial infection. A serious complication of chronic Q fever is\nendocarditis, generally involving the aortic heart valves, less commonly the\nmitral valve. Most patients who develop chronic Q fever have pre-existing\nvalvular heart disease or have a history of vascular graft. Transplant\nrecipients, patients with cancer, and those with chronic kidney disease are\nalso at risk of developing chronic Q fever. As many as 65 percent of persons\nwith chronic Q fever may die of the disease.\ufffd\nDoxycycline is the treatment of choice for acute Q fever. Antibiotic treatment\nis most effective when initiated within the first 3 days of illness. A dose of\n100 mg of doxycycline taken orally twice daily for 15-21 days is a frequently\nprescribed therapy. Quinolone antibiotics have demonstrated good in vitro\nactivity against _C. burnetii_ and may be considered by the physician. Therapy\nshould be started again if the disease relapses. Chronic Q fever endocarditis\nis much more difficult to treat effectively and often requires the use of\nmultiple drugs.\nSince _Coxiella burnetii_ is a highly infectious agent that is rather\nresistant to heat and drying, it is considered relevant in bioterrorism. It\ncan become airborne and inhaled by humans. A single _C. burnetii_ organism may\ncause disease in a susceptible person. This agent could be developed for use\nin biological warfare and is considered a potential terrorist threat. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\n2001\n----\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA Wyoming (02) 20010205.0234\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA (Wyoming) 20010201.0221\n1996\n----\nQ fever - San Mateo County (USA) (2) 19960922.1617\nQ Fever - San Mateo County (USA): RFI 19960920.1609\n........................ll/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The source is probably\ndiseased livestock such as sheep or goats, health officials said.\nThe state health department has confirmed 13 human cases in the state in 2005,\nincluding 6 in Weld County. Robertson, PhD\nDOR Biopharma\nMiami, FL\ufffd\n<grobertson@dorbiopharma.com>\n[The following is adapted from the CDC site on Q fever (a Category B\nbioterrorism disease)\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/qfever/index.htm#Significance%20for%\n20Bioterrorism>.\nQ fever is a zoonotic disease caused by _Coxiella burnetii_, a species of\nbacterium that is distributed globally. In 1999, Q fever became a notifiable\ndisease in the USA, but reporting is not required in many other countries.\nBecause the disease is underreported, scientists cannot reliably assess how\nmany cases of Q fever have actually occurred worldwide. Many human infections\nare inapparent.\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including other\nspecies of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does not usually\ncause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats and sheep\nhas been linked to infection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and\nfeces of infected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers in the amniotic fluids and the placenta. The organisms\nare resistant to heat, drying, and many common disinfectants. These features\nenable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. Infection\nof humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from air that\ncontains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental material,\nbirth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are often very\nsusceptible to the disease, and only very few organisms may be required to\ncause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration of\nthe contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other modes of\ntransmission to humans, including tick bites and human-to-human transmission,\nare rare.\nOnly about one-half of all people infected with _C. burnetii_ show signs of\nclinical illness. Most acute cases of Q fever begin with sudden onset of one\nor more of the following: high fevers (up to 104-105 degrees F), severe\nheadache, general malaise, myalgia, confusion, sore throat, chills, sweats,\nnon-productive cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and chest\npain. Fever usually lasts for 1 to 2 weeks. Weight loss can occur and persist\nfor some time. 30 to 50 percent of patients with a symptomatic infection will\ndevelop pneumonia. Additionally, a majority of patients have abnormal results\non liver function tests and some will develop hepatitis. In general, most\npatients will recover to good health within several months without any\ntreatment. Only 1-2 percent of people with acute Q fever die of the disease.\nChronic Q fever, characterized by infection that persists for more than 6\nmonths, is uncommon but is a much more serious disease. Patients who have had\nacute Q fever may develop the chronic form as soon as 1 year or as long as 20\nyears after initial infection. A serious complication of chronic Q fever is\nendocarditis, generally involving the aortic heart valves, less commonly the\nmitral valve. Most patients who develop chronic Q fever have pre-existing\nvalvular heart disease or have a history of vascular graft. Transplant\nrecipients, patients with cancer, and those with chronic kidney disease are\nalso at risk of developing chronic Q fever. As many as 65 percent of persons\nwith chronic Q fever may die of the disease.\ufffd\nDoxycycline is the treatment of choice for acute Q fever. Antibiotic treatment\nis most effective when initiated within the first 3 days of illness. A dose of\n100 mg of doxycycline taken orally twice daily for 15-21 days is a frequently\nprescribed therapy. Quinolone antibiotics have demonstrated good in vitro\nactivity against _C. burnetii_ and may be considered by the physician. Therapy\nshould be started again if the disease relapses. Chronic Q fever endocarditis\nis much more difficult to treat effectively and often requires the use of\nmultiple drugs.\nSince _Coxiella burnetii_ is a highly infectious agent that is rather\nresistant to heat and drying, it is considered relevant in bioterrorism. It\ncan become airborne and inhaled by humans. A single _C. burnetii_ organism may\ncause disease in a susceptible person. This agent could be developed for use\nin biological warfare and is considered a potential terrorist threat. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\n2001\n----\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA Wyoming (02) 20010205.0234\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA (Wyoming) 20010201.0221\n1996\n----\nQ fever - San Mateo County (USA) (2) 19960922.1617\nQ Fever - San Mateo County (USA): RFI 19960920.1609\n........................ll/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Robertson, PhD\nDOR Biopharma\nMiami, FL\ufffd\n<grobertson@dorbiopharma.com>\n[The following is adapted from the CDC site on Q fever (a Category B\nbioterrorism disease)\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/qfever/index.htm#Significance%20for%\n20Bioterrorism>.\nQ fever is a zoonotic disease caused by _Coxiella burnetii_, a species of\nbacterium that is distributed globally. In 1999, Q fever became a notifiable\ndisease in the USA, but reporting is not required in many other countries.\nBecause the disease is underreported, scientists cannot reliably assess how\nmany cases of Q fever have actually occurred worldwide. Many human infections\nare inapparent.\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including other\nspecies of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does not usually\ncause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats and sheep\nhas been linked to infection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and\nfeces of infected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers in the amniotic fluids and the placenta. The organisms\nare resistant to heat, drying, and many common disinfectants. These features\nenable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. Infection\nof humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from air that\ncontains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental material,\nbirth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are often very\nsusceptible to the disease, and only very few organisms may be required to\ncause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration of\nthe contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other modes of\ntransmission to humans, including tick bites and human-to-human transmission,\nare rare.\nOnly about one-half of all people infected with _C. burnetii_ show signs of\nclinical illness. Most acute cases of Q fever begin with sudden onset of one\nor more of the following: high fevers (up to 104-105 degrees F), severe\nheadache, general malaise, myalgia, confusion, sore throat, chills, sweats,\nnon-productive cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and chest\npain. Fever usually lasts for 1 to 2 weeks. Weight loss can occur and persist\nfor some time. 30 to 50 percent of patients with a symptomatic infection will\ndevelop pneumonia. Additionally, a majority of patients have abnormal results\non liver function tests and some will develop hepatitis. In general, most\npatients will recover to good health within several months without any\ntreatment. Only 1-2 percent of people with acute Q fever die of the disease.\nChronic Q fever, characterized by infection that persists for more than 6\nmonths, is uncommon but is a much more serious disease. Patients who have had\nacute Q fever may develop the chronic form as soon as 1 year or as long as 20\nyears after initial infection. A serious complication of chronic Q fever is\nendocarditis, generally involving the aortic heart valves, less commonly the\nmitral valve. Most patients who develop chronic Q fever have pre-existing\nvalvular heart disease or have a history of vascular graft. Transplant\nrecipients, patients with cancer, and those with chronic kidney disease are\nalso at risk of developing chronic Q fever. As many as 65 percent of persons\nwith chronic Q fever may die of the disease.\ufffd\nDoxycycline is the treatment of choice for acute Q fever. Antibiotic treatment\nis most effective when initiated within the first 3 days of illness. A dose of\n100 mg of doxycycline taken orally twice daily for 15-21 days is a frequently\nprescribed therapy. Quinolone antibiotics have demonstrated good in vitro\nactivity against _C. burnetii_ and may be considered by the physician. Therapy\nshould be started again if the disease relapses. Chronic Q fever endocarditis\nis much more difficult to treat effectively and often requires the use of\nmultiple drugs.\nSince _Coxiella burnetii_ is a highly infectious agent that is rather\nresistant to heat and drying, it is considered relevant in bioterrorism. It\ncan become airborne and inhaled by humans. A single _C. burnetii_ organism may\ncause disease in a susceptible person. This agent could be developed for use\nin biological warfare and is considered a potential terrorist threat. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\n2001\n----\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA Wyoming (02) 20010205.0234\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA (Wyoming) 20010201.0221\n1996\n----\nQ fever - San Mateo County (USA) (2) 19960922.1617\nQ Fever - San Mateo County (USA): RFI 19960920.1609\n........................ll/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever", "smallpox"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Weld County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Mateo County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208846", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever, contaminated wool - Russia (Moscow)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208846", "date": "2005-08-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER - USA (COLORADO)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInfectious Disease products\n<http://www.intl.elsevierhealth.com/infectiousdiseases/>\nDate: Tue, 9 Aug 2005\nFrom: George Robertson <grobertson@dorbiopharma.com>\nSource: The Denver Channel [edited]\n<http://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/2455821/detail.html>\n\nFever on bioterrorism watch list showing up in Colorado\n-------------------------------------------------------\nA disease called Q fever, which is on bioterrorism watch lists along with\nthings like smallpox and anthrax, has shown up in an unusual number of cases\nthis summer in Colorado, health officials say. The source is probably\ndiseased livestock such as sheep or goats, health officials said.\nThe state health department has confirmed 13 human cases in the state in 2005,\nincluding 6 in Weld County. In 2004, there were 3 confirmed cases throughout\nColorado, said John Pape, a state health department epidemiologist.\nQ fever, or \"query\" fever, is caused by a bacterium called _Coxiella\nburnetii_. It builds up in [livestock] placental tissues, putting\nveterinarians and farmers at high risk, though it is treatable with\nantibiotics and is rarely fatal. Symptoms include a high fever and headache,\nand may include profuse sweating and hallucinations.\n\"Most people, even untreated, get better in 2 to 3 weeks,\" said Dr. Daniel\nMogyoros, an infectious disease specialist with Kaiser Permanente. \"Most\ndoctors go through their training and most of their career without ever seeing\nthis disease.\"\nWeld County health officials have investigated 6 more possible cases but have\nnot yet confirmed them, said Jill Burch, a county public health nurse.\n--\nGeorge A. Robertson, PhD\nDOR Biopharma\nMiami, FL\ufffd\n<grobertson@dorbiopharma.com>\n[The following is adapted from the CDC site on Q fever (a Category B\nbioterrorism disease)\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/qfever/index.htm#Significance%20for%\n20Bioterrorism>.\nQ fever is a zoonotic disease caused by _Coxiella burnetii_, a species of\nbacterium that is distributed globally. In 1999, Q fever became a notifiable\ndisease in the USA, but reporting is not required in many other countries.\nBecause the disease is underreported, scientists cannot reliably assess how\nmany cases of Q fever have actually occurred worldwide. Many human infections\nare inapparent.\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including other\nspecies of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does not usually\ncause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats and sheep\nhas been linked to infection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and\nfeces of infected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers in the amniotic fluids and the placenta. The organisms\nare resistant to heat, drying, and many common disinfectants. These features\nenable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. Infection\nof humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from air that\ncontains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental material,\nbirth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are often very\nsusceptible to the disease, and only very few organisms may be required to\ncause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration of\nthe contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other modes of\ntransmission to humans, including tick bites and human-to-human transmission,\nare rare.\nOnly about one-half of all people infected with _C. burnetii_ show signs of\nclinical illness. Most acute cases of Q fever begin with sudden onset of one\nor more of the following: high fevers (up to 104-105 degrees F), severe\nheadache, general malaise, myalgia, confusion, sore throat, chills, sweats,\nnon-productive cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and chest\npain. Fever usually lasts for 1 to 2 weeks. Weight loss can occur and persist\nfor some time. 30 to 50 percent of patients with a symptomatic infection will\ndevelop pneumonia. Additionally, a majority of patients have abnormal results\non liver function tests and some will develop hepatitis. In general, most\npatients will recover to good health within several months without any\ntreatment. Only 1-2 percent of people with acute Q fever die of the disease.\nChronic Q fever, characterized by infection that persists for more than 6\nmonths, is uncommon but is a much more serious disease. Patients who have had\nacute Q fever may develop the chronic form as soon as 1 year or as long as 20\nyears after initial infection. A serious complication of chronic Q fever is\nendocarditis, generally involving the aortic heart valves, less commonly the\nmitral valve. Most patients who develop chronic Q fever have pre-existing\nvalvular heart disease or have a history of vascular graft. Transplant\nrecipients, patients with cancer, and those with chronic kidney disease are\nalso at risk of developing chronic Q fever. As many as 65 percent of persons\nwith chronic Q fever may die of the disease.\ufffd\nDoxycycline is the treatment of choice for acute Q fever. Antibiotic treatment\nis most effective when initiated within the first 3 days of illness. A dose of\n100 mg of doxycycline taken orally twice daily for 15-21 days is a frequently\nprescribed therapy. Quinolone antibiotics have demonstrated good in vitro\nactivity against _C. burnetii_ and may be considered by the physician. Therapy\nshould be started again if the disease relapses. Chronic Q fever endocarditis\nis much more difficult to treat effectively and often requires the use of\nmultiple drugs.\nSince _Coxiella burnetii_ is a highly infectious agent that is rather\nresistant to heat and drying, it is considered relevant in bioterrorism. It\ncan become airborne and inhaled by humans. A single _C. burnetii_ organism may\ncause disease in a susceptible person. This agent could be developed for use\nin biological warfare and is considered a potential terrorist threat. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\n2001\n----\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA Wyoming (02) 20010205.0234\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA (Wyoming) 20010201.0221\n1996\n----\nQ fever - San Mateo County (USA) (2) 19960922.1617\nQ Fever - San Mateo County (USA): RFI 19960920.1609\n........................ll/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever", "smallpox"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Weld County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Mateo County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208450", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Israel", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208450", "date": "2005-08-10 23:50:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER - USA (COLORADO)\n************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSponsored in part by Elsevier, publisher of\nInfectious Disease products\n<http://www.intl.elsevierhealth.com/infectiousdiseases/>\nDate: Tue, 9 Aug 2005\nFrom: George Robertson <grobertson@dorbiopharma.com>\nSource: The Denver Channel [edited]\n<http://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/2455821/detail.html>\n\nFever on bioterrorism watch list showing up in Colorado\n-------------------------------------------------------\nA disease called Q fever, which is on bioterrorism watch lists along with\nthings like smallpox and anthrax, has shown up in an unusual number of cases\nthis summer in Colorado, health officials say. The source is probably\ndiseased livestock such as sheep or goats, health officials said.\nThe state health department has confirmed 13 human cases in the state in 2005,\nincluding 6 in Weld County. In 2004, there were 3 confirmed cases throughout\nColorado, said John Pape, a state health department epidemiologist.\nQ fever, or \"query\" fever, is caused by a bacterium called _Coxiella\nburnetii_. It builds up in [livestock] placental tissues, putting\nveterinarians and farmers at high risk, though it is treatable with\nantibiotics and is rarely fatal. Symptoms include a high fever and headache,\nand may include profuse sweating and hallucinations.\n\"Most people, even untreated, get better in 2 to 3 weeks,\" said Dr. Daniel\nMogyoros, an infectious disease specialist with Kaiser Permanente. \"Most\ndoctors go through their training and most of their career without ever seeing\nthis disease.\"\nWeld County health officials have investigated 6 more possible cases but have\nnot yet confirmed them, said Jill Burch, a county public health nurse.\n--\nGeorge A. Robertson, PhD\nDOR Biopharma\nMiami, FL\ufffd\n<grobertson@dorbiopharma.com>\n[The following is adapted from the CDC site on Q fever (a Category B\nbioterrorism disease)\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/qfever/index.htm#Significance%20for%\n20Bioterrorism>.\nQ fever is a zoonotic disease caused by _Coxiella burnetii_, a species of\nbacterium that is distributed globally. In 1999, Q fever became a notifiable\ndisease in the USA, but reporting is not required in many other countries.\nBecause the disease is underreported, scientists cannot reliably assess how\nmany cases of Q fever have actually occurred worldwide. Many human infections\nare inapparent.\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including other\nspecies of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does not usually\ncause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats and sheep\nhas been linked to infection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and\nfeces of infected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers in the amniotic fluids and the placenta. The organisms\nare resistant to heat, drying, and many common disinfectants. These features\nenable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. Infection\nof humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from air that\ncontains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental material,\nbirth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are often very\nsusceptible to the disease, and only very few organisms may be required to\ncause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration of\nthe contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other modes of\ntransmission to humans, including tick bites and human-to-human transmission,\nare rare.\nOnly about one-half of all people infected with _C. burnetii_ show signs of\nclinical illness. Most acute cases of Q fever begin with sudden onset of one\nor more of the following: high fevers (up to 104-105 degrees F), severe\nheadache, general malaise, myalgia, confusion, sore throat, chills, sweats,\nnon-productive cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and chest\npain. Fever usually lasts for 1 to 2 weeks. Weight loss can occur and persist\nfor some time. 30 to 50 percent of patients with a symptomatic infection will\ndevelop pneumonia. Additionally, a majority of patients have abnormal results\non liver function tests and some will develop hepatitis. In general, most\npatients will recover to good health within several months without any\ntreatment. Only 1-2 percent of people with acute Q fever die of the disease.\nChronic Q fever, characterized by infection that persists for more than 6\nmonths, is uncommon but is a much more serious disease. Patients who have had\nacute Q fever may develop the chronic form as soon as 1 year or as long as 20\nyears after initial infection. A serious complication of chronic Q fever is\nendocarditis, generally involving the aortic heart valves, less commonly the\nmitral valve. Most patients who develop chronic Q fever have pre-existing\nvalvular heart disease or have a history of vascular graft. Transplant\nrecipients, patients with cancer, and those with chronic kidney disease are\nalso at risk of developing chronic Q fever. As many as 65 percent of persons\nwith chronic Q fever may die of the disease.\ufffd\nDoxycycline is the treatment of choice for acute Q fever. Antibiotic treatment\nis most effective when initiated within the first 3 days of illness. A dose of\n100 mg of doxycycline taken orally twice daily for 15-21 days is a frequently\nprescribed therapy. Quinolone antibiotics have demonstrated good in vitro\nactivity against _C. burnetii_ and may be considered by the physician. Therapy\nshould be started again if the disease relapses. Chronic Q fever endocarditis\nis much more difficult to treat effectively and often requires the use of\nmultiple drugs.\nSince _Coxiella burnetii_ is a highly infectious agent that is rather\nresistant to heat and drying, it is considered relevant in bioterrorism. It\ncan become airborne and inhaled by humans. A single _C. burnetii_ organism may\ncause disease in a susceptible person. This agent could be developed for use\nin biological warfare and is considered a potential terrorist threat. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\n2001\n----\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA Wyoming (02) 20010205.0234\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA (Wyoming) 20010201.0221\n1996\n----\nQ fever - San Mateo County (USA) (2) 19960922.1617\nQ Fever - San Mateo County (USA): RFI 19960920.1609\n........................ll/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Robertson, PhD\nDOR Biopharma\nMiami, FL\ufffd\n<grobertson@dorbiopharma.com>\n[The following is adapted from the CDC site on Q fever (a Category B\nbioterrorism disease)\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/qfever/index.htm#Significance%20for%\n20Bioterrorism>.\nQ fever is a zoonotic disease caused by _Coxiella burnetii_, a species of\nbacterium that is distributed globally. In 1999, Q fever became a notifiable\ndisease in the USA, but reporting is not required in many other countries.\nBecause the disease is underreported, scientists cannot reliably assess how\nmany cases of Q fever have actually occurred worldwide. Many human infections\nare inapparent.\nCattle, sheep, and goats are the primary reservoirs of _C. burnetii_.\nInfection has been noted in a wide variety of other animals, including other\nspecies of livestock and in domesticated pets. _C. burnetii_ does not usually\ncause clinical disease in these animals, although abortion in goats and sheep\nhas been linked to infection. Organisms are excreted in milk, urine, and\nfeces of infected animals. Most importantly, during birthing the organisms are\nshed in high numbers in the amniotic fluids and the placenta. The organisms\nare resistant to heat, drying, and many common disinfectants. These features\nenable the bacteria to survive for long periods in the environment. Infection\nof humans usually occurs by inhalation of these organisms from air that\ncontains airborne barnyard dust contaminated by dried placental material,\nbirth fluids, and excreta of infected herd animals. Humans are often very\nsusceptible to the disease, and only very few organisms may be required to\ncause infection.\nIngestion of contaminated milk, followed by regurgitation and inspiration of\nthe contaminated food, is a less common mode of transmission. Other modes of\ntransmission to humans, including tick bites and human-to-human transmission,\nare rare.\nOnly about one-half of all people infected with _C. burnetii_ show signs of\nclinical illness. Most acute cases of Q fever begin with sudden onset of one\nor more of the following: high fevers (up to 104-105 degrees F), severe\nheadache, general malaise, myalgia, confusion, sore throat, chills, sweats,\nnon-productive cough, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and chest\npain. Fever usually lasts for 1 to 2 weeks. Weight loss can occur and persist\nfor some time. 30 to 50 percent of patients with a symptomatic infection will\ndevelop pneumonia. Additionally, a majority of patients have abnormal results\non liver function tests and some will develop hepatitis. In general, most\npatients will recover to good health within several months without any\ntreatment. Only 1-2 percent of people with acute Q fever die of the disease.\nChronic Q fever, characterized by infection that persists for more than 6\nmonths, is uncommon but is a much more serious disease. Patients who have had\nacute Q fever may develop the chronic form as soon as 1 year or as long as 20\nyears after initial infection. A serious complication of chronic Q fever is\nendocarditis, generally involving the aortic heart valves, less commonly the\nmitral valve. Most patients who develop chronic Q fever have pre-existing\nvalvular heart disease or have a history of vascular graft. Transplant\nrecipients, patients with cancer, and those with chronic kidney disease are\nalso at risk of developing chronic Q fever. As many as 65 percent of persons\nwith chronic Q fever may die of the disease.\ufffd\nDoxycycline is the treatment of choice for acute Q fever. Antibiotic treatment\nis most effective when initiated within the first 3 days of illness. A dose of\n100 mg of doxycycline taken orally twice daily for 15-21 days is a frequently\nprescribed therapy. Quinolone antibiotics have demonstrated good in vitro\nactivity against _C. burnetii_ and may be considered by the physician. Therapy\nshould be started again if the disease relapses. Chronic Q fever endocarditis\nis much more difficult to treat effectively and often requires the use of\nmultiple drugs.\nSince _Coxiella burnetii_ is a highly infectious agent that is rather\nresistant to heat and drying, it is considered relevant in bioterrorism. It\ncan become airborne and inhaled by humans. A single _C. burnetii_ organism may\ncause disease in a susceptible person. This agent could be developed for use\nin biological warfare and is considered a potential terrorist threat. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\n2001\n----\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA Wyoming (02) 20010205.0234\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA (Wyoming) 20010201.0221\n1996\n----\nQ fever - San Mateo County (USA) (2) 19960922.1617\nQ Fever - San Mateo County (USA): RFI 19960920.1609\n........................ll/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever", "smallpox"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2005-03-16 00:00:00", "2004-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Colorado", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Weld County", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "San Mateo County", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208180", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Q fever, human - USA (TX)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208180", "date": "2002-06-27 23:50:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER, HUMAN, SHEEP, VACCINE - GERMANY:\nBACKGROUND\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Wed, 26 Jun 2002\nFrom: Stephen A. Berger, M.D. <mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\nSource: GIDEON <http://www.GideonOnline.com>\n\nThe following background data on Q-fever in Germany and details of\nthe human vaccine [an additional option in high-risk situations] are\nextracted from GIDEON.\nQ-fever was first recognized in Germany in 1947. Reporting was\ninstituted in West Germany in 1962, and in East Germany in 1979. The\n2 systems were combined in 1991. Most cases are reported in Bavaria,\nBaden-Wurttemberg, Rhineland-Palatinate, Hesse, Northrhine-\nWestphalia, and Thuringia. Hesse has experienced the greatest increase\nin incidence since 1990.\nYear/Cases/Rate per 100 000\n1964 /437\n1965 /28/0.05\n1970 /29\n1975/54\n1976/27\n1977/69\n1978/100\n1979/39\n1980/41/0.1\n1983/181\n1984/54\n1985/62\n1986/23\n1987/23\n1988/40\n1989/56\n1990/71/0.1\n1998/150/0.183\n1999/276/0.336\n2000/206/0.251\n2001/294\n22 percent of blood donors (nationwide, 1983 to 1986) and 22 percent\nof military personnel (1985 to 1987) are seropositive.\n12 percent of cattle in the southern Bavarian foothills are seropositive.\nThe average number of reported herds infected with Q fever was 71\nper year during 1971 to 1979; 328 during 1980 to 1989; 303 during 1990\nto 1998.\nOutbreaks currently peak during spring to summer, and may be related\nto urbanization.\n40 outbreaks were reported during 1947 to 1999. Sheep were\nimplicated in 24 of the outbreaks, and cattle in 6.\n2 laboratory outbreaks (in 1947 and 1948) were reported during 1947 to\n1999.\nAn epidemic occurred in Berlin during 1992, involving 80 cases,\nmostly staff from a veterinary institute. An outbreak in Hessen during\n1993 involved 121 cases.\nIn 1996, 60 cases were confirmed in the Rollshausen area (Lohra,\nHessen) during an outbreak associated with infected sheep.\nA University outbreak in May 1997 (105 confirmed cases) was\nassociated with proximity to sheep.\nAn outbreak in Dortmund during 1999 (81 cases) was associated with\nproximity to sheep.\nAn outbreak (68 clinical cases) was reported during December 2000 to\nJune 2001 in Hochsauerland and Nordhessen.\nRegarding the [human] vaccine: Q-fever vaccine is produced from\ninactivated phase I whole _Coxiella burnetii_ under the proprietary\nname Q-vax. The typical adult dosage consists of 0.5 ml s.c. (deltoid\nregion) for high-risk populations (e.g., occupational exposure).\nCurrently use is limited to Australia, notably among abattoir workers.\nProtection persists for at least 5 years, and there are no clear guidelines\nconcerning boosters. Potential side effects include fever and headache;\nthe only contraindication is known allergy to the vaccine itself.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[We are very grateful to Dr Berger for the epidemiological data. Some\nof the statements -- e.g. the alleged linkage between urbanization and\nthe observed Q fever peaks during spring to summer -- might need\nclarification (rural vacations of city dwellers?). More information on\nanimal vaccines, as requested in the RFI, will be helpful. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany: RFI 20020626.4607\n...............................as/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Berger, M.D. <mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\nSource: GIDEON <http://www.GideonOnline.com>\n\nThe following background data on Q-fever in Germany and details of\nthe human vaccine [an additional option in high-risk situations] are\nextracted from GIDEON.\nQ-fever was first recognized in Germany in 1947. Reporting was\ninstituted in West Germany in 1962, and in East Germany in 1979. The\n2 systems were combined in 1991. Most cases are reported in Bavaria,\nBaden-Wurttemberg, Rhineland-Palatinate, Hesse, Northrhine-\nWestphalia, and Thuringia. Hesse has experienced the greatest increase\nin incidence since 1990.\nYear/Cases/Rate per 100 000\n1964 /437\n1965 /28/0.05\n1970 /29\n1975/54\n1976/27\n1977/69\n1978/100\n1979/39\n1980/41/0.1\n1983/181\n1984/54\n1985/62\n1986/23\n1987/23\n1988/40\n1989/56\n1990/71/0.1\n1998/150/0.183\n1999/276/0.336\n2000/206/0.251\n2001/294\n22 percent of blood donors (nationwide, 1983 to 1986) and 22 percent\nof military personnel (1985 to 1987) are seropositive.\n12 percent of cattle in the southern Bavarian foothills are seropositive.\nThe average number of reported herds infected with Q fever was 71\nper year during 1971 to 1979; 328 during 1980 to 1989; 303 during 1990\nto 1998.\nOutbreaks currently peak during spring to summer, and may be related\nto urbanization.\n40 outbreaks were reported during 1947 to 1999. Sheep were\nimplicated in 24 of the outbreaks, and cattle in 6.\n2 laboratory outbreaks (in 1947 and 1948) were reported during 1947 to\n1999.\nAn epidemic occurred in Berlin during 1992, involving 80 cases,\nmostly staff from a veterinary institute. An outbreak in Hessen during\n1993 involved 121 cases.\nIn 1996, 60 cases were confirmed in the Rollshausen area (Lohra,\nHessen) during an outbreak associated with infected sheep.\nA University outbreak in May 1997 (105 confirmed cases) was\nassociated with proximity to sheep.\nAn outbreak in Dortmund during 1999 (81 cases) was associated with\nproximity to sheep.\nAn outbreak (68 clinical cases) was reported during December 2000 to\nJune 2001 in Hochsauerland and Nordhessen.\nRegarding the [human] vaccine: Q-fever vaccine is produced from\ninactivated phase I whole _Coxiella burnetii_ under the proprietary\nname Q-vax. The typical adult dosage consists of 0.5 ml s.c. (deltoid\nregion) for high-risk populations (e.g., occupational exposure).\nCurrently use is limited to Australia, notably among abattoir workers.\nProtection persists for at least 5 years, and there are no clear guidelines\nconcerning boosters. Potential side effects include fever and headache;\nthe only contraindication is known allergy to the vaccine itself.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[We are very grateful to Dr Berger for the epidemiological data. Some\nof the statements -- e.g. the alleged linkage between urbanization and\nthe observed Q fever peaks during spring to summer -- might need\nclarification (rural vacations of city dwellers?). More information on\nanimal vaccines, as requested in the RFI, will be helpful. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany: RFI 20020626.4607\n...............................as/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Berger, M.D. <mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\nSource: GIDEON <http://www.GideonOnline.com>\n\nThe following background data on Q-fever in Germany and details of\nthe human vaccine [an additional option in high-risk situations] are\nextracted from GIDEON.\nQ-fever was first recognized in Germany in 1947. Reporting was\ninstituted in West Germany in 1962, and in East Germany in 1979. The\n2 systems were combined in 1991. Most cases are reported in Bavaria,\nBaden-Wurttemberg, Rhineland-Palatinate, Hesse, Northrhine-\nWestphalia, and Thuringia. Hesse has experienced the greatest increase\nin incidence since 1990.\nYear/Cases/Rate per 100 000\n1964 /437\n1965 /28/0.05\n1970 /29\n1975/54\n1976/27\n1977/69\n1978/100\n1979/39\n1980/41/0.1\n1983/181\n1984/54\n1985/62\n1986/23\n1987/23\n1988/40\n1989/56\n1990/71/0.1\n1998/150/0.183\n1999/276/0.336\n2000/206/0.251\n2001/294\n22 percent of blood donors (nationwide, 1983 to 1986) and 22 percent\nof military personnel (1985 to 1987) are seropositive.\n12 percent of cattle in the southern Bavarian foothills are seropositive.\nThe average number of reported herds infected with Q fever was 71\nper year during 1971 to 1979; 328 during 1980 to 1989; 303 during 1990\nto 1998.\nOutbreaks currently peak during spring to summer, and may be related\nto urbanization.\n40 outbreaks were reported during 1947 to 1999. An outbreak in Hessen during\n1993 involved 121 cases.\nIn 1996, 60 cases were confirmed in the Rollshausen area (Lohra,\nHessen) during an outbreak associated with infected sheep.\nA University outbreak in May 1997 (105 confirmed cases) was\nassociated with proximity to sheep.\nAn outbreak in Dortmund during 1999 (81 cases) was associated with\nproximity to sheep.\nAn outbreak (68 clinical cases) was reported during December 2000 to\nJune 2001 in Hochsauerland and Nordhessen.\nRegarding the [human] vaccine: Q-fever vaccine is produced from\ninactivated phase I whole _Coxiella burnetii_ under the proprietary\nname Q-vax. The typical adult dosage consists of 0.5 ml s.c. (deltoid\nregion) for high-risk populations (e.g., occupational exposure).\nCurrently use is limited to Australia, notably among abattoir workers.\nProtection persists for at least 5 years, and there are no clear guidelines\nconcerning boosters. Potential side effects include fever and headache;\nthe only contraindication is known allergy to the vaccine itself.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[We are very grateful to Dr Berger for the epidemiological data. Berger, M.D. <mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\nSource: GIDEON <http://www.GideonOnline.com>\n\nThe following background data on Q-fever in Germany and details of\nthe human vaccine [an additional option in high-risk situations] are\nextracted from GIDEON.\nQ-fever was first recognized in Germany in 1947. Reporting was\ninstituted in West Germany in 1962, and in East Germany in 1979. The\n2 systems were combined in 1991. Most cases are reported in Bavaria,\nBaden-Wurttemberg, Rhineland-Palatinate, Hesse, Northrhine-\nWestphalia, and Thuringia. Hesse has experienced the greatest increase\nin incidence since 1990.\nYear/Cases/Rate per 100 000\n1964 /437\n1965 /28/0.05\n1970 /29\n1975/54\n1976/27\n1977/69\n1978/100\n1979/39\n1980/41/0.1\n1983/181\n1984/54\n1985/62\n1986/23\n1987/23\n1988/40\n1989/56\n1990/71/0.1\n1998/150/0.183\n1999/276/0.336\n2000/206/0.251\n2001/294\n22 percent of blood donors (nationwide, 1983 to 1986) and 22 percent\nof military personnel (1985 to 1987) are seropositive.\n12 percent of cattle in the southern Bavarian foothills are seropositive.\nThe average number of reported herds infected with Q fever was 71\nper year during 1971 to 1979; 328 during 1980 to 1989; 303 during 1990\nto 1998.\nOutbreaks currently peak during spring to summer, and may be related\nto urbanization.\n40 outbreaks were reported during 1947 to 1999. Sheep were\nimplicated in 24 of the outbreaks, and cattle in 6.\n2 laboratory outbreaks (in 1947 and 1948) were reported during 1947 to\n1999.\nAn epidemic occurred in Berlin during 1992, involving 80 cases,\nmostly staff from a veterinary institute. An outbreak in Hessen during\n1993 involved 121 cases.\nIn 1996, 60 cases were confirmed in the Rollshausen area (Lohra,\nHessen) during an outbreak associated with infected sheep.\nA University outbreak in May 1997 (105 confirmed cases) was\nassociated with proximity to sheep.\nAn outbreak in Dortmund during 1999 (81 cases) was associated with\nproximity to sheep.\nAn outbreak (68 clinical cases) was reported during December 2000 to\nJune 2001 in Hochsauerland and Nordhessen.\nRegarding the [human] vaccine: Q-fever vaccine is produced from\ninactivated phase I whole _Coxiella burnetii_ under the proprietary\nname Q-vax. The typical adult dosage consists of 0.5 ml s.c. (deltoid\nregion) for high-risk populations (e.g., occupational exposure).\nCurrently use is limited to Australia, notably among abattoir workers.\nProtection persists for at least 5 years, and there are no clear guidelines\nconcerning boosters. Potential side effects include fever and headache;\nthe only contraindication is known allergy to the vaccine itself.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[We are very grateful to Dr Berger for the epidemiological data. Some\nof the statements -- e.g. the alleged linkage between urbanization and\nthe observed Q fever peaks during spring to summer -- might need\nclarification (rural vacations of city dwellers?). More information on\nanimal vaccines, as requested in the RFI, will be helpful. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany: RFI 20020626.4607\n...............................as/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
