Berger, M.D. <mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\nSource: GIDEON <http://www.GideonOnline.com>\n\nThe following background data on Q-fever in Germany and details of\nthe human vaccine [an additional option in high-risk situations] are\nextracted from GIDEON.\nQ-fever was first recognized in Germany in 1947. Reporting was\ninstituted in West Germany in 1962, and in East Germany in 1979. The\n2 systems were combined in 1991. Most cases are reported in Bavaria,\nBaden-Wurttemberg, Rhineland-Palatinate, Hesse, Northrhine-\nWestphalia, and Thuringia. Hesse has experienced the greatest increase\nin incidence since 1990.\nYear/Cases/Rate per 100 000\n1964 /437\n1965 /28/0.05\n1970 /29\n1975/54\n1976/27\n1977/69\n1978/100\n1979/39\n1980/41/0.1\n1983/181\n1984/54\n1985/62\n1986/23\n1987/23\n1988/40\n1989/56\n1990/71/0.1\n1998/150/0.183\n1999/276/0.336\n2000/206/0.251\n2001/294\n22 percent of blood donors (nationwide, 1983 to 1986) and 22 percent\nof military personnel (1985 to 1987) are seropositive.\n12 percent of cattle in the southern Bavarian foothills are seropositive.\nThe average number of reported herds infected with Q fever was 71\nper year during 1971 to 1979; 328 during 1980 to 1989; 303 during 1990\nto 1998.\nOutbreaks currently peak during spring to summer, and may be related\nto urbanization.\n40 outbreaks were reported during 1947 to 1999. Sheep were\nimplicated in 24 of the outbreaks, and cattle in 6.\n2 laboratory outbreaks (in 1947 and 1948) were reported during 1947 to\n1999.\nAn epidemic occurred in Berlin during 1992, involving 80 cases,\nmostly staff from a veterinary institute. An outbreak in Hessen during\n1993 involved 121 cases.\nIn 1996, 60 cases were confirmed in the Rollshausen area (Lohra,\nHessen) during an outbreak associated with infected sheep.\nA University outbreak in May 1997 (105 confirmed cases) was\nassociated with proximity to sheep.\nAn outbreak in Dortmund during 1999 (81 cases) was associated with\nproximity to sheep.\nAn outbreak (68 clinical cases) was reported during December 2000 to\nJune 2001 in Hochsauerland and Nordhessen.\nRegarding the [human] vaccine: Q-fever vaccine is produced from\ninactivated phase I whole _Coxiella burnetii_ under the proprietary\nname Q-vax. The typical adult dosage consists of 0.5 ml s.c. (deltoid\nregion) for high-risk populations (e.g., occupational exposure).\nCurrently use is limited to Australia, notably among abattoir workers.\nProtection persists for at least 5 years, and there are no clear guidelines\nconcerning boosters. Potential side effects include fever and headache;\nthe only contraindication is known allergy to the vaccine itself.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[We are very grateful to Dr Berger for the epidemiological data. Berger, M.D. <mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\nSource: GIDEON <http://www.GideonOnline.com>\n\nThe following background data on Q-fever in Germany and details of\nthe human vaccine [an additional option in high-risk situations] are\nextracted from GIDEON.\nQ-fever was first recognized in Germany in 1947. Reporting was\ninstituted in West Germany in 1962, and in East Germany in 1979. The\n2 systems were combined in 1991. Most cases are reported in Bavaria,\nBaden-Wurttemberg, Rhineland-Palatinate, Hesse, Northrhine-\nWestphalia, and Thuringia. Hesse has experienced the greatest increase\nin incidence since 1990.\nYear/Cases/Rate per 100 000\n1964 /437\n1965 /28/0.05\n1970 /29\n1975/54\n1976/27\n1977/69\n1978/100\n1979/39\n1980/41/0.1\n1983/181\n1984/54\n1985/62\n1986/23\n1987/23\n1988/40\n1989/56\n1990/71/0.1\n1998/150/0.183\n1999/276/0.336\n2000/206/0.251\n2001/294\n22 percent of blood donors (nationwide, 1983 to 1986) and 22 percent\nof military personnel (1985 to 1987) are seropositive.\n12 percent of cattle in the southern Bavarian foothills are seropositive.\nThe average number of reported herds infected with Q fever was 71\nper year during 1971 to 1979; 328 during 1980 to 1989; 303 during 1990\nto 1998.\nOutbreaks currently peak during spring to summer, and may be related\nto urbanization.\n40 outbreaks were reported during 1947 to 1999. Sheep were\nimplicated in 24 of the outbreaks, and cattle in 6.\n2 laboratory outbreaks (in 1947 and 1948) were reported during 1947 to\n1999.\nAn epidemic occurred in Berlin during 1992, involving 80 cases,\nmostly staff from a veterinary institute. An outbreak in Hessen during\n1993 involved 121 cases.\nIn 1996, 60 cases were confirmed in the Rollshausen area (Lohra,\nHessen) during an outbreak associated with infected sheep.\nA University outbreak in May 1997 (105 confirmed cases) was\nassociated with proximity to sheep.\nAn outbreak in Dortmund during 1999 (81 cases) was associated with\nproximity to sheep.\nAn outbreak (68 clinical cases) was reported during December 2000 to\nJune 2001 in Hochsauerland and Nordhessen.\nRegarding the [human] vaccine: Q-fever vaccine is produced from\ninactivated phase I whole _Coxiella burnetii_ under the proprietary\nname Q-vax. The typical adult dosage consists of 0.5 ml s.c. (deltoid\nregion) for high-risk populations (e.g., occupational exposure).\nCurrently use is limited to Australia, notably among abattoir workers.\nProtection persists for at least 5 years, and there are no clear guidelines\nconcerning boosters. Potential side effects include fever and headache;\nthe only contraindication is known allergy to the vaccine itself.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[We are very grateful to Dr Berger for the epidemiological data. Some\nof the statements -- e.g. the alleged linkage between urbanization and\nthe observed Q fever peaks during spring to summer -- might need\nclarification (rural vacations of city dwellers?). More information on\nanimal vaccines, as requested in the RFI, will be helpful. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany: RFI 20020626.4607\n...............................as/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Berger, M.D. <mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\nSource: GIDEON <http://www.GideonOnline.com>\n\nThe following background data on Q-fever in Germany and details of\nthe human vaccine [an additional option in high-risk situations] are\nextracted from GIDEON.\nQ-fever was first recognized in Germany in 1947. Reporting was\ninstituted in West Germany in 1962, and in East Germany in 1979. The\n2 systems were combined in 1991. Most cases are reported in Bavaria,\nBaden-Wurttemberg, Rhineland-Palatinate, Hesse, Northrhine-\nWestphalia, and Thuringia. Hesse has experienced the greatest increase\nin incidence since 1990.\nYear/Cases/Rate per 100 000\n1964 /437\n1965 /28/0.05\n1970 /29\n1975/54\n1976/27\n1977/69\n1978/100\n1979/39\n1980/41/0.1\n1983/181\n1984/54\n1985/62\n1986/23\n1987/23\n1988/40\n1989/56\n1990/71/0.1\n1998/150/0.183\n1999/276/0.336\n2000/206/0.251\n2001/294\n22 percent of blood donors (nationwide, 1983 to 1986) and 22 percent\nof military personnel (1985 to 1987) are seropositive.\n12 percent of cattle in the southern Bavarian foothills are seropositive.\nThe average number of reported herds infected with Q fever was 71\nper year during 1971 to 1979; 328 during 1980 to 1989; 303 during 1990\nto 1998.\nOutbreaks currently peak during spring to summer, and may be related\nto urbanization.\n40 outbreaks were reported during 1947 to 1999. Sheep were\nimplicated in 24 of the outbreaks, and cattle in 6.\n2 laboratory outbreaks (in 1947 and 1948) were reported during 1947 to\n1999.\nAn epidemic occurred in Berlin during 1992, involving 80 cases,\nmostly staff from a veterinary institute. An outbreak in Hessen during\n1993 involved 121 cases.\nIn 1996, 60 cases were confirmed in the Rollshausen area (Lohra,\nHessen) during an outbreak associated with infected sheep.\nA University outbreak in May 1997 (105 confirmed cases) was\nassociated with proximity to sheep.\nAn outbreak in Dortmund during 1999 (81 cases) was associated with\nproximity to sheep.\nAn outbreak (68 clinical cases) was reported during December 2000 to\nJune 2001 in Hochsauerland and Nordhessen.\nRegarding the [human] vaccine: Q-fever vaccine is produced from\ninactivated phase I whole _Coxiella burnetii_ under the proprietary\nname Q-vax. The typical adult dosage consists of 0.5 ml s.c. (deltoid\nregion) for high-risk populations (e.g., occupational exposure).\nCurrently use is limited to Australia, notably among abattoir workers.\nProtection persists for at least 5 years, and there are no clear guidelines\nconcerning boosters. Potential side effects include fever and headache;\nthe only contraindication is known allergy to the vaccine itself.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[We are very grateful to Dr Berger for the epidemiological data. Some\nof the statements -- e.g. the alleged linkage between urbanization and\nthe observed Q fever peaks during spring to summer -- might need\nclarification (rural vacations of city dwellers?). For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-majordomo@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-06-26 00:00:00", "1947-03-16 00:00:00", "1962-03-16 00:00:00", "1979-03-16 00:00:00", "1991-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1964-03-16 00:00:00", "1965-03-16 00:00:00", "1970-03-16 00:00:00", "1983-03-16 00:00:00", "1986-03-16 00:00:00", "1980-03-16 00:00:00", "1989-03-16 00:00:00", "1990-03-16 00:00:00", "1998-03-16 00:00:00", "1947-03-16 00:00:00", "1948-03-16 00:00:00", "1947-03-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "1992-03-16 00:00:00", "1993-03-16 00:00:00", "1996-03-16 00:00:00", "1997-05-16 00:00:00", "1999-03-16 00:00:00", "2000-12-16 00:00:00", "2001-06-16 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "M.D.", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hochsauerland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Berlin", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hessen", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hesse", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dortmund", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "East Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bavaria", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "West Germany", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Thuringia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202054", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany: RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202054", "date": "2001-02-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER GOAT, SUSPECTED HUMAN - USA (WYOMING)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSee Also\nQ fever - Australia (Queensland) 20010129.0204\n1997\n-----\nQ fever - Australia (NSW) 19970212.0345\nQ fever - Australia (NSW) (06) 19970219.0405\nQ fever - Australia (Queensland) 19970327.0635\nQ fever vaccine, availability 19970218.0401\nQ fever vaccine, availability (05) 19970401.0688\nDate: 31 Jan 2001\nFrom: Edgardo Arza <Edgardo.Arza@aphis.usda.gov>\nSource: US Division of Viral and Rickettsial Diseases (DVRD), National\nCenter for Infectious Diseases (NCID) Official Release [edited\n\nOFFICIAL RELEASE\nDATE: 23 Jan 2001\nTO: Director, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)\nFROM: Director, Division of Viral and Rickettsial Diseases (DVRD), National\nCenter for Infectious Diseases (NCID)\nSUBJECT: Investigation of a possible outbreak of Q fever in humans and\ngoats in Wyoming\nLOCATION: Hulett, Wyoming\nNature of Problem: In late December [2000 and early January [2001, a goat\nherd consisting of approximately 400 animals in Hulett, Wyoming experienced\nvery high rates of abortion and stillbirths (over 50% of parturient\nanimals). The animals subsequently tested positive for antibodies to\n_Coxiella burnetii_, the etiologic agent of Q fever.\nOf 4 persons who had direct contact with the animals, 2 have developed\nclinical signs consistent with Q fever infection. Serologic tests are\npending. Because of the zoonotic nature of this disease and the possibility\nof environmental contamination, the state health department is requesting\nassistance for rapid assessment of the situation.\nDate Problem First Identified by the Requesting Agency: 22 Jan 2001\nDate of Initial CDC Contact: 23 Jan 2001\nIn addition to contacting the CDC, the Bioterrorism coordinator and the\nlaboratory director for the Wyoming Department of Health, and the United\nStates Department of Agriculture have also been alerted.\nObjectives of the investigation:\n1) To find cases of Q fever in humans who may have had contact with\ninfected animals,\n2) to determine the source of infection and mode of transmission,\n3) to assess the extent of _C. burnetii_ infection in the goat herd, and\n4) to provide recommendations for control and prevention.\nJim LeDuc, Ph.D.\nActing Director, DVRD, NCID\n--\nEdgardo Arza\n<Edgardo.Arza@aphis.usda.gov>\n[The causative agent (_Coxiella burnetii_) is highly infectious to animals\nand people by aerosol transmission of infected particles, by direct contact\nor by ingestion of certain tissues where the organism concentrates. The\norganism is concentrated in placentas, other reproductive fluids, body\nfluids, milk, urine and feces. The agent has been documented in the wool of\naffected sheep.\nTicks may serve as a reservoir of the organism, especially the Ixodid and\nArgasid ticks. The organism may circulate between the ectoparasites,\nusually ticks, and wild animals, independent of a cycle in domestic\nanimals. Worldwide distribution has affected birds, arthropods, and a\nvariety of wild and domestic mammals, including cattle, sheep, goats, dogs,\ncats and man.\nInfection in animals is often subclinical, but may be manifest as anorexia\nand abortion in sheep and goats. Infertility and sporadic abortion in\ncattle have been reported. _C. burnetii_ in ruminants may localize in\nmammary glands, supramammary lymph nodes, placenta, and uterus, from which\nit may be shed at subsequent parturitions and lactations.\nIn people, this disease may be self limiting, presenting as a nonspecific\nfebrile illness between 2 and 14 days in length, characterized by headache,\nfatigue, and myalgia. Pneumonia, hepatitis, aseptic meningitis,\nencephalitis, osteomyelitis, and culture-negative endocarditis are known\ncomplications. Pre-existing valvular heart disease is usually present in\nthose who develop endocarditis.\nNeither the human nor the animal vaccine is available in the United States.\nTetracycline and doxycycline are the drugs of choice for treatment in\nanimals and people. - Mod.TG/DS/SH\n.....................tg/pg/ds/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-01-31 00:00:00", "2001-01-23 00:00:00", "2001-01-22 00:00:00", "2001-01-23 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hulett", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2201565", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Q fever - Bosnia & Herzegovina (Livno)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2201565", "date": "2001-02-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER GOAT, SUSPECTED HUMAN - USA (WYOMING)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSee Also\nQ fever - Australia (Queensland) 20010129.0204\n1997\n-----\nQ fever - Australia (NSW) 19970212.0345\nQ fever - Australia (NSW) (06) 19970219.0405\nQ fever - Australia (Queensland) 19970327.0635\nQ fever vaccine, availability 19970218.0401\nQ fever vaccine, availability (05) 19970401.0688\nDate: 31 Jan 2001\nFrom: Edgardo Arza <Edgardo.Arza@aphis.usda.gov>\nSource: US Division of Viral and Rickettsial Diseases (DVRD), National\nCenter for Infectious Diseases (NCID) Official Release [edited\n\nOFFICIAL RELEASE\nDATE: 23 Jan 2001\nTO: Director, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)\nFROM: Director, Division of Viral and Rickettsial Diseases (DVRD), National\nCenter for Infectious Diseases (NCID)\nSUBJECT: Investigation of a possible outbreak of Q fever in humans and\ngoats in Wyoming\nLOCATION: Hulett, Wyoming\nNature of Problem: In late December [2000 and early January [2001, a goat\nherd consisting of approximately 400 animals in Hulett, Wyoming experienced\nvery high rates of abortion and stillbirths (over 50% of parturient\nanimals). The animals subsequently tested positive for antibodies to\n_Coxiella burnetii_, the etiologic agent of Q fever.\nOf 4 persons who had direct contact with the animals, 2 have developed\nclinical signs consistent with Q fever infection. Serologic tests are\npending. Because of the zoonotic nature of this disease and the possibility\nof environmental contamination, the state health department is requesting\nassistance for rapid assessment of the situation.\nDate Problem First Identified by the Requesting Agency: 22 Jan 2001\nDate of Initial CDC Contact: 23 Jan 2001\nIn addition to contacting the CDC, the Bioterrorism coordinator and the\nlaboratory director for the Wyoming Department of Health, and the United\nStates Department of Agriculture have also been alerted.\nObjectives of the investigation:\n1) To find cases of Q fever in humans who may have had contact with\ninfected animals,\n2) to determine the source of infection and mode of transmission,\n3) to assess the extent of _C. burnetii_ infection in the goat herd, and\n4) to provide recommendations for control and prevention.\nJim LeDuc, Ph.D.\nActing Director, DVRD, NCID\n--\nEdgardo Arza\n<Edgardo.Arza@aphis.usda.gov>\n[The causative agent (_Coxiella burnetii_) is highly infectious to animals\nand people by aerosol transmission of infected particles, by direct contact\nor by ingestion of certain tissues where the organism concentrates. The\norganism is concentrated in placentas, other reproductive fluids, body\nfluids, milk, urine and feces. The agent has been documented in the wool of\naffected sheep.\nTicks may serve as a reservoir of the organism, especially the Ixodid and\nArgasid ticks. The organism may circulate between the ectoparasites,\nusually ticks, and wild animals, independent of a cycle in domestic\nanimals. Worldwide distribution has affected birds, arthropods, and a\nvariety of wild and domestic mammals, including cattle, sheep, goats, dogs,\ncats and man.\nInfection in animals is often subclinical, but may be manifest as anorexia\nand abortion in sheep and goats. Infertility and sporadic abortion in\ncattle have been reported. _C. burnetii_ in ruminants may localize in\nmammary glands, supramammary lymph nodes, placenta, and uterus, from which\nit may be shed at subsequent parturitions and lactations.\nIn people, this disease may be self limiting, presenting as a nonspecific\nfebrile illness between 2 and 14 days in length, characterized by headache,\nfatigue, and myalgia. Pneumonia, hepatitis, aseptic meningitis,\nencephalitis, osteomyelitis, and culture-negative endocarditis are known\ncomplications. Pre-existing valvular heart disease is usually present in\nthose who develop endocarditis.\nNeither the human nor the animal vaccine is available in the United States.\nTetracycline and doxycycline are the drugs of choice for treatment in\nanimals and people. - Mod.TG/DS/SH\n.....................tg/pg/ds/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The\norganism is concentrated in placentas, other reproductive fluids, body\nfluids, milk, urine and feces. The agent has been documented in the wool of\naffected sheep.\nTicks may serve as a reservoir of the organism, especially the Ixodid and\nArgasid ticks. The organism may circulate between the ectoparasites,\nusually ticks, and wild animals, independent of a cycle in domestic\nanimals. Worldwide distribution has affected birds, arthropods, and a\nvariety of wild and domestic mammals, including cattle, sheep, goats, dogs,\ncats and man.\nInfection in animals is often subclinical, but may be manifest as anorexia\nand abortion in sheep and goats. Because of the zoonotic nature of this disease and the possibility\nof environmental contamination, the state health department is requesting\nassistance for rapid assessment of the situation.\nDate Problem First Identified by the Requesting Agency: 22 Jan 2001\nDate of Initial CDC Contact: 23 Jan 2001\nIn addition to contacting the CDC, the Bioterrorism coordinator and the\nlaboratory director for the Wyoming Department of Health, and the United\nStates Department of Agriculture have also been alerted.\nObjectives of the investigation:\n1) To find cases of Q fever in humans who may have had contact with\ninfected animals,\n2) to determine the source of infection and mode of transmission,\n3) to assess the extent of _C. burnetii_ infection in the goat herd, and\n4) to provide recommendations for control and prevention.\nJim LeDuc, Ph.D.\nActing Director, DVRD, NCID\n--\nEdgardo Arza\n<Edgardo.Arza@aphis.usda.gov>\n[The causative agent (_Coxiella burnetii_) is highly infectious to animals\nand people by aerosol transmission of infected particles, by direct contact\nor by ingestion of certain tissues where the organism concentrates. The\norganism is concentrated in placentas, other reproductive fluids, body\nfluids, milk, urine and feces. The agent has been documented in the wool of\naffected sheep.\nTicks may serve as a reservoir of the organism, especially the Ixodid and\nArgasid ticks. The organism may circulate between the ectoparasites,\nusually ticks, and wild animals, independent of a cycle in domestic\nanimals. Worldwide distribution has affected birds, arthropods, and a\nvariety of wild and domestic mammals, including cattle, sheep, goats, dogs,\ncats and man.\nInfection in animals is often subclinical, but may be manifest as anorexia\nand abortion in sheep and goats. Infertility and sporadic abortion in\ncattle have been reported. _C. burnetii_ in ruminants may localize in\nmammary glands, supramammary lymph nodes, placenta, and uterus, from which\nit may be shed at subsequent parturitions and lactations.\nIn people, this disease may be self limiting, presenting as a nonspecific\nfebrile illness between 2 and 14 days in length, characterized by headache,\nfatigue, and myalgia. Pneumonia, hepatitis, aseptic meningitis,\nencephalitis, osteomyelitis, and culture-negative endocarditis are known\ncomplications. Pre-existing valvular heart disease is usually present in\nthose who develop endocarditis.\nNeither the human nor the animal vaccine is available in the United States.\nTetracycline and doxycycline are the drugs of choice for treatment in\nanimals and people. - Mod.TG/DS/SH\n.....................tg/pg/ds/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever", "encephalitis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["1997-03-16 00:00:00", "2001-01-31 00:00:00", "2001-01-23 00:00:00", "2001-01-22 00:00:00", "2001-01-23 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Queensland", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Hulett", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2199332", "headline": "PRO/AH> Q fever - Australia: background (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2199332", "date": "2001-02-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER GOAT, SUSPECTED HUMAN - USA (WYOMING)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSee Also\nQ fever - Australia (Queensland) 20010129.0204\n1997\n-----\nQ fever - Australia (NSW) 19970212.0345\nQ fever - Australia (NSW) (06) 19970219.0405\nQ fever - Australia (Queensland) 19970327.0635\nQ fever vaccine, availability 19970218.0401\nQ fever vaccine, availability (05) 19970401.0688\nDate: 31 Jan 2001\nFrom: Edgardo Arza <Edgardo.Arza@aphis.usda.gov>\nSource: US Division of Viral and Rickettsial Diseases (DVRD), National\nCenter for Infectious Diseases (NCID) Official Release [edited\n\nOFFICIAL RELEASE\nDATE: 23 Jan 2001\nTO: Director, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)\nFROM: Director, Division of Viral and Rickettsial Diseases (DVRD), National\nCenter for Infectious Diseases (NCID)\nSUBJECT: Investigation of a possible outbreak of Q fever in humans and\ngoats in Wyoming\nLOCATION: Hulett, Wyoming\nNature of Problem: In late December [2000 and early January [2001, a goat\nherd consisting of approximately 400 animals in Hulett, Wyoming experienced\nvery high rates of abortion and stillbirths (over 50% of parturient\nanimals). The animals subsequently tested positive for antibodies to\n_Coxiella burnetii_, the etiologic agent of Q fever.\nOf 4 persons who had direct contact with the animals, 2 have developed\nclinical signs consistent with Q fever infection. Serologic tests are\npending. Because of the zoonotic nature of this disease and the possibility\nof environmental contamination, the state health department is requesting\nassistance for rapid assessment of the situation.\nDate Problem First Identified by the Requesting Agency: 22 Jan 2001\nDate of Initial CDC Contact: 23 Jan 2001\nIn addition to contacting the CDC, the Bioterrorism coordinator and the\nlaboratory director for the Wyoming Department of Health, and the United\nStates Department of Agriculture have also been alerted.\nObjectives of the investigation:\n1) To find cases of Q fever in humans who may have had contact with\ninfected animals,\n2) to determine the source of infection and mode of transmission,\n3) to assess the extent of _C. burnetii_ infection in the goat herd, and\n4) to provide recommendations for control and prevention.\nJim LeDuc, Ph.D.\nActing Director, DVRD, NCID\n--\nEdgardo Arza\n<Edgardo.Arza@aphis.usda.gov>\n[The causative agent (_Coxiella burnetii_) is highly infectious to animals\nand people by aerosol transmission of infected particles, by direct contact\nor by ingestion of certain tissues where the organism concentrates. The\norganism is concentrated in placentas, other reproductive fluids, body\nfluids, milk, urine and feces. The agent has been documented in the wool of\naffected sheep.\nTicks may serve as a reservoir of the organism, especially the Ixodid and\nArgasid ticks. The organism may circulate between the ectoparasites,\nusually ticks, and wild animals, independent of a cycle in domestic\nanimals. Worldwide distribution has affected birds, arthropods, and a\nvariety of wild and domestic mammals, including cattle, sheep, goats, dogs,\ncats and man.\nInfection in animals is often subclinical, but may be manifest as anorexia\nand abortion in sheep and goats. Infertility and sporadic abortion in\ncattle have been reported. _C. burnetii_ in ruminants may localize in\nmammary glands, supramammary lymph nodes, placenta, and uterus, from which\nit may be shed at subsequent parturitions and lactations.\nIn people, this disease may be self limiting, presenting as a nonspecific\nfebrile illness between 2 and 14 days in length, characterized by headache,\nfatigue, and myalgia. Pneumonia, hepatitis, aseptic meningitis,\nencephalitis, osteomyelitis, and culture-negative endocarditis are known\ncomplications. Pre-existing valvular heart disease is usually present in\nthose who develop endocarditis.\nNeither the human nor the animal vaccine is available in the United States.\nTetracycline and doxycycline are the drugs of choice for treatment in\nanimals and people. - Mod.TG/DS/SH\n.....................tg/pg/ds/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": [], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2190481", "headline": "PRO/AH> Q fever vaccine, availability (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2190481", "date": "1997-03-22 23:50:00", "main_text": "Q FEVER VACCINE, AVAILABILITY (03)\n==================================\nDate: Fri, 21 Mar 97 16:41:43 EST\nFrom: <W._Russell_Byrne_at_USAMRIID4__FTDETRCK@ftdetrck-ccmail.army.mil>\n[see\nQ fever vaccine, availability 970218180712\nQ fever vaccine, availability (02) 970228172147]\nThe Q fever vaccine currently used by the Army, IND 610, is very similar to\nthe licensed Australian vaccine, Q-Vax, and it is used here at Fort Detrick,\nMaryland, to protect non-immune individuals who may be exposed to _Coxiella\nburnetii_ in the course of their work. There are a number of other\nfacilities in this country and Canada at which this vaccine is utilized, in\naccordance with an investigational protocol.\nBecause this vaccine has, in the past, caused severe local reactions in\nindividuals already immune to _Coxiella burnetii_, a screening intradermal\nskin test with Q fever antigen is required prior to vaccination. The purpose\nof the skin test is to identify those individuals at risk of developing\nsevere local reactions to the vaccine, and individuals with a positive skin\ntest should not be vaccinated. A similar problem exists with the Australian\nvaccine, and a screening skin test is also required prior to use of that\nproduct. In addition, it should be noted that individuals with positive skin\ntest reactions to this Q fever antigen do not need vaccination, because the\npositive skin test reflects pre-existing protective immunity to Q fever.\nAs an investigational product, IND 610 is subject to applicable FDA\nregulations and policies. It can be administered only according to an\napproved investigational protocol under the supervision of the principal or\nan associate investigator, but it is not being \"held in reserve\". Inquiries\nregarding the availability and use of this Q fever vaccine should be directed\nto the Commander/Director, USAMMDA, Fort Detrick, Frederick, MD 21702, Ph.\n301/619-7643.\n---\nCOL W. Russell Byrne\nBacteriology Division\nUSAMRIID/Fort Detrick\nFrederick, MD\ne-mail: <W._Russell_Byrne_at_USAMRIID4__FTDETRCK@ftdetrck-ccmail.army.mil>\n[Thanks to Colonel Byrne for clarifying the situation. -- Mod CHC]\n............................................................................\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
